description: Abies concolor has a distinctive tall, pyramid-like form and features eye-catching blue-grey needles. It flourishes in areas that experience long winters and mild summers, and it can endure dry soil conditions and even short periods of drought once it's well-established. Nevertheless, it prefers to grow in soil that is moist and well-draining, and it struggles in heavy clay or persistently wet soils. Abies concolor is an ideal choice for container gardening or as a bonsai subject, and it's also a great option as a Christmas tree. Abies concolor is evergreen and native to the United States and Mexico. Learn more about Abies concolor.

Acacia baileyana 'Purpurea' has greyish-green fern-like leaves, and when new growth appears, it's a beautiful shade of purple. During the winter, Acacia baileyana 'Purpurea' is covered in a profusion of golden-yellow flowers. It thrives in soil that is dry and stony, and it needs to have proper drainage. Once Acacia baileyana 'Purpurea' has taken root, it can endure periods of drought. All in all, it's a remarkable tree that has both stunning foliage and blossoms. Acacia baileyana is evergreen and native to the state of New South Wales in Australia. Learn more about Acacia baileyana.

Acacia floribunda has an elegant, wide-spreading, and bushy shape with an open form and slender leaves. In late winter and spring, Acacia floribunda produces delightful, pale-yellow flowers that form fluffy clusters and exude a pleasant fragrance. Acacia floribunda can tolerate heavy clay soils as well as periodically wet soils. Although it can endure dry soil in a garden setting, it prefers to grow in soil that is consistently moist or wet. Acacia floribunda is a versatile choice that can be employed as a windbreak, hedge, or screen. Acacia floribunda is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Acacia floribunda.

Acacia howittii is available for sale in New Zealand in a dwarf, weeping variety. It's a charming tree that grows gracefully, with branches that hang down. It prefers to grow in soil that is moist and well-drained, but it can withstand short periods of drought. Acacia howittii produces fragrant, pale-yellow flowers during the spring season. It's also a great option for bonsai enthusiasts. Acacia howittii is evergreen and native to the state of Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Acacia howittii.

Acacia melanoxylon is highly valued for its exquisite marbled wood. It's a fast-growing and robust tree that provides ample shade and shelter. Acacia melanoxylon has a dense, rounded crown, and it produces lovely, pale-yellow flowers during late winter and early spring. It can thrive in regions with high rainfall and can tolerate some drought, but it prefers to grow in soil that is consistently moist. Its shallow root system features densely packed, surface-level roots that feed heavily from the soil. Additionally, Acacia melanoxylon is capable of converting atmospheric nitrogen into the soil, which benefits the surrounding environment. It's an excellent choice for hedges, screens, and shelterbelts. Acacia melanoxylon is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Acacia melanoxylon.

This hardy maple is an excellent choice for street plantings and as a shade tree. It initially grows in an upright pattern, which gradually transforms into a rounded canopy as it matures. The new growth of Acer buergerianum appears as a striking copper-red hue, which later turns green during summer. During autumn, the leaves turn into vivid shades of red, apricot, and yellow. Acer buergerianum thrives in full sun and requires well-drained soil. Once it's established, it can endure windy conditions and is somewhat tolerant of drought. Acer buergerianum also has a moderate ability to tolerate coastal environments and can handle air pollution. It's a great option for bonsai enthusiasts. Acer buergerianum is deciduous and native to China, Taiwan, and Japan. Learn more about Acer buergerianum.

Acer campbellii 'Gwavas' has sizable leaves that are deeply-lobed and begin as bronze-purple before transitioning to an olive-green color with prominent veins. It has an upright, spreading growth pattern. During the autumn season, the leaves take on vibrant hues of yellow and orange, which make them appear to glow. Acer campbellii 'Gwavas' thrives in full sun and prefers moist, well-drained soil. Acer campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Bhutan, northern India, Myanmar, Nepal, and Vietnam. Learn more about Acer campbellii. Acer campbellii 'Gwavas' was discovered at Gwavas Station in Tikokino, Hawkes Bay, New Zealand.

otherCommonNames: Hedge Maple, Feldahorn, Veldesdoorn, Spaanse Aak
description: Acer campestre has a compact structure and features a dense, rounded canopy, along with corky bark. It has small leaves that are rounded with lobes and appear dark green in the summer months, transitioning into a beautiful yellow color during the fall season. Acer campestre prefers soil that is moist and well-drained but can still withstand dry and clay soils. It's also able to tolerate air pollution, making it a great choice for urban environments. Acer campestre produces green, inconspicuous flowers in early to mid-spring. Additionally, it can handle strong winds and coastal sites. Bonsai enthusiasts would enjoy growing Acer campestre. Acer campestre is deciduous and native to much of Europe, southwest Asia from Turkey to the Caucasus Mountains, and the Atlas mountains in north Africa. Learn more about Acer campestre.

otherCommonNames: Hair-foot Maple, Red Snakebark Maple, Kyushu Maple, Hosoe-Kaede, Ashiboso-urinoki
description: Acer capillipes has a vase-like shape, with red new stems and bark that features green and white stripes. During autumn, the leaves take on orange and scarlet tones, which provide a stunning display. Acer capillipes prefers soil that is moist and well-drained, as well as part-shade, particularly in hot climates. It can also tolerate air pollution, making it a suitable option for urban environments. Acer capillipes is deciduous and native to the islands of Honshū, Kyūshū, and Shikoku in Japan. Learn more about Acer capillipes.

otherCommonNames: Caucasian Maple, Coliseum Maple, Colchican Maple
description: During spring, Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum' produces young foliage that is bright-yellow with orange-red margins. As summer approaches, the leaves transition to a light-green color. However, during autumn, the leaves turn bright-yellow, creating a lovely display. Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum' can tolerate periods of drought but prefers soil that is moist and well-drained. It's worth noting that Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum' has a shallow root system. It's best to avoid exposed, windy areas when planting Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum'. Acer cappadocicum is deciduous and native to Asia, from central Turkey (ancient Cappadocia) east along the Caucasus and the Himalayas to southwestern China. Learn more about Acer cappadocicum. Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum' was first introduced by Hesse Nurseries of Weener, Germany in 1914.

otherCommonNames: Caucasian Maple, Coliseum Maple, Colchican Maple
description: During spring, Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum' produces new leaves that are a striking blood-red color. Throughout summer, the leaves remain large and green. As autumn arrives, the leaves turn bright-yellow, providing a vibrant contrast. Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum' has a compact, rounded crown and can tolerate periods of drought, but prefers soil that is moist and well-drained. Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum' has a shallow root system. It's best to avoid exposed, windy areas when planting Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum'. Acer cappadocicum is deciduous and native to Asia, from central Turkey (ancient Cappadocia) east along the Caucasus and the Himalayas to southwestern China. Learn more about Acer cappadocicum. Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum' was first distributed in 1842 by Booth Nurseries in Hamburg, Germany.

Acer caudatifolium 'Summer Surprise' boasts stunning features throughout the year. During spring, it produces pink new stems and green leaves, and during summer, the leaves become variegated with green. As autumn arrives, the leaves turn a beautiful orange-red. Acer caudatifolium 'Summer Surprise' grows best in part-shade and prefers soil that is moist and well-drained. It's important to keep Acer caudatifolium 'Summer Surprise' sheltered from strong winds. One of the standout features of Acer caudatifolium 'Summer Surprise' is its striped bark. Acer caudatifolium is deciduous and native to Taiwan. Learn more about Acer caudatifolium.

Acer davidii has an erect, open, and spreading form, and its bark is shiny and green with silver-white stripes. Its glossy green leaves feature deep-red veins, and during autumn, the leaves turn beautiful shades of red, yellow, and orange. Acer davidii prefers soil that is moist and well-drained and is best suited for growing in part-shade. Acer davidii is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Acer davidii.

This snakebark maple is a stunning tree that displays bright-orange autumn colors. In the spring, it is particularly striking with its bright-pink new growth. The summer leaves are a blend of pink, white, and green, making it a very showy tree throughout the year. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and is best suited for growing in part-shade. Acer 'Gracefield' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, was introduced by Frank's Trees in Nelson, New Zealand.

The growth habit of this maple is upright and narrow. Its chestnut-brown bark peels in thin strips, uncovering cinnamon-red wood. Acer griseum produces leaves in late spring to avoid damage from strong winds. It displays stunning fiery-red and orange leaves in autumn. This maple thrives in moist, well-drained soils and can also tolerate clay soils, but does not thrive in drought or dry soils. It is also suitable for use in bonsai. Acer griseum is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Acer griseum.

Acer japonicum 'Vitifolium' has a stiff, spreading branch structure and its leaves are similar to grapevine foliage. The leaves are light to robust green in spring and summer, and turn orange-yellow and bright red in autumn. Acer japonicum 'Vitifolium' prefers moist, well-drained soils in part-shade, and can grow in full sun but may experience leaf scorch in hot summers. It is vulnerable to damage from strong winds and new foliage can be affected by late frosts. Acer japonicum is deciduous and native to the islands of Honshū, Hokkaidō, and Kyūshū in Japan, and also southern Korea. Learn more about Acer japonicum.

Acer monspessulanum has a rounded, densely-branched form and features thick, leathery leaves. Its autumn leaves are yellow in color. Acer monspessulanum can tolerate hot and dry conditions, and it's also suitable for bonsai. Acer monspessulanum is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and central and southern Europe. Learn more about Acer monspessulanum.

This is an upright tree with striking carmine-pink and green leaves in spring, transitioning to white and green in summer, and ultimately to red in autumn. It is a great fit for smaller gardens and produces small, yellow-green flowers in early to mid-spring. However, it does not tolerate shade or strong winds, and its seeds are toxic to horses. Once established, it can withstand air pollution, drought, and occasional water-logged soils. It is also cold hardy. Acer negundo is deciduous and native to south-central Canada, much of the United States, and Guatemala. Learn more about Acer negundo. Acer negundo 'Flamingo' was raised in the Netherlands before 1976.

This maple has golden-yellow spring leaves that turn lime-green in summer and pale-yellow in autumn. It has a tidy, upright growth habit and is ideal for brightening up dark areas. It is hardy and grows quickly, producing small yellow-green flowers in early to mid-spring. It does not tolerate shade or strong winds and its seeds are toxic to horses. However, it can tolerate air pollution, drought, and occasionally water-logged soils once established. It is also cold hardy. Acer negundo is deciduous and native to south-central Canada, much of the United States, and Guatemala. Learn more about Acer negundo. Acer negundo 'Kelly's Gold' was raised in New Zealand before 1989.

Acer negundo 'Variegatum' has an attractive, neat and upright growth habit with grey-green leaves that have silver edges and are flushed with rose-pink when young. It is hardy and quick-growing and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Acer negundo 'Variegatum' produces small, yellow-green flowers in early to mid-spring, but is intolerant of shade and strong winds. Its seeds are toxic to horses, but it tolerates air pollution, drought, and occasionally water-logged soils once established. Acer negundo 'Variegatum' is also cold hardy. Acer negundo is deciduous and native to south-central Canada, much of the United States, and Guatemala. Learn more about Acer negundo. Acer negundo 'Variegatum' first appeared as a sport on the green-leaved type at a nursery in Toulouse, France in 1845.

Acer negundo var. violaceum has eye-catching burgundy tassels on bare branches before the new spring growth. The young shoots and leaves are purple-maroon and mature into green summer leaves that turn golden in autumn. It produces small, pink-purple flowers in early to mid-spring. Acer negundo var. violaceum does not tolerate shade and strong winds, and its seeds are toxic to horses. However, it can tolerate air pollution, drought, and occasionally water-logged soils once established. It is cold hardy. Acer negundo is deciduous and native to south-central Canada, much of the United States, and Guatemala. Learn more about Acer negundo.

Acer palmatum develops a round-headed, open, airy structure with slender stems. The green leaves are deeply-lobed and dissected, and turn brilliant shades of yellow, orange, and red in autumn. It makes an excellent shade tree and is a great choice for planting along the street. Acer palmatum prefers moist, well-drained soils but may suffer from leaf scorch due to excess sun, wind, and drought. It is cold hardy and can also be used for bonsai. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, Korea, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. Learn more about Acer palmatum.

The spring leaves of Acer palmatum 'Atropurpureum' are a rich-crimson color that turn bronze-purple in summer and finally change to scarlet in autumn. Acer palmatum 'Atropurpureum' prefers moist, well-drained soils, but may suffer leaf scorch from excess sun, wind, and drought. It is cold hardy and also suitable for bonsai. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, Korea, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. Learn more about Acer palmatum. Acer palmatum 'Atropurpureum' by rights belongs to Louis van Houtte's nursery which he established in 1839 at Gentbrugge near Ghent, Belgium. Described in Flore des Serres, Vol. 12, 1857, t. 1273. Since 1857, new seedlings and clones have been selected and distributed under this name.

This maple tree features bamboo-like leaves and bright-red new growth in spring. The deeply-dissected foliage with narrow lobes creates a stunning display in the sunlight. The leaves turn scarlet in autumn, adding to the beauty of Acer palmatum 'Beni-otake'. It has a spreading habit, making it a great choice for smaller gardens. This maple prefers moist, well-drained soils but may experience leaf scorch from excess sun, wind, and drought. It is cold hardy and can also be used for bonsai. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, Korea, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. Learn more about Acer palmatum. Acer palmatum 'Beni-otake' was discovered in 1980 by Edward Wood and was then introduced by T.C. Plants Inc. of Hillsboro, Oregon, United States.

Acer palmatum 'Beni-shi-en' bears large, deeply-dissected leaves that are purplish with a delicate cream edge. Each leaf is unique in its appearance. It is an excellent choice to brighten up gloomy areas. Acer palmatum 'Beni-shi-en' produces orange-red leaves in the autumn. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and may suffer leaf scorch due to excess sun, wind, or drought. Acer palmatum 'Beni-shi-en' is cold hardy and suitable for bonsai. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, Korea, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. Learn more about Acer palmatum. Acer palmatum 'Beni-shi-en' was discovered by Harold Johnston from Tallassee, Alabama. He found Acer palmatum 'Beni-shi-en' among a population of seedlings from various Japanese maples which he had collected and planted. A patent was filed for Acer palmatum 'Beni-shi-en' in the United States on November 19, 1996.

Acer palmatum 'Bloodgood' has large, robust purple-red leaves that retain their color throughout the spring and summer. In the autumn, the leaves transform into a fiery crimson-red color. Acer palmatum 'Bloodgood' prefers moist, well-drained soils and may experience leaf scorch from excessive sun, wind, and drought. It is cold hardy and suitable for use in bonsai. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, Korea, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. Learn more about Acer palmatum. Acer palmatum 'Bloodgood' was developed before 1940 by Bloodgood Nursery in Long Island, New York, United States (founded in 1793) and named after the nursery.

Acer palmatum 'Burgundy Lace' has deeply-lobed leaves resembling lace, and they turn a burgundy-wine color through summer before changing to scarlet in autumn. Acer palmatum 'Burgundy Lace' is cold hardy and is also great for bonsai. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, Korea, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. This exceptional dwarf tree is perfect for sheltered areas, with its spring leaves bursting in bright carmine-pink, transitioning to a pink-red hue, and then maturing to green during summer. Come fall, Acer palmatum 'Chishio' dons striking orange to red colors. It's a fantastic choice for container gardening and thrives in well-draining, moist soils, but caution must be taken to avoid leaf scorch caused by excessive sun, wind, and drought. This small slow-growing specimen boasts a weeping habit, creating a captivating mushroom-like display. Noted for retaining it's vibrant red colour throughout the growing season, the leaves start as bright crimson in spring, transition to a deep red purple in summer, and finish in a fiery scarlet hue during autumn. Acer palmatum is deciduous and native to Japan, China, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia.

Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Crimson Queen' has finely-cut, large leaves that are bright crimson-red in the spring and become a deep purple-red throughout the summer. Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Crimson Queen' prefers moist, well-drained soils, but may suffer from leaf scorch if exposed to excess sun, wind, or drought. Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Emerald Lace' produces very finely-cut, lime-green leaves in the spring that gradually darken as summer approaches, while turning dark red in the fall. Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Emerald Lace' prefers moist, well-drained soils, but excessive exposure to sunlight, wind, or drought may cause leaf scorching. Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Flavescens' has lacy foliage that appears yellow-green during the spring and darkens to a mid-green color over the summer. Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Green Mist' has soft pale green dissectum leaves that create a flowing elegant effect. It is slow growing, with a horizontal weeping habit, and thrives in partial shade. Spring leaves are finely-cut and crimson-red in color. They turn purple-red in summer and scarlet in autumn. Acer palmatum var. dissectum 'Tamukeyama' is a vigorous, mound-forming grower. It produces brilliant orange-red autumn leaves that are sure to make a statement. Acer rubrum 'Columnare' is quick-growing and bears small, red flowers during the early to mid-spring period. It thrives in moist, well-drained soil and full-sun conditions, but it is also capable of growing in a range of soils, including sandy, heavy clay, peat, dry, and poor-draining soil. Additionally, Acer rubrum 'Columnare' is cold-hardy and able to tolerate windy conditions. Acer rubrum is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Acer rubrum. Acer rubrum 'Columnare' has an unknown origin, but it appeared in Garden and Forest, 1894, p. 65, which showed a specimen growing on private grounds in Flushing, New York, United States.

Acer rubrum 'Jeffersred' produces large, green leaves during the spring and summer months. It then transitions to a stunning display of orange-red to scarlet-red leaves during the autumn season. Acer rubrum 'Jeffersred' has a vase-shaped growth habit and can be pruned to function as a narrow wind screen. It very rarely produces flowers, fruit, or seeds. Acer rubrum 'Jeffersred' thrives in moist, well-drained soil and full-sun conditions, but it is also capable of growing in a range of soils, including sandy, heavy clay, peat, dry, and poor-draining soil. Additionally, Acer rubrum 'Jeffersred' is cold-hardy and able to tolerate windy conditions. Acer rubrum is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Acer rubrum. Acer rubrum 'Jeffersred' is a hybrid between Acer rubrum and Acer saccharinum. Acer rubrum 'Jeffersred' was selected in 1980 by Jeffers Nursery in Fostoria, Ohio, United States.

Acer rubrum 'Red Sunset' produces large, fresh-green leaves that transition to a spectacular orange-red color during the autumn season. It has a broad, columnar head growth habit and bears small, red flowers during the early to mid-spring period. Acer rubrum 'Red Sunset' thrives in moist, well-drained soil and full-sun conditions, but it is also capable of growing in a range of soils, including sandy, heavy clay, peat, dry, and poor-draining soil. Additionally, Acer rubrum 'Red Sunset' is cold-hardy and able to tolerate windy conditions. Acer rubrum is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Acer rubrum. Acer rubrum 'Red Sunset' was introduced in 1966 and developed in the 1940s by J. Frank Schmidt, Jr. of J. Frank Schmidt & Son Co. Wholesale Nursery in Boring, Oregon, United States.

Acer rubrum 'Scanlon' has an erect and slender growth habit. It displays green foliage throughout the spring and summer, while showcasing purple, red, and orange hues during the fall season. Additionally, it produces petite red flowers in the early to mid-spring. Acer rubrum 'Scanlon' thrives in moist and well-draining soil when placed in full sun, but can also grow in various soil types, such as sandy, heavy clay, peat, dry, and poorly draining soils. Furthermore, Acer rubrum 'Scanlon' is highly tolerant of cold temperatures and windy conditions. Acer rubrum is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Acer rubrum. Acer rubrum 'Scanlon' was selected in 1956 by Scanlon Nursery of Olmsted Falls, Ohio, United States.

Acer saccharinum features light-green leaves with lobes and silver undersides that create a beautiful visual effect when rustled by the wind. During the autumn season, its leaves turn yellow. With an open vase shape, it grows rapidly, but its shallow root system can cause issues by uplifting sidewalks and driveways, and damaging pipes. It is ideal for areas with wet soil or seasonal flooding. Although it can tolerate some wind, it may sustain damage during strong winds. While it can develop weak limbs as it ages, it remains an excellent option for quickly providing shade in challenging soil conditions. Acer saccharinum is deciduous and native to eastern and central United States and southeastern Canada. Learn more about Acer saccharinum.

Acer saccharum boasts large, green, lobed leaves that transform into stunning autumnal hues of red, orange, and yellow in colder regions. It has a compact crown and up-swept branches, and its sap is commercially used for producing maple syrup. However, Acer saccharum is sensitive to heat and air pollution, and its roots have the potential to damage pipes and crack sidewalks. It requires moist, well-drained soil and is not suited for dry or poorly draining soil types. Additionally, it is not tolerant of moderate to strong winds. Acer saccharum is one of the major sources of sap for making maple syrup and is deciduous and native to the hardwood forests of eastern Canada and eastern United States. Learn more about Acer saccharum.

Acer shirasawanum 'Autumn Moon' has apricot-orange leaves during the spring that transition to a yellow-green hue in the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn orange and yellow. It is important to protect Acer shirasawanum 'Autumn Moon' from direct sunlight, as the leaves can easily get scorched. It is also recommended to provide shelter from strong winds. To support healthy growth, Acer shirasawanum 'Autumn Moon' should be grown in moist and well-drained soil. Acer shirasawanum is deciduous and native to Honshū, Shikoku, and Kyūshū islands in Japan. Learn more about Acer shirasawanum. Acer shirasawanum 'Autumn Moon' was discovered as a seedling by J. D. Vertrees at Maplewood Nursery in Roseburg, Oregon, United States.

Acer tschonoskii showcases green leaves during the spring and summer months, while displaying autumnal shades of yellow, red, and orange as the seasons change. When young, it grows in a compact, upright manner, but as it ages, it has a tendency to spread out. Acer tschonoskii is deciduous and native to Japan and the Kuril Islands. Learn more about Acer tschonoskii.

Aesculus x carnea has a wide, round head and large, fan-shaped dark-green leaves. It produces giant red flower candles in late-spring, and glossy-brown nuts in the autumn, which are toxic to both humans and animals. The foliage may scorch in very dry or windy conditions. Aesculus x carnea is challenging to transplant once established due to its taproot. It is ideal for use as a shade, avenue, or paddock tree, and it displays beautiful golden-yellow leaves during the autumn season. Aesculus x carnea prefers moist and well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus x carnea is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Aesculus pavia and Aesculus hippocastanum. Learn more about Aesculus x carnea.

Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' is a compact grower and has large, dark-green, fan-shaped leaves. It produces giant red flower candles in late spring, and its glossy-brown nuts in autumn are toxic to humans and animals. The foliage is susceptible to scorching in dry or windy conditions. Once established, Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' is challenging to transplant due to its taproot. It is an excellent choice for use as a shade, avenue, or paddock tree, and it showcases beautiful golden-yellow leaves during the autumn season. Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' has larger flowers than Aesculus x carnea and is slower-growing due to the greater number of flowers it produces, and will ultimately mature as a smaller tree. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and does not tolerate dry soils well. Aesculus x carnea is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Aesculus pavia and Aesculus hippocastanum. Learn more about Aesculus x carnea. Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' was raised from seed in Trianon-Versailles near Paris, France in 1858. Named in 1858 to honor Pierre Louis Briot (1804-1888), the chief horticulturist of the State gardens at Trianon-Versailles.

Aesculus hippocastanum is tall and stately, with a wide crown. It boasts large, deep-green, fan-shaped leaves and produces giant white flower candles in mid-spring. In the autumn, it bears glossy-brown nuts that are toxic to humans and animals. The foliage is susceptible to scorching in dry or windy conditions. Once established, it is difficult to transplant due to its taproot. Aesculus hippocastanum is well-suited for use in large gardens, parks, and paddocks, and it displays beautiful yellow leaves during the autumn season. It prefers moist, well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus hippocastanum is deciduous and native to a small area in the Pindus Mountains (Northern Greece) mixed forests and Balkan (Albania) mixed forests of southeast Europe. Learn more about Aesculus hippocastanum.

Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' is characterized by large, dark-green, fan-shaped leaves and produces giant double white flower candles in mid-spring. It has a narrower growth habit and blooms later and for a longer duration compared to Aesculus hippocastanum. The flowers of Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' are mostly sterile, resulting in minimal fruit production. The nuts produced in autumn are toxic to humans and animals. Once established, Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' is challenging to transplant due to its taproot. It is ideal for use as a shade or paddock tree and features yellow autumn leaves. Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' prefers moist, well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus hippocastanum is deciduous and native to a small area in the Pindus Mountains (Northern Greece) mixed forests and Balkan (Albania) mixed forests of southeast Europe. Learn more about Aesculus hippocastanum. Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' was noticed by A. N. Baumann (according to him) as a sport on a tree of Aesculus hippocastanum growing in the garden of a Mons. Duval, near Geneva, during the years 1819 to 1822. He sent grafts to his father's famous nursery at Bollwiller in Alsace, France, from whence it spread into cultivation.

Aesculus indica has large and attractive leaves that initially appear as bronze-green in spring and then mature to a dark-green hue by summer. It produces frilly, white flower panicles in early to mid-summer, about a month later than Aesculus hippocastanum. The white flowers have a red flush and yellow spots. In autumn, Aesculus indica bears glossy-brown nuts that are toxic to humans and animals. It is an excellent shade tree, and its leaves turn beautiful shades of orange and yellow during the autumn season. Aesculus indica thrives in moist, well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus indica is deciduous and native to the Himalayan Lowlands, between Kashmir and Western Nepal at elevations between 900 and 3,000 metres. Learn more about Aesculus indica.

Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' showcases remarkable new leaves that are pink-orange in color and gradually change to cream-green as spring progresses and become green throughout the summer season. It has a slow growth rate, and it is essential to protect it from strong winds. During spring, Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' produces pale-yellow flowers with a red base, borne in erect panicles. As the autumn season arrives, its leaves turn beautiful shades of orange and yellow. Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' seldom produces nuts. Aesculus x neglecta is deciduous and possibly a hybrid between Aesculus flava (syn. Aesculus octandra) and Aesculus sylvatica. Learn more about Aesculus x neglecta. Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' was first distributed by Späth nursery in Berlin, Germany before 1935.

Aesculus turbinata has huge, fan-shaped leaves and produces large, red-spotted, white flower panicles in late-spring. It bears glossy-brown nuts in the autumn that are toxic to humans and animals. Aesculus turbinata is excellent for use as a large shade tree, and it displays beautiful yellow leaves during the autumn season. Aesculus turbinata is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Aesculus turbinata.

Afrocarpus mannii grows densely and can be trimmed to form a hedge. Its long leaves are fresh-green when young. It is a quick and vigorous grower. Afrocarpus mannii is evergreen and native to the Afromontane forests of São Tomé Island in the Gulf of Guinea, growing at altitudes of 1,300m up to the summit at 2,024m. Learn more about Afrocarpus mannii.

This slender, pyramidal tree has the ability to fit into a confined space for several years, despite kauri trees attaining a broad size with age. When young, it needs protection from frosts and wind, and requires moist soil during dry periods for establishing. However, it can tolerate light frosts and heavy clay soils once it has matured. The leaves of Agathis australis are bronze when young, maturing to green with age. Agathis australis thrives in moist, well-drained soil. Agathis australis is evergreen and native to the northern regions of New Zealand's North Island. Learn more about Agathis australis.

This erect, pyramidal tree features young leaves that are bronze in color and is characterized by larger leaves compared to our native kauri, Agathis australis. When young, it requires protection from frosts and wind, as well as moist soil during dry periods for establishing. Once established, it can tolerate light frosts and heavy clay soils. Agathis robusta thrives in moist, well-drained soil. Agathis robusta is evergreen and native to Papua New Guinea and the state of Queensland in Australia. Learn more about Agathis robusta.

Agonis flexuosa is characterized by a pendulous habit and produces small, white flowers in the spring and summer months. It has long, slender, dark-green leaves and is drought tolerant once established. It can tolerate moderate coastal winds and is best suited for moist, sandy soils, but can adapt to other well-drained soils. Agonis flexuosa is an excellent option for use as a street tree as it responds well to trimming under power lines, and it can also be utilized for screening off areas to provide privacy. Agonis flexuosa is evergreen and native to the southwest of Western Australia in a subcoastal strip from just north of Perth, southward through the Swan Coastal Plain, then along the coast to outlying islands east of Bremer Bay. Learn more about Agonis flexuosa.

Albizia julibrissin produces deep-pink, silky, fragrant summer flowers with ferny leaves on its wide-spreading branches. It does not leaf out until very late in the spring, and it is an excellent choice for use as a shade tree. Albizia julibrissin is capable of tolerating heat and drought, and it flowers best when it is grown in full-sun. However, it has weak limbs that are susceptible to damage from strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin.

Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' is characterized by deep-pink, silky, fragrant summer flowers that appear on its wide-spreading branches, which are adorned with ferny leaves. It does not leaf out until very late in the spring and is an excellent shade tree. Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' is capable of tolerating both heat and drought, and it tends to flower best when it is grown in full-sun. However, it has weak limbs that can be damaged by strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin. Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' was selected and introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Albizia julibrissin 'Rosea' is distinguished by its silky, pink, and fragrant summer flowers that appear on its wide-spreading branches, which are adorned with ferny leaves. It does not leaf out until very late in the spring, and it makes for an excellent shade tree that can tolerate heat and drought. It typically flowers best when grown in full-sun. However, it has weak limbs that can be damaged by strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin 'Rosea' is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin.

Albizia julibrissin 'Summer Chocolate' features rich chocolate-burgundy, ferny leaves on its wide-spreading branches, which are adorned with silky, pink, and fragrant flowers in the summer. It typically does not leaf out until very late in the spring and is an excellent option for use as a shade tree. It flowers best when grown in full-sun and can tolerate heat and drought. However, it has weak limbs that can be damaged by strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin 'Summer Chocolate' is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin. Albizia julibrissin 'Summer Chocolate' was discovered in a controlled breeding program in Japan and selected by Masato Yokoi from thousands of seedlings in 1990. After testing and trial growing in selected gardens it was introduced into the United States and patented in 2003.

Alectryon excelsus grows upright with a rounded head and produces a mix of orange and rose-pink new leaves that mature into glossy, olive-green, pinnate leaves. During the summer, it bears shiny black seeds that emerge from scarlet arils (an outgrowth that covers the seed), which are attractive to seed-eating birds. It can tolerate light frosts once established and makes for an excellent shade tree and street tree. Alectryon excelsus thrives in moist, well-drained soil. Alectryon excelsus is evergreen and native to New Zealand, in coastal and lowland forests throughout most of the North Island and from Banks Peninsula to central Westland in the South Island. Learn more about Alectryon excelsus.
uses: street, attracts-birds, paddocks, shade, topiary, pleaching

description: Alnus cordata is characterized by its shining, heart-shaped, green leaves and quick-growing, upright form. It can grow in both moist, swampy soils and dry, infertile soils, making it useful for erosion control and windbreaks. It is an excellent option for use as a street or shade tree. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, Alnus cordata can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus cordata is deciduous and native to the southern Apennine Mountains in Italy (Campania, Basilicata and Calabria, mainly on western mountain sides) and the north-eastern mountains of Corsica. Learn more about Alnus cordata.

Alnus glutinosa is characterized by its pyramidal form and ability to thrive in very wet areas. It can also tolerate dry, infertile soils and is a vigorous, quick-growing plant. It is an excellent option for use as a shelter tree and is great for erosion control and stabilizing river banks. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, Alnus glutinosa can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus glutinosa is deciduous and native to almost the whole of continental Europe (except for both the extreme north and south) as well as the United Kingdom and Ireland. Learn more about Alnus glutinosa.

Alnus glutinosa 'Imperialis' is characterized by its elegant appearance and outspreading branches. It features fine and deeply-cut, green leaves and is tolerant of wet soils, making it an excellent choice for planting near water. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, Alnus glutinosa 'Imperialis' can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus glutinosa is deciduous and native to almost the whole of continental Europe (except for both the extreme north and south) as well as the United Kingdom and Ireland. Learn more about Alnus glutinosa. Alnus glutinosa 'Imperialis' has an unknown origin, but has been in cultivation since before 1859.

Alnus glutinosa 'Laciniata' features a conical-growing shape and finely-cut, green leaves. It is capable of tolerating wet and windy sites, making it a resilient choice for outdoor planting. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, Alnus glutinosa 'Laciniata' can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus glutinosa is deciduous and native to almost the whole of continental Europe (except for both the extreme north and south) as well as the United Kingdom and Ireland. Learn more about Alnus glutinosa. Alnus glutinosa 'Laciniata' originated in France in the early 1800s. It is said that Trochereau de la Berliere found this form growing in the wild, which he took and planted in his garden near Saint Germain.

Alnus incana 'Aurea' is a large, conical-shaped plant that produces yellow leaves in the spring, which mature to yellow-green in the summer before turning yellow in the autumn. The young branches are orange-yellow, providing a stunning display in the winter months. During the early to mid-spring, it produces red-pink catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, Alnus incana 'Aurea' can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus incana is deciduous and native to various regions across the Northern Hemisphere. Learn more about Alnus incana. Alnus incana 'Aurea' was raised in Germany in the late-1800s, and potentially released into commerce in 1892.

Alnus inokumae is a fast and straight-growing alder that features attractive, dark-green leaves. It is an excellent option for use as a fast-growing screening tree and is capable of tolerating wet sites. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Additionally, Alnus inokumae can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. In the autumn months, its leaves turn yellow, adding a lovely touch of color to any outdoor space. Alnus inokumae is deciduous and native to the islands of Honshu and Hokkaido in Japan. Learn more about Alnus inokumae.

Alnus jorullensis is fast-growing and features long, green, toothed leaves. It is easy to prune and can be shaped to suit a variety of needs. It is an excellent option for use as a dense screen or privacy hedge. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Additionally, Alnus jorullensis can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus jorullensis is evergreen and native to eastern and southern Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras. Learn more about Alnus jorullensis.

Alnus rubra features a slender, pyramidal form and produces red buds that reveal red-green catkins in the spring. Its green leaves have a blue-green underside and the inner bark is orange-red, adding a lovely touch of color to any outdoor space. It is a hardy plant that is capable of tolerating moist soils. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Additionally, Alnus rubra can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus rubra is deciduous and native to western North America. Learn more about Alnus rubra.

Amelanchier canadensis is a compact and tidy tree with a rounded head. Its bronze new leaves in the spring turn into a stunning array of red, yellow, and orange in the autumn, adding a lovely touch of color to any outdoor space. In the late winter to late spring months, it produces lacy, white, drooping flower clusters. During the early summer, it also produces edible berries that start out red and then turn purple when they are ripe and ready to eat. Amelanchier canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America in Canada from Newfoundland west to southern Ontario, and in the United States from Maine south to Alabama. Learn more about Amelanchier canadensis.

Araucaria araucana is slow-growing and features a pyramidal growth habit when young that spreads out with age. It has leathery, spiky, triangle-shaped leaves on widely-spaced branches, adding a unique and interesting texture to any outdoor space. Araucaria araucana is evergreen and native to central and southern Chile and western Argentina. Learn more about Araucaria araucana.

Araucaria heterophylla is a stately and erect tree with a pyramidal form, making it an ideal hardy coastal tree. It is an enduring tree that works well in large outdoor spaces. Additionally, it can be grown in a container and kept small, making it a versatile option for a variety of outdoor spaces. Araucaria heterophylla is evergreen and native to Norfolk Island. Learn more about Araucaria heterophylla.

otherCommonNames: Canary Madrone, Canary Islands Strawberry Tree
description: Arbutus canariensis has bold and attractive green foliage. In autumn to early winter, large, upright panicles of white-pink, bell-shaped flowers cover Arbutus canariensis, making it a great source of pollen for bees. It also produces green fruit in the winter after the flowers, which take almost a full year to ripen. The fruit changes color from yellow to red and ripens when the next year's autumn flowers appear. The fruit is a favorite of birds. Arbutus canariensis has peeling, red-brown bark and is tolerant of wind and heat, making it a great option for a variety of outdoor spaces. Arbutus canariensis is evergreen and native to the Canary Islands of Spain. Learn more about Arbutus canariensis.

otherCommonNames: Irish Strawberry Tree, Killarney Strawberry Tree, Cane Apple
description: Arbutus unedo is very hardy and can withstand adverse conditions such as coastal, heat, and cold environments. It produces small, white flowers in autumn and winter, which are a great source of pollen for bees. It also produces green fruit in the winter after the flowers, which take almost a full year to ripen. The fruit changes color from yellow to red and ripens when the next year's autumn flowers appear. Birds love the fruit, making it a great addition to a garden or outdoor space. Arbutus unedo has peeling, red-brown bark, which adds to its attractive appearance. Arbutus unedo is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean region and western Europe. Learn more about Arbutus unedo.

In spring, it produces cream to rose-pink flowers, which are followed by dark-red to purple-black berries in summer that are attractive to native birds. The leaves may have pink-red undersides. It can tolerate light frosts and may be semi-evergreen in colder climates. Aristotelia serrata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Aristotelia serrata.

A decorative plant that grows in clusters and has broad, spiky, silver-green leaves that hang down at the ends. It can be grown easily in areas with full sun or partial shade, and it can tolerate both damp and dry conditions. It creates a striking effect when planted in groups and is well-suited for coastal regions. It also performs excellently in containers. Astelia chathamica is evergreen and native to the Chatham Islands of New Zealand. Learn more about Astelia chathamica.

otherCommonNames: Mountain Astelia, Bush Flax, Bush Lily
description: Astelia nervosa 'Westland' forms clumps and is prized for its ornamental value, with broad, spiky, silver-green leaves that are tinged with red-bronze. It can be grown with ease in areas with full sun or partial shade, and it can adapt to both wet and dry soil conditions. It has a dramatic effect when planted in groups and is also an excellent choice for containers. Astelia nervosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Astelia nervosa.

Azara microphylla features branches that arch and bear small, glossy, dark-green leaves. In the spring, it produces small golden-yellow flowers that emit a pleasant vanilla scent. It can be pruned to form a dense screen or trained into an espaliered shape. Azara microphylla is evergreen and native to Chile and Argentina. Learn more about Azara microphylla.

This bamboo is a dense, clump-forming species that has long, arching canes and light-green foliage. It prefers moist, well-drained soil, and it is advisable to shelter Bambusa gracilis from strong winds to prevent damage. Bambusa gracilis is evergreen and native to Cambodia, Laos, Nepal, Vietnam, and the West Himalayas. Learn more about Drepanostachyum falcatum.

Bambusa multiplexa 'Wang Tsai' is a clump bamboo with graceful arching green to orange-brown stems and dark green tufted foliage. Dense and upright grower. Awesome for privacy and screening. Grows on a wide range of soils, except extreme wet or dry, but will tolerate moderate frost and coastal condtions. Should be protected while its establishing.

When young, Banksia integrifolia grows upright, but as it ages, it develops a more open form. It grows rapidly and can thrive in coastal environments. Large yellow brush flowers bloom from autumn through spring, attracting tuis and bellbirds. It's an excellent choice for providing shelter and can be pruned into any desired shape or size. Banksia integrifolia is evergreen and native to Australia, occurring between the states of Victoria and Queensland. Learn more about Banksia integrifolia.

Beilschmiedia tarairi stands tall and erect and has smooth brown bark. Its young shoots are covered in fine brown hairs, and its broad olive-green leaves are leathery, heavily-veined, and glossy. It prefers moist soil and can tolerate light to medium frosts. Wood pigeons are fond of the large purple berries ofBeilschmiedia tarairi, which ripen in autumn. Beilschmiedia tarairi is evergreen and native to the North Island of New Zealand. Learn more about Beilschmiedia tarairi.

Beilschmiedia tawa grows slowly but is long-lasting, and ultimately, it can become a giant in the forest. It grows erect with almost black bark, and its small willowy leaves are pale green and hang in a graceful manner. In the winter, the large purple berries of Beilschmiedia tawa are beloved by wood pigeons. Beilschmiedia tawa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Beilschmiedia tawa.

Berberis thunbergii f. atropurpurea 'Helmond Pillar' has deep purple to red leaves that retain their color throughout the spring and summer and transition to bright red in the fall. Its tight column of upright stems maintains its shape without the need for trimming. However, the stems are lined with sharp thorns. It's a great option for small or limited spaces. Berberis thunbergii is deciduous and native to Japan and eastern Asia. Learn more about Berberis thunbergii.

Betula costata has gorgeous peeling bark that features cream-white tones with pink-orange hues. It grows upright and has bright green leaves with noticeable veining. In the fall, its leaves turn a vibrant gold color. However, it's not tolerant of drought conditions. Betula costata is deciduous and native to Korea and the Russian Far East in Russia. Learn more about Betula costata.

Betula ermanii is graceful and vigorous, and it has peeling bark that features cream-white tones with pink-orange hues. This gives it a warm glow that stands out among darker evergreen trees, particularly during the winter months. Its bright green leaves turn a vibrant yellow color in the fall. Betula ermanii has a conical, upright-growing habit that broadens with age. Betula ermanii is deciduous and native to Northeast China, Korea, Japan, and the Russian Far East in Russia (Kuril Islands, Sakhalin, Kamchatka). Learn more about Betula ermanii.

This birch tree has a trunk that is pure white and its bark peels. The green leaves of Betula ermanii 'Polar Bear' transition to a buttery yellow color in the fall. Betula ermanii is deciduous and native to Northeast China, Korea, Japan, and the Russian Far East in Russia (Kuril Islands, Sakhalin, Kamchatka). Learn more about Betula ermanii.

Betula nigra is an excellent choice for wet areas and has a strong pyramidal shape. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath. On older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. The glossy green leaves of Betula nigra have a glaucous underside and turn bright yellow in the fall. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra.

Betula nigra 'Heritage' has a graceful appearance with its pendant branches. Its shiny, deep-green leaves turn yellow in the autumn, and it bears long and striking male catkins in late winter. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath, while on older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra 'Heritage' can thrive in both moist and dry areas. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra. Betula nigra 'Heritage' was found by Earl Cully growing in St. Louis, Missouri, United States.

Betula nigra 'Summer Cascade' features gently weeping, pendulous branches and pink, peeling bark. Its foliage is dark green during the spring and summer months, but transforms into a stunning yellow color during the autumn. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath, while on older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra. Betula nigra 'Summer Cascade' was introduced by John and Daniel Allen of Shiloh Nursery in Harmony, North Carolina, United States.

Betula nigra 'Uru Tawhai' is well-suited for planting in wet areas, and its green leaves transform into a bright yellow color during the fall. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath, while on older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra.

This birch is highly regarded for its noticeable white trunk and elegant, drooping young stems. Its glossy green leaves turn yellow during the autumn season. It's particularly lovely when planted in groups. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula.

Betula pendula 'Black Prince' has slender, cascading branches that grow in a narrow form. Its rich purple foliage retains its color well throughout the spring and summer. The young branches are purple-black, and Betula pendula 'Black Prince' has white bark, although it's not as white as that of Betula pendula. It's important to protect Betula pendula 'Black Prince' from strong winds. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula.

Betula pendula 'Dalecarlica' has a similar graceful habit to Betula pendula, but its branches cascade even more. The rich green leaves are deeply cut and serrated, which imparts a light, delicate appearance to Betula pendula 'Dalecarlica'. It has white trunks when mature, and its yellow autumn leaves add to its charm. However, it's less tolerant of prolonged dry spells. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula. Betula pendula 'Dalecarlica' was discovered in 1767 by Hans Gustaf Hiordt in the village of Ornäs, in the central Swedish province of Dalarna.

This birch tree has a compact, upright growth habit, and its lime-green leaves add a vibrant touch throughout the summer months. Its autumn foliage is a brilliant gold color, while its branch stems transition from golden-orange to pink-red during the winter. Betula pendula 'Wade's Gold' develops very white trunks, which adds to its aesthetic appeal. It's an excellent choice as a street tree. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula.

Betula pendula 'Youngii' forms a dome-shaped canopy of slender, drooping side-branches that emerge from a straight trunk. Its small green leaves turn a bright yellow color during the autumn season. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula. Betula pendula 'Youngii' was found as a chance seedling trailing on the ground and was introduced by the nursery of Maurice Young in Milford, Surrey, England in about 1874.

synonyms: Betula pendula subsp. mandshurica, Betula platyphylla subsp. mandshurica, Betula mandshurica var. japonica
description: This beautiful birch tree has a slender form similar to that of other birch trees, but its leaves are larger and more substantial. Its leaves turn a bright yellow color in the autumn season. Betula platyphylla var. japonica has very white bark that extends all the way down to the ground, even as it ages. Its leaves are also resistant to rust. Betula platyphylla is deciduous and native to subarctic and temperate Asia in Japan, China, Korea, Mongolia, and the Russian Far East and Siberia. Learn more about Betula platyphylla.

Betula populifolia 'Whitespire' has a narrow growth habit and is an excellent choice as a street tree, for avenues, or in spaces with limited room. Its dazzling white bark is present from ground level and persists even as Betula populifolia 'Whitespire' ages. Its leaves turn a beautiful yellow color during the autumn season. Betula populifolia is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Betula populifolia 'Whitespire' was selected and introduced in 1983 by Edward R. Hasselkus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Wisconsin, United States. Learn more about Betula populifolia.

This birch tree is beautiful and features dazzling white peeling bark that extends from top to bottom and remains even as Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii ages. Its growth habit is neat and erect, and its large tapering dark-green leaves turn a bright yellow color during the autumn season. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis.

This is a superior variety of Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii, and it's known for its stunning, snow-white bark. Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Dazzler' is lovely, with dazzling, peeling bark that extends from top to bottom and persists even as Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Dazzler' ages. Its growth habit is neat and erect, and its large tapering dark-green leaves turn a bright yellow color during the autumn season. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis.

Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Jermyns' is vigorous and has a broad, conical shape. It features an attractive white bark that peels off in horizontal, papery flakes. Its dark green leaves turn a beautiful golden-yellow color during the autumn season. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis. Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Jermyns' originally came to Messrs Hillier in the United Kingdom from a Belgian nursery as Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii and were so uniform as to indicate that they had been propagated vegetatively.

Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Silver Shadow' has a conical crown and features clear white bark on both its trunk and branches. Its oval leaves are dark green and drooping, but turn yellow during the autumn season. The male catkins of Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Silver Shadow' are noticeable in early spring. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis.

Brachychiton acerifolius grows into a tall and stately, upright form with a spreading crown. Its large, glossy, lobed leaves drop in the spring before flowering, which reveals vivid scarlet bells hanging in trusses. Brachychiton acerifolius tends to flower best in hot, dry climates. Brachychiton acerifolius is semi-evergreen and native to tropical and subtropical regions on the east coast of Australia. Learn more about Brachychiton acerifolius.

Brachychiton rupestris has an upright, spreading growth habit and produces panicles of cream-yellow flowers with red markings in the spring season. It has a large, bulbous trunk and is a drought-deciduous succulent, which means it sheds very few leaves. Brachychiton rupestris is semi-evergreen and native to Queensland, Australia. Learn more about Brachychiton rupestris.

Buxus 'Green Gem' features a natural rounded shape. During spring, the new growth is adorned in a soft lime green hue which transforms into a darker glossy green as it matures. Buxus 'Green Gem' grows well in both sunny and partially shaded enviroments. It has a higher resistance to Buxus blight compared to Buxus sempervirens.

Buxus sempervirens is an evergreen shrub native to Europe, North Africa and West Asia. This versatile shrub is well-suited for both large formal gardens and smaller garden spaces. With its lush green foliage it is ideal for hedging, providing an elegant touch to edges, borders and small boundaries. Often chosen as a popular box hedging selection, it is typically tightly clipped into formal low hedges. Known for its hardiness and forgiving nature.

Buxus sempervirens 'Graham Blandy' has a tall, columnar growth habit and features shiny, dark green, rounded leaves. It grows slowly and is hardy in both sun and semi-shade. Buxus sempervirens is evergreen and native to western and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia. Learn more about Buxus sempervirens. Buxus sempervirens 'Graham Blandy' was selected from seedlings at the Blandy Experimental Farm in Virginia, United States around 1936 and named by Lynn Batdorf.

Callistemon 'Better John' is bred from the cultivar Callistemon 'Little John', and native to Australia. It features soft blue-green dense foliage, with a soft and hairy texture and is a very compact low-maintenance plant. With vibrant red bottlebrush flowers in spinrg, it is a perfect choice for low hedging, borders or pots. It will grow best in full or part sun, and well draining soil.

Callistemon citrinus produces red flowers during the spring season and may bloom again in the autumn if it's adequately watered. It's suitable for planting in coastal areas and wet sites, and it can also tolerate some dry soils. Callistemon citrinus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Callistemon citrinus.

Callistemon citrinus 'Red Cluster' has a vigorous, rounded growth habit and produces a profusion of crimson-red brush-like flowers during the spring season, with a second flowering occurring in the autumn. Its flowers are attractive to nectar-seeking birds. Once established, Callistemon citrinus 'Red Cluster' is drought-tolerant. Callistemon citrinus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Callistemon citrinus.

Callistemon citrinus 'Western Glory' has green, slender, leathery leaves and produces large heads of red-pink flowers in the late spring through to the summer season. Its flowers attract nectar-seeking bees, and Callistemon citrinus 'Western Glory' is hardy in both coastal and drought conditions. Callistemon citrinus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Callistemon citrinus. Callistemon citrinus 'Western Glory' was selected from a batch of Callistemon citrinus seedlings about 1980 by George Lullfitz in Wanneroo, Western Australia.

Callistemon 'Hot Pink' is a spreading grower and produces large, bright pink, brush-like flowers during the spring season. Its flowers are attractive to nectar-feeding birds, and Callistemon 'Hot Pink' is tolerant to both drought and coastal conditions. Callistemon 'Hot Pink' is evergreen and a hybrid between Callistemon citrinus 'Splendens' and Callistemon pallidus. Callistemon 'Hot Pink' was bred in South Africa.

Callistemon 'John Mashlan' has a compact, upright growth habit and produces a profusion of candy-floss pink brush-like flowers during the spring and summer seasons. Once established, Callistemon 'John Mashlan' is drought-tolerant. Callistemon 'John Mashlan' is evergreen and not native to New Zealand.

Callistemon 'Kings Park Special' is compact and free-flowering, with bright-red flower-heads that bloom during the spring and summer seasons. It's highly adaptable and can thrive in a range of soil types and positions. Callistemon 'Kings Park Special' is well-suited as both a feature or screen plant. Callistemon 'Kings Park Special' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a seedling that was raised at Kings Park and Botanic Garden in Perth, Australia in the 1970s. The original plant was selected and propagated by E. Wittwer. The origin of the seed is not known.

Callistemon salignus features pink-red new foliage and produces beautiful cream-colored bottlebrush flowers throughout the spring, summer, and autumn seasons. It's capable of tolerating waterlogged soils for extended periods, as well as drought conditions. Callistemon salignus is hardy and easy to grow. Callistemon salignus is evergreen and native to eastern Australia. Learn more about Callistemon salignus.

Callistemon viminalis has dark-green leaves and produces deep-red bottlebrush flowers in the late spring through early summer, with some spot-flowering occurring throughout the year. Callistemon viminalis is capable of tolerating wet sites as well as short spells of drought. Callistemon viminalis is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia in Australia. Learn more about Callistemon viminalis.

Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' features a more compact growth habit and improved flower presentation. It has fresh-green, toned foliage with bushy and neat growth, and responds very well to pruning after flowering. Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' produces beautiful red flowers for most of the year and is resistant to myrtle rust. Callistemon viminalis is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia in Australia. Learn more about Callistemon viminalis. Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' is a hybrid between Callistemon viminalis 'Little John' and Callistemon viminalis 'Captain Cook'. Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' was developed by Ozbreed in Australia.

Callistemon viminalis 'Red Alert' is a unique bottlebrush that produces vivid-red new growth for two months in both the autumn and spring seasons, along with light-red new growth for even more months. It's low-maintenance, drought and frost-tolerant, and thrives in windy conditions, making it suitable for most soils. Callistemon viminalis is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia in Australia. Learn more about Callistemon viminalis. Callistemon viminalis 'Red Alert' was developed by Ozbreed in Australia.

Callitris rhomboidea grows in a columnar shape and features green, cypress-like foliage. It can be utilized as a specimen, and over time, it forms a beautiful pyramid shape. It's also well-suited for use as a trimmed hedge or screen. During cold weather, the foliage takes on a purple-brown tinge. Callitris rhomboidea is highly resistant to canker. Callitris rhomboidea is evergreen and native to the states of South Australia, Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, and Tasmania in Australia. Learn more about Callitris rhomboidea.

Camellia 'Ariel's Song' is a bushy grower that produces small, single, white flowers during the spring season. It makes for a great specimen or hedge. Camellia 'Ariel's Song' has an upright, open growth habit with pendulous branches and light-green leaves typically measuring 9cm long by 3cm wide. The flowers are usually 4cm across by 2.5cm deep with five petals, featuring gold anthers on white filaments. Camellia 'Ariel's Song' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia fraterna and Camellia tsaii. Camellia 'Ariel's Song' was produced by A. B. Durrant in Rotorua, New Zealand and first flowered in 1973.

Camellia 'Black Lace' is a formal-looking camellia with large, dark-red, double flowers that bloom during the spring season. It's a compact, upright-grower that's ideal for use as a hedge. Camellia 'Black Lace' features dark-green, glossy leaves, usually measuring 8cm long by 4cm wide. The flowers are typically 11cm wide by 4cm deep, containing 130-140 petals and never showing stamens. Camellia 'Black Lace' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia x williamsii 'Donation' and Camellia x reticulata 'Crimson Robe'. Camellia 'Black Lace' was produced by L. W. Ruffin in Mississippi, United States and first flowered in 1965.

Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' produces miniature flowers with a semi-double to rose form. It features a profusion of pink buds that open to pale-pink or white, blooming from late-autumn to early-spring. Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' is a strong, upright grower that's excellent for use in narrow spaces. It has light green leaves, usually measuring 5cm long by 2.8cm wide. The flowers are typically 5.3cm wide by 2.5cm deep, containing 18 petals and 22 petaloids, orange anthers, white filaments, and a deep cinnamon fragrance. Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Kan'yōtai' and Camellia lutchuensis. Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' was produced by W. Ackerman in Glendale, Maryland, United States and first flowered in 1967.

Camellia 'Fairy Blush' features a profusion of deep-pink buds that open up to single, white to pale-pink flowers that are blushed pink around the edges. The lightly fragrant flowers are typically 5cm wide by 2cm deep, with yellow anthers on creamy filaments. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' has an upright and open growth habit, with small, dark green leaves that are usually 3cm long by 2cm wide. It blooms from late-autumn to early-spring and is perfect for use as a superb hedge. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' prefers full sun or semi-shade. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid of Camellia lutchuensis. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' was produced by M. C. Jury in North Taranaki, New Zealand and first flowered in 1988.

Camellia 'Fairy Wand' features small, semi-double red-pink flowers and has an upright, open growth habit with dark-green leaves, usually measuring 5cm long by 2.5cm wide. It blooms from early-winter through spring, and the flowers are typically 4cm wide by 2.5cm deep, containing 15 petals. Camellia 'Fairy Wand' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia 'Tiny Princess' and the hybrid formed between Camellia saluenensis and Camellia japonica 'Kon-wabisuke' (syn. Camellia japonica 'Fuyajo'). Camellia 'Fairy Wand' was produced by Oswald Blumhardt in Whangārei, New Zealand.

Camellia 'High Fragrance' produces large, peony pink-white flowers that open from salmon-pink buds and exude a delicious, strong fragrance reminiscent of Camellia lutchuensis. Blooming for an extended period from mid-winter through mid-spring, it has an open growth habit with dark-green leaves that typically measure 7.5cm long by 4.5cm wide. The flowers are usually 9-10cm wide by 6.5cm deep, and contain 30 petals, about 10 petaloids, and some stamens with white filaments and yellow anthers. Camellia 'High Fragrance' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Mrs Bertha A. Harms' and the hybrid formed from Camellia 'Salab' and Camellia 'Scentuous'. Camellia 'High Fragrance' was produced by J. R. Finlay in Whangārei, New Zealand and first flowered in 1985.

This is a compact, upright shrub with gracefully hanging branches. It produces small to medium-sized, double to peony flowers in a delicate light-pink shade, each flower having 45 to 50 petals. The flowering period of this shrub is from early autumn to late winter. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Ave Maria' was produced by Caesar Breschini in San Jose, California, United States and first flowered in 1953.

synonyms: Camellia japonica 'Sara C. Hastie', Camellia japonica 'French Pink Peony', Camellia japonica 'Wutai Xinxiu'
description: Camellia japonica 'Debutante' has an upright growth habit and produces plenty of sizeable, light-pink flowers in a peony-style from winter to early spring. These blooms create a pleasing contrast with the glossy, dark-green foliage. It's an ideal choice for a hedge or privacy screen, effectively concealing unattractive spaces. The flowers typically measure 8 to 10cm across. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Debutante' was produced at the Magnolia Plantation and Gardens, Charleston, South Carolina, United States in the early 1900s.

Camellia japonica 'Ecclefield' is a semi-double bloom with chalky white flowers, set against dark green glossy foliage. It flowers from mid-winter to early spring. Plant in a sunny or partly shaded location, in well draining soil. Trim lightly in spring to keep a robust upright form.Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan.Camellia japonica 'Ecclefield' was released in California in 1969.

Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Beauty' is a chance seedling from Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme'. Its deep-red buds unfurl into magnificent, peony-style, rosy-red blooms that emit a delightful fragrance. Against the glossy, dark-green leaves, the flowers create a stunning contrast, illuminating lightly-shaded areas. It flowers from early to late winter and looks stunning in woodland borders, foundation plantings, or as a hedge. With its compact and upright growth habit, it's an excellent choice for various landscaping purposes. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Beauty' was produced by Kramer Brothers Nurseries in California, United States.

The magnificent peony-style flowers of Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme' begin as deep-red buds and open into rosy-red blooms that are complemented by a delightful fragrance. The contrast between the stunning flowers and the glossy, dark-green foliage brightens lightly-shaded areas. Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme' produces flowers from early to late winter, making it a perfect addition to woodland borders and foundation plantings, or as a hedge. Its beauty is sure to impress in any landscaping setting. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme' was produced by August Kramer of Kramer Brothers Nurseries in California, United States.

Camellia japonica 'Mark Alan' produces large semi-double flowers in a range of rose to wine-red shades from late autumn to late winter, and is known for its abundant blooms. It thrives in full sun or semi-shade and typically produces flowers that are 12.5cm wide by 5cm deep, consisting of 12 to 15 petals and 25 to 30 long, slender petaloids interspersed with yellow stamens. Camellia japonica 'Mark Alan' has an upright and dense growth habit. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Mark Alan' was produced by H. E. Ashby in Charleston, South Carolina, United States.

Camellia japonica 'Roger Hall' is known for its beautiful, formal, double, red flowers, which contrast well against its handsome, glossy, green, finely-serrated foliage. It's an outstanding performer that can make a strong statement in either a garden or container. The flowers usually measure 6.5 to 7.5cm wide and appear from late winter to early spring. Camellia japonica 'Roger Hall' thrives in semi-shade and has an upright and dense growth habit, with dark-green leaves that typically measure 9cm long by 4.5cm wide. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Roger Hall' was produced by Roger Hall in Tea Tree Gully, South Australia, Australia.

Camellia japonica 'Takanini' features glowing, medium-sized anemone-shaped flowers in a deep-red color with a slight fragrance. It has a strong, bushy, and narrow-growing habit, producing flowers from early winter to late spring. The growth habit of Camellia japonica 'Takanini' is upright, with dark-green leaves that are typically 9cm long by 4cm wide. The flowers are usually 8 to 9cm wide by 3.5cm deep, with 15 petals and 140 to 200 petaloids, occasionally featuring anthers. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Takanini' was produced by Neville Haydon in Auckland, New Zealand and first flowered in 1984.

Camellia japonica 'Tom Knudsen' produces dark-red flowers with deeper veining in a peony to double form. The blooms appear from late winter to early spring, and typically measure 11cm wide by 7.5cm deep, with 50 petals and 4 petaloids. Camellia japonica 'Tom Knudsen' has a compact and upright growth habit, with dark-green leaves that usually measure 7.5cm long by 5.5cm wide. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Tom Knudsen' was produced by Frank Maitland in Sylmar, California, United States and first flowered in 1956.

Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' produces beautiful semi-double pale-pink flowers from late autumn to mid-spring. The flowers typically measure 11cm wide by 3.5cm deep and consist of 16 petals, cream filaments, and gold anthers.
