Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' is a compact grower with dark-green leaves that are usually 8.5cm long by 3.5cm wide. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' is a great choice for pots, planters, and small gardens. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia pitardii and Camellia japonica. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' was produced by A. B. Durrant in Rotorua, New Zealand and first flowered in 1972.

Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' produces large, bright-red flowers with frilly petals in anemone to peony form. The blooms are typically 8cm wide by 5cm deep and consist of 16 petals, about 137 petaloids, and gold stamens. They are very showy and contrast beautifully against the large, glossy, deep-green leaves, which are usually 9cm long by 5cm wide. Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' flowers from late winter to late spring and has a dense, compact growth habit with a pyramidal form. Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Kimberley' and Camellia x williamsii 'Dark Nite'. Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' was produced by Les Jury in New Plymouth, New Zealand and first flowered in 1987.

Camellia sasanqua 'Crimson King' produces large, semi-double, pink-red flowers from early autumn to early winter. The blooms are usually 12cm wide and have attractive golden stamens. Camellia sasanqua 'Crimson King' is a great choice for hedges and screens. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Crimson King' was produced in Japan in the early 1900s.

Camellia sasanqua 'Early Pearly' produces small, formal, double flowers that are white with a hint of pink. The flowers are typically 4cm wide by 1.2cm deep and appear early, from late autumn to mid-winter. Camellia sasanqua 'Early Pearly' has an upright, open growth habit, with dark-green leaves that are usually 2.5cm long by 1.2cm wide. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Early Pearly' was produced by Mervin B. Wine in Thomasville, Georgia, United States and first flowered in 1969.

Camellia sasanqua 'Gay Border' produces large fragrant single flowers in autumn and winter, displaying a white to pale pink hue, with rose-red shading on the borders. The glossy dark green leaves with finely serrated edges respond well to pruning, forming an excellent hedge.Camellia sansanqua 'Gay Border' thrives in acidic soil and partial shade, but can also tolerate full sun. It originated in New Zealand by Jack Clark, Auckland, from the parent plant Camellia sasanqua.

synonyms: Camellia sasanqua 'White Doves', Camellia sasanqua 'Snow On The Mountain', Camellia sasanqua 'Snow On The Peak', Camellia sasanqua 'Snow', Camellia sasanqua 'Baige', Camellia sasanqua 'Alpine Snow'
description: Camellia sasanqua 'Mine-no-yuki' is known for its elegant, snow-white, double blooms that feature orange anthers and cream filaments scattered among the 3 to 4 tiers of petals. It enjoys an upright, willowy habit, with arching, cascading branches that add to its visual appeal. Camellia sasanqua 'Mine-no-yuki' flowers from early autumn to early winter, offering a beautiful display during this time. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Mine-no-yuki' was produced in Japan.

Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Blush' produces deep-pink buds that open into stunning semi-double white flowers with a rose-pink blush on the edges. It flowers from early autumn to late winter, adding color and beauty to the garden during the colder months. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Blush' has a thick, compact, and upright growth habit, making it a great choice for hedging and screening. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Blush' was produced by Paradise Plants Nursery in Kulnura, New South Wales, Australia.

Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Sayaka' is an exquisite cultivar with single to semi-double, white flowers that are broadly edged with soft, salmon-pink. It produces blooms from early autumn to late winter, providing a beautiful display during the colder months. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Sayaka' has an upright, dense growth habit, making it an excellent choice for restricted sites where narrow growth is required. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Sayaka' was produced by Paradise Plants Nursery in Kulnura, New South Wales, Australia.

Camellia sasanqua 'Plantation Pink' thrives in moist, well draining soils and a sheltered site with full sun to partial shade. In autumn to early winter, Camellia sasanqua 'Planatation Pink' produces large light pink flowers with a yellow centre. Its leaves are narrow and dark green. An evergreen perfect for hedging, Camellia sasanqua 'Planatation Pink' was grown from the parent plant Camellia sasanqua and originated in Australia by E.G. Waterhouse.

synonyms: Camellia sasanqua 'Fluted White', Camellia sasanqua 'Wavy White', Camellia sasanqua 'Elegant Friends'
description: Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' produces medium-sized, single to semi-double flowers in pure white with 7 to 12 incurved petals and a slight fragrance. Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' blooms from early autumn to mid-winter, and has an upright, vigorous growth habit with deep-green leaves usually measuring 5 to 7cm long by 2 to 3cm wide. Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' is an excellent choice for hedges, providing a beautiful and fragrant border. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' was produced by Jisuke Minagawa in Japan.

Camellia sasanqua 'Silver Dollar' produces medium-sized, ruffled, double flowers in pure white, which appear in autumn and early winter. Camellia sasanqua 'Silver Dollar' has a slow-growing but dense, upright growth habit, making it an excellent choice for a low hedge. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Silver Dollar' was produced by Nuccio's Nurseries in Altadena, California, United States, first flowered in 1978, and was introduced into commerce in 1985.

Camellia 'Spring Festival' produces pure-pink, double flowers that are typically 5 to 6cm wide. It flowers profusely from mid-winter to early spring, adding color and beauty to the garden during the colder months. Camellia 'Spring Festival' has a narrow, upright growth habit with dense foliage. Camellia 'Spring Festival' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid of Camellia cuspidata. Camellia 'Spring Festival' was produced by Toichi Domoto in Hayward, California, United States and first flowered in 1970.

Camellia transnokoensis is a dense-foliaged bush with an upright growth form, making it an excellent choice for screening. It produces a mass of small, white, single flowers that emerge from pink-red buds and completely cover the bush from late winter to early spring. Camellia transnokoensis is hardy and vigorous, able to thrive in a variety of growing conditions. Camellia transnokoensis is evergreen and native to southeastern China, Taiwan, and the Ryukyu Islands of Japan. Learn more about Camellia transnokoensis.

Camellia 'Transtasman' produces masses of single, white to pale-pink flowers that bloom in winter and spring, opening from pink-red buds. The flowers are slightly fragrant and usually measure 4cm wide by 2cm deep, with six petals. Camellia 'Transtasman' has an upright growth habit with glossy, green leaves that are typically 4.5cm long by 1.8cm wide. Camellia 'Transtasman' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia pitardii and Camellia transnokoensis. Camellia 'Transtasman' was produced by Ray Garnett in Beaumaris, Victoria, Australia and first flowered in 1987.

synonyms: Camellia x vernalis 'Flying Dragon', Camellia x vernalis 'Red Bird', Camellia x vernalis 'Scarlet Bird', Camellia x vernalis 'Scarlet Dragon', Camellia x vernalis 'Fire Dragon'
description: Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū' produces bright, red-pink, single to semi-double flowers in abundance. It flowers throughout autumn into early winter, providing a colorful display during the colder months. Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū' is a vigorous and hardy cultivar, making it an excellent choice as a screen or large filler. It grows well in both sun and semi-shade. Camellia x vernalis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia sasanqua and Camellia japonica. Learn more about Camellia x vernalis. Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū' was produced in Japan and imported into the United States in 1906 by E. Fenerosa in Mobile, Alabama, United States.

Camellia x vernalis 'Yuletide' has an upright, compact growth habit with dark-green leaves that are typically 4.5cm long by 2.5cm wide. It produces single, red flowers over a long period, from early winter to early spring. The flowers feature golden anthers and usually measure 7.5cm wide with 5 to 7 petals. Camellia x vernalis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia sasanqua and Camellia japonica. Learn more about Camellia x vernalis. Camellia x vernalis 'Yuletide' is a seedling from Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū', was produced by Nuccio's Nurseries in Altadena, California, United States, and first flowered in 1959.

Camellia x williamsii 'Jury's Yellow' is a compact and erect grower with light-green foliage that usually measures 7cm long by 4cm wide. It produces anemone-form flowers that feature 9 white petals and approximately 50 cream-yellow petaloids in the center. The flowers are typically 8cm wide and appear from late autumn to early spring. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Jury's Yellow' is a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Gwenneth Morey' and the hybrid formed between Camellia saluenensis and Camellia japonica 'Edith Linton'. Camellia x williamsii 'Jury's Yellow' was produced by Les Jury in New Plymouth, New Zealand and first flowered in 1971.

Camellia x williamsii 'Les Jury' produces large, double to peony-form, deep crimson-red flowers that are typically 10cm wide by 5cm deep, with 75 or more petals and 10 or more petaloids. It blooms from early to late winter, adding a pop of color during the colder months. Camellia x williamsii 'Les Jury' has an upright growth habit with dark-green leaves that are usually 8cm long by 4cm wide, and makes an excellent hedge plant. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Les Jury' is a seedling from Camellia x williamsii 'Rendezvous' and was produced by Les Jury in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Camellia x williamsii 'Super Star' produces pure-white, semi-double flowers in spring that are typically 12cm wide by 6cm deep, with 10 petals, white filaments, and golden anthers. Camellia x williamsii 'Super Star' blooms from early to mid-spring, providing a beautiful display during this time. It has an upright growth habit with green leaves that are usually 9cm long by 4cm wide. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Super Star' was produced by J. E. Shaw in Waima, Northland, New Zealand and first flowered in 1972.

Camellia x williamsii 'Water Lily' has an upright, compact growth habit with dark-green leaves that are usually 6.5cm long by 4cm wide. It produces double, rose-pink flowers that are typically 11cm wide by 5cm deep with about 50 petals. Camellia x williamsii 'Water Lily' flowers from early autumn to mid-spring, providing a beautiful display during the cooler months. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Water Lily' was produced by Felix Jury in Waitara, New Zealand.

Carpinus betulus has a strong, pyramidal form when young, which becomes rounded with age. The rich-green leaves are heavily-ribbed and turn yellow in autumn, followed by brown leaves throughout the winter. Carpinus betulus is excellent for use as a hedge, and is very popular for pleaching. Its yellow-green catkins in early to mid-spring are a good source of pollen for bees, making it a great addition to a bee-friendly garden. Carpinus betulus is deciduous and native to Western Asia and central, eastern, and southern Europe, including southern England. Learn more about Carpinus betulus.

Carpinus betulus 'Fastigiata' has an upright, pyramidal form that is quite narrow when young and becomes broader with age. It is an excellent choice as an avenue or street tree, thanks to its attractive appearance and hardiness. Carpinus betulus 'Fastigiata' produces yellow autumn leaves and holds some brown leaves through the winter, although less than Carpinus betulus. Its yellow-green catkins in early to mid-spring are a good source of pollen for bees, making it a great addition to a pollinator-friendly garden. Carpinus betulus is deciduous and native to Western Asia and central, eastern, and southern Europe, including southern England. Learn more about Carpinus betulus. Carpinus betulus 'Fastigiata' has been sold since the 1880s.

Carpinus japonica features beautiful, elongated and corrugated green leaves that are a distinctive feature of Carpinus japonica. In early spring, yellow-green catkins hang from the branches along with the newly emerging leaves, adding a beautiful display of color. Carpinus japonica also produces yellow autumn leaves, providing additional seasonal interest. Carpinus japonica is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Carpinus japonica.

Carpodetus serratus is an attractive tree with spreading branches and green, marbled, and serrated leaves. It goes through a juvenile phase with divaricating branches and small, rounded leaves. From late spring to early autumn, Carpodetus serratus produces a profusion of small, white flowers, adding to its visual appeal. However, it should be noted that Carpodetus serratus does not tolerate drought or wind well, so care should be taken to ensure it is adequately watered and sheltered. Carpodetus serratus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Carpodetus serratus.

Castanea sativa forms a tall and stately tree with wide-spreading branches, making it an excellent choice for providing shade in wide, open spaces. Castanea sativa has glossy, deep-green leaves with sharply-toothed margins. In autumn, Castanea sativa produces red-brown fruits wrapped in a green, spiky case that add to its visual appeal. Castanea sativa also produces yellow autumn leaves, providing additional seasonal interest. While Castanea sativa has both male and female flowers on the same tree, it is mostly self-incompatible, so more than one tree is required for pollination and nut production. Castanea sativa is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Asia Minor and is found across the Mediterranean region, from the Caspian Sea to the Atlantic Ocean. Learn more about Castanea sativa.

Castanea sativa '1005' is a commercial fruiting cultivar and produces red-brown fruits wrapped in a green, spiky case that ripen in autumn. It is known for being a heavy-cropper, producing a large yield of fruit. Castanea sativa '1005' is a strong, upright-grower and is self-fertile, which means it does not require other trees for pollination. In autumn, Castanea sativa '1005' also produces yellow leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Castanea sativa is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Asia Minor and is found across the Mediterranean region, from the Caspian Sea to the Atlantic Ocean. Learn more about Castanea sativa. Castanea sativa '1005' was developed in New Zealand.

Casuarina cunninghamiana is a hardy tree that is suitable for windy, wet, and coastal sites. It is able to withstand the challenging growing conditions of these areas. The foliage of Casuarina cunninghamiana is quite palatable to stock, making it a good choice for livestock grazing areas. Casuarina cunninghamiana is also effective for use as a shelterbelt, providing protection from the wind. In addition, it is useful for soil stabilisation in areas with erosion, making it a versatile and practical choice for a range of growing conditions. Casuarina cunninghamiana is evergreen and native to Australia from Daly River in the Northern Territory, north and east in Queensland, and eastern New South Wales. Learn more about Casuarina cunninghamiana.

Catalpa bignonioides is an upright-growing lawn and avenue tree that has a tropical appearance. Its most notable feature is its big, green, heart-shaped leaves, which give it a distinctive look. In late spring, Catalpa bignonioides produces huge clusters of trumpet-shaped flowers that are white with yellow stripes and purple speckles, adding to its visual appeal. During the summer months, long, bean-shaped capsules appear on Catalpa bignonioides. In the fall, Catalpa bignonioides produces yellow leaves, providing additional seasonal interest. Catalpa bignonioides is deciduous and native to the southeastern United States in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, and Mississippi. Learn more about Catalpa bignonioides.

Cedrela sinensis 'Flamingo' is characterized by its slender, erect branches that bear pinnate leaves of rich, warm-pink in early spring. As the season progresses, the leaves transition to cream-yellow and then to green by summer. Cedrela sinensis 'Flamingo' can be halved in height or pruned to the ground to encourage a profusion of new stems. In the fall, Cedrela sinensis 'Flamingo' produces yellow leaves, adding to its seasonal interest. Cedrela sinensis 'Flamingo' also produces beautiful, fragrant white flowers that are arranged in drooping clusters during the summer months. Cedrela sinensis is deciduous and native to eastern and southeastern Asia. Learn more about Cedrela sinensis. Cedrela sinensis 'Flamingo' was developed in Australia before 1930.

Cedrus atlantica is an attractive conifer that has an upright, conical form. It prefers moist, well-drained soil but is also able to tolerate clay soils. Once established, Cedrus atlantica is drought-tolerant, meaning it is able to survive in drier conditions. Overall, it is a hardy and versatile plant that can thrive in a range of growing conditions. Cedrus atlantica is evergreen and native to the Atlas Mountains of Morocco (Middle Atlas, High Atlas), to the Rif Mountains, and to the Tell Atlas in Algeria. Learn more about Cedrus atlantica.

synonyms: Cedrus libani subsp. atlantica 'Glauca', Cedrus libani var. atlantica 'Glauca', Cedrus atlantica f. glauca
description: Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca' is an upright and stately tree that has silver-blue needles, giving it a unique and striking appearance. It is known for its tolerance of strong winds, which makes it a great choice for windy locations. Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca' is also moderately coastal-hardy, meaning it can withstand the challenging growing conditions of coastal areas, including salty air and strong winds. Overall, Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca' is a hardy and visually striking option for a range of growing conditions. Cedrus atlantica is evergreen and native to the Atlas Mountains of Morocco (Middle Atlas, High Atlas), to the Rif Mountains, and to the Tell Atlas in Algeria. Learn more about Cedrus atlantica. Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca', along with various other blue cultivars of Cedrus atlantica, was selected in the wild and has been in cultivation since the early 1800s.

synonyms: Cedrus libani subsp. atlantica 'Glauca Pendula', Cedrus libani var. atlantica 'Glauca Pendula'
description: Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca Pendula' is an imposing conifer that has curtains of silver-blue foliage cascading from a dome-shaped crown, giving it a unique and striking appearance. When growing Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca Pendula', it is typically recommended to stake it initially to encourage Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca Pendula' to reach the desired height before allowing it to weep to the ground, as this helps to ensure a full and well-proportioned appearance. Overall, Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca Pendula' is an attractive and visually interesting option for a range of landscaping and garden applications. Cedrus atlantica is evergreen and native to the Atlas Mountains of Morocco (Middle Atlas, High Atlas), to the Rif Mountains, and to the Tell Atlas in Algeria. Learn more about Cedrus atlantica. Cedrus atlantica 'Glauca Pendula' was selected around 1900 by Paillet Nursery in Châtenay, France.

Cedrus deodara is an upright-growing conifer that has a strong, pyramidal form. The evenly-spaced branches are gracefully-pendulous at their tips, which gives Cedrus deodara a soft appearance. However, this shape is also practical because it helps to shake off any snow that may accumulate on the branches. The light-blue to grey-green needles are generously-frosted, adding to the visual interest of Cedrus deodara. Overall, this conifer is a hardy and visually striking option that is well-suited for a range of growing conditions. Cedrus deodara is evergreen and native to the Himalayas. Learn more about Cedrus deodara.

Celtis australis is a straight-trunked tree with smooth, grey bark, and small, beautiful green leaves. It is a popular choice for city street planting due to its upright form and the fact that it is tolerant of drought and wind, making it well-suited for urban growing conditions. In the autumn, the leaves of Celtis australis turn a vibrant yellow color, adding to its visual interest. Overall, Celtis australis is a hardy and attractive option that is well-suited for a range of applications in both urban and suburban settings. Celtis australis is deciduous and native to Southern Europe, North Africa, and Asia Minor. Learn more about Celtis australis.

Cercidiphyllum japonicum is able to tolerate wet positions and prefers moist growing conditions. In the spring, it produces striking red-purple new leaves that add a burst of color to the landscape. As the season progresses, the leaves transition to a blue-green color and continue to provide visual interest throughout the summer months. In the autumn, the leaves of Cercidiphyllum japonicum turn a bright yellow, orange, and red, adding a beautiful array of colors to the landscape. One unique aspect of Cercidiphyllum japonicum is that the autumn leaves have a pleasant cinnamon to burnt-sugar smell when they first fall from Cercidiphyllum japonicum. Overall, Cercidiphyllum japonicum is a hardy and visually interesting option that is well-suited for a range of growing conditions. Cercidiphyllum japonicum is deciduous and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Cercidiphyllum japonicum.

Cercidiphyllum japonicum 'Pendulum' features pendulous branches and makes for a great specimen tree to highlight in your garden. It is tolerant of wet positions and prefers moist growing conditions. Cercidiphyllum japonicum 'Pendulum' produces stunning red-purple new leaves in the spring, which provide a striking contrast against its branches. As the leaves mature, they transition to a blue-green color that lasts throughout the summer months. Come autumn, the leaves of Cercidiphyllum japonicum 'Pendulum' transform into a beautiful array of bright yellow, orange, and red colors that are sure to catch the eye. Interestingly, the fallen autumn leaves of Cercidiphyllum japonicum 'Pendulum' have a pleasant cinnamon to burnt-sugar smell when they first hit the ground. Overall, Cercidiphyllum japonicum 'Pendulum' is a hardy and visually interesting option that is well-suited for a range of growing conditions. Cercidiphyllum japonicum is deciduous and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Cercidiphyllum japonicum. Cercidiphyllum japonicum 'Pendulum' has been grown in Japan since the 17th century.

otherCommonNames: American Redbud, American Judas Tree, Judas Tree
description: Cercis canadensis 'Forest Pansy' has a rounded shape and bears large, heart-shaped leaves that glow in a deep purple color. In autumn, the leaves change color to glowing orange and red. It produces numerous rose-pink, pea-shaped flowers on its bare branches in the spring. The bark of Cercis canadensis 'Forest Pansy' is dark red-brown and has a scaly surface that forms deep fissures to reveal a cinnamon-orange interior. The young stems start out brown and gradually become almost black, adding winter interest. Cercis canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Cercis canadensis. Cercis canadensis 'Forest Pansy' was discovered in 1947 as a chance seedling at Forest Nursery in McMinnville, Tennessee, United States.

otherCommonNames: American Redbud, American Judas Tree, Judas Tree
description: In spring, a round-headed tree with large heart-shaped leaves turns orange-red and eventually transitions to gold, fading to yellow-green during the summer. The autumn colours of Cercis canadensis 'Hearts Of Gold' range from bright yellow-orange to red. In the springtime, the bare branches of Cercis canadensis 'Hearts Of Gold' become covered in rose-pink flowers. The dark red-brown bark of Cercis canadensis 'Hearts Of Gold' has a scaly surface, which develops deep fissures, revealing the cinnamon-orange interior. The young stems of Cercis canadensis 'Hearts Of Gold' begin brown and eventually turn almost black, making them an interesting feature during the winter season. Cercis canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Cercis canadensis. Cercis canadensis 'Hearts Of Gold' was discovered by Jon Roethling growing in a garden at a private residence in Greensboro, North Carolina, United States in 2002. Propagation by grafting began at Hidden Hollow Nursery in Belvidere, Tennessee, United States in August of 2002.

otherCommonNames: American Redbud, American Judas Tree, Judas Tree
description: Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' is renowned for its dark wine-red foliage and exceptional ability to endure drought and heat. It has a compact form with an upright, dense, vase-like shape, making it an ideal addition to any area, including small gardens. Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' features lovely pink, pea-shaped flowers that bloom in the spring, and its leaves turn shades of red, orange, and yellow in the fall. The bark of Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' is dark red-brown, with a scaly surface and deep fissures that reveal a cinnamon-orange interior. The young stems begin as brown and gradually darken to nearly black, creating visual interest during the winter months. Cercis canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Cercis canadensis. Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' is a hybrid between Cercis canadensis 'Forest Pansy' and Cercis canadensis var. texensis 'Texas White' and was introduced in 2009 by North Carolina State University, North Carolina, United States in conjunction with the JC Ralston Arboretum, North Carolina, United States. Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' was bred by Dr. Dennis Werner, Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' breeder in the Department of Horticultural Science, North Carolina State University. The original parent trees were adjacent trees in a North Carolina State University campus landscape planting from which seed was collected in 1998 and these seedlings were reared in isolation at the Sandhills Research Station in Jackson Springs, North Carolina, United States. The seedlings flowered in 2002, from which Cercis canadensis 'Merlot' was selected.

otherCommonNames: American Redbud, American Judas Tree, Judas Tree
description: Cercis canadensis 'Ruby Falls' is distinguished by its distinct weeping habit, featuring a compact form with an abundance of pink, pea-like flowers that bloom profusely in the spring. Its foliage begins as a vibrant red in the spring before turning to a rich burgundy color and eventually maturing to green by late summer. In the fall, the leaves of Cercis canadensis 'Ruby Falls' turn shades of red and orange. The bark of Cercis canadensis 'Ruby Falls' is dark red-brown with a scaly surface, and it forms deep fissures that reveal a cinnamon-orange interior. The young stems begin as brown and gradually transform into an almost black color, creating visual appeal during the winter season. Cercis canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Cercis canadensis. Cercis canadensis 'Ruby Falls' is a hybrid between Cercis canadensis 'Forest Pansy' and Cercis canadensis 'Covey' and was selected in 2006 by Dr. Dennis Werner, Cercis canadensis 'Ruby Falls' breeder in the Department of Horticultural Science, North Carolina State University, North Carolina, United States.

otherCommonNames: American Redbud, American Judas Tree, Judas Tree
description: Cercis canadensis 'Silver Lining' boasts variegated green and white leaves, and its foliage turns a beautiful shade of yellow during the autumn season. In the springtime, the bare branches of Cercis canadensis 'Silver Lining' are covered in rose-pink flowers. Cercis canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Cercis canadensis. Cercis canadensis 'Silver Lining' was introduced in 1964 by Yew Dell Nursery in Crestwood, Kentucky, United States.

A tree with a round-shaped canopy and large, attractive, heart-shaped leaves that have a shiny green color. The leaves turn a bright yellow hue during the autumn season. In the spring, the bare branches of Cercis canadensis var. texensis 'Oklahoma' become covered with a profusion of wine-red, pea-shaped flowers. Cercis canadensis var. texensis is deciduous and native to the states of Texas and Oklahoma in the United States. Learn more about Cercis canadensis var. texensis. Cercis canadensis var. texensis 'Oklahoma' was discovered in 1964 in the Arbuckle Mountains of Oklahoma, United States and was named and released by Warren & Son Nursery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma in 1964.

Cercis canadensis var. texensis 'Texas White' has a round-shaped canopy and large, handsome, heart-shaped leaves with a shining green color. During the autumn season, the leaves turn a bright yellow hue. In the springtime, the bare branches of Cercis canadensis var. texensis 'Texas White' become adorned with a profusion of pure-white, pea-shaped flowers. Cercis canadensis var. texensis is deciduous and native to the states of Texas and Oklahoma in the United States. Learn more about Cercis canadensis var. texensis. Cercis canadensis var. texensis 'Texas White' was introduced by Germany's Nursery in Fort Worth, Texas, United States in the 1960s.

Cercis chinensis 'Avondale' has an upright growth habit and features large, light-green, heart-shaped leaves that transform into a bright yellow color during the autumn season. In early spring, the bare branches of Cercis chinensis 'Avondale' become covered with a profusion of deep cerise-pink, pea-shaped flowers that persist for an extended period. Cercis chinensis 'Avondale' is particularly suitable for small spaces. Cercis chinensis is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Cercis chinensis. Cercis chinensis 'Avondale' was selected in Avondale, Auckland, New Zealand and introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Cercis chinensis 'Spring Snow' has large, rich-green, heart-shaped leaves that transform into a yellow hue during the autumn season. In early spring, the bare branches of Cercis chinensis 'Spring Snow' become covered with masses of white flowers. It has a compact growth habit, making it an ideal choice for smaller gardens. Cercis chinensis is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Cercis chinensis. Cercis chinensis 'Spring Snow' was developed in New Zealand and the name was registered in 2015.

Cercis siliquastrum is an attractive species with a flat and spreading crown. It features green, heart-shaped leaves and pink flowers that adorn its branches in the early spring. During the autumn season, its leaves turn a lovely shade of yellow. Cercis siliquastrum is particularly suitable for dry sites and is known for its hardiness, making it a great option for small landscapes. Cercis siliquastrum is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Western Asia. Learn more about Cercis siliquastrum.

Cercis siliquastrum 'Alba' is renowned for its beautiful and abundant display of pea-shaped, white flowers that bloom in the spring. In the autumn season, its leaves turn a lovely shade of yellow. Cercis siliquastrum is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Western Asia. Learn more about Cercis siliquastrum. Cercis siliquastrum 'Alba' originated as a natural form of Cercis siliquastrum, originally growing in the Mediterranean area.

Chamaecyparis pisifera 'Boulevard' has a dense and pyramidal growth habit, with silver-blue leaves that are soft to the touch. Its unique color and form are particularly outstanding. Chamaecyparis pisifera is evergreen and native to central and southern Japan, on the islands of Honshū and Kyūshū. Learn more about Chamaecyparis pisifera. Chamaecyparis pisifera 'Boulevard' originated in 1934 as a sport on a specimen of Chamaecyparis pisifera 'Squarrosa' and was introduced to the nursery trade by Mike Kempenaar of Boulevard Nurseries, Middletown, Rhode Island, United States.

Chimonanthus praecox is a multi-stemmed and bushy grower that produces sulphur-yellow flowers on its bare branches during mid-winter. These flowers give off a delightful fragrance that combines spice and violet scents. Chimonanthus praecox grows best in cold climates and dry summers. Additionally, its leaves turn a lovely shade of yellow during the autumn season. Chimonanthus praecox is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Chimonanthus praecox.

Choisya ternata is a compact and rounded bush that features attractive deep-green leaves and a distinctive fragrance. It is ideal for use as hedging or as a gap filler in the garden, and it is known for its hardiness. During the spring season, Choisya ternata produces clusters of pure-white flowers. It can tolerate drought conditions and prefers well-drained soils. Choisya ternata is evergreen and native to Mexico. Learn more about Choisya ternata.

Cinnamomum camphora is an excellent choice for providing shade and has a picturesque form. Its new leaves emerge with a green color and a red tinge, maturing to a solid green color. Cinnamomum camphora has smooth bark, and its crushed leaves and twigs give off a pleasant camphor fragrance. During the spring season, it produces masses of small white flowers, followed by clusters of black, berry-like fruit in the autumn which are beloved by birds. Once established, Cinnamomum camphora can tolerate drought conditions. Cinnamomum camphora is evergreen and native to China south of the Yangtze River, Taiwan, southern Japan, Korea, India, and Vietnam. Learn more about Cinnamomum camphora.

Citrus x aurantiifolia 'Sublime' is a compact grower that is virtually thornless and is well-suited for growing in a large pot. It is an excellent choice for small gardens and produces a prolific crop of large-sized fruit that start green and change to yellow-green when ripe. The fruit is commonly used for cooking and flavoring drinks. Citrus x aurantiifolia 'Sublime' has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the spring and summer, and it is self-fertile. It prefers warmer climates and is very sensitive to frost. In tropical climates, Citrus x aurantiifolia 'Sublime' can produce limes year-round. However, in subtropical climates, it typically only produces one yearly crop that usually matures by late summer, though the timing of fruit maturity depends on the local conditions. Citrus x aurantiifolia is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus micrantha (syn. Citrus hystrix var. micrantha) and Citrus medica. Citrus x aurantiifolia is evergreen and native to tropical Southeast Asia. Learn more about Citrus x aurantiifolia.

This lime is a cold-hardy and heavier-bearing cultivar. It has an upright and bushy growth habit and produces prolific crops of large-sized fruit that start off green but turn green-yellow when ready to harvest. It produces fruit both in the winter and summer seasons and has a high juice content. Citrus x latifolia 'Bearss' also features scented white flowers throughout the summer season, and it is self-fertile. Citrus x latifolia is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x aurantiifolia and Citrus x limon. Learn more about Citrus x latifolia. Citrus x latifolia 'Bearss' is named after John T. Bearss, who developed this seedless cultivar about 1895 at his nursery in Porterville, California, United States.

This cold-hardy lime is an ideal choice for home gardens as it commences fruiting quickly. It has an upright and bushy growth habit and produces prolific crops of large-sized fruit that start green and turn yellow-green when ready to harvest. It produces fruit throughout the winter season and has a high juice content. This lime is excellent for growing in containers and also features scented white flowers throughout the summer season. Additionally, it is self-fertile. Citrus x latifolia is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x aurantiifolia and Citrus x limon. Learn more about Citrus x latifolia.

This almost thornless cultivar is known for producing juicy, highly-sour fruit with very few seeds and a smooth, medium-thin rind. As a true lemon, it has a more sour taste than hybrid lemons. Once established, it will fruit all year round, with the biggest crops occurring in the spring and summer seasons. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the year, and it is self-fertile. However, Citrus x limon 'Eureka' is less cold-tolerant than other lemon cultivars, so it is best suited for warmer and/or coastal areas where frost damage is less likely to occur. Citrus x limon is evergreen and native to Asia, primarily Northeast India (Assam), Northern Myanmar, and China. Learn more about Citrus x limon. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' originated in Los Angeles, California, United States in the late 1800s, possibly having its ancestry from Citrus x limon 'Lunario' from Italy. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' was selected in about 1877 from seedlings that were planted in 1858. C. R. Workman provided Thomas A. Garey with budwood from one of these seedlings and he propagated the first Citrus x limon 'Eureka'.

This almost thornless cultivar produces juicy, highly-sour fruit with very few seeds. As a true lemon, it has a more sour taste than hybrid lemons. The fruit ripens in the winter season, providing a delicious flavor during the colder months. Citrus x limon 'Villa Franca' features scented white flowers that bloom throughout the summer season, and it is self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. Citrus x limon is evergreen and native to Asia, primarily Northeast India (Assam), Northern Myanmar, and China. Learn more about Citrus x limon. Citrus x limon 'Villa Franca' is said to have originated in Sicily and was then introduced into Florida, United States by H. S. Sandford about 1875 and later into California, United States.

Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' has a compact growth habit and produces large, oval fruits that are tangy and excellent for culinary use. As a true lemon, it has a more sour taste than hybrid lemons. The fruit has a high juice content, very few seeds, and a thin rind. The fruit ripens in mid to late-winter, providing a great flavor during the colder months. Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' is one of the hardiest lemon cultivars available. It also features scented white flowers that bloom throughout the summer season, and it is self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. Citrus x limon is evergreen and native to Asia, primarily Northeast India (Assam), Northern Myanmar, and China. Learn more about Citrus x limon. Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' was selected as a sport of Citrus x limon 'Lisbon' at Benyenda Citrus in Queensland, Australia in the late 1930s. Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' has been trialled in New Zealand since 1978.

Citrus limon x reticulata produces pale-yellow fruit that is similar to a lemon in appearance. However, the fruit has a mild, fresh, grapefruit-like flavor that is very refreshing to eat off Citrus limon x reticulata. Citrus limon x reticulata is a heavy cropper during mid-winter to early-spring, with smaller summer crops sometimes occurring. It is also an excellent choice for growing in containers. Citrus limon x reticulata has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the spring season, and it is self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. Citrus limon x reticulata is evergreen and a hybrid of unknown origin, although it is believed to be a hybrid between a lemon (Citrus x limon) and a mandarin (Citrus reticulata). Citrus limon x reticulata was discovered as a chance seedling in New Zealand in the 1980s.

Citrus x meyeri is the most popular lemon cultivar for home gardens. It is cold-hardy and quick to commence fruiting, making it an ideal choice for gardeners. Citrus x meyeri has a low-spreading growth habit, which will create a large bush. Its large fruit has a high juice content and lower acid level than other cultivars, giving it a unique flavor profile. As a hybrid lemon, it has a sweeter taste than true lemons. Citrus x meyeri is also an excellent choice for growing in containers. Once established, it will fruit all year round, with the biggest crops occurring in the autumn and winter seasons. Citrus x meyeri has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the year, and it is self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. Citrus x meyeri is evergreen and most likely a hybrid between Citrus medica and the hybrid formed between Citrus maxima and Citrus reticulata. Citrus x meyeri is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Citrus x meyeri. Citrus x meyeri was discovered growing in Beijing, China by agricultural explorer Frank Nicholas Meyer, an employee of the United States Department of Agriculture, although it was established in China many hundreds of years before he introduced it to America.

Citrus x paradisi 'Cutlers Red' has large, deep orange, sweet, juicy fruit with just a little zing. The rind is thick. The fruit ripens July to November. Works best in a sunny position with well drained fertile soil. Water well during hot dry summer periods.Ideal for screening or hedging. Evergreen.(3m wide by 3m tall after 10 years)

Citrus x paradisi 'Golden Special' produces a thin-skinned grapefruit that has few seeds. The fruit has a golden-yellow skin and orange flesh. It is a heavy-bearer, producing juicy, sweet, and tangy grapefruit. Citrus x paradisi 'Golden Special' has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the summer season. The fruit ripens from mid-winter to late-spring, providing a delicious flavor during the colder months. It is also self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x sinensis and Citrus maxima. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and native to Barbados. Learn more about Citrus x paradisi. Citrus x paradisi 'Golden Special' has been the most common grapefruit cultivar in New Zealand since the 1970s.

synonyms: Citrus x aurantium 'Star Ruby', Citrus x paradisi 'Rio Star', Citrus x aurantium 'Rio Star'
description: Citrus x paradisi 'Star Ruby' produces abundant crops of juicy, red-fleshed fruit with yellow-orange skins. The fruit ripens from late-winter to mid-spring, and in cooler climates, the intensity of the red flesh may be lessened. The fruit holds well on Citrus x paradisi 'Star Ruby', and it is low-seeded or even seedless in some cases, with a very good flavor. Citrus x paradisi 'Star Ruby' has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the summer season, and it is self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. However, it prefers warmer climates and may not tolerate cold areas with significant frosts. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x sinensis and Citrus maxima. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and native to Barbados. Learn more about Citrus x paradisi. Citrus x paradisi 'Star Ruby' was produced by R. A. Hensz of Texas A&I University, Texas, United States and released in 1970.

Citrus reticulata 'Encore' produces medium-sized fruit with a thin, yellow-orange rind and deep-orange, juicy flesh that has a rich flavor. The fruit ripens from late-spring to late-summer, providing a delicious taste during the warmer months. Citrus reticulata 'Encore' has scented white flowers that bloom throughout the summer season, and it is self-fertile, meaning that it does not require additional pollination from other trees to produce fruit. Citrus reticulata 'Encore' grows upright with almost no thorns, making it easy to care for and harvest. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata. Citrus reticulata 'Encore' is a hybrid between the King mandarin (Citrus nobilis) and Willowleaf mandarin (Citrus x deliciosa) produced by H. B. Frost and introduced in 1965.

This Satsuma selection boasts a superior quality with its effortless peeling and an upright, spreading growth habit. Its sweet and juicy fruit ripen throughout winter, and typically measure 9cm in width by 4cm in depth, containing around 10 segments. It's an excellent choice for container gardening, and it also produces scented white flowers during the summer months. Additionally, Citrus reticulata 'Miho' is self-fertile and capable of withstanding cold temperatures. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata. Citrus reticulata 'Miho' was selected from seedlings planted in Japan in 1984 and first fruited in 1990.

This Satsuma selection is characterized by its large, seedless fruit and yellow-orange skin that is both easy to peel and segment. The fruit is typically harvested in the fall, while Citrus reticulata 'Okitsu' produces white flowers during the summer months. Additionally, Citrus reticulata 'Okitsu' is self-fertile, making it a reliable option for growers. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata. Citrus reticulata 'Okitsu' originated as a seedling of Citrus reticulata 'Miyagawa' during a controlled pollination by M. Kajiura and T. Iwasaki at the Horticultural Research Station in Okitsu, Japan. Citrus reticulata 'Okitsu' was distributed for trial in 1953, registered in 1963, and introduced into Europe in 1983.

This mandarin cultivar is known for its cold-hardiness and fruit that is easy to peel. Citrus reticulata 'Satsuma' produces heavy crops of mild-flavored, juicy, seedless fruit that ripen in early winter. It is also well-suited for container gardening due to its slower growth rate. Citrus reticulata 'Satsuma' features scented white flowers during the summer months and is self-fertile, making it a great option for gardeners who desire low-maintenance fruit production. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata.

Citrus x sinensis 'Best's Seedless' is characterized by its sweet, juicy, and seedless flesh. The fruit typically ripens from late winter to late spring, while Citrus x sinensis 'Best's Seedless' produces scented white flowers during the summer months. Additionally, this variety is self-fertile, making it a convenient option for gardeners who want to cultivate fruit without the need for additional pollinators. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Best's Seedless' was selected in New Zealand.

Citrus x sinensis 'Blood Orange' fruits from late winter, producing dark red flesh when the days are hot, and the nights are cold. Will tolerate light frosts but thrives in warm temperatures and prefers slightly acidic soil. Fertilize during spring and summer every month with a balanced fertilizer.Citrus x sinensis is evergreen and native to China India and Mynamar.

Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' is known for its excellent flavor, sweetness, and seedless nature. The fruit can remain juicy for up to 2-3 months if left on Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel', and typically ripens in late winter. Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' produces scented white flowers throughout the summer months and is self-fertile, making it an easy and convenient option for gardeners looking to cultivate fruit without the need for additional pollinators. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' is presumed to be a bud variation of unknown origin. Several old trees of Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' were noted about 1925 in the A. N. Carter orchard at Sierra Madre, California, United States. Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' was introduced by Armstrong Nurseries in Ontario, California, United States in 1928.

Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' produces sweet, juicy, and seedless fruit that features a strong red-orange tinge to the rind. The fruit is known for its excellent flavor and typically ripens in late winter. It thrives in full sun, and Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' produces scented white flowers during the summer months. Additionally, Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' is self-fertile, making it a low-maintenance option for gardeners who want to cultivate fruit without the need for additional pollinators. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' is believed to be a naturally occurring mutation of a Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' tree that was found in the 1960s in the garden of S. Fukumoto in Kokawa (Kokawa-Cho), Naga District, Wakayama Prefecture, Japan. It was was donated to an American doctor named W. P. Bitters in 1983. Bitters selected Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' from a display of Japanese citrus trees and then brought Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' to the United States Department of Agriculture quarantine facility in Glenn Dale, Maryland, United States. It then spent a few years in quarantine before being released in September 1986.

Citrus x sinensis 'Harwoods Late' was developed in New Zealand from a Citrus x sinensis 'Valencia' seedling, and it delightfully sweet and juicy, containing few seeds. The fruit ripens from summer through to autumn, and will thrive in a sunny well drained spot, being resistant to temperatures as low as -4C. Citrus x sinensis 'Harwoods Late' is evergreen and needs protecting from moderate to heavy frosts.

Citrus x sinensis 'Newhall' produces consistent crops of very sweet and juicy fruit. The fruit is oval, with a deep orange rind, and usually seedless. Plant Citrus x sinensis 'Newhall' in full sun, with well-drained fertile soil. This resilient variety can tolerate temperatures as low as -3C, making it suitable for colder climates. Water regularly during hot, dry spells, and fertilize during spring to mid-summer. Citrus x sinensis 'Newhall' originates in California by Paul Hackney of the Newhall Land and Water Company of Piru.

Citrus x sinensis 'Powell Navel' is a late navel variety, celebrated for its excellent flavour, sweetness and juciness. The peel, deeper orange and fine, is easily removable. The fruit has a more elongated shape compared to other navel varieties. As a vigorous tree, there are some thorns on the branches, but the fruit is seedless. The fruit ripens from late winter, holds well on the tree, and stores fine. Citrus x sinensis 'Powell Navel' was first selected in Australia by Clive Neil Powell. It was discovered in an orchard of Citrus x sinensis 'Valencia Late', but is probably a mutation of Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel'.

Citrus x sinensis 'Parent Navel' produces very juicy and sweet fruit that is practically seedless and easy to peel. The fruit typically ripens in late winter, while Citrus x sinensis 'Parent Navel' produces scented white flowers throughout the summer months. Additionally, Citrus x sinensis 'Parent Navel' is self-fertile, which means that it does not require another tree for pollination, making it a great option for gardeners who want to cultivate fruit without the need for additional trees. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis.

This fruit tree produces bright-orange fruit with thin skin. The flesh of the fruit is firm, rich in flavor, and contains only a few seeds. The fruit typically ripens from mid-spring to early autumn, while Citrus x sinensis 'Valencia' produces scented white flowers throughout the summer months. Additionally, Citrus x sinensis 'Valencia' is self-fertile, which means that it can produce fruit without the need for additional trees for pollination, making it a convenient option for gardeners. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Valencia' was named after the famed sweet oranges produced in València, Spain and was first hybridized by William Wolfskill (1798-1866) in the mid-1800s on his farm in Santa Ana, California, United States.

This popular cultivar is known for its large, sweet, and seedless fruit, which boast excellent flavor and plenty of juice. The fruit typically ripens from mid to late winter and can be left on Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' for several months. Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' produces scented white flowers throughout the summer months and is self-fertile, making it an easy and low-maintenance option for gardeners. Additionally, it is considered one of the best oranges for eating fresh, making it a great choice for those who enjoy a juicy and flavorful snack straight from Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel'. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' is believed to be a bud sport of Citrus x sinensis 'Selecta' that was found in the early 1880s. Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' was imported from Bahia, Brazil into the United States in 1870 where it was propagated by the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington, D.C. and then sent sent to California and Florida. Only Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel's that went to Eliza Tibbets in Riverside, California thrived, and from there, Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' was released into commerce.

Clianthus maximus is a small shrub that flowers with clusters of large red flowers that mimic a Kaka Beak, during winter and spring. These showy flowers attract nectar-eating birds. Clianthus maximus can tolerate full sun and part-shade, and will grow in most free-draining soils.Clianthus maximus is native to the North Island of New Zealand.

Clianthus maximus 'Kaka King' is an evergreen shrub that has hanging clusters of vibrant red flowers throughout spring and summer, bringing the birds. It thrives in shelter, and both full sun and partial shade. Clianthus maximus 'Kaka King' can withstand light to moderate frosts, and occasional dry spells. It has a more upright form than the parent Clianthus maximus. Clianthus maximus is native to the North Island of New Zealand.

Coprosma autumnalis is characterized by its attractive, yellow-green leaves that are mottled with dark-green and purple, with new growth appearing quite purple. Coprosma autumnalis produces orange berries that are beloved by birds, typically between mid-spring and mid-summer. It thrives in a sheltered site with cool soils and regular moisture, making it an ideal option for bush restoration. Additionally, Coprosma autumnalis produces small, white flowers in autumn, adding to its visual appeal. Coprosma autumnalis is evergreen and native to New Zealand and is widespread in both the North and South Island. Learn more about Coprosma autumnalis.

Coprosma brockii is an ideal choice for creating a hedge or screen due to its ability to clip easily into shape. It is a very hardy tree that can grow in most conditions and is very adaptable, including in dry and exposed sites. The new growth of Coprosma brockii is purple, while the mature growth is glossy and dark green-purple, with purple undersides, providing a visually appealing feature to any landscape. Additionally, the hardiness and adaptability of Coprosma brockii make it an excellent choice for gardeners looking to add a robust and low-maintenance option to their garden. Coprosma brockii is evergreen and native to New Zealand.

This low-growing native tree features small, sage-green leaves that are edged with cream-white, providing an eye-catching contrast that can brighten up any area. It is an excellent choice for container gardening, as well as for use as a groundcover or low hedge. The unique coloration of Coprosma x kirkii 'Variegata' adds interest to any landscape and makes it a great choice for those looking to add a distinctive feature to their garden. Coprosma x kirkii is evergreen and a hybrid between Coprosma acerosa and Coprosma repens. Coprosma x kirkii is evergreen and native to New Zealand.

Coprosma repens features thick, dark-green, and glossy leaves that make it an excellent choice for coastal planting. It is extremely tolerant of salt-laden harsh winds and drought, making it well-suited for use in coastal areas. Coprosma repens can be used as a screening plant to provide shelter for more tender plants and to filter out sand, making it a versatile and practical addition to any landscape. Additionally, Coprosma repens produces small green-white flowers from mid-winter to mid-summer, adding a touch of visual interest to the attractive foliage of Coprosma repens. Coprosma repens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma repens.

Coprosma repens 'Inferno' features glossy green leaves that are edged with yellow-orange during spring and summer, adding a pop of color to any garden. The leaves then transform to a dark-purple with red margins during autumn and winter, making it a multi-seasonal plant. It is a trouble-free grower that requires little maintenance, making it an ideal choice for gardeners who want to add some visual interest to their garden without the need for extensive upkeep. Additionally, it can be grown in a patio container, making it a versatile option for those with limited garden space. Coprosma repens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma repens. Coprosma repens 'Inferno' was bred by Peter John Fraser in Waikato, New Zealand (PVR 3106).

Coprosma repens 'Poor Knights' is a prostrate form of Coprosma repens, which makes it an ideal choice for use as a groundcover in coastal gardens. It is well-suited for use in dry, windy conditions and is also effective for erosion control. Coprosma repens 'Poor Knights' has a low, spreading growth habit, and grows wider than it does high, which makes it a great option for filling in large areas of garden space. Additionally, its tolerance of coastal conditions makes it a practical and low-maintenance choice for those looking to add a hardy and versatile plant to their landscape. Coprosma repens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma repens. Coprosma repens 'Poor Knights' is named after the Poor Knights Islands, New Zealand where it naturally grows. Coprosma repens 'Poor Knights' was supposedly first collected in 1769 by Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander on the HMS Endeavour.

Coprosma rhamnoides is a hardy shrub with very small green leaves in shade, turning purple in full sun, and flowering in mid-spring with cream-coloured flowers. It will thrive in full sun or dry conditions and attracts native birds when fruiting. If you desire hundreds of red/black berries, it is recommended to plant several to improve the chances of having both males and female plants. Coprosma rhamnoides is native to New Zealand.

Coprosma virescens is a divaricating grower with tiny green leaves, and its branch stems can vary in color from yellow-orange to red-orange. It is known for its toughness and ability to tolerate poor soil and dry conditions, making it an ideal choice for gardeners who want a low-maintenance plant that can thrive in challenging environments. The narrow-growing habit of Coprosma virescens makes it a great option for creating a hedge or screen without the need for regular trimming. Additionally, its hardiness and adaptability make it a practical and versatile addition to any landscape. Coprosma virescens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma virescens.

Cordyline australis is a versatile choice for group and specimen plantings, as well as for use in containers. It is hardy enough to grow in all situations and climates, making it a low-maintenance option for gardeners. Cordyline australis features green leaves that form large tufts, and in late spring, it produces stunning cream flowers borne in large panicles that emit a sweet fragrance and add to the visual appeal of Cordyline australis. Cordyline australis also produces fruit in mid-summer to early-autumn, which is beloved by birds, making it a practical and attractive addition to any garden. Cordyline australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline australis.

Cordyline australis 'Albertii' has green leaves that are broadly-margined with butter-yellow, providing an eye-catching contrast that adds interest to any garden. It is just as tough as Cordyline australis, but is slower-growing and more slender, making it a great option for gardeners who want a plant that is low-maintenance and adaptable to a range of conditions. The unique coloration of Cordyline australis 'Albertii' and its attractive growth habit make it particularly lovely as a container plant, adding visual interest to patios and other outdoor spaces. Additionally, its hardiness and versatility make it a practical and visually appealing choice for any garden. Cordyline australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline australis.

Cordyline australis 'Red Star' is characterized by its bronze-red, strap-like leaves, which add a unique touch of color to any garden. Once established, it is both coastal and frost tolerant, making it well-suited for a range of climates and environments. Cordyline australis 'Red Star' thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, and is particularly well-suited for use in containers, adding both color and texture to outdoor spaces. Additionally, its hardiness and adaptability make it a practical and visually appealing choice for any garden. Cordyline australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline australis. Cordyline australis 'Red Star' was produced by Twyford Laboratories in the United Kingdom.

Cordyline banksii features broad leaves and a clump-forming, bushy, compact habit that is often multi-branched. It produces beautiful, drooping panicles of fragrant, white flowers in the summer, adding both visual and olfactory appeal to any garden. The attractive growth habit of Cordyline banksii and its lovely blooms make it a popular choice among gardeners who want to add a touch of beauty and elegance to their landscape. Cordyline banksii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline banksii.

Cordyline 'Broadsword' is a superb native that features very wide, shorter, sword-like green leaves and a compact growth habit. It is an ideal choice for use in containers, as well as for gardens of all sizes. The unique growth habit of Cordyline 'Broadsword' and its attractive foliage make it a popular choice among gardeners who want to add a touch of visual interest to their landscape without taking up too much space. Additionally, its adaptability and versatility make it a practical and low-maintenance option for those looking to add a native plant to their garden. Cordyline 'Broadsword' is evergreen and a hybrid between Cordyline obtecta and Cordyline australis. Cordyline 'Broadsword' was developed by Thirkettle Nurseries in Nelson, New Zealand (PVR 32779).

otherCommonNames: Cabbage Tree, Three Kings Cabbage Tree
description: Cordyline obtecta 'Green Goddess' is characterized by its broad, fresh-green leaves with branches that are close to the ground and a very compact head of leaves. Its attractive foliage and compact growth habit make it a great choice for use in a range of garden settings. The adaptability of Cordyline obtecta 'Green Goddess' and ease of maintenance also make it a practical and low-maintenance option for those looking to add some greenery to their landscape. Cordyline obtecta is evergreen and native to New Zealand and Norfolk Island. Learn more about Cordyline obtecta.

Cordyline 'Renegade' is known for its broad, glossy, dark-purple leaves and sturdy growth habit, which matures with multi-trunks. In early spring, it produces panicles of small, white, fragrant flowers, adding both visual and olfactory interest to any garden. Cordyline 'Renegade' is an excellent choice for use in large containers, as its unique growth habit and attractive foliage can add a touch of elegance and sophistication to outdoor spaces. Additionally, its adaptability and ease of maintenance make it a practical and versatile option for gardeners looking to add some color and texture to their landscape. Cordyline 'Renegade' is evergreen and a hybrid between Cordyline australis and Cordyline banksii. Cordyline 'Renegade' was produced by Dave Lloyd at Plantlife Propagators in Ashhurst, New Zealand (PVR 2655). Dave sowed seed of purple Cordyline australis in 1999 and from the resulting plants selected Cordyline 'Renegade'.

synonyms: Cornus sericea subsp. sericea 'Elegantissima', Cornus alba 'Sibirica Variegata', Cornus sericea subsp. sericea 'Sibirica Variegata', Cornus alba 'Argenteomarginata', Cornus sericea subsp. sericea 'Argenteomarginata'
description: Cornus alba 'Elegantissima' is characterized by its thicket of erect, red stems, which are particularly striking in the winter months when the bare stems take on a glowing-scarlet color. Cornus alba 'Elegantissima' can tolerate very wet growing conditions, making it well-suited for use in a range of garden settings. It features green leaves with white margins, cream bunches of spring flowers, and blue-white fruit that follow. To promote new growth, it is recommended to cut back old stems to the ground every few years. In the autumn, the leaves of Cornus alba 'Elegantissima' turn orange and red, adding a touch of color to the garden. The unique growth habit of Cornus alba 'Elegantissima', its attractive foliage, and its adaptability make it a practical and visually appealing choice for any garden. Cornus alba is deciduous and native to Siberia, northern China, and Korea. Learn more about Cornus alba.

Cornus alba 'Sibirica' is known for forming a thicket of erect, red stems, which are particularly striking in the winter months when the bare stems take on a glowing-scarlet color. It is capable of tolerating very wet growing conditions, making it a great option for use in a range of garden settings. Cornus alba 'Sibirica' features green leaves and cream bunches of spring flowers, followed by blue-white fruit. To promote new growth, it is recommended to cut back old stems to the ground every few years. In the autumn, the leaves of Cornus alba 'Sibirica' turn orange and red, adding a touch of color to the garden. Its unique growth habit, attractive foliage, and adaptability make it a practical and visually appealing choice for any garden. Cornus alba is deciduous and native to Siberia, northern China, and Korea. Learn more about Cornus alba. Cornus alba 'Sibirica' was introduced into commerce in the United Kingdom by the Loddiges family.

Cornus alternifolia 'Argentea' features small green leaves that are edged with white, giving it a silver appearance. Its branches grow in tiers, providing a visually interesting growth habit. In the autumn, the leaves of Cornus alternifolia 'Argentea' turn red and purple, adding a touch of color to the garden. Additionally, in early summer, clusters of cream-white flowers top the branches, further adding to the visual appeal of Cornus alternifolia 'Argentea'. The unique foliage of Cornus alternifolia 'Argentea', its attractive growth habit, and its lovely blooms make it a popular choice among gardeners who want to add some visual interest and elegance to their landscape. Cornus alternifolia is deciduous and native to eastern North America, from Newfoundland west to southern Manitoba and Minnesota, and south to northern Florida and Mississippi. Learn more about Cornus alternifolia. Cornus alternifolia 'Argentea' was put into commerce before 1900 by Temple and Beard in the United States.

otherCommonNames: Himalayan Flowering Dogwood, Himalayan Evergreen Dogwood, Himalayan Strawberry Tree, Bentham's Cornel, Strawberry Dogwood
description: Cornus capitata features green leaves with fuzzy undersides, providing a unique texture to its foliage. During the summer, it produces white flower blooms, adding visual interest to Cornus capitata. In the autumn, it produces red fruit, adding a pop of color to the garden. The attractive foliage and fruit of Cornus capitata make it a popular choice among gardeners who want to add a touch of visual interest and practicality to their landscape. Cornus capitata is evergreen and native to the low-elevation woodlands of the Himalayas in China, India, Pakistan, Nepal, and Bhutan. Learn more about Cornus capitata.

Cornus controversa is characterized by its picturesque, horizontal, sweeping branches that grow in layered tiers, providing a unique and eye-catching growth habit. Its glossy, dark-green leaves are glaucous beneath, adding a touch of texture to its foliage. In the autumn, the leaves turn a rich purple-red color, which persists well into winter, providing a stunning visual display. In late spring to early summer, cream-white flowers sit atop the branches, further adding to the visual appeal of Cornus controversa. In late summer to autumn, blue-purple to black fruit follow, which birds relish. The unique growth habit of Cornus controversa, its attractive foliage, and its practicality make it a popular choice among gardeners who want to add some visual interest to their landscape. Cornus controversa is deciduous and native to China, Korea, the Himalayas, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus controversa.

Cornus controversa 'Golden Wedding' has exquisitely arranged branches that are layered and adorned with green leaves that have broad margins of gold. During spring, new growth appears green with edges of pink-orange, while cream-white flowers bloom on the branches in late spring to early summer. As the season progresses, blue-purple to black fruit emerge in late summer to autumn, which are a favorite among birds. The leaves of Cornus controversa 'Golden Wedding' turn red in autumn, and due to its slow growth, it is particularly striking as a specimen. Cornus controversa is deciduous and native to China, Korea, the Himalayas, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus controversa. Cornus controversa 'Golden Wedding' was produced in Taranaki, New Zealand by Vance Hooper (PVR 30959).

Cornus controversa 'Variegata' features stunningly arranged branches that are tiered in layers, and are adorned with green leaves that have broad margins of cream. In late spring to early summer, cream-white flowers bloom on the branches, followed by blue-purple to black fruit in late summer to autumn that are enjoyed by birds. As autumn arrives, the leaves turn yellow, making Cornus controversa 'Variegata' even more beautiful. Cornus controversa 'Variegata' is particularly impressive as a specimen. Cornus controversa is deciduous and native to China, Korea, the Himalayas, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus controversa. Cornus controversa 'Variegata' was cultivated in Japan in the mid-1800s and was introduced into Europe in 1889 by Veitch Nuseries in Exeter, England.

Cornus 'Eddie's White Wonder' has an upright growth pattern, and its tiered branches are semi-weeping. In late spring, large, flat, lime-green flowers can be seen which eventually age to white. During autumn, small red fruit appear, which are a favorite among birds. Cornus 'Eddie's White Wonder' flourishes in warmer regions and has beautiful burnt-orange and scarlet autumn leaves that are sure to impress. It is an excellent choice for a street tree, as well as an ideal shade tree. Cornus 'Eddie's White Wonder' is deciduous and a hybrid between Cornus nuttallii and Cornus florida, discovered by nurseryman Henry Matheson Eddie (1881-1953) of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada in 1945, and has been commercially propagated since 1955.

Cornus florida has a slender, erect trunk and delicate, tiered branches. In spring, it produces masses of four-petalled, upward-facing white flowers. During autumn, clusters of red fruit appear, which are a source of food for birds. Cornus florida also boasts vivid autumn leaves that range in color from orange to red and purple. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida.

In early spring, Cornus florida 'Andrea Hart' displays a profusion of lovely pink flowers. As the season progresses, the fresh green leaves turn into a striking combination of purple and red hues, which are particularly beautiful in autumn. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida.

Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' showcases large, flat, pink, four-petalled flowers on its bare branches in the spring. The new growth in spring is a striking bronze-red color. Throughout summer, Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' has deep-green, glossy leaves. During autumn, the leaves turn yellow, scarlet, and wine-colored, creating a stunning display of colors. Due to its exceptional beauty, Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' is an excellent choice for a street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' was discovered as a chance seedling by Isaac J. Hawkersmith growing at his nursery, Ike Hawkersmith Nursery, near Sweetwater, Tennessee, United States in the early 1950s. In 1958, Isaac was granted a patent (USPP1710P) for Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief'.

Cornus florida 'Cherokee Daybreak' has large, green leaves with broad, cream margins and wavy edges, making for exceptional foliage. In early spring, it produces a few large, white, flat flowers. During autumn, the leaves turn from a salmon-pink to a rose-purple color, adding to the visual appeal of Cornus florida 'Cherokee Daybreak'. It is an excellent choice for a street tree due to its remarkable foliage and overall beauty. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Daybreak' was discovered by Hubert A. Nicholson as a chance seedling in Franklin County, Tennessee, United States (USPP6320P).

With its low-branching, broadly-pyramidal form, Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess' is a striking addition to any landscape. The glossy, light-green leaves turn into a fiery blend of orange and red in the autumn, adding a burst of color to the surroundings. Additionally, Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess' produces white flowers in mid-spring, enhancing its beauty even further. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess' was developed by Isaac J. Hawkersmith at his nursery, Ike Hawkersmith Nursery, near Sweetwater, Tennessee, United States in 1950. Isaac originally named Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess' Cornus florida 'Sno-White', before changing the name to Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess'.

The new green leaves of Cornus florida 'Cherokee Sunset' are variegated with cream-yellow and pink margins, adding to its visual interest. During the summer, the leaves are broadly-margined with yellow. In the spring, large, pink-red, flat flowers appear alongside the new leaves. During autumn, the leaves turn a beautiful blend of red and purple. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Sunset' was discovered by Hubert A. Nicholson as a branch sport growing on a Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' in Franklin County, Tennessee, United States (USPP6305P).

Cornus florida 'Cloud Nine' provides a magnificent mass display of large, flat, white flowers with overlapping bracts and prominent green eyes in the spring, even from an early age. It thrives particularly well in warmer climates. This strong-growing tree has an erect form and boasts yellow, scarlet, orange, and purple autumn leaves, which add to its appeal. Due to its exceptional beauty and growth pattern, it makes an excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cloud Nine' was developed by Chase Nursery in Chase, Alabama, United States and was patented in 1961 (USPP2112).

Cornus florida 'First Lady' has yellow-variegated foliage, which is a unique feature that sets it apart. In the spring, it produces large yet delicate white blooms, adding to its beauty. Cornus florida 'First Lady' has an excellent wide-spreading form, making it a great choice for landscaping. It requires rich, well-drained soil and adequate precipitation, and is best grown with some shelter. During autumn, the leaves turn purple and red, making Cornus florida 'First Lady' even more stunning. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'First Lady' was discovered in 1957 by Fernando Campbell Boyd Jr. and was first observed flowering in 1967.
