Cornus florida 'First Lady' was put into commerce by Boyd Nursery Company in McMinnville, Tennessee, United States and received a patent in 1969 (USPP2916).

In the spring, the leaves of Cornus florida 'Old Gold' are a beautiful golden color. As the season progresses, the leaves transform into an antique-gold hue. During the autumn, the leaves turn red, providing a striking contrast to the rest of the landscape. Additionally, Cornus florida 'Old Gold' produces white flowers in the spring, adding to its overall beauty. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Cornus florida 'Pendula' has a slow-growing form, with stiffly-weeping branches, making for a unique and striking appearance. During autumn, the leaves of Cornus florida 'Pendula' turn into a deep-purple and scarlet color, making it even more beautiful. Cornus florida 'Pendula' was produced by Meehan's Nursery in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States before 1880 and was propagated from a Cornus florida tree discovered in Maryland, United States.

Cornus florida 'Purple Glory' showcases light-purple leaves in the spring, which mature into a dark-purple color during the summer before ultimately becoming a striking black-purple color in the autumn. In the spring, Cornus florida 'Purple Glory' produces long-lasting and showy red flowers, which add to its overall appeal. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Purple Glory' was found as a chance seedling by Clark Boyd of Boyd Nursery Company in McMinnville, Tennessee, United States in 1966. Cornus florida 'Purple Glory' was patented in 1979 (USPP4627).

Cornus florida 'Rainbow' has large green leaves with golden margins, making for a striking appearance. In the autumn, the leaves turn into a brilliant array of colors, ranging from rainbow-pink to carmine-red, and lavender-blue to purple-red. Cornus florida 'Rainbow' also produces white flowers in the spring, which enhance its beauty even further. Due to its exceptional foliage and overall appearance, it is an excellent choice for a street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. This round-headed tree has a slender trunk and spreading branches, making for an attractive addition to any landscape. In the spring, Cornus florida 'Spring Song' produces large, rose-pink, four-petalled, flat flowers that are sure to impress. During autumn, the leaves turn vivid shades of orange, red, and wine-purple, further adding to the beauty of Cornus florida 'Spring Song'. Cornus florida 'Spring Song' originated at Hoyt's Sons Nursery in New Canaan, Connecticut, United States and was registered with the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University in Boston, Massachusetts, United States in 1963.

This strong-growing tree has an ascending branch structure that adds to its visual appeal. In the spring, Cornus florida 'Stoke's Pink' is covered in rich-pink, four-petalled flowers, which are a sight to behold. It flowers particularly well in warmer regions. During autumn, the leaves turn into rich shades of red and purple, which persist well into the winter, making it a great choice for a year-round display. The exceptional beauty of Cornus florida 'Stoke's Pink' and its growth pattern make it an excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. This multi-stemmed tree has a lower horizontal branching pattern, giving it an oval upper crown. During the spring, Cornus florida 'Weaver's White' produces a profusion of cream-white, flat flowers, making for a breathtaking display. In the autumn, the leaves of Cornus florida 'Weaver's White' turn into stunning shades of maroon and red. Additionally, Cornus florida 'Weaver's White' produces small red fruit that are enjoyed by birds. Overall, Cornus florida 'Weaver's White' is a beautiful and unique addition to any landscape. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Weaver's White' appeared in the 1941 catalogue of Glen Saint Mary Nurseries Company in Glen Saint Mary, Florida, United States.

Cornus 'Greenvale' is a vigorous, hardy, and highly-ornamental variety that thrives in sunny locations with rich soil. During early summer, Cornus 'Greenvale' is adorned with large, cream-white flowers that can last up to 8 weeks, providing a beautiful display. In the autumn, the leaves of Cornus 'Greenvale' turn into stunning shades of orange and red, adding to its overall beauty. Cornus 'Greenvale' is semi-evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Cornus capitata and Cornus kousa that was discovered in Greenvale, Southland, New Zealand by L. Paterson (PVR 2854).

Cornus kousa has a vase-shaped structure when young, which becomes more rounded as it ages. In late spring to early summer, Cornus kousa produces beautiful white flowers, adding to its visual appeal. The red fruit that follows is a source of food for birds. During autumn, the green foliage of Cornus kousa turns into a beautiful purple-red color, making for a striking display. Additionally, Cornus kousa is known for its hardiness, making it a great choice for any landscape. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' boasts glossy-green leaves, adding to its overall beauty. When young, it has an elegant vase-shaped structure, which becomes more rounded as it matures. During the spring, Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' produces deep-pink flowers, making for a lovely display. In the autumn, the leaves of Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' turn into beautiful shades of purple and red, adding to its visual appeal. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' was produced by Nobuo Yamashita, Hisao Ishikawa, Toshihiro Hagiwara at their nursery in Shinkyo, Gotenba-shi, Shizuoka-ken, Japan. In 1970, they planted a number of seeds they had collected from Cornus kousa trees growing on the southeastern slopes of Mount Fuji. In the subsequent years, they selected seedlings with an unusually high amount of red coloration in their leaves and the tips of their stems. Eventually, from this selection they selected Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' in June 1978 (USPP8676P).

Cornus kousa 'Bonfire' features a subtle blend of cream, soft-gold, and lime-green variegated leaves, which give it a unique and eye-catching appearance. In early summer, Cornus kousa 'Bonfire' produces a mass of flat, four-petalled, white, star-shaped flowers, which add to its beauty. During autumn, the leaves turn into a blend of red and burgundy, providing a stunning display of colors. Cornus kousa 'Bonfire' has a bushy, erect growth pattern, making it an excellent choice for a street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Cornus kousa 'China Girl' is a vigorous grower and produces a profusion of flowers at a very early age. The small flowers start out as lime-green and gradually mature and enlarge into four-petalled, snow-white flowers in early summer, enhancing the beauty of Cornus kousa 'China Girl'. Cornus kousa 'China Girl' has an erect, upright growth pattern, making it ideal for landscaping. Additionally, the orange and red autumn leaves of Cornus kousa 'China Girl' provide a beautiful display of colors. Due to its exceptional growth and appearance, it is an excellent choice for a street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'China Girl' has been cultivated since 1910, but was given its current cultivar name in 1978 to distinguish it from Cornus kousa var. chinensis.

Cornus kousa 'Doubloon' is a tall, upright grower and produces large white flowers in the spring that have extra bracts, giving them a semi-double effect. During autumn, the leaves of Cornus kousa 'Doubloon' turn into stunning shades of red and orange, making for a beautiful display of colors. Overall, Cornus kousa 'Doubloon' is a unique and attractive addition to any landscape. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' has a distinctive rounded growth habit, making it a unique addition to any landscape. During early summer, the cascading branches of Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' become smothered in large, white, flat, four-petalled flowers, creating a beautiful display. Following the flowers, Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' produces red, strawberry-like fruit, which are enjoyed by birds. During the autumn, the leaves of Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' turn a stunning shade of red, adding to its beauty. Overall, Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' is a great choice for anyone looking for a unique and attractive option. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' was selected by Baier Lustgarten from seedlings grown at Baier Lustgarten Farms and Nurseries in Long Island, New York, United States. Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' was introduced into commerce by James Cross in Cutchogue, New York, United States and was registered with the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University in Boston, Massachusetts, United States in 1978.

Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' has horizontal branches that grow in tiers, making for an eye-catching structure. The leaves of Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' are pointy and deep-green, with a bold gold central stripe, adding to its visual interest. During spring, Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' produces a profusion of cream-white flowers, making for a beautiful display. Throughout the summer, Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' also produces magnificent pink berries, further enhancing its beauty. In the autumn, the leaves turn into a vivid brick-red color, creating a stunning display of colors. Overall, Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' is a beautiful and unique addition to any landscape. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' was introduced in Japan in 1977 by the Sakata Nursery Company in Yokohama and then into commerce in the United States in 1983.

Cornus kousa 'Milky Way' is a vigorous grower and becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, white, star-shaped flowers in early summer, making for a striking display. Following the flowers, Cornus kousa 'Milky Way' produces red, strawberry-like fruit that is relished by birds. During the autumn, the leaves turn into spectacular shades of red and purple, creating a beautiful display of colors. Due to its exceptional beauty and growth pattern, it is an excellent choice for a street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Milky Way' originated at Wayside Gardens in Mentor, Ohio, United States in the 1960s.

Cornus kousa 'Moonbeam' produces huge, flat flowers of cream-white with pink tips in both the spring and summer, which are sure to impress. Following the flowers, Cornus kousa 'Moonbeam' produces red fruit that is enjoyed by birds. Cornus kousa 'Moonbeam' has a rounded structure, making it well-suited for smaller gardens. During the autumn, the leaves of Cornus kousa 'Moonbeam' turn into stunning shades of red and maroon, providing a beautiful display of colors. Overall, Cornus kousa 'Moonbeam' is a beautiful and unique addition to any landscape. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Cornus kousa 'National' is a vigorous grower and becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, ivory-white flowers in early summer, creating a beautiful display. Cornus kousa 'Southern Cross' becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, cream-white, star-shaped flowers in early summer, creating a beautiful display. Cornus nuttallii is a tall, willow-like grower with tiered, semi-weeping branches, making for an elegant appearance. Cornus nuttallii produces large, flat, six-petalled green flowers that age to white before flushing soft-pink. The flowers bloom in late spring and then again in late summer or early autumn, providing a prolonged period of beauty. Cornus nuttallii also has large green leaves that turn yellow and red in the autumn, adding to its visual interest. Overall, Cornus nuttallii is a beautiful and unique addition to any landscape. Cornus sericea 'Flaviramea' forms a thicket of erect, golden stems that provide a stunning sight in the winter when bare. It is tolerant of very wet growing conditions, making it a great choice for damp areas. When mass-planted, it creates a magnificent display. To promote new growth, Cornus sericea 'Flaviramea' should be cut back to the ground every few years. Corokia x cheesemanii is a slender, erect, multi-branched grower with dense, interlacing branches, making it an excellent choice for screening and hedging. Corokia x cheesemanii is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x cheesemanii is evergreen and native to New Zealand.

Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate' has large, glossy, green and chocolate-brown leaves that deepen in color in the winter, adding to the visual interest of Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate'. During the spring, Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate' becomes smothered in star-shaped, bright-yellow flowers, creating a beautiful display. Following the flowers, Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate' is a beautiful and practical addition to any landscape. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate' was developed in New Zealand.

Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Ghost' is a compact, dwarf-grower with slender, dark-green leaves that have a silver sheen, providing a unique and attractive appearance. It can be clipped into any shape, making it an ideal choice for containers and edging gardens. Additionally, it is drought and coastal hardy, making it a great choice for a variety of different environments. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Ghost' produces small, yellow flowers in the spring, which are a beautiful sight. Following the flowers, Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Ghost' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Ghost' is a beautiful and practical addition to any landscape, especially for those who love to shape and maintain their gardens. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Ghost' was developed before 2002 by M. F. Geenty in Hamilton, New Zealand (PVR 2531).

Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Giant' is hardy and an excellent choice for screening, offering longer green leaves compared to Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green'. During the spring, Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Giant' produces masses of small, yellow, daisy flowers, creating a beautiful display. Following the flowers, Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Giant' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Giant' is a practical and attractive addition to any landscape, especially for those who want to create a natural barrier or privacy screen. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Giant' was developed by M. F. Geenty in Hamilton, New Zealand.

Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green' is a dense, erect-growing, multi-branched grower with large, glossy, green leaves that provide a beautiful backdrop for its bright-yellow, star-shaped flowers during the spring. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. It is an excellent choice for formal hedging in dry, windy positions and can be shaped into any form, offering versatility and functionality for any landscaping project. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green' is a practical and visually-pleasing addition to any landscape. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green' was developed by M. F. Geenty in Hamilton, New Zealand.

Corokia x virgata 'Mangatangi' features silver-green foliage that provides a unique and attractive appearance. During the spring, Corokia x virgata 'Mangatangi' produces small, yellow flowers, adding a beautiful touch of color to the landscape. Following the flowers, Corokia x virgata 'Mangatangi' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. Corokia x virgata 'Mangatangi' is great for hedging, providing an effective natural barrier or privacy screen. Additionally, it is tolerant of dry and windy conditions, making it a practical choice for a variety of different environments. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Mangatangi' is a beautiful and functional addition to any landscape. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata.

Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' is a dense, bushy grower with brown-green to brown-black leaves that maintain their color through spring, summer, and autumn. During the winter, the leaves turn almost black, creating an interesting contrast to the surrounding landscape. Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' is tolerant of dry and windy sites, making it a practical choice for a variety of different environments. During the spring, Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' produces small, yellow flowers, adding a beautiful touch of color to the landscape. Following the flowers, Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' is great for low hedging, containers, and topiary, offering versatility and functionality for any landscaping project. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' is a practical and visually-pleasing addition to any landscape. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' was developed by City Park Services in Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 30655).

Corokia x virgata 'Pounamu' is a dense, bushy grower with dark-green leaves that maintain their color throughout spring, summer, and autumn. Corokia x virgata 'Pounamu' is tolerant of dry and windy sites, making it a practical choice for a variety of different environments. During the spring, Corokia x virgata 'Pounamu' produces small, yellow flowers, adding a beautiful touch of color to the landscape. Following the flowers, Corokia x virgata 'Pounamu' produces red, orange, or yellow berries in the autumn, which are enjoyed by birds. Corokia x virgata 'Pounamu' is great for low hedging, containers, and topiary, offering versatility and functionality for any landscaping project. Overall, Corokia x virgata 'Pounamu' is a practical and visually-pleasing addition to any landscape. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata.

Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' is a vigorous grower and an excellent producer of large nuts. The nuts ripen from red-orange to brown in late-summer to early-autumn. Other hazelnut trees such as Corylus avellana 'Butler', Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller', and Corylus avellana 'Tonda di Giffoni' can serve as pollinators. Hazelnut trees thrive in mild summers and cool winters and require protection from high summer temperatures and wind. The ideal annual average temperature is between 12°C and 16°C, with a maximum of 35°C to 36°C and a minimum of -8°C to -10°C. Annual rainfall of 800mm to 1000mm, spread evenly throughout the growing season, is ideal. In areas with prolonged dry periods from late-spring to mid-summer, particularly in free-draining soils (sandy or stony), irrigation will be required. Corylus avellana is evergreen and native to Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Corylus avellana. Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' is an old cultivar widely distributed in Western Europe and probably originated in Spain. Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' has been the main cultivar grown in Oregon, United States since the mid-1800s.

Corylus avellana 'Contorta' is native to Europe, Western Asia, and Northern Africa. It boasts an unusual contorted and twisted growth habit, adding a unique look to any setting. Hardy in various conditions, it features attractive flower tassles in spring, accompanied by yellow heart-shaped foliage that turns green throughout summer. In autumn, the foliage transforms into a light green colour. Corylus avellana 'Contorta' performs best in full sun to part shade, and planted in rich, moist, well drained soils.

Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller' grows vigorously and yields large, high-quality nuts that ripen from red-orange to brown in late summer to early autumn. It serves as a valuable pollinator for other hazelnut cultivars such as Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' and Corylus avellana 'Whiteheart'. Hazelnut trees thrive in regions with mild summers and cool winters but require protection from wind and high temperatures in summer. The ideal temperature range is an annual average of 12°C to 16°C, with a maximum of 35°C to 36°C and a minimum of -8°C to -10°C. For optimal growth, annual rainfall should be evenly distributed throughout the growing season and range from 800mm to 1000mm. In areas that experience prolonged dry spells, particularly from late spring to mid-summer, and where the soil is free-draining (sandy or stony), irrigation will be necessary. Corylus avellana is evergreen and native to Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Corylus avellana. Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller' originated in 1788 as a seedling selection by C. G. Bultner in Halle, Germany.

Corylus avellana 'Whiteheart' produces small, round nuts that are primarily used for processing and provides good yields. The nuts ripen from red-orange to brown in late summer to early autumn. Pollinators for Corylus avellana 'Whiteheart' include Corylus avellana 'Alexandra', Corylus avellana 'Auckland No. 2', and Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller'. Hazelnut trees thrive in regions with mild summers and cool winters and require protection from wind and high temperatures in summer. The ideal temperature range is an annual average of 12°C to 16°C, with a maximum of 35°C to 36°C and a minimum of -8°C to -10°C. For optimal growth, annual rainfall should be evenly distributed throughout the growing season and range from 800mm to 1000mm. In areas that experience prolonged dry spells, particularly from late spring to mid-summer, and where the soil is free-draining (sandy or stony), irrigation will be necessary. Corylus avellana is evergreen and native to Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Corylus avellana. Corylus avellana 'Whiteheart' was selected in the 1980s by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Corylus colurna is an erect, conical-grower with a very symmetrical branching habit. It bears edible brown nuts in the autumn, but the nuts are enclosed in a thick, hard, green shell that makes them challenging to extract. Fruit production occurs every two to three years and is inconsistent. Corylus colurna can withstand hot, dry climates and is an excellent option for street planting. It has corky bark and yellow-green catkins that bloom from early spring to early summer, providing pollen for bees. In the fall, the leaves of Corylus colurna turn yellow. It has a deep root system and does not transplant well. Corylus colurna is deciduous and native to southeast Europe and southwest Asia, from the Balkans through northern Turkey to northern Iran. Learn more about Corylus colurna.

Corylus maxima 'Purpurea' is a deciduous tree native to the Balkans that thrives in chalky soil under partially shaded conditions. Early in spring, well before the leaves emerge, long pink catkins appear. This is followed by edible nuts covered by a long shell. In autumn, it's foliage transforms to a dark plum-purple.

Corymbia ficifolia is sturdy and single-trunked with a round-headed, compact crown and large, thick green leaves. It blooms in mid-summer, producing striking red, orange, and pink flowers that attract nectar-seeking birds. Corymbia ficifolia can withstand drought and coastal winds, making it a resilient choice for challenging environments. Corymbia ficifolia is evergreen and native to Western Australia. Learn more about Corymbia ficifolia.

Corynocarpus laevigatus is a handsome, upright-growing species with large, glossy, leathery, deep-green leaves. It grows naturally alongside waterways and can tolerate moderate coastal winds, frosts (once established), and dry conditions. In late summer, Corynocarpus laevigatus produces large, orange fruit that are enjoyed by wood pigeons. Corynocarpus laevigatus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corynocarpus laevigatus.

Cotinus coggygria 'Golden Spirit' has lime and golden foliage that lasts throughout the spring and summer, providing a bright contrast to darker areas. In the fall, the foliage of Cotinus coggygria 'Golden Spirit' turns a beautiful shade of orange and red. While it may not flower as profusely as other Cotinus coggygria cultivars, it may produce pink flower plumes on old wood in mid-summer. Cotinus coggygria 'Golden Spirit' grows best in part-shade and requires consistently moist soil. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China. Learn more about Cotinus coggygria. Cotinus coggygria 'Golden Spirit' was discovered in 1989 in Boskoop, Netherlands by Sanders-van Harn and Adriana Christina Bastiana (USPP13082).

Cotinus coggygria 'Purpurea' will flourish in various conditions but thrives best in a well-drained soil under full sun exposure. The soft purple foliage deepens in colour throughout summer, particulary in sunny locations, and in autumn it transitions to a brilliant orange. During mid to late summer, tiny pink flowers grow from the end of a long stalk, looking like a plume of smoke. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia, and the Himalayans to northern China.

Cotinus coggygria 'Red Spirit' produces new leaves that are red and eventually mature into a green color with blue undertones. In early summer, the bush is covered in fluffy heads of pink-red flowers. Cotinus coggygria 'Red Spirit' also has stunning autumn foliage, with leaves turning shades of orange, red, and purple. It can be trimmed into any desired shape or form, making it a versatile landscaping choice. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China. Learn more about Cotinus coggygria. Cotinus coggygria 'Red Spirit' was developed by Miyoshi & Co. Ltd. in Japan.

Cotinus coggygria 'Royal Purple' is a large, bushy grower with rounded leaves that are attractive in appearance. In the spring, the new leaves emerge as a rich maroon-red and gradually mature to a deep wine-purple hue over the summer. In the fall, the leaves become more red in color. Cotinus coggygria 'Royal Purple' also produces large, pink, feathery flower plumes in the spring, giving it a smoke-like appearance. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China. Learn more about Cotinus coggygria. Cotinus coggygria 'Royal Purple' was selected by Lombarts Nursery in Boskoop, Netherlands and was introduced into the United States in 1953.

Cotinus 'Grace' produces purple leaves during the spring and summer that turn a vibrant orange and red in the fall. In the summer, Cotinus 'Grace' also bears large, conical, purple-pink flower clusters. It is a strong, upright-grower with a rounded head, making it an excellent choice as a street tree. Cotinus 'Grace' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Cotinus coggygria 'Velvet Cloak' and a male Cotinus obovatus. Cotinus 'Grace' was developed in 1978 by Peter Dummer at Hillier Nurseries in Ampfield, United Kingdom. Peter named Cotinus 'Grace' after his wife.

Cotinus obovatus is a vigorous grower that produces purple-pink new leaves that gradually fade to blue-green. The autumn colors of Cotinus obovatus are stunning, with leaves turning shades of red, orange, and purple. Cotinus obovatus also produces plume-like, pink flower-heads over the summer. It is known to grow well in poor soil and is primarily cultivated for its brilliant autumn color. Once established, it can tolerate drought conditions and is also resilient to urban pollution. Cotinus obovatus is deciduous and native to scattered locations in the states of Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas, Missouri, Alabama, and Tennessee in the United States. Learn more about Cotinus obovatus.

otherCommonNames: Midland Hawthorn, English Hawthorn, Woodland Hawthorn
description: Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' is upright in growth with a compact, rounded head. It produces impressive double crimson-red flowers that completely cover Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' in late spring. In the fall, Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' produces red fruits that are enjoyed by birds. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' is an excellent choice for street planting. However, it does not develop any significant autumn color, and its branches have thorns. It is a very tough tree that can grow in almost all conditions. Crataegus x media is a hybrid between Crataegus monogyna and Crataegus laevigata. Crataegus x media is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Crataegus x media. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' originated in 1858 as a sport growing on a Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' in the garden of Christopher Boyd near Waltham Cross, England. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' was propagated by William Paul and unveiled at the International Horticultural Exhibition of 1866.
tolerates: windy, coastal, drought, heavy-rainfall, light-frosts, heavy-frosts

otherCommonNames: Midland Hawthorn, English Hawthorn, Woodland Hawthorn
synonyms: Crataegus laevigata 'Rosea Flore Pleno', Crataegus laevigata 'Coccinea Flore Pleno', Crataegus x media 'Coccinea Flore Pleno', Crataegus laevigata 'Punicea Flore Pleno', Crataegus x media 'Punicea Flore Pleno'
description: Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' is upright in growth with a compact, rounded head. It produces impressive double salmon-pink flowers that completely cover Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' in late spring. In the fall, Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' produces red fruits that are enjoyed by birds. Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' is an excellent choice for street planting. However, it does not develop any significant autumn color, and its branches have thorns. It is a very tough tree that can grow in almost all conditions. Crataegus x media is a hybrid between Crataegus monogyna and Crataegus laevigata. Crataegus x media is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Crataegus x media. Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' has been in cultivation since before 1832.
tolerates: windy, coastal, drought, heavy-rainfall, light-frosts, heavy-frosts

description: Cryptomeria japonica is fast-growing and quickly becomes a tall, stately tree. Its foliage grows from the ground up, making it an excellent shelter tree. Cryptomeria japonica is a lovely and enduring specimen, with a pyramidal form. It is known for being tolerant of strong winds, making it a good choice for planting in areas with harsh weather conditions. Cryptomeria japonica is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Cryptomeria japonica.

Cryptomeria japonica 'Egmont' is a selected form of Cryptomeria japonica with superior form, wind hardiness, and growth rate. It is an excellent option for making a screen or hedge and can be pruned to maintain its shape. Cryptomeria japonica 'Egmont' is known for being able to tolerate most coastal conditions, except for the most severe. Cryptomeria japonica is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Cryptomeria japonica. Cryptomeria japonica 'Egmont' was developed by Cedar Lodge Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Cunonia capensis produces bronze-red new foliage that matures into a beautiful glossy, dark-green. It bears large, fragrant, white panicles of flowers resembling candles throughout the summer. Cunonia capensis is an ideal choice for smaller gardens and can be grown in large pots since it does not have an invasive root system. However, it does not like windy conditions or hot and dry weather. Cunonia capensis prefers a temperate climate that mimics the sheltered forest environment where it occurs naturally. Cunonia capensis is evergreen and native to southern Africa. Learn more about Cunonia capensis.

synonyms: Hesperocyparis arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice', Callitropsis arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice'
description: This conifer is compact and pyramidal in growth, with smooth, frosted, blue leaves. It is very amenable to pruning and can be trimmed into any desired shape or form. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice' is quick-growing and hardy, withstanding strong winds and drought. It makes an excellent choice for dense shelter. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice' is almost immune to cypress canker, making it a low-maintenance option for gardeners. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra is evergreen and native to a wide area around Sedona, Arizona, United States. Learn more about Cupressus arizonica. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice' was discovered as a chance seedling in 1960 by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and introduced by them into commerce in 1984.

The foliage of Cupressus cashmeriana grows in pendulous sprays of blue-green with slender, flattened shoots. Young trees, up to about five years old, have juvenile foliage with soft, needle-like leaves. Cupressus cashmeriana prefers a warm, sheltered site with regular moisture, but it is still hardy enough to grow in various conditions. Cupressus cashmeriana is evergreen and native to the eastern Himalayas in Bhutan and adjacent areas of Arunachal Pradesh in northeastern India. Learn more about Cupressus cashmeriana.

Cupressus gigantea has a narrow, columnar growth habit with attractive blue-grey foliage. It prefers well-drained soils and is hardy and drought-tolerant, making it a resilient choice for various environments. Cupressus gigantea can also be trimmed into a hedge or a shelter belt. Cupressus gigantea is evergreen and native to southeastern Tibet and China on the Qinghai-Tibetan plateau, particularly in the dry valleys of Nyang River and Yarlung Tsangpo River. Learn more about Cupressus gigantea.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Ferndown', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Ferndown', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Ferndown', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Ferndown'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Ferndown' has light-green foliage and grows with a narrow form, featuring pendulous branches. It is a great choice for shelter belts. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Ferndown' originated in 1940 as a seedling selected from seed collected from a garden near Ferndown, Dorset, United Kingdom. Cupressus x leylandii 'Ferndown' was raised at the nurseries of M. Barthelemy in Stapehill, Wimborne, United Kingdom.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Leighton Green', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Leighton Green', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Leighton Green', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Leighton Green'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Leighton Green' is a very fast-growing cultivar with naturally wide-spreading branches. It can be easily pruned into a narrow, dense screen, making it an ideal choice for privacy barriers. Cupressus x leylandii 'Leighton Green' always has fresh-green leaves that are soft to the touch. It is tolerant of moderate coastal exposure. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Leighton Green' originated in 1911 as a seedling selected from seed collected from Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Naylor's Blue', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Naylor's Blue', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Naylor's Blue', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Naylor's Blue'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Naylor's Blue' has attractive blue-green foliage and is an excellent choice for hedging and screening. Its dense growth pattern and attractive foliage make it an ideal choice for creating a natural privacy barrier. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Naylor's Blue' originated in 1911 as a seedling selected from seed collected from Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Stapehill', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Stapehill', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Stapehill', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Stapehill'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Stapehill' has light-green foliage and grows with a narrow form, featuring a lightly-branched structure. It is a great choice for shelter belts and hedges due to its dense growth and narrow habit. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Stapehill' originated in 1940 as a seedling selected from seed collected from a garden near Ferndown, Dorset, United Kingdom. Cupressus x leylandii 'Stapehill' was raised at the nurseries of M. Barthelemy in Stapehill, Wimborne, United Kingdom.

Cupressus x ovensii grows well in warmer areas and is a fast-growing variety with naturally wide-spreading branches. It can be easily pruned into a narrow, dense screen, making it a popular choice for privacy barriers. Cupressus x ovensii always has fresh-green leaves that are soft to the touch. It is tolerant of strong winds, but not coastal winds, and has better canker resistance compared to Cupressus x leylandii cultivars. Cupressus x ovensii is evergreen and a hybrid between Callitropsis nootkatensis and Cupressus lusitanica. Cupressus x ovensii was raised by Howard Ovens at Tan-Y-Cae, Bethel, Caernarfon, United Kingdom from seeds collected in 1961 from Westonbirt, United Kingdom. Learn more about Cupressus x ovensii.

Cupressus sempervirens is a beautiful upright, columnar variety with green to blue-green foliage. It prefers hot, dry climates and well-drained soils, and once established, it is drought-tolerant. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens.

The foliage of Cupressus sempervirens 'Gracilis' is more refined and threadlike, with a fresh-green color. It grows to a tapering point, giving it a distinctive appearance. Cupressus sempervirens 'Gracilis' prefers to grow in well-drained soil and can thrive in both sun or semi-shade environments. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens. Cupressus sempervirens 'Gracilis' was developed in New Zealand.

Cupressus sempervirens 'Stricta' is an upright cultivar that forms a narrow column of blue-green. Occasional pruning will help to maintain its shape and appearance. Cupressus sempervirens 'Stricta' is tolerant of coastal conditions, drought, and wind, making it a good choice for planting in harsher environments. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens.

Cupressus sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' is a slender, erect, conical variety with golden leaves. It always retains its form, and it does not require pruning or tying to maintain its shape. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens. Cupressus sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' originated in 1944 as a seedling sourced from a Cupressus sempervirens 'Stricta' at the Swane Brothers Nursery in New South Wales, Australia. Cupressus sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' was introduced into commerce in 1956 and was patented in the United States in 1976 (USPP3839).

Cupressus sempervirens 'Totem' is characterized by its slender, erect form and deep-green leaves. It is a striking choice for gardeners who want to add some upright greenery to their landscape. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens. Cupressus sempervirens 'Totem' originated as a seedling around 1984 in New Zealand.

Cupressus torulosa is an upright grower with green to blue-green foliage. It has good tolerance to cypress canker and is an excellent choice for shelter belts where trimming is difficult or not possible. It can also be used for hedging. Cupressus torulosa prefers to grow in free-draining soil. Cupressus torulosa is evergreen and native to the mountainous northern regions of the Indian subcontinent, primarily the Himalayas. Learn more about Cupressus torulosa.

otherCommonNames: Gully Tree Fern, Slender Tree Fern
description: Cyathea cunninghamii is a slender-trunked grower, similar to Cyathea smithii, but when mature, it has a clean trunk without the skirt of dead frond stalks seen on Cyathea smithii. It naturally grows in damp forest areas, particularly in stream gullies and riverbanks. However, it has a lower tolerance for drought than other tree fern species, and it prefers to grow in moist environments. Cyathea cunninghamii is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the North Island, South Island, and Chatham Islands and also to the states of Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, and Tasmania in Australia. Learn more about Cyathea cunninghamii.

Cyathea dealbata is easily distinguished by the silver-white undersides of mature fronds. It naturally grows in lowland and hill country forests up to about 700m altitude. Cyathea dealbata tolerates drought better than most other tree ferns and enjoys warm summers but prefers to grow in moist soils. It will only tolerate light frosts and does not tolerate strong winds, so it's best to plant it in a sheltered spot. Cyathea dealbata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cyathea dealbata.

Cyathea medullaris is the tallest-growing of New Zealand's tree ferns and is characterized by its distinctive tall, black trunk. Cyathea medullaris prefers moisture-rich soil and shelter from wind. It naturally grows in lowland and hilly forest terrain up to about 600m altitude and on partially open sites throughout the country. However, it does not tolerate heavy frosts, major drought, or strong winds. Cyathea medullaris has a very wide, almost horizontal, frond spread (about 10m to 14m when fully grown), making it best for larger gardens. Cyathea medullaris is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the North Island, South Island, and Chatham Islands and also in Fiji, the Marquesas Islands, Pitcairn Island, Society Island, and Tubuai Island. Learn more about Cyathea medullaris.

Cyathea smithii is the most tolerant of cold temperatures among tree ferns and is characterized by its thin and soft fronds. It has a skirt of dead frond stalks on its trunk, which is a defining characteristic of Cyathea smithii. Cyathea smithii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cyathea smithii.

Cycas revoluta is frost-tender and slow-growing. Its leaves are a deep, semi-gloss green and grow out into a feather-like rosette, with small protective barbs that should be avoided. Cycas revoluta is evergreen and native to southern Japan. Learn more about Cycas revoluta.

This is an attractive fruiting tree with large, pale-green fruit that ripen to a soft yellow when fully mature. The white flesh has a slight pineapple taste and tastes best when cooked or mixed with other fruit. Cydonia oblonga 'Pineapple' is hardy and tolerant, but it thrives best in full sun. It typically fruits from mid-autumn through to early-winter, and its pink buds open to white flowers in mid to late-spring. It is self-fertile, so it doesn't need another tree for pollination. Cydonia oblonga is deciduous and native to the Hyrcanian forest region south of the Caspian Sea. Learn more about Cydonia oblonga. Cydonia oblonga 'Pineapple' was developed in the late 1800s by Luther Burbank (1849-1926) in Santa Rosa, California, United States.

This is a moderately vigorous fruit tree that produces large, furrowed, oblong to pear-shaped, golden-yellow, and very aromatic fruit. The flesh is mild, tender, and light-yellow, and the fruit keeps very well. Cydonia oblonga 'Smyrna' has unusually large leaves, and it typically fruits from mid-autumn through to early-winter. Its pink buds open to white flowers in mid to late-spring, and Cydonia oblonga 'Smyrna' is self-fertile, so it doesn't require another tree for pollination. Cydonia oblonga is deciduous and native to the Hyrcanian forest region south of the Caspian Sea. Learn more about Cydonia oblonga. Cydonia oblonga 'Smyrna' was developed in Turkey.

This fruit tree produces aromatic, yellow-skinned fruit with lemon-coloured flesh, which can be used for making cider, jams, and preserves. Cydonia oblonga 'Taihape' is tolerant and easy to grow in a sunny spot, and it typically fruits from mid-autumn through to early-winter. Its pink buds open to white flowers in mid to late-spring, and Cydonia oblonga 'Taihape' is self-fertile and disease-resistant, so it doesn't require another tree for pollination and is less susceptible to diseases. Cydonia oblonga is deciduous and native to the Hyrcanian forest region south of the Caspian Sea. Learn more about Cydonia oblonga. Cydonia oblonga 'Taihape' was developed from an old tree growing at the Brown Sugar Cafe in Taihape, New Zealand.

This is a handsome, narrow-growing tree with semi-weeping branches and soft-green leaves. The juvenile foliage is brown before turning green. It prefers moist situations next to streams, lakes, and ponds, and produces yellow-green catkins in mid-spring to mid-summer, which are a source of pollen for bees. Dacrycarpus dacrydioides also produces orange-red fruit, which grow under a purple-black seed from mid-summer to mid-autumn and are a great source of food for birds. Dacrycarpus dacrydioides is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dacrycarpus dacrydioides.

Dacrydium cupressinum is a slow-growing species that can be easily planted in a home garden for up to fifty years. When young, it has a pyramidal crown and drooping branches, but as it matures, it develops a round-topped crown with sturdy lateral branches that carry drooping twigs and leaves. During winter, the foliage of young trees may turn bronze, but in spring, it returns to its green color. In mid-spring to mid-summer, Dacrydium cupressinum produces green catkins that are a good source of pollen for bees. From mid-summer to mid-autumn, Dacrydium cupressinum bears orange-red fruit that grows under a purple-black seed, but the seed is only produced every few years. Dacrydium cupressinum is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dacrydium cupressinum.

Daphniphyllum macropodum has glossy, dark-green leaves resembling those of rhododendrons, which typically hang down during the winter months, exposing the bright-red leaf stalks on new growth. In the spring, new growth appears in a pale-green hue, sometimes tinged with pink. Male flowers, which are purple-pink, and female flowers, which are pale-green, are produced by separate plants in late spring. Once pollinated, the female plants produce blue-black berries in the autumn season. Daphniphyllum macropodum is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Korea. Learn more about Daphniphyllum macropodum.

Davidia involucrata is an impressive specimen, with sturdy branches and a rounded crown that exudes a stately presence. It produces extraordinary white flowers that look like fluttering handkerchiefs in late spring, hanging gracefully beneath the beautifully ribbed leaves. It's advisable to shelter Davidia involucrata from strong winds. In some instances, Davidia involucrata produces shades of orange and red during the autumn season. Davidia involucrata is deciduous and native to South Central and Southeast China. Learn more about Davidia involucrata.

Dicksonia fibrosa has a red-brown, fibrous trunk that is frequently accompanied by a tidy cluster of dead fronds at its base. Its crown is cone-shaped but inverted. It has the ability to withstand both sun and shade, as well as moderate levels of frost, wind, and drought. Dicksonia fibrosa is indigenous to lowland and hill areas located south of the central North Island and can typically be found at elevations of up to approximately 800m. Dicksonia fibrosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dicksonia fibrosa.

Dicksonia squarrosa is known for its resilience among tree ferns, being able to tolerate some full sun (excluding strong afternoon sun during the warmer months), drier soils, and light winds. Additionally, it can withstand moderate frosts. Dicksonia squarrosa has a black trunk, and its crown is flatter, with shorter leaf fronds, making it ideal for smaller gardens. Dicksonia squarrosa is typically found in lowland and hill forests across the country, including Stewart Island, Chatham Island, and Three Kings Islands, at elevations of up to around 800m. Dicksonia squarrosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dicksonia squarrosa.

Dysoxylum spectabile is an attractive, erect species that is well-suited for coastal areas with windy conditions, although it requires good soil and protection from frost. It produces scented white flowers in panicles from early autumn to mid-winter, which add to its visual appeal. Dysoxylum spectabile also has large, glossy green leaves, which further enhance its beauty. Dysoxylum spectabile is correctly known as Didymocheton spectabilis, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Didymocheton spectabilis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Didymocheton spectabilis.

Dodonaea viscosa is a fast-growing, erect species that forms a bushy structure from the ground up. Its long, narrow leaves are a pale-green color. Dodonaea viscosa produces yellow-green to red-green flowers from late winter to mid-summer. It is an incredibly resilient species, capable of tolerating sub-zero temperatures, salt-laden winds, drought, and polluted atmospheres. As such, it is well-suited for screening and erosion control purposes. Dodonaea viscosa is evergreen and native to tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate regions of Africa, the Americas, southern Asia, and Australasia. Learn more about Dodonaea viscosa.

Dodonaea viscosa 'Purpurea' is a fast-growing, upright cultivar that forms a bushy structure from the ground up. Its long, narrow leaves are a striking purple-bronze color. Dodonaea viscosa 'Purpurea' is incredibly resilient, capable of tolerating sub-zero temperatures, salt-laden winds, drought, and polluted atmospheres. It produces yellow-green to red-green flowers from late winter to mid-summer, further adding to its ornamental value. Dodonaea viscosa is evergreen and native to tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate regions of Africa, the Americas, southern Asia, and Australasia. Learn more about Dodonaea viscosa. Dodonaea viscosa 'Purpurea' was discovered by Thomas Wilkins in the early 1890s growing along the Wairau River in Malborough, New Zealand.

The leaves of Elaeagnus x submacrophylla are green with silver-grey spots when young, but they turn into a dark-green color with silver-grey undersides as they mature. This tough and fast-growing plant is ideal for hedging and screening, and it is well-suited to tolerate both drought and salt-laden winds. It can be grown in either sun or shade and is known to produce highly fragrant and sweet-scented white flowers in autumn, which are then followed by orange berries in the winter. Overall, Elaeagnus x submacrophylla makes for a very robust and resilient hedge. Elaeagnus x submacrophylla is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Elaeagnus macrophylla and Elaeagnus pungens. Elaeagnus x submacrophylla was first discovered in 1929 by Simon Doorenbos, the director of the Parks Department in The Hague, Netherlands. Simon sowed seed from several Elaeagnus species next to each other, and from these arose the hybrid Elaeagnus x submacrophylla.

Elaeocarpus hookerianus is a cold-tolerant forest tree that thrives in various terrains, from valleys to mountainous areas. It has a distinctive juvenile form, as the branches interlace, with tiny leaves that become large light green leaves in its mature form. Elaeocarpus hookerianus flowers in from late spring to early summer, with delicate white blossoms hanging in small clusters, creating a lacy appearance. This followed by dark purple oval-shaped fruit that are fleshy, resembling an olive. Elaeocarpus hookerianus is native to New Zealand, in both main islands and Stewart Island, named after Sir Joseph Dalton Hooker, a famous botanist.

Eriobotrya japonica produces clusters of small, white flowers during the winter season. It also bears yellow-orange fruit that ripen from early spring to early summer, with a sweet-tart flavor resembling that of a plum or cherry. Eriobotrya japonica prefers moist, well-drained soil in full sun, but it can tolerate partial shade. Once established, it can withstand drought conditions. Additionally, Eriobotrya japonica is self-fertile. Eriobotrya japonica is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Eriobotrya japonica.

This coastal-hardy tree produces sweet, easy-to-peel fruit with yellow-orange skin and yellow flesh that ripens in early summer, resembling apricots in flavor. Eriobotrya japonica 'Golden Orb' is well-suited for large containers and can thrive in gardens of all sizes. Additionally, Eriobotrya japonica 'Golden Orb' is self-fertile, meaning that it can produce fruit without the need for cross-pollination. Eriobotrya japonica is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Eriobotrya japonica.

Eucalyptus cinerea is both an attractive ornamental and a shelter species. Its juvenile trees have rounded silvery blue-green leaves, while mature trees have long leaves. Eucalyptus cinerea is capable of tolerating dry soils and coastal exposure, making it a versatile choice for a range of environments. Eucalyptus cinerea is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus cinerea.

Eucalyptus crenulata boasts attractive, silver, egg-shaped to heart-shaped leaves with serrated edges, which are frequently used in cut-flower arrangements. It also produces clusters of cream-white flowers in the spring. Eucalyptus crenulata is versatile and can thrive in both wet and dry conditions. Eucalyptus crenulata is evergreen and native to a small area in Victoria, Australia. Only two natural populations are known, one growing near the Acheron River valley near Buxton, and the other on the Yarra River floodplain in Yering. Learn more about Eucalyptus crenulata.

otherCommonNames: Tasmanian Blue Gum, Southern Blue Gum
description: Eucalyptus globulus subsp. globulus has juvenile leaves that are blue or purple, maturing to be a glossy dark blueish-green. Spring is the peak flowering season, with creamy white flowers, either singly or in clusters on short stalks. It is well suited to high altitudes with good drainage. Eucalyptus globulus subsp. globulus is evergreen and native to the southeastern region of Australia, specifically in areas such as Tasmania, including King Island, and the islands of the Furneaux group, and various districts in southern Victoria.

Eucalyptus johnstonii has thick, dark-green leaves and its bark is a distinctive yellow-green color. It is capable of growing in wet areas and can also tolerate drought conditions. Additionally, Eucalyptus johnstonii is known for its fast growth rate. Eucalyptus johnstonii is evergreen and native to Tasmania, Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus johnstonii.

Eucalyptus leucoxylon 'Rosea' is one of the hardiest varieties of gums and is capable of tolerating extreme drought and cold conditions. Its adult leaves are long and have a grey-green coloration. In the autumn and winter months, Eucalyptus leucoxylon 'Rosea' produces a profusion of deep-pink to red flowers that hang from its branches. These flowers are a valuable nectar source for a range of bird species, including tuis, bellbirds, and wax-eyes. Eucalyptus leucoxylon 'Rosea' is also tall and erect in its growth habit. Eucalyptus leucoxylon is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus leucoxylon. The origin of Eucalyptus leucoxylon 'Rosea' is not known.

Eucalyptus nicholii is a graceful species with narrow, light-green to blue-green leaves that emit a peppermint fragrance when crushed. It is an excellent choice for providing shade and screening, and is able to tolerate both frosts and drought conditions. Eucalyptus nicholii is evergreen and native to New South Wales, Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus nicholii.

Eucalyptus sideroxylon is fast-growing and has distinct red-brown to black bark. It is prized for its high-quality wood, which is incredibly strong and durable and is used for a variety of purposes. Eucalyptus sideroxylon is capable of tolerating drought conditions and is also able to grow in wet areas. Eucalyptus sideroxylon is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus sideroxylon.

Eucryphia cordifolia has a broad, columnar growth habit and produces beautiful white flowers that bloom from late summer into autumn. Eucryphia cordifolia is evergreen and native to Chile and Argentina. Learn more about Eucryphia cordifolia.

Eucryphia moorei is an erect grower with beautiful pinnate leaves. In the late summer, it bears large, fragrant, single white blossoms. It is an excellent choice for smaller gardens or as a street tree. Eucryphia moorei is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucryphia moorei.

Eucryphia x nymansensis 'Nymansay' is an erect grower with larger leaves and very large, pure-white, fragrant blossoms. It blooms from late summer to autumn and prefers cooler growing areas. Eucryphia x nymansensis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Eucryphia cordifolia and Eucryphia glutinosa. Eucryphia x nymansensis arose from a batch of garden-origin seed that was sown in 1914 at the Nymans garden in West Sussex, England. Eucryphia x nymansensis 'Nymansay' was one of these seedlings. Learn more about Eucryphia x nymansensis.

Fagus sylvatica is a tall and dense species with a pyramidal shape, and its lower branches sweep down to the ground. Its new green leaves have a silky sheen, while the autumn leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is a popular choice for hedging and pleaching. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica.

Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Gold' is a tall, columnar cultivar that broadens as it matures. Its bright, golden-yellow leaves have a shiny sheen in the spring, and it has green-yellow leaves throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Gold' is ideal for use in limited space and makes an excellent choice as a street tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Gold' is a seedling of Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' that was raised in 1968 by Dick van Hoey-Smith at the Trompenburg Arboretum in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' is a tall, columnar cultivar that broadens as it matures. Its deep-green leaves have a bronze tinge and shiny sheen in the spring, and it has deep-green leaves throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' is an excellent choice for use in limited space and is ideal as a street tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' was discovered by John Naesmyth at the Dawyck House in Stobo, Scotland in the early 1800s. The original tree still stands at the rear of the house on the boundary with the Dawyck Botanic Garden.

Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Purple' is a tall, columnar cultivar that retains its narrow form. Its deep purple-red spring leaves have a shiny sheen and it maintains its purple leaves throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Purple' is an excellent choice for use in limited space and is ideal as a street tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Purple' is a seedling of Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' that was raised in 1968 by Dick van Hoey-Smith at the Trompenburg Arboretum in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

synonyms: Fagus sylvatica 'Luteovariegata', Fagus sylvatica 'Aureo-variegata', Fagus sylvatica 'Aureovariegata', Fagus sylvatica 'Aurea Variegata', Fagus sylvatica f. luteo-variegata
description: Fagus sylvatica 'Luteo-variegata' is a tall, dense, pyramidal species with lower branches that sweep down to the ground. Its green leaves have yellow-green variegations, and the autumn leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Luteo-variegata' is hardy and able to withstand challenging growing conditions. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Luteo-variegata' has been known in England since about 1770.

Fagus sylvatica 'Pendula' forms a tall, narrow, and magnificent tree with arching side branches that weep down to the ground. It has glossy light-green leaves, and its autumn leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Pendula' has been extensively planted for over 200 years and was introduced to North America before 1834.

Fagus sylvatica 'Purple Fountain' grows into a columnar form with cascading side branches. It produces red new leaves in the spring that deepen to purple by summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Purple Fountain' is a seedling of Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea Pendula' that was discovered in the 1960s in the Netherlands and has been in North American commerce since about 1983.

Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea' forms a tall, dense, pyramidal tree with lower branches that sweep down to the ground. Its new spring leaves are copper-red with a silky sheen, while its summer leaves are deep-purple. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea' has been cultivated for hundreds of years, and the oldest recorded discovery is from a work dated 1680 where Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea' was discovered in Buchs, Zürich, Switzerland.

Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea Pendula' has an amazing form that creates a mushroom-shaped dome. Its foliage is a deep-purple in the spring, which turns to purple-green later in the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea Pendula' was introduced into commerce around 1865.

Fagus sylvatica 'Red Obelisk' has a narrow, upright form and produces rich purple leaves on a columnar growing tree. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Red Obelisk' was developed by Dick van Hoey-Smith in the Netherlands by crossing Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' with Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green'.

Fagus sylvatica 'Riversii' is a large, dome-shaped tree with an open branch structure and smooth grey bark. It produces larger leaves than the usual purple beech and has rich, deep, purple, shiny leaves in the spring that maintain their color throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Riversii' is a magnificent specimen tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Riversii' was first listed in the catalogues of the Rivers nursery in Sawbridgeworth, United Kingdom in the 1870s.

Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' is a tall, dense, pyramidal tree with lower branches that sweep down to the ground and has smooth grey bark. Its spring leaves are a deep red-purple with a silky sheen and become dark-purple by summer. The striking feature of Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' is the deeply-lobed, decorative, oak-like leaves. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' was developed by V. Mašek in 1894 on the estate of Prince Camille de Rohan in Sychrov, Bohemia (now in the Czech Republic).

Fagus sylvatica 'Swat Margaret' produces new leaves that unfold as red-purple and turn dark-purple in the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Swat Margaret' tends to hold its purple coloring later into autumn compared to other cultivars. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Swat Margaret' was raised in Germany in the 1880s by Timm and Co., and was introduced into commerce in 1895.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Anatoki' is an early-season feijoa, fruiting in late-autumn, with fruit that is quite large, round and sweet. Beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Partly self-fertile, so will need planting with a pollinator such as Feijoa sellowiana 'Unique', or Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri'. It has a compact growing habit. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands or southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Feijoa sellowiana 'Anatoki' was first bred by Roy Hart in New Zealand (PVR FEI011).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Apollo' produces medium to large fruit with thin and smooth skin in mid-autumn. The fruit is subject to bruising and purpling, but the pulp is well-developed and slightly gritty. The flavor is very pleasant, and the quality is excellent. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Apollo' has an upright and spreading growth habit and is both vigorous and productive. It is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Apollo' was developed by Hayward Wright in New Zealand (PVR 176).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Den's Choice' produces medium to large fruit with outstanding flavor, typically harvested in mid to late-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Den's Choice' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. It is partially self-fertile, but better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Den's Choice' was developed by Dennis Barton in New Zealand.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Gemini' is a high-yielding cultivar with an upright, spreading growth habit. It produces small to medium-sized, oval-shaped fruit with very smooth, thin skin and excellent flavor and texture, typically harvested in early-autumn. Feijoa sellowiana 'Gemini' also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. It is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. For optimal growth, plant in a sunny position with free-draining soil. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Gemini' was developed by HortResearch in Havelock North, New Zealand (PVR 175).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Golden Goose' produces large to extra-large fruit with smooth, thick, gold-green skin and sweet, golden-yellow flesh. The fruit is typically harvested from late-autumn to early-winter and has an extra-long shelf-life. Feijoa sellowiana 'Golden Goose' has a rounded, bushy growth habit and produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. It is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Golden Goose' was developed by Tharfield Nursery in Katikati, New Zealand.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri' is known for producing exceptionally sweet, tasty, and large to extra-large fruit typically harvested in early to mid-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri' was developed by Roy Hart in Motueka, New Zealand (PVR 3128).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Kākāriki' produces large and very sweet fruit that is typically harvested in early to mid-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kākāriki' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kākāriki' was developed by Roy Hart in Motueka, New Zealand (PVR 3129).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Mammoth' produces medium to large-sized fruit with sweet, soft, juicy, and slightly gritty pulp. It is a strong-growing plant that forms a large bush and typically fruits from late-autumn to early-winter. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Mammoth' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. The fruit is typically harvested from mid to late-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Opal Star' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana.

While it is partially self-fertile, it will produce better crops when planted alongside another feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. The fruit ripen in early winter and are accompanied by beautiful red flowers that bloom from late spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Triumph' is well-suited for coastal and windy environments and can be used to create attractive hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, it will produce better crops when planted alongside another feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Unique' produces medium-sized, smooth-skinned, light-green fruit with a delicate, juicy flavor. It is a compact grower and the fruit ripen in mid-autumn. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Ficus Tuffy is an evergreen shrub grown for its lush attractive foliage and rapid growth. Leaves are are glossy light green, eventually turning dark green as the plant matures. The Foliage is dense and lush, providing the perfect hedging and screening option. Ficus Tuffy thrives in full sun or partial shade on a well drained site. It will tolerate moderate winds. Grows to around 3m tall and 2m wide, the perfect tree for a small garden, providing perfect privacy with its lush dense foliage.

Fraxinus angustifolia subsp. oxycarpa 'Raywood' has an elegant, pyramidal growth habit when young, which broadens to a rounded canopy with age. It is a popular choice for areas with limited space but a need for height. The new growth is bronze-purple, which turns dark-green over the summer. In the autumn, Fraxinus angustifolia subsp. oxycarpa 'Raywood' displays beautiful colors of orange, purple, and red. It is an excellent choice for use as an avenue, driveway, or street tree. Fraxinus angustifolia is deciduous and native to Western Europe north to France and northwest Africa. Learn more about Fraxinus angustifolia. Fraxinus angustifolia subsp. oxycarpa 'Raywood' originated in about 1910 at the Raywood House gardens in Aldgate, Adelaide, Australia and had entered the British nursery trade by 1928 and entered the North American nursery trade in about 1956.

Fraxinus excelsior forms a large, wide-rounded head and is an ideal choice as a shade tree for large areas such as parks and paddocks. It is also well-suited as a stock shelter. Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Lime' also produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Mint' has rich-green, oval, leathery, and glossy leaves with wavy edges, and golden stems. It is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it a versatile option. Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Mint' is tough and able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, except for excessive moisture in the soil. It can tolerate heavy frosts, making it a good option for colder climates. Additionally, Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Mint' produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Canterbury' has small, dark-green, glossy leaves with distinctive red stems. It is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it an ideal option for hedging and screening. Griselinia littoralis 'Canterbury' is tough and able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, except for excessive moisture in the soil. It can tolerate heavy frosts, making it a good option for colder climates. Additionally, Griselinia littoralis 'Canterbury' produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Gecko Green' is a compact grower with dense, glossy, emerald-green foliage. It is an excellent option for low-hedging due to its tidy and compact growth habit.
