Griselinia littoralis 'Gecko Green' is tolerant to wind and coastal conditions, but it requires a well-drained site in full sun to semi-shade. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Variegata' has rich-green, wavy leaves that are blotched and irregularly margined with pale-gold. It is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it an ideal option for hedging and screening. Griselinia littoralis 'Variegata' is able to tolerate most soils, except for those that are poorly drained. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Whenuapai' has large, glossy, dark-green leaves that form a tight, narrow column, making it an excellent choice for architectural plantings. The foliage has a distinctive pointed leaf tip, which gives it a neat and tidy appearance. It is ideally suited for hedging, topiary work, and coastal plantings. Griselinia littoralis 'Whenuapai' prefers fertile, well-drained soils in full sun to part shade and is a hardy variety. Additionally, it produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis. Griselinia littoralis 'Whenuapai' was developed by Kiwi Flora in Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 2520).

Griselinia lucida is bushy and has stout, erect stems that are clothed in large, highly-polished, fresh-green leaves. It can grow in either sun or shade, and adds a luxuriant tropical feel to the garden. It is also an excellent option for containers. Griselinia lucida is able to tolerate coastal conditions and is hardy against light frosts. Griselinia lucida is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia lucida.

Hedycarya arborea is an attractive erect-growing specimen with dark-green leaves. It produces small, white flowers in late spring to late summer, which are followed by large, orange fruit in early autumn to mid-winter. It is important to plant more than one tree, with both male and female specimens, to ensure the production of fruit. Hedycarya arborea requires good soil with adequate moisture and shelter from frosts in order to thrive. Hedycarya arborea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hedycarya arborea.

otherCommonNames: Hibiscus, Syrian Ketmia, Shrub Althea, Rose Mallow
description: Hibiscus syriacus 'Snowdrift' is a multi-stemmed grower that produces large, single, white flowers which cover the bush from mid-summer to early-autumn. It is able to grow equally well in cold and hot climates. To encourage new stems to flower the following summer, it is recommended to prune Hibiscus syriacus 'Snowdrift' by half after the flowering period. Hibiscus syriacus is deciduous and native to Korea and south-central and southeast China. Learn more about Hibiscus syriacus.

Hoheria angustifolia grows into a slender shape with graceful, semi-weeping branches. It has narrow, elongated leaves with heavily-serrated edges, adding to its unique appearance. During the summer, Hoheria angustifolia produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, creating a stunning display. Hoheria angustifolia is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria angustifolia.

Hoheria populnea is very graceful, with slender branches that add to its delicate appearance. Its fresh-green leaves are heavily-serrated, giving them a distinctive texture. During the summer, Hoheria populnea produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, creating a beautiful display. It is an excellent option for rapid screening. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea.

Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' is very graceful, with slender branches that add to its delicate appearance. Its dark-green leaves are heavily and irregularly margined with cream-white, creating an eye-catching contrast. Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' makes for a magnificent shade tree and can brighten up dark areas in a garden. During the summer, it produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, adding to its beauty. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea. Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' was discovered in New Zealand in the 1920s on a Hoheria populnea 'Variegata'. Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' was first listed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand in an undated catalogue from about 1930.

Hoheria populnea 'Purple Wave' is an erect-growing variety with dark-green leaves that are purple underneath, giving them a unique appearance. During the summer, Hoheria populnea 'Purple Wave' produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Hoheria populnea 'Purple Wave' is a quick and hardy grower, making it an excellent option for use as a screen or as a specimen tree. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea.

Hoheria populnea 'Variegata' is very graceful, with slender branches that add to its delicate appearance. Its larger leaves are dark-green with irregular yellow blotches and margins, creating a unique and eye-catching contrast. Hoheria populnea 'Variegata' makes for a magnificent shade tree and can brighten up dark areas in a garden. During the summer, it produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, adding to its beauty. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea. Hoheria populnea 'Variegata' originated in New Zealand and was listed in 1926 in the catalogue of Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Hoheria sexstylosa has a graceful form with slender branches, forming an erect columnar shape. Its pointed green leaves are heavily-serrated, adding to its unique appearance. During the summer, Hoheria sexstylosa produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, creating a beautiful display. Hoheria sexstylosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria sexstylosa.

Hoheria sexstylosa 'Purple Lace' is very graceful, with slender branches forming an erect columnar shape. Its pointed green leaves are purple underneath, giving them a unique appearance. In late summer to autumn, Hoheria sexstylosa 'Purple Lace' produces large clusters of star-shaped, fragrant white flowers that almost obscure the branches. Hoheria sexstylosa 'Purple Lace' is an excellent option for rapid screening, and it adds beauty and fragrance to any garden. Hoheria sexstylosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria sexstylosa.

Hydrangea paniculata 'Limelight' has large conical flower heads, that are stunning in summer and autumn. They begin in a lime green-yellow, transitioning gradually to cream, and then to a rich smokey pink. It is essential to prune in early spring, as it encourages flowers on the new growth. Hydrangea paniculata 'Limelight' will grow in both full sun and partial shade and thrive in humus-rich soils. Hydrangea paniculata is deciduous and native to southern and eastern China, Korea, Japan, and Russia.

Hymenosporum flavum has an erect and graceful open form and is a very fast grower. Its glossy, dark-green leaves add to its attractive appearance. During late spring through summer, Hymenosporum flavum produces clusters of honey-scented, yellow, tubular flowers. Hymenosporum flavum is tolerant of dry and windy conditions, making it a hardy option for a variety of environments. It is also well-suited for smaller gardens. Hymenosporum flavum is evergreen and native to Australia and New Guinea. Learn more about Hymenosporum flavum.

Idesia polycarpa 'Female' has a tiered horizontal branch structure and a broad crown. It produces red berries in autumn, but requires the male Idesia polycarpa 'Male' for pollination. Both male and female forms produce small, yellow-green flowers during the summer. In the autumn, the leaves of Idesia polycarpa 'Female' turn yellow, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Idesia polycarpa is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Learn more about Idesia polycarpa.

Idesia polycarpa 'Male' has a tiered horizontal branch structure and a broad crown, and is characterized by its handsome heart-shaped leaves. Both male and female forms produce small, yellow-green flowers during the summer. In the autumn, the leaves of Idesia polycarpa 'Male' turn yellow, adding to its aesthetic appeal. It serves as a pollinator for Idesia polycarpa 'Female'. Idesia polycarpa is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Learn more about Idesia polycarpa.

Ilex x altaclerensis 'Hendersonii' has an upright, pyramidal form and features spineless leaves. During the winter, it produces clusters of red berries, which add to its aesthetic appeal. It is an excellent option for screening and hedges, and can be trimmed into any shape. Ilex x altaclerensis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Ilex aquifolium and Ilex perado. Learn more about Ilex x altaclerensis. Ilex x altaclerensis 'Hendersonii' was developed by Thomas Hodgins in Dunganstown, Ireland in the early 19th century.

Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' has a narrow, columnar-growing habit with small, dark-green, spineless leaves. It is an excellent option for use as a screen, as it doesn't require side pruning. Additionally, Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' is a great option for use in containers or as a focal point in a contemporary garden due to its unique appearance. Ilex crenata is evergreen and native to eastern China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Sakhalin Island. Learn more about Ilex crenata. Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' was discovered by Norihiro Shibamichi on Mount Daisen, Japan. Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' found its way to the private collection of Masato Yokoi in Kawaguchi, Japan. Masato then donated propogation material to Sylvester March and Frederick Darke during a United States National Arboretum collecting trip in 1985. Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' was then introduced into commerce by the United States National Arboretum in 1992.

Ilex 'Largo' features dark-green foliage and has an upright, bushy growth habit. It is an excellent option for use in topiary and hedging, as it is easy to trim into various shapes. Ilex 'Largo' prefers to be planted in full sun for optimal growth. Ilex 'Largo' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' is a female cultivar and features dark, blue-green, soft, spiny leaves with purple-black stems. It is a slow, dense, upright grower and produces a profusion of small, white blossoms during the summer. To attain scarlet red berries in autumn, it is recommended to plant Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' in combination with the male pollinator Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince'. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' can tolerate semi-shade and cold conditions. Ilex x meserveae is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Ilex aquifolium and Ilex rugosa. Ilex x meserveae was first crossed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' was developed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s (USPP03662).

Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' is a male cultivar and features dark, blue-green, spiny leaves with purple-black stems. It is a slow, dense, bushy grower and produces a profusion of small, white flowers during the summer. It is recommended to plant Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' as a companion pollinator to the female Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel'. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' is an excellent option for use in hedging and can tolerate semi-shade and cold conditions. Ilex x meserveae is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Ilex aquifolium and Ilex rugosa. Ilex x meserveae was first crossed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' was developed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s (USPP3517).

Jacaranda mimosifolia is best suited for warm, sunny climates with no frosts. It has soft, ferny leaves that cover the spreading branches radiating from the single trunk. During the spring and early summer, Jacaranda mimosifolia produces large, lavender-blue, trumpet-like flowers that are borne in racemes. Jacaranda mimosifolia is an excellent option for use as a shade tree. Jacaranda mimosifolia is semi-evergreen and native to northwestern Argentina and southern Bolivia. Learn more about Jacaranda mimosifolia.

Juglans nigra is a fast-growing option with a tall, straight trunk and a wide, spreading head. It is characterized by its dark-brown to black bark and the walnuts that ripen during the autumn months. These walnuts are edible and have a desirable taste, but can be more difficult to extract compared to those produced by Juglans regia. Additionally, Juglans nigra is self-fertile. The wood of Juglans nigra is highly-valued for commercial purposes, such as furniture. Juglans nigra is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Juglans nigra.

Juglans regia is a slow-growing option with a wide-spreading, rounded head. It is an excellent choice for planting in paddocks. Juglans regia produces easy-to-crack walnuts during the autumn months, usually around fifteen years from planting. During the late spring to early summer, Juglans regia produces yellow-green catkins which serve as a source of pollen for bees. While Juglans regia is self-fertile, it can produce better crops when planted with a walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Meyric', Juglans regia 'Shannon', or Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder'. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia.

Juglans regia 'Meyric' produces large walnuts and prefers free-draining soil. It typically starts producing walnuts at around five years of age. The brown nuts are held in a green husk. While Juglans regia 'Meyric' is self-fertile, it can produce better crops when planted with another walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Shannon' or Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder'. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia. Juglans regia 'Meyric' was discovered by Chris Ryan in Hawkes Bay, New Zealand and then propagated by Vernon Harrison.

This is a top-quality walnut tree that produces large crops of well-flavored nuts. The nuts are easy to crack and are held in a green husk. Juglans regia 'Shannon' prefers free-draining soils and typically starts producing walnuts at around five years of age. While it is self-fertile, it can produce better crops when planted with another walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Meyric' or Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder'. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia. Juglans regia 'Shannon' was propagated by Vernon Harrison in New Zealand.

Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder' is vigorous and starts bearing at a young age, producing large thin-shelled nuts with a sweet flavor. It thrives in free-draining soil and begins to bear walnuts at around three years old. The nuts are brown and encased in a green husk. While self-fertile, planting with another walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Meyric' or Juglans regia 'Shannon' can lead to better crops. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia. Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder' was imported into New Zealand by Vernon Harrison and others.

Juniperus chinensis 'Kaizuka' has long, gracefully-curving branches growing out at all angles that are covered in dense clusters of bright-green leaves, making it an architectural focal point. It is also able to tolerate strong winds. Juniperus chinensis is evergreen and native to China, Myanmar, Japan, Korea, Mongolia, Taiwan, and the Russian Far East. Learn more about Juniperus chinensis. Juniperus chinensis 'Kaizuka' originated around 1920 at Yokohama Nursery in Yokohama, Japan.

This is a narrow-growing, columnar conifer with blue-grey foliage that is suitable for use as a screen or windbreak. Once established, it is drought-tolerant and rarely requires pruning. However, it does require full sun to thrive. Juniperus scopulorum is evergreen and native to western North America, from southwest Canada to the Great Plains of the United States. Learn more about Juniperus scopulorum. Juniperus scopulorum 'Skyrocket' was discovered and named in 1949 by Schuel Nursery in South Bend, Indiana, United States.

Knightia excelsa has a narrow, columnar form similar to a poplar and is ideal for planting in restricted areas where height is desired. It has large, long, heavily-serrated, leathery leaves and produces red flowers in early summer that attract nectar-seeking birds. Knightia excelsa can tolerate poor soils, light frosts, and strong winds, making it an excellent choice as a street tree. Knightia excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Knightia excelsa.

Koelreuteria paniculata has an open, spreading form and is adorned with pinnate leaves. The leaves emerge as soft-pink in spring, mature to green, and turn yellow in autumn. In early summer, Koelreuteria paniculata produces panicles of golden-yellow flowers which are followed by dangling, rose-red, papery capsules. It thrives in regions with hot summers and cold winters and is an excellent choice as a street tree. Koelreuteria paniculata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Koelreuteria paniculata.

Kunzea robusta features small, narrow, dark-green, and aromatic leaves that are soft to the touch. In early summer, it produces sprays of glistening white flowers. Kunzea robusta is very hardy, withstanding frosts, drought, and poor soils with ease. It's an excellent choice for use as a screen or to provide shelter for more tender plants. Additionally, it is attractive to bees, making it a great choice for supporting pollinator populations. Kunzea robusta is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Kunzea robusta.

This weeping tree produces beautiful, golden-yellow blossoms in late spring. It grows best in full sun and requires soil that won't dry out over the summer. Laburnum alpinum 'Pendulum' can also be trained to grow over an archway for added interest and beauty. Laburnum alpinum is deciduous and native to Albania, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Greece, Italy, Switzerland, and Yugoslavia. Learn more about Laburnum alpinum.

Laburnum x watereri 'Vossii' has a compact, rounded head and produces fragrant racemes of yellow flowers that hang from the branches in late spring. Its branches are pliable enough to be trained over high arches, adding architectural interest to any landscape. Laburnum x watereri 'Vossii' does not produce seeds, and it's an excellent choice as a street tree. Laburnum x watereri is a hybrid between Laburnum anagyroides and Laburnum alpinum. Laburnum x watereri is deciduous and native to Switzerland. Learn more about Laburnum x watereri. Laburnum x watereri 'Vossii' was raised in the Netherlands in the late 19th century.

Lagerstroemia fauriei 'Townhouse' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. It produces lime-green leaves in the spring, which mature to green in the summer before turning brilliant red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. In the summer, Lagerstroemia fauriei 'Townhouse' produces large, cone-shaped panicles of pure-white flowers. It can handle moderate winds and has beautiful red-brown bark. Lagerstroemia fauriei is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Lagerstroemia fauriei. Lagerstroemia fauriei 'Townhouse' arose as a chance seedling at the JC Raulston Arboretum in Raleigh, North Carolina, United States and was selected in the 1980s.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Bergerac' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. Its lime-green leaves in the spring transition to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. In the summer, Lagerstroemia indica 'Bergerac' produces large conical panicles of crimped, deep-pink to red flowers. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica 'Bergerac' was selected by Desmartis & Cie. in Bergerac, France and was introduced into commerce in 1978.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red' features beautiful, deep red-purple to black foliage that emerges in early spring. During the summer, masses of vivid crimson-red flowers cover Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red'. In the autumn, the foliage turns orange and red, adding to its seasonal appeal. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red' was developed by Cecil Pounder at the United States Department of Agriculture. Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red' was then distributed by J. Berry Nursery in Grand Saline, Texas, United States.

Lagerstroemia indica 'De'Puard' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. It produces lime-green leaves in the spring that mature to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. In the summer, Lagerstroemia indica 'De'Puard' produces large, cone-shaped panicles of light-pink to pale-purple flowers. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica.

Lagerstroemia indica x fauriei 'Sioux' creates a stunning visual impact over a lengthy period with masses of intense-pink flowers blooming over the summer, followed by stunning rich foliage in shades of yellow, red, and orange in the autumn. It can withstand moderate winds. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica x fauriei 'Sioux' was selected in 1979 and originated from the research project of Donald Egolf that started in 1959 at the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States. Lagerstroemia indica x fauriei 'Sioux' was then introduced in 1987 by the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States.

This is an upright, wide-spreading, multi-stemmed tree that thrives in medium-moisture, well-drained soils in full sun. It can also do well in loamy, clay soils with good drainage. Lagerstroemia indica x fauriei 'Tuscarora' has a long bloom period, producing bright-pink flowers in the summer. It also features exfoliating bark and stunning autumn colors in shades of orange, red, and yellow. It can handle moderate winds. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica x fauriei 'Tuscarora' was selected in 1971 and originated from the research project of Donald Egolf that started in 1959 at the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States. Lagerstroemia indica x fauriei 'Tuscarora' was then introduced in 1978 by the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States.

This is an upright, vase-shaped tree that produces frilly, white flowers in the summer. It has yellow, orange, and red autumn leaves, making it an attractive tree for multiple seasons. Lagerstroemia indica 'Kimono' is frost-hardy and can withstand moderate winds. Once established, it is also drought-tolerant. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Saint Émilion' features a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. It has lime-green spring leaves that mature to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. During the summer, Lagerstroemia indica 'Saint Émilion' produces large, cone-shaped panicles of deep-pink to red flowers. It is able to withstand moderate winds. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Soir D'été' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. Its lime-green leaves in the spring transition to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. During the summer, Lagerstroemia indica 'Soir D'été' produces large, cone-shaped panicles of salmon-pink flowers. It is able to withstand moderate winds. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica.

This is a dwarf crepe myrtle that produces purple flowers in the summer. It has lime-green leaves in the spring that mature to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. Lagerstroemia indica 'Tango' can withstand moderate winds. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Yang-Tse' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. Its lime-green leaves in the spring transition to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. During the summer, Lagerstroemia indica 'Yang-Tse' produces large, cone-shaped panicles of bright pink-red flowers. It is able to withstand moderate winds. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica 'Yang-Tse' was developed by Jacques Desmartis in Bergerac, France and was introduced in 1973 by Desmartis & Cie. in Bergerac, France.

This is a handsome and stately pyramidal-growing tree that is adorned with thick, olive-green leaves. It produces a profusion of miniature, hibiscus-shaped pink flowers throughout the summer and autumn. Lagunaria patersonia is an excellent choice for use as a dense screen or hedge, and it can be easily clipped to maintain its shape. It is very tough and can endure coastal winds and drought. Lagunaria patersonia is evergreen and native to Norfolk Island and also the states of New South Wales and Queensland in Australia. Learn more about Lagunaria patersonia.

Larix kaempferi has soft, blue-green leaves that turn yellow and orange in the autumn before dropping. On young trees, the bare red-brown branches are a winter feature. Larix kaempferi is very amenable to pruning and shaping, making it a great choice for those who want to maintain its size and shape. Larix kaempferi is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Larix kaempferi.

This slow-growing tree has a dense, bushy habit and a columnar form that can last for many decades. Its glossy, deep-green leaves have serrated edges and complement the red new stems. Laurelia novae-zelandiae is a great fit for home gardens and can be easily accommodated. It thrives in moist positions and is well-suited for sites on the edge of ponds and streams. Laurelia novae-zelandiae produces small, green-white flowers from mid-spring to early-summer. Laurelia novae-zelandiae is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Laurelia novae-zelandiae.

Laurus nobilis forms a compact, pyramidal shape and has leathery, dark-green leaves that are used for flavoring food. It is very amenable to pruning and shaping into any form, making it a great choice for those who want to maintain its size and shape. It can also be used to make a dense, aromatic hedge. Laurus nobilis is excellent for coastal gardens. Laurus nobilis is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean region. Learn more about Laurus nobilis.

Laurus nobilis 'BayGold' forms a compact, pyramidal shape and has leathery leaves that are used for flavoring food. The new leaves are golden-yellow and fade to green as they mature. Laurus nobilis 'BayGold' is very amenable to pruning and shaping into any form, making it a great choice for those who want to maintain its size and shape. It can also be used to make a dense, aromatic hedge. Laurus nobilis 'BayGold' is excellent for coastal gardens. Laurus nobilis is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean region. Learn more about Laurus nobilis.

Laurus nobilis f. angustifolia differs from Laurus nobilis in that it has narrow, willow-like leaves. It forms a compact, pyramidal shape and has leathery, dark-green leaves that are used for flavoring food. Laurus nobilis f. angustifolia is very amenable to pruning and shaping into any form, making it a great choice for those who want to maintain its size and shape. It can also be used to make a dense, aromatic hedge. Laurus nobilis f. angustifolia is excellent for coastal gardens. Laurus nobilis is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean region. Learn more about Laurus nobilis.

This is a columnar-growing selection of bay tree that is great for narrow spaces. It has leathery, dark-green leaves that are used for flavoring food. Laurus nobilis 'Tuscan Tower' is very amenable to pruning and shaping into any form, making it a great choice for those who want to maintain its size and shape. It can also be used to make a dense, aromatic hedge. Laurus nobilis 'Tuscan Tower' is excellent for coastal gardens. Laurus nobilis is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean region. Learn more about Laurus nobilis. Laurus nobilis 'Tuscan Tower' was developed by Lyndale Nurseries in Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 34679).

This quick-growing tree has red young stems and is covered in small, bronze-purple leaves that smother its arching branches. It can be pruned to form a dense, colourful shelter or screen. Leptospermum nitidum 'Copper Sheen' produces a profusion of single, white flowers in the summer. It is very hardy and can tolerate drought conditions. Leptospermum nitidum is evergreen and native to Tasmania, Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum nitidum. Leptospermum nitidum 'Copper Sheen' has an unknown origin, although it has been in cultivation since before 1966. Most likely, Leptospermum nitidum 'Copper Sheen' is a chance seedling that arose in cultivation.

Leptospermum scoparium makes an excellent screen or shelter and is fast-growing and very hardy. It can tolerate hot dry soils and cold temperatures. The bushes are smothered with a profusion of single, white flowers from spring, which are much loved by bees. Leptospermum scoparium also features aromatic foliage. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Blossom' produces large, double coral pink flowers during winter and spring. With reddish stems, and small long leaves, it is a bushy grower which is great for small hedges. Prune after it flowers to encourage new growth and another flowering season the following year. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand, and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Burgundy Queen' produces dark burgundy-red, double flowers in the spring and summer, which add a striking pop of color to any garden or landscape. Leptospermum scoparium 'Burgundy Queen' also has red-purple foliage, making it an attractive addition to the garden throughout the growing season. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Burgundy Queen' was developed at the nursery of E. F. Jenkins & Sons in Cranbourne South, Victoria, Australia in the mid to late 20th century.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Coral Candy' produces a beautiful display of double, red-pink flowers in the spring and summer. The bright and colorful blooms add a stunning focal point to any garden or landscape. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Coral Candy' was developed at the nursery of E. F. Jenkins & Sons in Cranbourne South, Victoria, Australia in the mid to late 20th century.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Crimson Glory' produces a beautiful display of double, crimson-red flowers in late winter and spring, making it an excellent choice for adding color to the garden during the cooler months. Its new foliage is red-purple, which fades to a deep green as it matures, providing an attractive contrast with the striking blooms. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Crimson Glory' was developed at the nursery of E. F. Jenkins & Sons in Cranbourne South, Victoria, Australia in the mid to late 20th century.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Electric Red' produces a vibrant display of red flowers in the spring, completely covering the bush and creating a stunning burst of color in the garden. It is best planted in a sunny location and is a great choice for dry, exposed areas and coastal locations due to its hardiness and ability to tolerate harsh conditions. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Electric Red' was developed by the New Zealand Institute for Crop and Food Research (PVR 2446).

Leptospermum scoparium 'Kiwi' produces a beautiful display of single, pink flowers in the spring and summer, which add a lovely touch of color to any garden or landscape. It also features purple-green foliage, making it an attractive addition to the garden throughout the growing season. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Kiwi' was developed by Victor Davies of Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and was first listed in their 1956 catalogue.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Martini' produces single, pink-white flowers in the spring, which add a delicate and charming touch to any garden or landscape. The lovely blooms make Leptospermum scoparium 'Martini' a great choice for adding color and beauty to the garden. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Martini' arose as a seedling in the nursery of Martin in Whanganui, New Zealand and was first listed in the catalogue of Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand in about 1945.

This dense, bushy plant is covered in small, red-green leaves and is a hardy choice for well-drained, sunny positions. The flower buds of Leptospermum scoparium 'Red Damask' are a feature over the winter, before bursting into bright, crimson-red, double-blossoms which completely cover the bush over an extended period in the spring. This stunning display of colorful blooms makes Leptospermum scoparium 'Red Damask' a beautiful addition to any garden. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Red Damask' was developed by W. E. Lammerts in California, United States in the early to mid 20th century.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Princess Anne' produces beautiful, double, white flowers with a dark-maroon center in the spring, making it a stunning addition to any garden or landscape. Leptospermum scoparium 'Princess Anne' is hardy and prefers full sun with free-draining soil, and is also frost and drought tolerant once established, making it a great choice for a wide range of growing conditions. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Princess Anne' was first listed in the catalogue of Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand in 1962.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Donna' bears large, single, crimson flowers in the spring, which create a striking visual contrast against the beautiful, purple-red foliage. Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Donna' is hardy and prefers full sun with free-draining soil, and is also frost and drought tolerant once established, making it a great choice for a variety of growing conditions. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Donna' was developed by Jack Hobbs of the Auckland Regional Botanic Gardens in New Zealand in the late 20th century.

This dense, bushy plant is covered in small, bright-green leaves, and its flower buds are a feature over the winter before bursting into bright-red, double-blossoms which completely cover the bush over an extended period in the spring. Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Joan' produces hardly any seeds, making it a low-maintenance choice for the garden. It is hardy and prefers well-drained sunny positions, making it a great choice for a variety of growing conditions. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Joan' was developed by Jack Hobbs of the Auckland Regional Botanic Gardens in New Zealand in the late 20th century.

Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Shelley' produces beautiful single, light-pink flowers in the spring, which add a lovely touch of color to any garden or landscape. The delicate blooms make Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Shelley' a great choice for adding beauty and interest to the garden. Leptospermum scoparium is evergreen and native to New Zealand and the states of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Leptospermum scoparium. Leptospermum scoparium 'Wiri Shelley' was developed by Jack Hobbs of the Auckland Regional Botanic Gardens in New Zealand in the late 20th century.

Libocedrus plumosa is a handsome, symmetrical, pyramidal tree that features bright-green, scale-like leaves. It is an excellent choice for use as a neat-growing screen, for breaking up dark greenery, or for lining driveways, as its shape and foliage create a striking visual presence in the landscape. Libocedrus plumosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Libocedrus plumosa.

Liquidambar acalycina has large, three-lobed leaves, with rich, purple-bronze new spring leaves that add a striking pop of color to the garden. In the fall, the leaves of Liquidambar acalycina turn a gorgeous apricot-orange and yellow, and persist on Liquidambar acalycina well into the winter, providing seasonal interest. Liquidambar acalycina has a smooth bark and a dense, conical growth habit. Liquidambar acalycina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Liquidambar acalycina.

Liquidambar styraciflua forms a stately, pyramidal tree with well-spaced branches and rugged, corky bark. Its shining, five to seven-lobed, maple-shaped leaves provide a handsome look to Liquidambar styraciflua. In the autumn, Liquidambar styraciflua puts on a riot of red, orange, yellow, and purple colors over a long period, making it a great choice for adding seasonal interest to the garden. The coloration of Liquidambar styraciflua is known to be consistent across different climates. However, it's important to note that Liquidambar styraciflua develops a taproot in dry soils that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' is a selected clone with a narrower, pyramidal form when young, which broadens with age. It features larger maple-shaped leaves that emerge earlier than other cultivars. In the autumn, the leaves of Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' turn a rich, red-burgundy color, which persist well into winter, providing seasonal interest. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' is known to color well in all climates and is an excellent choice for use as a street tree. It is important to note that in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' was selected in 1963 by the Saratoga Horticultural Foundation in California, United States.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Festeri' has smooth bark and puts on a brilliant autumn display of red, purple, yellow, and orange colors that can last well into winter in warmer areas, making it an excellent choice for adding seasonal interest to the garden. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Festeri' produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Festeri' was discovered by Mr Fester, a gardener at Kenmore Hospital in Goulburn, New South Wales, Australia and was named in his honour by the Hazelwood Brothers nursery in New South Wales, Australia in 1947.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Golden Treasure' has large green leaves that are broadly-margined with gold, providing a striking look to Liquidambar styraciflua 'Golden Treasure'. During the autumn season, the leaves take on glowing red and burgundy hues, adding to its beauty. The round-headed growth habit makes it an ideal choice for smaller gardens. It is known to color well in all climates. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Golden Treasure' produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Golden Treasure' was introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand before 1974.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Gumball' has a dense, rounded ball-shaped growth habit and features maple-shaped leaves that turn brilliant shades of purple, orange, yellow, and red in the autumn. These leaves often persist well into the winter, providing an extended period of seasonal interest. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Gumball' is an excellent choice as a street tree or for formal planting, and it does not produce seed capsules. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Gumball' produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Gumball' was discovered by Hiram Stubblefield of Forest Nursery in Tennessee, United States around 1965.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' has a neat, pyramidal growth habit with smooth bark and distinctive, rich crimson-red to purple autumn leaves. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' reliably produces brilliant fall colors every year, regardless of the climatic conditions. It's an excellent choice as a street tree. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' was discovered in the garden of Cedric Lane-Roberts in Hertfordshire, England. Harold Hillier noticed Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' when he visited the garden and first listed it in The Hillier Manual of Trees and Shrubs in 1971.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lees Red' is known for coloring early and holding its colorful crimson-red leaves until early winter. In dry soil, it produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lees Red' was selected from a tree growing on Lees Road in Feilding, New Zealand.

This is a dwarf selection with a narrow, upright growth habit. The leaves turn a brilliant red and orange in autumn, and it tolerates moist and clay soil conditions. In dry soil, it produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Little Richard' is very popular in New Zealand, but is believed to be of Australian origin.

Instead of pointed lobes like other cultivars, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Rotundiloba' has round leaf lobes. It also has smooth bark. During the summer, it has shining green leaves and grows narrowly and pyramidally. In the fall, the leaves of Liquidambar styraciflua 'Rotundiloba' turn a glowing burgundy-red color. It does not produce seeds and is an excellent choice for planting along streets. When grown in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Rotundiloba' develops a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, while in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and is less tolerant of strong winds. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Rotundiloba' was discovered by R. E. Wicker near Pinehurst, North Carolina, United States and was first described by Alfred Rehder in 1931.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Worplesdon' has an upright, pyramidal shape, and its outer branches droop gracefully. Its leaves are similar in shape to those of a maple tree, with fine cuts and deep lobes. In the autumn, the leaves of Liquidambar styraciflua 'Worplesdon' are a striking mix of purple, red, orange, and yellow. When grown in dry soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Worplesdon' develops a taproot that helps to reinforce it against wind. However, when grown in wetter soil, Liquidambar styraciflua 'Worplesdon' only produces superficial roots and is not able to tolerate strong winds. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Worplesdon' was selected in 1968 by George Jackman from a tree in Worplesdon, Surrey, England.

During summer, this robust tree produces yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. It is a rare species that has blue-green leaves of remarkable size, which transform into a butter-yellow hue during autumn. Liriodendron chinense has a broad, columnar shape and purple-tinted emerging leaves. It is an outstanding choice for planting in parks and paddocks. Liriodendron chinense is deciduous and native to China and Vietnam. Learn more about Liriodendron chinense.

Liriodendron tulipifera is a magnificent, tall, pyramidal specimen with a broad, spreading crown. Its beautiful bright-green leaves transform into a glorious butter-yellow hue during autumn. In summer, it produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. It is an excellent choice as a large lawn and paddock tree. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera.

In spring, Liriodendron tulipifera 'Allenton Gold' displays beautiful butter-yellow leaves which fade to yellow-green during summer, and its autumn foliage is a deep gold. It has a neat, broadly-conical growth habit, but it grows slower than Liriodendron tulipifera. However, its yellow foliage is more prone to burning in very hot weather. In summer, Liriodendron tulipifera 'Allenton Gold' produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera.

Liriodendron tulipifera 'Aureomarginatum' has strikingly variegated large green leaves that are heavily bordered with a rich golden-yellow. The color may become more muted during summer, but it intensifies through autumn. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Aureomarginatum' forms a pyramid of up-swept branches and can lighten up any dull area. In summer, Liriodendron tulipifera 'Aureomarginatum' produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Aureomarginatum' was first noted by Louis van Houtte in Belgium in 1869.

With a narrow, upright, and columnar form, Liriodendron tulipifera 'Fastigiatum' is an excellent choice for confined spaces, avenues, screens, or focal points in formal gardens. Its beautiful green leaves in summer turn a glorious butter-yellow during autumn. It is also an excellent street tree. In summer, Liriodendron tulipifera 'Fastigiatum' produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Fastigiatum' was first catalogued at the Arboretum de Segrez in France in 1877.

Liriodendron tulipifera 'Snowbird' has a pyramid shape with up-swept branches. Its large green leaves are strikingly variegated and heavily-bordered with cream-white. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Snowbird' displays golden-yellow autumn leaves. In summer, Liriodendron tulipifera 'Snowbird' produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Snowbird' was developed by by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand (PVR 30591).

This is a fast-growing tree that can tolerate drought once established. Its wood is strong and durable, and is commonly used in shipbuilding, making floors and bridges, and for general building timber. Lophostemon confertus features salmon-colored bark that flakes off during summer, revealing orange-brown tones on the trunk. It produces clusters of small white flowers in both spring and summer. Lophostemon confertus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Lophostemon confertus.

Lophozonia menziesii has an erect, pyramidal, and narrow-growing form. It features small, deep-green leaves, and its young spring growth appears pale-green against the silver-white trunk. Lophozonia menziesii prefers cooler climates but can grow in warm climates with adequate moisture and shelter from hot winds. Lophozonia menziesii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Lophozonia menziesii.

Loropetalum chinense var. rubrum 'Fire Dance' has deep red-purple leaves that may fade to green during the summer. It produces beautiful, bright-pink flowers from early spring, making it a stunning choice for low-hedging. Once established, Loropetalum chinense var. rubrum 'Fire Dance' is drought-tolerant. Loropetalum chinense is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Loropetalum chinense.

Macadamia 'GT205' has been specifically bred to withstand cooler and wetter growing conditions, and it begins producing at an early age. The nuts are enclosed in a green shell which turns brown and drops in mid-spring to early summer, although they can be hand-picked earlier. Macadamia 'GT205' produces heavy yields of nuts with a high oil content, making it an excellent choice for roasting. Cross-pollination with another macadamia cultivar, such as Macadamia 'GT207' or Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont', is necessary. Macadamia 'GT205' also boasts pink flowers that bloom in both spring and summer. Macadamia 'GT205' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Ian Gordon in Titirangi, Auckland, New Zealand.

Macadamia 'GT207' is an excellent choice for a home garden, as it drops ripe nuts, making harvesting easier. The early-season nuts have a high oil content and are ready to be harvested in mid-autumn to early-winter. Cross-pollination with another macadamia cultivar, such as Macadamia 'GT205' or Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont', is necessary. Macadamia 'GT207' also produces pink flowers in both spring and summer. Macadamia 'GT207' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Ian Gordon in Titirangi, Auckland, New Zealand.

Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont' produces new leaves that are red-maroon in color, and bright-pink flowers that bloom from spring to summer. It begins bearing macadamia nuts at a young age and continues to improve with age. The brown nuts, enclosed in a green husk, are typically borne from summer to autumn. Unlike some other cultivars, this one does not drop its own crop, so the nuts must be picked by hand. Although it is partially self-fertile, planting it with another macadamia cultivar such as Macadamia 'GT205' or Macadamia 'GT207' can result in better crops. Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and an Australian selection that was trialled at the John H. Beaumont Agricultural Research Center in Hawaii, United States in the 1930s.

A New Zealand-bred Macadamia cultivar that produces large crops of large thick-shelled nuts during spring. It typically take 4-5 years to bear its first fruit, with the nuts maturing over a 7-8 month period. The leaves are small and have few prickles, with fragrant pink flowers blooming over spring and summer. Macadamia 'TM2' requires frost protection as it grows well in warmer regions. Additionally it is toxic to dogs. Partly self-fertile, but for best results plant with another Macadamia variety to allow cross-pollination.

Magnolia acuminata 'Koban Dori' produces soft-yellow, cup-shaped blooms with six tepals that are typically 5cm to 7.5cm wide. The flowers appear in the spring as the leaves begin to emerge, and Magnolia acuminata 'Koban Dori' is an excellent choice for adding color to a mixed garden or brightening up a dull corner. It is an upright, pyramidal grower, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Magnolia acuminata is deciduous and native to Ontario, Canada and the central and eastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia acuminata. Magnolia acuminata 'Koban Dori' was introduced in Japan before 1989.

Michelia 'Allure' has a tight and compact form, making it a great choice for screening or creating a topiary. It also features attractive foliage, and in the winter, it produces striking flower-buds that add to its visual appeal. Additionally, it produces delightful blush-pink spring flowers. Michelia 'Allure' can be grown in both sun or light shade and is also suitable for growing in pots. Michelia 'Allure' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Allure', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Allure' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' produces bright purple-pink blooms in the spring and is a free-flowering tree. It begins to bloom at a young age and continues to produce an abundance of flowers. Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' has an upright, sturdy, shrub-like growth habit and tends to clump from the base, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' was raised by Vance Hooper at Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and was named in about 1995.

Magnolia 'Arabian Nights' is a strong, upright, and rounded grower that tends to get larger with age. In the early spring, it produces a profusion of large, bowl-shaped blooms with a rich purple-red color, adding to its visual appeal. Magnolia 'Arabian Nights' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Sayonara' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Arabian Nights' was raised by Stuart Robertson in about 2000 at the Auckland Botanic Gardens in Auckland, New Zealand and was named in about 2007.

Magnolia 'Athene' is an erect, vase-shaped tree that becomes more rounded as it matures. It starts flowering from an early age and should produce its first blooms within a year of planting. The large, fragrant flowers are cup and saucer-shaped with thick and rounded tepals. The flowers are ivory-white, but they are also flushed with violet-pink at the base, adding to their visual appeal. Magnolia 'Athene' typically blooms in the mid-spring. Magnolia 'Athene' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia 'Mark Jury'. Magnolia 'Athene' was bred by Felix Jury in New Zealand in the early 1960s and introduced in 1988.

Magnolia 'Atlas' produces large, cup-shaped flowers that are lilac-pink in color with cream-white interiors. The flowers can reach up to 35cm in diameter, with tepals that are up to 15cm wide. It typically blooms in mid-spring and starts producing flowers from an early age. Magnolia 'Atlas' has an erect and open-headed tree form, but it only produces flowers at the branch tips, adding to its unique visual appeal. Magnolia 'Atlas' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia 'Mark Jury'. Magnolia 'Atlas' was bred by Felix Jury in New Zealand in the 1960s and introduced in 1989.

In spring, Magnolia 'Billowing Cloud' produces numerous fragrant white flowers with a pinkish hue at the base. Magnolia 'Billowing Cloud' has a rounded habit. Magnolia 'Billowing Cloud' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Amabilis' and Magnolia cylindrica. Magnolia 'Billowing Cloud' was raised by Vance Hooper at Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Black Tulip' is perfect for smaller gardens due to its compact and upright growth habit. It blooms in mid-spring, producing cup-shaped, thick-textured flowers with a glowing dark-purple color. The flowers are typically 15cm wide and can withstand windy conditions. Additionally, Magnolia 'Black Tulip' begins flowering at a young age. Magnolia 'Black Tulip' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Vulcan' and Magnolia 'Iolanthe'. Magnolia 'Black Tulip' was raised by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 1998 (PVR 1498).

This neat and spreading tree is well-suited for smaller gardens and blooms in mid-spring with large, cup and saucer-shaped flowers. The flowers are a rich-pink color with pale-pink interiors and Magnolia 'Brixton Belle' typically begins flowering in the first year with an abundance of blooms. In some cases, it may have a second flowering during the summer. Magnolia 'Brixton Belle' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia campbellii 'Sir Harold Hillier' and the hybrid formed between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia 'Black Tulip'. Magnolia 'Brixton Belle' was raised by Vance Hooper in Brixton, Taranaki, New Zealand and released into commerce by Magnolia Grove in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand about 2010.

Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' is an upright grower and produces late-spring flowers that are green and purple-pink on the outside, with yellow-white interiors that are veined with pink. It is an excellent choice for street planting. Magnolia x brooklynensis is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata and Magnolia liliiflora. Magnolia x brooklynensis was first crossed in the 1950s by Evamaria Sperber at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Kitchawan Research Station in New York City, New York, United States. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' is a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata 'Klassen' and Magnolia liliiflora 'O'Neill'. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' was raised by Joe McDaniel in Illinois, United States and first flowered in 1972.

As its leaves emerge in the spring, Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' produces a profusion of beautiful yellow flowers with six tepals that typically range from 7.5cm to 10cm in length. When the flowers first open, they may have a slight green tinge. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' has an upright, pyramidal growth habit. Magnolia x brooklynensis is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata and Magnolia liliiflora. Magnolia x brooklynensis was first crossed in the 1950s by Evamaria Sperber at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Kitchawan Research Station in New York City, New York, United States. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' is a hybrid between Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Evamaria' and Magnolia acuminata var. subcordata. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' was raised by Doris Stone in 1967 at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Kitchawan Research Station in New York City, New York, United States.

Magnolia 'Burgundy Star' produces a profusion of large, slightly-fragrant, glowing wine-red flowers that can reach up to 25cm in width. It is a very floriferous tree, beginning to flower at an early age and continuing to do so for an extended period. With a narrow, erect growth habit, it is an excellent choice for limited spaces and is also a great street tree. Its blooms appear in mid-spring. Magnolia 'Burgundy Star' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Burgundy Star' was raised in 1993 by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and was introduced in 2006 (PVR 30707).

Magnolia 'Butterflies' is very free-flowering and produces a mass of cream-yellow, star-shaped flowers that resemble butterflies perched atop the branches in spring. The flowers emerge before the leaves and typically have 10 to 14 tepals and red stamens. Magnolia 'Butterflies' forms a rounded shape and starts to flower at an early age. Magnolia 'Butterflies' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata 'Fertile Myrtle' and Magnolia denudata 'Sawada's Cream'. Magnolia 'Butterflies' was raised by Phil Savage before 1989 in Michigan, United States.

Magnolia 'Cameo' produces tulip to cup-shaped blooms in spring, with flower tepals that are red-purple on the outside and white flushed with red-purple on the interior. The blooms are wind-resistant and are produced in abundance from the first year. The high rate of flower production of Magnolia 'Cameo' limits its height, resulting in a small, compact habit. Magnolia 'Cameo' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia 'Black Tulip'. Magnolia 'Cameo' was selected in 2000 by Vance Hooper in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand and released in 2013 by Magnolia Grove in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand (USPP27222).

This large and upright-growing tree produces a magnificent display of huge, white, cup and saucer-shaped flowers from late-winter to early-spring. The flowers can be as large as 30cm across and make a spectacular sight. Although Magnolia campbellii 'Alba' takes around five years to start flowering, it is well worth the wait. Magnolia campbellii 'Alba' has wide-spreading branches that further enhance its beauty. Magnolia campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Myanmar, Nepal, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Learn more about Magnolia campbellii.

This large and upright-growing tree produces a magnificent display of huge, purple-pink, cup and saucer-shaped flowers with white flushed pink interiors from late-winter to early-spring. The flowers have 12 tepals and can be as wide as 23cm. Although Magnolia campbellii 'Charles Raffill' takes around five years to start flowering, it is well worth the wait. Magnolia campbellii 'Charles Raffill' has wide-spreading branches that further enhance its beauty. Magnolia campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Myanmar, Nepal, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Learn more about Magnolia campbellii. Magnolia campbellii 'Charles Raffill' was selected in the 1960s from seedlings sent by Charles Raffill of Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew in Richmond, United Kingdom (that he worked on in the 1940s) to The Valley Gardens, Windsor Great Park in The Crown Estate Windsor Great Park, United Kingdom.

This magnificent magnolia is a sight to behold, with large, woolly buds that open to reveal deep-magenta, cupped blooms that age to deep-purple. Magnolia campbellii 'Lanarth' blooms from late-winter to early-spring and, although it may take a few years to flower, it is well worth the wait. The flowers can be up to 23cm wide, while the leaves are typically 25cm long by 15cm wide. For best results, plant Magnolia campbellii 'Lanarth' in a sheltered spot. It has an upright growth habit and is a good choice for narrow sites. Magnolia campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Myanmar, Nepal, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Learn more about Magnolia campbellii. Magnolia campbellii 'Lanarth' arose from a seedling collected by George Forrest in China in 1924 that was planted at a garden in Lanarth, Cornwall, England.

Magnolia 'Charisma' produces large, cup and saucer-shaped flowers in the spring with a red-pink to purple coloration. The flowers are typically 20cm to 30cm wide, making for an impressive display. Magnolia 'Charisma' has an upright to spreading growth habit. Magnolia 'Charisma' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Charisma' was selected before 2018 by Ian Baldick in Drury, New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Cleopatra' begins to flower at an early age, producing a profusion of goblet-shaped blooms that are red-purple both inside and out. The flowers are up to 20cm wide and bloom in early spring, with the possibility of a second summer flowering in warm summers. It is an excellent street tree, with an upright and conical growth habit that is well-suited to areas with limited space. Magnolia 'Cleopatra' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia 'Black Tulip'. Magnolia 'Cleopatra' was selected in 2003 by Vance Hooper in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand (PVR 30845).

This delightful tree produces large, cup and saucer-shaped flowers that are pure-white with a hint of pink at the base. Magnolia 'David Clulow' begins to flower at an early age and is well-suited to smaller gardens, with a spreading growth habit. Its flowers bloom in early spring. Magnolia 'David Clulow' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia x veitchii 'Peter Veitch'. Magnolia 'David Clulow' was selected before 1998 by John Giordano from the hybrids produced by Todd Gresham from 1955 to 1969 at Todd's home in Santa Cruz, California, United States.

Magnolia denudata is characterized by goblet-shaped, pure-white flowers with broad, fleshy petals that glisten on its bare branches from late winter to early spring. Magnolia denudata has a broad pyramidal form with wide-spreading branches and begins to flower from an early age. Magnolia denudata is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia denudata.

Magnolia denudata 'Gere' produces the same beautiful flowers as Magnolia denudata, but blooms later in mid to late spring. It is a useful choice for areas that experience late frosts. Magnolia denudata 'Gere' has an upright, pyramidal growth habit, and it starts flowering from an early age. It is an excellent option for street planting. Magnolia denudata is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia denudata. Magnolia denudata 'Gere' was selected before 1987 by Joe McDaniel from a tree in a cemetery in Urbana, Illinois, United States and was given the name on the nearest tombstone.

Magnolia 'Deryk' produces rich, glowing, velvet-red flowers from late winter to early spring. It sets flowers on all tips, which can result in a slower growth rate. Magnolia 'Deryk' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a seedling of Magnolia 'Genie'. Magnolia 'Deryk' was raised by Magnolia Grove in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand and named in honour of Deryk Lawrence who raised various magnolia hybrids at the garden he developed with his wife, Nancy, in Otamarakau, New Zealand.

This strong-growing tree has a neat, pyramidal shape and produces highly-perfumed, magnolia-like blooms in early spring to early summer. The flowers are large, cream-white, and emerge from showy, brown, furry buds. The glossy, rich-green leaves of Michelia doltsopa drop when it's in bloom, but it quickly refoliates. Michelia doltsopa is correctly known as Magnolia doltsopa, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia doltsopa is evergreen and native to Bhutan, Myanmar, China, India, and Nepal. Learn more about Magnolia doltsopa.

This selection of Magnolia doltsopa begins flowering in its first years, producing large, cream-white flowers that bloom from early spring to early summer. The flowers can be up to 20cm wide and typically have about 30 tepals. Michelia doltsopa 'Silver Cloud' is correctly known as Magnolia doltsopa 'Silver Cloud', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia doltsopa is evergreen and native to Bhutan, Myanmar, China, India, and Nepal. Learn more about Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia doltsopa 'Silver Cloud' was selected in the 1950s or 1960s by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand from a seedling sent to New Zealand by Hillier Nurseries in the United Kingdom.

Michelia 'Fairy Blush' is a dense and bushy grower with shining, pale-green leaves. From early spring, it produces a profusion of long, russet buds that open to fragrant, lilac-pink flowers with cream-white interiors. Michelia 'Fairy Blush' is ideal for hedging, and can be pruned into any shape or grown as a specimen tree. Michelia 'Fairy Blush' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Fairy Blush', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Fairy Blush' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2008 (PVR 3094).

Michelia 'Fairy Cream' has shining, pale-green leaves and a strong, horizontal branching structure that makes it ideal for training, particularly pleaching. From early spring, it produces long, russet buds that open to fragrant, star-shaped cream flowers. Michelia 'Fairy Cream' can be grown as a specimen tree. Michelia 'Fairy Cream' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Fairy Cream', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Fairy Cream' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2013 (PVR 31113).

Michelia 'Fairy White' has shining, pale-green leaves and a strong, horizontal branching structure that makes it ideal for training, particularly pleaching. From early spring, it produces long, russet buds that open to fragrant, star-shaped flowers of pure-white. Michelia 'Fairy White' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Fairy White', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Fairy White' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2013 (PVR 31112).

Magnolia 'Felix' produces large, heavily-textured, and fragrant cup-shaped flowers that are red and age to rose-pink. The flowers can be as wide as 35cm and begin to bloom at an early age. Magnolia 'Felix' has an upright growth habit with spreading branches and large leaves, and its flowers appear in mid-spring. Magnolia 'Felix' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Atlas' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Felix' was raised in 1986 by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2000 (PVR 1875).

Michelia figo is a dense and multi-stemmed grower, with glossy, pale-green leaves that extend down to the ground. Small yellow and pink flowers are hidden among the leaves and release a fruity fragrance from late spring through summer. Michelia figo is ideal for hedging, can be pruned into any shape, or grown as a specimen tree. Michelia figo is correctly known as Magnolia figo, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia figo is evergreen and native to China and probably originated in cultivation. Learn more about Magnolia figo.

Michelia x foggii 'Bubbles' forms a wide-spreading, pyramidal shape and has glossy, deep-green leaves. Its velvet buds open to slightly fragrant, cream-white, rounded flowers with pink edges in the spring. Michelia x foggii 'Bubbles' is correctly known as Magnolia x foggii 'Bubbles', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia x foggii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia figo and Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia x foggii was first crossed in 1972 by John Fogg at the Morris Arboretum in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. Learn more about Magnolia x foggii. Magnolia x foggii 'Bubbles' was developed before 2000 by Oswald Blumhardt in Whangārei, New Zealand.

Michelia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss' forms a pyramidal shape and has shining, pale-green leaves. Its velvet buds open to deliciously fragrant, cream-white, rounded flowers with purple edges in the spring. Michelia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss' drops its leaves as the flowers emerge, but quickly refoliates once flowering has finished. Michelia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss' is correctly known as Magnolia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia x foggii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia figo and Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia x foggii was first crossed in 1972 by John Fogg at the Morris Arboretum in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. Learn more about Magnolia x foggii. Magnolia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss' was developed before 1996 by Oswald Blumhardt in Whangārei, New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Forrest's Pink' produces lightly-scented, goblet-shaped flowers with 9 to 11 tepals in the spring. The flowers are deep-pink at the base and fade to pink-white near the top. Magnolia 'Forrest's Pink' has an upright growth habit. Magnolia 'Forrest's Pink' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and usually listed as a Magnolia denudata cultivar. However, unpublished data has shown that it is almost certainly a hybrid. Its precise parentage remains unknown. Magnolia 'Forrest's Pink' was raised as a seedling (possibly from one of George Forrest's seed collections) in the 1920s at Caerhays Estate in Cornwall, England.

Magnolia 'Galaxy' produces fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers in late spring with 11 to 12 tepals. The flowers are initially red-purple at the base and fade to pink near the top and inside. It is an ideal choice for areas that experience late frosts. The flowers of Magnolia 'Galaxy' are up to 25cm wide and Magnolia 'Galaxy' itself has an upright, pyramidal growth habit that spreads with age. It begins to flower at an early age and is an excellent street tree. Magnolia 'Galaxy' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' and Magnolia sprengeri var. diva 'Diva'. Magnolia 'Galaxy' was developed in 1963 by William Kosar at the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States and was released into commerce in 1980.

Magnolia 'Genie' produces goblet-shaped flowers that are dark purple-red and bloom for about ten weeks through the spring, with a possible second summer flowering. The flowers have up to 12 tepals. Magnolia 'Genie' produces healthy leaves and is proven to be frost hardy, making it a great choice for cooler climates. It is ideal for planting in areas with limited space. Magnolia 'Genie' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Sweet Valentine' and the hybrid formed between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra'. Magnolia 'Genie' was selected by Vance Hooper in 1998 in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand (PVR 2853).

Magnolia 'Gold Star' bears a profusion of fragrant, large, star-shaped flowers in a soft cream-yellow color with up to 14 tepals. Magnolia 'Gold Star' flowers in mid-spring and has bronze-red spring leaves that turn green through the summer. It has an upright growth habit with spreading branches. Magnolia 'Gold Star' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata var. subcordata 'Miss Honeybee' and Magnolia stellata 'Rubra'. Magnolia 'Gold Star' was developed before 2000 by Phil Savage in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, United States.

Magnolia grandiflora 'Blanchard' has a strong, compact, columnar form, and large, glossy-green leaves with a thick under-coating of cinnamon-brown. It produces large, white, single flowers from spring through autumn and is able to grow in most soils. This makes it a great option as an avenue or driveway specimen. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Blanchard' was discovered in the early 1960s in the yard of D. D. Blanchard in Wallace, North Carolina, United States and was first distributed by Robbins Nursery in Willard, North Carolina, United States.
