Magnolia grandiflora 'Ferruginea' has large, handsome, deep glossy-green leaves that are rusty-brown felted beneath. Its pure white, thickly-textured flowers are strongly scented of citrus and are produced from spring through autumn. Magnolia grandiflora 'Ferruginea' has an elegant round-headed growth habit and makes a great specimen shade tree. It is also tolerant of poorly drained positions. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Ferruginea' has been in the British nursery trade since 1804.

This handsome, large evergreen tree has a broad, conical shape and large, glossy-green leaves with no russeting underneath. It produces huge, cream-white, fragrant blooms from spring through autumn. Magnolia grandiflora 'Jade Emperor' is quite wind hardy and prefers moist soil. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Jade Emperor' was developed in New Zealand.

Magnolia grandiflora 'Kay Parris' has a very compact, upright growth habit and responds well to pruning, making it a great option for hedges. It produces large, white flowers from spring through autumn. Magnolia grandiflora 'Kay Parris' has shiny, green, wavy leaves with orange-brown fuzzy undersides and bright pink new leaves and shoots. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Kay Parris' is a seedling of Magnolia grandiflora 'Little Gem' that was selected in 1991 by Kevin Parris in Spartanburg, South Carolina, United States.

Magnolia grandiflora 'Little Gem' has a compact, narrowly-columnar growth habit and features glossy, deep-green leaves with brown felt underneath. It produces white, citrus-scented flowers from spring through autumn. Magnolia grandiflora 'Little Gem' is excellent for smaller gardens and as a street tree, and is tolerant of poorly-drained positions. Its leaves are usually 12.5cm long by 5cm wide. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Little Gem' was selected in 1952 by Warren Steed in Candor, North Carolina, United States.

Magnolia grandiflora 'Main Street' has a narrow, upright, columnar growth habit and a very compact form, making it an ideal selection as a street or avenue tree. It has handsome, large, glossy-green leaves that are heavily-russeted with felt underneath. Magnolia grandiflora 'Main Street' produces large, lemon-scented, cream-white flowers from spring through autumn and prefers moist soil. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Main Street' was introduced by Cedar Lane Farm in Madison, Georgia, United States.

Magnolia grandiflora 'Russet' has a compact, narrow growth habit and features handsome, large, glossy-green leaves that are heavily-russeted with felt underneath. It produces large, lemon-scented, cream-white flowers from spring through autumn with up to 16 tepals and can be as wide as 20cm. Magnolia grandiflora 'Russet' prefers moist soil. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Russet' was selected in 1952 by Maunsell van Rensellaer in California, United States and was introduced in 1966 by the Saratoga Horticultural Research Foundation in California, United States.

Magnolia grandiflora 'Teddy Bear' has a narrow, columnar growth habit and is slower but neater than other evergreen forms, with a tight branch structure. It features glossy-green leaves with fuzzy, brown undersides and produces large, fragrant, white flowers from spring through autumn. The flowers of Magnolia grandiflora 'Teddy Bear' can be as wide as 13.5cm. It is ideal for large containers, paths, and almost anywhere requiring height instead of width. Magnolia grandiflora is evergreen and native to the southeastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia grandiflora. Magnolia grandiflora 'Teddy Bear' was selected in 1985 by Bob Head in Seneca, South Carolina, United States (USPP13049 and PVR 30690).

Magnolia 'Heaven Scent' produces erect, pastel lavender-pink, tulip-shaped blooms with white interiors that are paler towards the tips. Its unique color among magnolias and its pleasantly fragrant flowers make it a desirable option. Magnolia 'Heaven Scent' has an upright, rounded growth habit, flowers in mid-spring from an early age, and is an excellent street tree. Magnolia 'Heaven Scent' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' and Magnolia x veitchii 'Peter Veitch'. Magnolia 'Heaven Scent' was produced by Todd Gresham sometime from 1955 to 1969 at his home in Santa Cruz, California, United States.

Magnolia 'Hollywell' produces large, soft-pink blooms in spring with firm texture that open to reveal a white interior and a delicious, delicate fragrance. Magnolia 'Hollywell' has an upright, columnar habit. Magnolia 'Hollywell' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a seedling of Magnolia sprengeri var. diva 'Diva'. Magnolia 'Hollywell' was produced by Ian Baldick in Drury, New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Honey Tulip' is a golden form of Magnolia 'Black Tulip' and produces the same heavily-textured, goblet-shaped flowers as its counterpart, but with a smaller growth habit. Magnolia 'Honey Tulip' retains its yellow coloring without fading and produces flowers that are up to 15cm wide in late-winter to early-spring. It is great for the smaller garden, flowers from an early age, and is an excellent street tree. Magnolia 'Honey Tulip' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' and Magnolia 'Iolanthe'. Magnolia 'Honey Tulip' was raised in 1993 by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2013 (USPP26685).

Magnolia 'Ian's Red' produces large, saucer-shaped flowers with a glowing, clear-red color and heavy texture in late-winter. The flowers can be as wide as 20cm and have 12 tepals. Magnolia 'Ian's Red' is a prolific bloomer from an early age and forms a round-headed shape. Magnolia 'Ian's Red' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Pickard's Ruby' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Ian's Red' was raised before 2004 by Ian Baldick in Drury, New Zealand.

Michelia 'Inspiration' has an upright and dense growth habit, making it an ideal choice where space is limited. It has shiny, dark-green leaves and produces velvet-brown buds that open to porcelain-white, star-shaped flowers from early-spring over many weeks. The flowers have a delightful fragrance. Michelia 'Inspiration' can grow in partly shaded areas and is frost tolerant. Michelia 'Inspiration' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Inspiration', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Inspiration' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x foggii 'Loving Memories' and Magnolia laevifolia 'Warm Fuzzies'. Magnolia 'Inspiration' was selected in 1996 by Barry Sligh at Taunton Gardens and Nursery in Lyttelton, New Zealand (PVR 30824 and Australian PBR 2016/252).

Magnolia 'Iolanthe' produces large, bowl-shaped flowers with a pastel lavender-pink color and cream-pink interiors. The flowers have a heavily textured appearance and can be as wide as 28cm. Magnolia 'Iolanthe' blooms from an early age and over a long period from early-spring. It sets flowers all along the branches and forms a neat, rounded shape with an open, airy branching habit. Magnolia 'Iolanthe' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei' and Magnolia 'Mark Jury'. Magnolia 'Iolanthe' was produced by Felix Jury in New Zealand and introduced in the early 1970s by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' produces large, glowing red-purple flowers with pink interiors, which are bowl-shaped and can be as wide as 15cm. Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' blooms prolifically from an early age, typically in mid-spring. It has a large, upright and spreading form with an open and airy appearance. Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia sargentiana and Magnolia sprengeri var. diva 'Diva'. Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' was raised by Phillip Tregunna, the head gardener at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England. Julian Williams registered Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' and named it after his grandfather, who was responsible for planting the Caerhays garden.

In early-spring, it bears white flowers that may have a slight pale-pink hint. It requires well-drained soil and is intolerant of excessively dry or wet soil conditions. Magnolia kobus may not produce a good amount of flowers when it is young, but once mature, it produces an impressive display of flowers. Magnolia kobus is deciduous and native to Japan and Korea. Learn more about Magnolia kobus.

Michelia yunnanensis is a tidy, pyramid-shaped cultivar that has lustrous, dark green foliage. It blooms extensively from early spring, producing numerous small, cream-white, star-shaped flowers from velvety buds. It is versatile, as it can be used for hedging, trimmed into any desired form, or grown as a distinctive tree. Michelia yunnanensis is correctly known as Magnolia laevifolia, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia laevifolia is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia laevifolia.

Michelia 'Gracipes' has leaves that are rounded in shape. It is a tidy, pyramid-shaped cultivar with deep-green foliage. From early spring, it produces an abundance of pure-white flowers over an extended period. It is suitable for use as a hedging plant, can be pruned into any desired shape, or can be grown as a distinctive tree. Michelia 'Gracipes' is correctly known as Magnolia laevifolia 'Gracipes', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia laevifolia is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia laevifolia. Magnolia laevifolia 'Gracipes' was developed in New Zealand.

Michelia yunnanensis 'Princess Isabella' is a neat and compact cultivar that blooms during the spring season. Its golden-brown buds unfurl into fragrant clusters of cream-white flowers. While it can be grown as a distinctive tree, it is also easy to maintain as a hedge. Michelia yunnanensis 'Princess Isabella' is correctly known as Magnolia laevifolia 'Princess Isabella', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia laevifolia is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia laevifolia. Magnolia laevifolia 'Princess Isabella' was developed in New Zealand.

Michelia yunnanensis 'Velvet And Cream' produces fragrant white flowers during the spring season. It responds well to regular clipping and can be easily shaped into a hedge. It thrives in soil that is consistently moist. Michelia yunnanensis 'Velvet And Cream' is correctly known as Magnolia laevifolia 'Velvet And Cream', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia laevifolia is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia laevifolia. Magnolia laevifolia 'Velvet And Cream' was selected before 2004 by Peter Cave in New Zealand.

Michelia 'Lemon Fragrant' is a tidy, pyramid-shaped cultivar that features appealing, fresh-green foliage. It produces a profusion of large, cream-white, star-shaped flowers with a delightful lemon scent throughout the early spring and for an extended period. It is versatile and can be used for hedging, trimmed into any desired form, or grown as a distinctive tree. Michelia 'Lemon Fragrant' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Lemon Fragrant', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Lemon Fragrant' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x foggii 'Bubbles' and Magnolia foveolata. Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' has slender buds that unfurl into dark red-purple flowers with cream-white interiors. Each flower features six tepals. It typically starts blooming at a young age and produces flowers mostly in spring, but can also continue blooming into the summer. Magnolia liliiflora is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia liliiflora. Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' was introduced from Japan into Britain in 1861 by John Gould Veitch.

In mid-spring, Magnolia x loebneri 'Leonard Messel' becomes adorned with an abundance of deep lilac buds that ultimately unfold into soft lilac-pink flowers with white interiors. These flowers can reach up to 12cm in width and contain as many as 12 tepals. Magnolia x loebneri 'Leonard Messel' starts blooming at a young age and is a fantastic option for a street tree. Magnolia x loebneri is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia kobus and Magnolia stellata that was first produced before 1914 by Max Löbner in Pillnitz, Dresden, Germany. Magnolia x loebneri 'Leonard Messel' was raised by James Comber, the head gardener at the Nymans garden in West Sussex, England, and named after Leonard Messel, the then owner of the Nymans estate. Magnolia x loebneri 'Leonard Messel' was registered in 1955.

During the spring season, Magnolia x loebneri 'Merrill' is covered in a blanket of star-shaped white flowers, which typically range from 10cm to 15cm in width and can contain as many as 15 tepals. It starts blooming at a young age and has a spreading growth habit, featuring a broad crown. Magnolia x loebneri is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia kobus and Magnolia stellata that was first produced before 1914 by Max Löbner in Pillnitz, Dresden, Germany. Magnolia 'Lois' produces well-formed, cup-shaped blooms with bright-yellow color, which emerge from green buds. The flowers are up to 8cm long and have nine tepals. They typically appear alongside the leaves during a period of four to five weeks in mid to late-spring. Magnolia 'Lois' has a rounded, conical shape and is considered to be one of the best yellow magnolias available. Magnolia 'Manchu Fan' produces medium-sized, goblet-shaped flowers that are cream-white in color with a purple-pink flush at the base. The flowers typically have 9 tepals and bloom prolifically from an early age during mid-spring. Magnolia 'Manchu Fan' has a vigorous growth habit with an erect, pyramidal form. Magnolia 'Manchu Fan' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia x veitchii. Magnolia 'Manchu Fan' was produced by Todd Gresham sometime from 1955 to 1969 at his home in Santa Cruz, California, United States.

Magnolia 'Margaret Helen' produces cup and saucer to bowl-shaped blooms with pointed petals that are rose-red at the base and gradually fade to purple-pink near the tips. The flowers typically have 12 tepals, are about 12cm wide by 6cm deep, and have a light, fruity fragrance. Magnolia 'Margaret Helen' has an upright, vase-shaped growth habit when young, which becomes more rounded as it ages. Magnolia 'Margaret Helen' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' and Magnolia campbellii. Magnolia 'Margaret Helen' was raised in the early 1990s by Vance Hooper for Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and was named after Vance's mother.

Michelia 'Melody' is a stunning pyramidal grower. It produces large, broad, thickly-petalled, white flowers that open widely and cover the branches in late winter. The flowers are highly scented, providing an intoxicating fragrance. Michelia 'Melody' thrives in a sheltered garden that is free from late frosts. Michelia 'Melody' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Melody', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Melody' is evergreen and a hybrid between Magnolia laevifolia and Magnolia maudiae. Magnolia 'Melody' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Milky Way' produces large, heavily-textured, ice-white flowers with a soft-pink base. The cup-shaped blooms are deliciously fragrant and appear in spring. Magnolia 'Milky Way' has an upright, neatly-rounded growth habit, making it ideal for smaller gardens. It starts blooming at a young age. Magnolia 'Milky Way' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia 'Mark Jury'. Magnolia 'Milky Way' was raised by Felix Jury in New Zealand and was introduced in 1988.

Michelia 'Paton Pink' has excellent, dark-green leaves that densely cover its pyramidal growth habit. In the spring season, it produces pink, tulip-shaped flowers. This is a healthy and easy-to-grow plant that retains its leaves well. Michelia 'Paton Pink' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Paton Pink', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Paton Pink' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Thirkettle Nurseries in Nelson, New Zealand.

Michelia 'Princess Cinderella' is a tidy grower that produces flowers during both the winter to spring and summer to autumn seasons. The cream-white flowers are lightly perfumed and contrast beautifully with the deep-green, leathery foliage. Michelia 'Princess Cinderella' is versatile and can be grown as a specimen, but it is also easily maintained as a hedge or screen. Michelia 'Princess Cinderella' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Princess Cinderella', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Purple Sensation' produces large, luscious, cup and saucer-shaped flowers in pink-purple during mid-spring. Magnolia 'Purple Sensation' has an upright, columnar growth habit and starts blooming at a young age. Magnolia 'Purple Sensation' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora and Magnolia campbellii 'Lanarth'. Magnolia 'Red As' produces goblet-shaped, firmly-textured flowers in a dark purple-red color. The flowers bloom in mid-spring and are well-suited for smaller gardens. Magnolia 'Red As' starts blooming at a young age and is an excellent option for a street tree. It has an upright growth habit. Magnolia 'Royal Purple' has a narrow, upright growth habit and produces cup-shaped flowers in a rose-purple color. The flowers bloom during the early to mid-spring season. Magnolia 'Royal Purple' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and potentially a seedling of Magnolia sprengeri var. diva 'Diva'. Magnolia 'Royal Purple' was bred by Peter Cave in New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Serene' produces large, rounded, bowl-shaped flowers in a deep rose-pink color with ivory-white interiors. Magnolia 'Shirazz' produces large, spectacular, tulip-shaped flowers in a rich purple-red color with pale-purple interiors. Magnolia 'Shirazz' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia denudata and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia sieboldii has a wide, multi-stemmed, and spreading growth habit. It produces pendant, cup-shaped flowers in a creamy-white color with prominent crimson stamens throughout the summer season. Following the flowers, crimson seed pods appear. It is recommended to plant this species on a bank or raise it up so that the exquisite flowers can be viewed from below. Magnolia sieboldii is deciduous and native to China, Japan, and Korea. Learn more about Magnolia sieboldii.

During late winter to early spring, Magnolia 'Sir Harold Hillier' produces large, goblet-shaped flowers that are pure white in color. These flowers can reach a width of up to 30cm. Magnolia 'Sir Harold Hillier' itself has a broad, conical shape and typically begins to flower around three years after it has been planted. Magnolia 'Sir Harold Hillier' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia campbellii 'Alba' and possibly Magnolia denudata. Magnolia 'Sir Harold Hillier' was selected by Nigel Holman before 2000 in Cornwall, England.

The flowers of Michelia 'Snow Dove' are a pure, ice-white color and emit a delightful sweet and spicy scent. They bloom abundantly during the spring season. Michelia 'Snow Dove' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Snow Dove', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Snow Dove' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia maudiae and Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia 'Solar Flair' produces tulip-shaped flowers that are cream-yellow in color, with occasional hints of pink at the base, emerging from green buds. Magnolia 'Solar Flair' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' and Magnolia 'Gold Star'. The flowers of Magnolia x soulangeana have a goblet shape and are cream-white, with a pink-purple flush at the base and white interiors. They bloom from an early age and Magnolia x soulangeana is easy to cultivate. The flowering takes place in mid-spring. Magnolia x soulangeana is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia denudata and Magnolia liliiflora. Learn more about Magnolia x soulangeana. Magnolia x soulangeana probably occurred spontaneously in Japanese gardens or nurseries a long time ago. However, it was first recognised from deliberate crosses made by Étienne Soulange-Bodin (1774 - 1846). Étienne was a retired cavalry officer in Napoleon's army who became a plantsman and gardener. He first made the Magnolia x soulangeana cross in 1820 at his home in Fromont, France.

Magnolia x soulangeana 'Old Port' features wine-red flowers with an off-white interior that bloom in the spring before the leaves appear. Michelia 'Star Bright' is covered in large, crisp-white, star-shaped flowers that emerge from long, velvet-brown buds in late winter. Michelia 'Star Bright' features beautiful, dark-green leaves, and has a pyramidal form with horizontal branches radiating from it. Michelia 'Star Bright' is an excellent choice for clipping into any desired shape. Magnolia 'Star Wars' produces rich purple-pink flowers with pale-pink interiors that appear before or with the new spring leaves. The flowers are typically 15cm wide, but can occasionally reach up to 28cm wide. Magnolia 'Star Wars' begins to flower in the spring from an early age and continues to bloom for six to eight weeks. Magnolia stellata forms a compact, rounded, multi-branched tree, making it an excellent choice for smaller gardens. Magnolia stellata produces star-shaped, pure-white, and fragrant flowers from mid-winter until the leaves grow in the spring. Additionally, it begins to flower from an early age. Magnolia stellata 'Dawn' is considered one of the best pink-flowering star magnolias. Its flowers are pink in bud, opening to a blush-pink color and fading to white-pink. The flowers have between 40 to 45 tepals and are a lighter pink shade than those of Magnolia stellata 'Jane Platt'. Magnolia stellata 'Dawn' is a strong and vigorous grower, and it produces an abundance of flowers in early spring. Magnolia stellata is deciduous and native to Japan. Magnolia stellata 'Jane Platt' forms a compact, densely-branched, spreading tree that is highly desirable. It produces deep-pink buds that open to frilly flowers of white with pink undersides. The flowers usually have between 20 to 30 tepals and are a darker pink shade than those of Magnolia stellata 'Dawn'. Magnolia stellata 'Jane Platt' is very pretty and begins to flower in early spring from an early age. Magnolia stellata is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Magnolia stellata. Magnolia stellata 'King Rose' is a compact, rounded, multi-branched grower that is an excellent choice for smaller gardens. Magnolia stellata 'Rosea' is a compact, rounded, multi-branched grower that is an excellent choice for smaller gardens. Magnolia stellata 'Rosea' produces star-shaped, blush-pink, and fragrant flowers from deep-pink buds in mid-winter until the leaves grow in the spring. The flowers usually have up to 13 tepals, and Magnolia stellata 'Rosea' begins to flower from an early age. Magnolia stellata is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Magnolia stellata. Magnolia stellata 'Rosea' was imported from Japan in 1885 to the United States by the Domoto Brothers Nursery in Oakland, California and in 1893 to Britain by James Herbert Veitch (1868 - 1907).

Magnolia stellata 'Royal Star' is a compact, multi-stemmed grower that produces star-shaped white flowers with a touch of pink. Magnolia stellata 'Waterlily' is a vigorous, compact, multi-branched grower that produces large, semi-double flowers with many petals. Magnolia 'Strawberry Fields' produces large, vibrant, strawberry-red flowers in early spring. It begins to flower from an early age and is an excellent choice for a street tree. Magnolia 'Sundance' produces elegant yellow flowers which appear on the bare branches in mid-spring. The flowers can reach up to 20cm wide. Magnolia 'Sundance' has a tidy, conical shape with slender branches, and it begins to flower from an early age. Magnolia 'Sundance' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata and Magnolia denudata. Magnolia 'Sundance' was raised before 1986 by August Kehr in North Carolina, United States from seed provided by Joe McDaniel in Illinois, United States.

Magnolia 'Sunsation' has green buds that open up to goblet-shaped, yellow flowers with a green tinge and a pink flush at the base. The flowers are sizable, up to 17cm wide. Magnolia 'Sunsation' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' and Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Elizabeth'. Magnolia 'Sunsation' was selected in 1997 by August Kehr in North Carolina, United States and was introduced in 2000.

Magnolia 'Susan' produces erect, long, tapered, deep claret-purple buds that open up to red-purple flowers with white-tinged purple-red interiors. The flowers can reach up to 15cm wide and have six tepals. They bloom in great abundance in late spring, from an early age. Additionally, the flowers are slightly fragrant. Magnolia 'Sweet Merlot' produces medium-sized, globe-shaped flowers that are colored purple-red with pale red-pink interiors. Magnolia 'Vulcan' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia campbellii and Magnolia liliiflora. Magnolia 'Vulcan' was raised by Felix Jury in New Zealand and was introduced in 1989.

Magnolia 'Yellow Fever' produces cup-shaped, fragrant flowers that appear just before the leaves in mid-spring. The flowers are initially yellow with a light-pink flush at the base before fading to cream as they open. Magnolia 'Yellow Fever' is an upright, conical grower and begins to flower from an early age, making it an excellent choice for a street tree. Magnolia 'Yellow Fever' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata and Magnolia denudata. Magnolia 'Yellow Fever' was selected before 1984 by Ken Durio in Louisiana, United States.

Magnolia 'Yellow Lantern' produces large yellow flowers with a hint of pink at the base, and the flowers bloom in mid-spring. Magnolia 'Yellow Lantern' has an upright and symmetrical growing habit. Magnolia 'Yellow Lantern' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata var. subcordata 'Miss Honeybee' and Magnolia x soulangeana 'Alexandrina'. Magnolia 'Yellow Lantern' was raised before 1985 by Phil Savage in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, United States.

Malus 'Arrow Gold' produces bunches of large, white-pink blossoms in mid-spring, and in the autumn, there is a profusion of large, clear-yellow crabapples that grow on the branches. These crabapples can be used to make jelly. Malus 'Arrow Gold' is an excellent cultivar for pleaching or espaliering, and its leaves turn yellow and orange in the autumn. Malus 'Arrow Gold' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was bred in Arrowtown, New Zealand.

Malus 'Autumn Gold' produces stunning pear-shaped, gold crabapples in the autumn and single white blossoms in the spring. It is an excellent cultivar for making jelly. Malus 'Autumn Gold' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand (PVR 35633).

Malus baccata 'Jackii' is a broad-headed, upright grower with dark-green leaves that can reach up to 11cm long. In the spring, shell-pink buds open up to large, white flowers that are approximately 4cm wide. Additionally, small, purple-red crabapples that are about 1cm wide can be found on Malus baccata 'Jackii' in the autumn. Malus baccata 'Jackii' is an excellent all-round tree and is resistant to disease and pollution. It is ideal for planting in avenues and as a street tree, and its leaves turn yellow and orange in the autumn. Malus baccata is deciduous and native to Russia, Mongolia, China, Korea, Bhutan, India, and Nepal. Learn more about Malus baccata. Malus baccata 'Jackii' was collected in 1905 by J. G. Jack in Seoul, South Korea for the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University in Boston, Massachusetts, United States.

Malus 'Ballerina Maypole' has a columnar growth habit and produces large carmine-red blossoms that are nestled among the new copper-red leaves in the spring. In the autumn, large dark-red crabapples stud the branches of Malus 'Ballerina Maypole'. Malus 'Ballerina Maypole' is also resistant to disease. Malus 'Ballerina Maypole' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus domestica 'Wijcik McIntosh' and Malus 'Baskatong'. Malus 'Ballerina Maypole' was developed by Kenneth Tobutt at the East Malling Research Station in Kent, England and was introduced in 1988.

Malus 'Barbara Ann' produces fragrant, double pink blossoms in the spring that contrast with the new red leaves. Malus 'Barbara Ann' has an upright and open growing habit, making it well-suited for training, such as espaliering. In the autumn, small dark red-purple crabapples can be found on Malus 'Barbara Ann'. Malus 'Barbara Ann' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus 'Dorothea' and Malus x purpurea.

Malus 'Coronet Peak' is a neat-growing shade tree with horizontal spreading branches. It produces pink buds that open to pure-white blossoms in the spring and a mass of gold-yellow crabapples in the autumn. Malus 'Coronet Peak' is deciduous and not native to New Zealand.

Malus domestica 'Braeburn' is one of the world's top commercial apples, with delicious, crisp, juicy flesh and a superb sweet-tart flavour. It is an excellent keeper, and its fruits can be harvested from late summer to mid-autumn. Malus domestica 'Braeburn' produces pink buds that open to white flowers in the spring. It is partially self-fertile, but it is best to plant it with another cultivar that has a similar bloom period, such as Malus domestica 'Fuji' or Malus domestica 'Granny Smith'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Braeburn' was discovered in 1952 as a chance seedling by O. Moran in the Moutere Hills near Motueka, New Zealand and was cultivated by the Williams Brothers nursery in Motueka, New Zealand.

Malus domestica 'Cox's Orange Pippin' produces sweet, orange-red apples with rich and nutty-flavoured flesh that is very aromatic. The apples ripen from mid-summer to early-autumn. Malus domestica 'Cox's Orange Pippin' also produces pink buds that open to white flowers in the spring. It is partially self-fertile, but it is best to plant it with another cultivar that has a similar bloom period, such as Malus domestica 'Gala', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', Malus domestica 'Initial', Malus domestica 'Royal Gala', Malus domestica 'Freyberg', Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise', and Malus domestica 'Granny Smith'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Cox's Orange Pippin' was first grown in 1825 by Richard Cox in Colnbrook, England and was introduced for sale by the 1850s by Charles Turner.

Malus domestica 'Freyberg' produces sweet and refreshing, golden-green apples in the autumn. Malus domestica 'Freyberg' also produces pink buds that open to white flowers in the spring. It is partially self-fertile, but it is best to plant it with another cultivar that has a similar bloom period, such as Malus domestica 'Fuji', Malus domestica 'Gala', and Malus domestica 'Granny Smith'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Freyberg' was developed in the early 1900s by James Hutton Kidd in Greytown, New Zealand. The seedlings he developed were transferred to the New Zealand Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, who released Malus domestica 'Freyberg' in 1959. Malus domestica 'Freyberg' was named after Bernard Freyberg who served as Governor-General of New Zealand from 1946 to 1952.

Malus domestica 'Fuji' produces large, sweet, crisp, red-skinned apples, similar to 'Red Delicious'. The fruit ripens in late autumn and is excellent for eating and storage. Malus domestica 'Fuji' is a vigorous grower and produces pink buds that open to white flowers in spring. It requires Malus domestica 'Braeburn', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', or Malus domestica 'Red Delicious' for pollination and fruit production. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Fuji' was developed in the late 1930s at Tohoku Research Station in Fujisaki, Aomori, Japan and was released into commerce in 1962.

Malus domestica 'Gala' bears yellow-skinned apples with a red flush, and its juicy, creamy flesh boasts a rich flavor. The fruit becomes ripe from late summer to early autumn, while the pink buds unfurl into white flowers during spring. Although partially self-fertile, optimal fruit production requires a cultivar such as Malus domestica 'Fuji', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', or Malus domestica 'Red Delicious' that has a comparable bloom period. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Gala' was developed in the early 1900s by James Hutton Kidd in Greytown, New Zealand. The seedlings he developed were transferred to the New Zealand Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, who released Malus domestica 'Gala'.

The fruit has a medium size, is ribbed and crowned, and features bright orange-red flesh with red stripes over gold, along with inconspicuous, fine russet dots. Pink buds turn into white flowers during spring. Malus domestica 'Galaxy' is partially self-fertile, but it is best to have a cultivar with a similar bloom period such as Malus domestica 'Fuji', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', or Malus domestica 'Red Delicious' for optimal fruit production. The fruit becomes ripe from late summer to early autumn. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Galaxy' was discovered in 1985 by Kenneth Kiddle at Huarangi Farm in Havelock North, New Zealand (USPP6955).

This apple cultivar is suitable for desserts and functions as an excellent pollinator for other apple trees. The fruit is green-yellow, but it turns yellow as it ages, and the apples taste honeyed and very sweet when they ripen well. The fruit becomes ripe in late autumn, and the pink buds transform into white flowers during spring. While Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious' is self-fertile, planting it with Malus domestica 'Fuji', Malus domestica 'Gala', or Malus domestica 'Red Delicious' can lead to better crops. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious' was discovered at the Mullins' family farm in Clay County, West Virginia, United States and was first sold in 1914 by Stark Brothers Nurseries in Louisiana, Missouri, United States.

Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' bears a green-skinned apple that is excellent for both eating and cooking, featuring a good, crisp texture. The fruit is large and ripens in mid-autumn, and it is known for being an excellent keeper. During spring, the pink buds of Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' develop into white flowers. Although Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' is self-fertile, planting it with Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious' or Malus domestica 'Red Delicious' can lead to better crops. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' originated in 1868 in Eastwood, New South Wales, Australia and was named after Maria Ann Smith who discovered and then propagated Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' from a chance seedling.

Malus domestica 'Initial' produces a large red apple that is highly resistant to black spot disease. The fruit has excellent flavor, with low acidity, high sugar content, and a strong aroma. The fruit ripens from late summer to early autumn, while the pink buds develop into white flowers during spring. To ensure proper pollination, Malus domestica 'Initial' requires cross-pollination from other cultivars such as Malus domestica 'Gala', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', Malus domestica 'Granny Smith', Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise', and Malus domestica 'Royal Gala'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Initial' was developed before 2003 by the Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique (INRA) in France (PVR 2710).

Malus domestica 'Initial/Sir Prize' is a double apple. Malus domestica 'Sir Prize' is a type of large yellow apple similar to Golden Delicious but with a blush. The fruit is very juicy with crisp, tender flesh, and it is known for being an excellent keeper. The fruit becomes ripe in mid to late autumn, and during spring, the pink buds on Malus domestica 'Initial/Sir Prize' open up to white flowers. See Malus domestica 'Initial' for description. First image is of Malus domestica 'Initial', second is of Malus domestica 'Sir Prize'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Sir Prize' was developed in 1955 by the breeding cooperative of Purdue University in Indiana, United States, Rutgers University in New Jersey, United States, and Illinois University in Illinois, United States and was released into commerce in 1975.

This apple variety is an excellent choice for organic growers as it is highly resistant to black spot disease and requires little, if any, spraying. The fruit has a red blush, with a crisp, juicy, sweet-tart flavor, and Malus domestica 'Liberty' is known to be a heavy bearer. The fruit becomes ripe from mid to late autumn, and in spring, the pink buds develop into white flowers. While Malus domestica 'Liberty' is self-fertile, it is best to plant it with early-flowering cultivars such as Malus domestica 'Braeburn' to achieve the best crop. Additionally, the fruit is an excellent keeper. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Liberty' was developed in 1955 by the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station in Geneva, New York, United States and was first released into commerce in 1978.

Malus domestica 'Liberty/Sir Prize' is a double apple. Malus domestica 'Sir Prize' is a type of large yellow apple similar to Golden Delicious but with a blush. The fruit is very juicy with crisp, tender flesh, and it is known for being an excellent keeper. The fruit becomes ripe in mid to late autumn, and during spring, the pink buds on Malus domestica 'Liberty/Sir Prize' open up to white flowers. See Malus domestica 'Liberty' for description. First image is of Malus domestica 'Liberty', second is of Malus domestica 'Sir Prize'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Sir Prize' was developed in 1955 by the breeding cooperative of Purdue University in Indiana, United States, Rutgers University in New Jersey, United States, and Illinois University in Illinois, United States and was released into commerce in 1975.

Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise' is an excellent choice for eating, featuring a good, crisp texture, and light-green skin striped with red. Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise' bears large fruit that ripens in mid-autumn, and it is disease-resistant. During spring, the pink buds of Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise' develop into white flowers. Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise' potentially has great health benefits, find out more at Heritage Food Crops. To ensure proper pollination, Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise' requires cross-pollination from other cultivars such as Malus domestica 'Gala', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', Malus domestica 'Granny Smith', Malus domestica 'Initial', and Malus domestica 'Royal Gala'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise' was discovered in April 2000 by Mark Christensen and friends in a remote part of the central North Island, New Zealand.

Malus domestica 'Pacific Rose' produces apples with clear, rose-pink skin and firm, crispy, and juicy flesh with a rich and sweet taste. The fruit becomes ripe in mid-autumn, while the pink buds on Malus domestica 'Pacific Rose' open to white flowers during spring. To ensure proper pollination, Malus domestica 'Pacific Rose' requires cross-pollination from other cultivars such as Malus domestica 'Gala', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', Malus domestica 'Granny Smith', Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise', Malus domestica 'Initial', and Malus domestica 'Royal Gala'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Pacific Rose' was developed before 1989 by the Horticulture and Food Research Institute of New Zealand (PVR 624).

Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' produces medium-sized apples that are red-streaked with fine-textured flesh that is crisp, sweet, and juicy. The fruit matures in mid-summer, while the pink buds on Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' develop into white flowers during spring. To ensure proper pollination, Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' requires cross-pollination from other cultivars such as Malus domestica 'Gala', Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', Malus domestica 'Granny Smith', Malus domestica 'Monty's Surprise', and Malus domestica 'Initial'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' was developed in the early 1900s by James Hutton Kidd in Greytown, New Zealand. The seedlings he developed were transferred to the New Zealand Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, who released Malus domestica 'Royal Gala'.

Malus domestica 'Royal Gala/Braeburn' is a double apple. The pink buds on Malus domestica 'Royal Gala/Braeburn' open up to white flowers during spring. See Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' and Malus domestica 'Braeburn' for descriptions. First image is of Malus domestica 'Royal Gala', second is of Malus domestica 'Braeburn'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica.

Malus domestica 'Royal Gala/Golden Delicious' is a double apple. The pink buds on Malus domestica 'Royal Gala/Golden Delicious' open up to white flowers during spring. See Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' and Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious' for descriptions. First image is of Malus domestica 'Royal Gala', second is of Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica.

Malus domestica 'Royal Gala/Granny Smith' is a double apple. The pink buds on Malus domestica 'Royal Gala/Granny Smith' open up to white flowers during spring. See Malus domestica 'Royal Gala' and Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' for descriptions. First image is of Malus domestica 'Royal Gala', second is of Malus domestica 'Granny Smith'. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica.

Malus domestica 'Wandin Glory' is a weeping apple tree that produces fruit that becomes ripe in mid-summer, featuring red-green skin and delicious sweet flesh. During spring, the pink buds on Malus domestica 'Wandin Glory' open to white flowers. While Malus domestica 'Wandin Glory' is partially self-fertile, it is best to plant it with Malus domestica 'Golden Delicious', Malus domestica 'Gala', or Malus domestica 'Granny Smith' to achieve the best crop. Malus domestica is deciduous and native to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and China. Learn more about Malus domestica. Malus domestica 'Wandin Glory' was developed in Australia.

synonyms: Malus x gloriosa 'Oekonomierat Echtermeyer', Malus 'Dekon Echtermeyer', Malus 'Hugo Echtermeyer', Malus 'Pink Weeper', Malus x purpurea 'Pendula', Malus x purpurea 'Echtermeyer'
description: Malus 'Echtermeyer' has a graceful, wide-spreading canopy and produces red-tinted new leaves that change to purple and then to purple-green over the summer. In the spring, Malus 'Echtermeyer' produces beautiful rose-crimson flowers, and in the autumn, small red-purple crabapples follow. Malus 'Echtermeyer' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus x scheideckeri 'Exzellenz Thiel' and Malus sieversii f. niedzwetzkyana. Malus 'Echtermeyer' was introduced in 1914 by Späth nursery in Berlin, Germany.

Malus 'Ellerslie' is an excellent choice and produces red new leaves that change to purple-green throughout the summer, and then become red again in autumn. In the spring, Malus 'Ellerslie' features dark-red buds that open to soft-crimson flowers, followed by small, red crabapples in the autumn. Malus 'Ellerslie' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand (PVR 1025).

Malus 'Flamingo' is hardy and has a columnar habit. It features double red buds that open up to deep-pink flowers in spring. The new foliage of Malus 'Flamingo' is a deep burgundy-red to plum-purple, changing to purple-green during the summer. In the autumn, Malus 'Flamingo' produces deep-red to purple crabapples. Malus 'Flamingo' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by John McLaren in Cromwell, New Zealand (PVR 33152).

This strong-growing tree can be trained to form a horizontal canopy of arching branches. During early spring, Malus x floribunda produces a mass of crimson-red buds that open to white flowers with a hint of pink. In the autumn, Malus x floribunda develops small red crabapples, and they are often quickly consumed by birds. Malus x floribunda is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and probably a hybrid between Malus toringo and Malus baccata. Malus x floribunda was first introduced to Europe from Japanese cultivation sometime in the 19th century by Philipp Franz von Siebold (1796 - 1866).

This round-headed tree is adorned with white blossoms on its branches during the spring season. In the autumn, Malus 'Gorgeous' produces spectacular crops of bright crimson-red fruit that hang like cherries on long thin stalks. These crabapples are ideal for making superb jelly. Malus 'Gorgeous' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus x zumi and Malus halliana. Malus 'Gorgeous' was raised by Hayward Wright in Auckland, New Zealand and was introduced in 1925.

This vase-shaped tree features a profusion of large, pink-white, semi-double flowers that emerge from pink buds during late spring. Malus ioensis 'Plena' produces lovely yellow, orange, and red autumn leaves but hardly any fruit. Due to its characteristics, Malus ioensis 'Plena' is an excellent option as a street tree. Malus ioensis is deciduous and native to the United States. Learn more about Malus ioensis. Malus ioensis 'Plena' was discovered in about 1840 by E. A. Bechtel in the wild in Illinois, United States and was introduced in 1888.

This rounded tree produces masses of white blossoms from red buds in mid-spring. It is considered one of the best cultivars for large production of brilliantly coloured crabapples, which are bright-crimson, flushed yellow, and orange, and appear in the autumn. The fruit is excellent for making jelly, and Malus 'Jack Humm' is self-fertile, meaning it does not require cross-pollination to produce fruit. Malus 'Jack Humm' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus 'Gorgeous' and Malus 'John Downie'. Malus 'Jack Humm' was developed in New Zealand.

This upright, compact tree becomes covered in mid-spring with large, fragrant, pure-white blossoms that last for a long period. Malus 'Jelly King' produces huge crops of medium-sized, pink-red crabapples in the autumn. It is an excellent option as a street tree and is resistant to disease. Additionally, Malus 'Jelly King' is self-fertile, so it doesn't need another tree to produce fruit. Malus 'Jelly King' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand (PVR 1390).

Malus 'Kaitoke' has attractive purple-red new leaves during the spring season, which turn purple-green by summer. Malus 'Kaitoke' produces masses of crimson flower buds that open to carmine-red blossoms in spring. It is well-suited for smaller gardens and produces purple-red crabapples in the summer. Malus 'Kaitoke' has semi-weeping branches, which add to its visual appeal. Malus 'Kaitoke' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

This flat-topped tree has wide-spreading, horizontal branches. Rose-red buds open to pink-white blossoms in spring, and they sit among the emerging purple-green new leaves. Malus 'Lambada' produces purple crabapples in the autumn season. Malus 'Lambada' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

This round-headed tree is smothered with clusters of slightly-fragrant, vivid, wine-red flowers in mid-spring. The purple spring leaves turn purple-green throughout the summer season, and Malus x moerlandsii 'Profusion' produces small, blood-red fruit in the autumn. It also has yellow and orange autumn leaves, which add to its visual appeal. Malus x moerlandsii 'Profusion' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus x purpurea 'Lemoinei' and Malus toringo. Malus x moerlandsii 'Profusion' was developed before 1938 by Simon Doorenbos at The Hague Parks Department in The Hague, Netherlands.

Malus 'Mt Aurum' has an upright, pyramidal habit and produces pink buds that open to white flowers in the spring. It produces large, gold-yellow fruit in heavy clusters during the autumn season, which are great for making jelly. Malus 'Mt Aurum' also has yellow autumn leaves, which add to its visual appeal. Additionally, Malus 'Mt Aurum' is self-fertile and doesn't need another tree to produce fruit. Malus 'Mt Aurum' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Malus 'Mt Earnslaw' has an upright, pyramidal growth habit. It produces pure-white spring blossoms, and heavy clusters of oval-shaped fruit in the autumn season. The fruit is soft-red, flushed with yellow and is great for making jelly. Malus 'Mt Earnslaw' has a neat-growing habit and is self-fertile, meaning it doesn't require another tree for pollination. Malus 'Mt Earnslaw' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Malus 'Pearlie Emma' produces beautiful pink-white flowers in the spring and red-yellow crabapples in the autumn season. Malus 'Pearlie Emma' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand (PVR 1389).

This is a weeping tree with wide-spreading branches that cascade to the ground. In the spring, clusters of pink buds open to reveal white flowers with a pink blush. In the autumn season, Malus 'Red Jade' produces small scarlet crabapples. Malus 'Red Jade' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a seedling of Malus x scheideckeri 'Exzellenz Thiel'. Malus 'Red Jade' was raised in 1935 by George Reed at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens in New York City, New York, United States and was introduced in 1953.

This is a compact, upright tree that produces a profusion of semi-double, dark-pink blossoms in the spring season. The bright-red new leaves turn green throughout the summer. Small, red crabapples follow in the autumn season. It's an excellent street tree. Malus 'Red Top' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

An ideal choice for confined spaces that need some vertical appeal, this slender, erect, columnar tree is adorned with red buds that burst into big, dark-pink blossoms in spring, along with new bronze-red leaves. Come autumn, Malus 'Strathmore' produces red to purple fruit resembling cherries. With its superb suitability as a street tree, this specimen is sure to impress. Malus 'Strathmore' is deciduous and not native to New Zealand.

In spring, stunning scarlet-red flowers are produced, while from early autumn to late winter, clusters of dark-red, oval-shaped crabapples can be seen. Malus 'Tom Matthews' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand.

Beautiful gold-yellow fruit with yellow flesh are produced in autumn that birds adore. The crabapples are also great for making jelly. Produces stunning single, white blossoms in spring. Malus 'Tom's Gold' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand.

In autumn, Malus 'Tom's Orange' yields beautiful orange fruit that are a favorite of birds, and the crabapples are also perfect for making jelly. Furthermore, in spring, Malus 'Tom's Orange' produces stunning single white blossoms. Malus 'Tom's Orange' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand.

Malus 'Tom's Red' produces beautiful red fruit in autumn, which are highly sought after by birds, and the crabapples are also ideal for making jelly. Additionally, in spring, Malus 'Tom's Red' produces stunning single white blossoms. Malus 'Tom's Red' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed by Matthews Nurseries in Whanganui, New Zealand.

Malus toringo 'Snowbright' has a round-headed form with arching branches. In mid-spring, pale salmon-pink buds open to reveal pure-white blossoms that cover the branches. During summer and autumn, Malus toringo 'Snowbright' produces marble-sized crimson-red crabapples. Additionally, in the fall season, the leaves of Malus toringo 'Snowbright' turn a showy yellow-orange color. Malus toringo is deciduous and native to China, Japan, North Korea, and South Korea. Learn more about Malus toringo. Malus toringo 'Snowbright' was developed before 1989 by the Horticulture and Food Research Institute of New Zealand in Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 629).

Malus trilobata has an erect, pyramidal growth habit, with sturdy stems that bear gorgeous, deeply-lobed leaves resembling those of a maple tree. The leaves are glossy green during the summer months and transform into brilliant shades of red and orange in the autumn season. In the spring, Malus trilobata produces large, single white blossoms, but it hardly produces any fruit. Overall, this specimen makes an excellent street tree. Malus trilobata is deciduous and native to Bulgaria, Greece, Israel, Lebanon, Syria, and Turkey. Learn more about Malus trilobata.

Malus tschonoskii is a beautiful, pyramidal grower with spring leaves that have a silver-white, felted appearance. During summer, the leaves of Malus tschonoskii are bright green and have a white, felted underside. In the fall, Malus tschonoskii puts on a magnificent display of orange, red, and purple leaves. Additionally, Malus tschonoskii produces white flowers in the spring, but hardly any fruit. This makes it an excellent choice as a street tree. Malus tschonoskii is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Malus tschonoskii.

Malus 'Van Eseltine' is columnar in shape, with erect branches. In the spring, large, pink-white, semi-double flowers open from scarlet buds, creating a stunning display. During autumn, the yellow fruit of Malus 'Van Eseltine' become flushed with red. Malus 'Van Eseltine' is ideal for smaller gardens and is also a great choice as a street tree. In the fall, the leaves of Malus 'Van Eseltine' turn a beautiful shade of yellow. Malus 'Van Eseltine' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Malus x arnoldiana and Malus spectabilis. Malus 'Van Eseltine' was developed by Glen Parker Van Eseltine at the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station in Geneva, New York, United States and was introduced in 1930.

This crabapple is a spectacular fruiting tree that produces large, crimson-red fruit in the autumn season. In the spring, Malus 'Wright's Scarlet' produces white blossoms, and its spreading canopy of branches creates a beautiful display. During the fall, the leaves of Malus 'Wright's Scarlet' turn a lovely shade of yellow. Malus 'Wright's Scarlet' is great for making jelly, and it is self-fertile. Malus 'Wright's Scarlet' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand and named after Hayward Wright, a plant breeder who lived in Auckland, New Zealand in the early 20th century.

This quick-growing tree features a stout trunk and an open form with wide-spreading branches that provide light shade. Melia azedarach produces green, pinnate leaves that appear alongside the sweetly-scented, caramel-colored panicles of lilac-pink flowers in late spring. During the fall, the leaves of Melia azedarach turn a clear yellow color. It can withstand strong winds and drought conditions. However, it is important to note that the fruit of Melia azedarach are poisonous to both humans and animals. Melia azedarach is deciduous and native to India and China. Learn more about Melia azedarach.

Melicope ternata forms a rounded, large bush of shiny, lime-green leaves. It grows well in sandy soils that are sheltered from the coastal winds. Melicope ternata can tolerate light frosts. Small, yellow-green flowers are produced from late winter to late spring. From late spring to early autumn, Melicope ternata produces brown fruit that, once ripe, open to reveal a black seed that birds are fond of. Melicope ternata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Melicope ternata.

Melicytus chathamicus has large, oval-shaped green leaves with toothed margins. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in the spring season. Additionally, Melicytus chathamicus is able to tolerate cold, windy, and coastal conditions. Melicytus chathamicus is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the Chatham Islands. Learn more about Melicytus chathamicus.

This is a multi-stemmed, bushy tree that is perfect for quick screening. It is hardy and can thrive in dry conditions in both sun and semi-shade. Melicytus ramiflorus features attractive green leaves, and during the autumn season, it produces purple berries. In addition, small, green-yellow flowers appear on Melicytus ramiflorus from late spring to late summer. Melicytus ramiflorus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Melicytus ramiflorus.

Meryta sinclairii has a striking appearance with its tropical look, featuring large, paddle-shaped leaves that are glossy and light-green in color. It thrives best in a sunny, frost-free position and can tolerate coastal exposure. When grown on the coast, Meryta sinclairii has a more bushy and lower growth habit. Additionally, Meryta sinclairii is an excellent choice for growing in containers. Meryta sinclairii is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the Three Kings Islands. Learn more about Meryta sinclairii.

Metasequoia glyptostroboides is handsome all year round and has a slender, pyramidal form similar to that of the California Redwood. It makes an excellent specimen tree with its upright growth habit. Metasequoia glyptostroboides features soft, ferny leaves that are bright green during the summer season and turn red-brown to orange-brown as the season changes. For optimal growth, Metasequoia glyptostroboides prefers soil that is able to retain moisture. Metasequoia glyptostroboides is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Metasequoia glyptostroboides.

Metasequoia glyptostroboides 'Gold Rush' is a conical grower and has soft, ferny foliage. The cypress-like timber of Metasequoia glyptostroboides 'Gold Rush' is moderately durable. It prefers to grow in damp to wet sites. During the spring season, the foliage is a deep gold-yellow color and matures to green-yellow during the summer. As the autumn season approaches, the foliage turns red-brown to orange-brown. Metasequoia glyptostroboides is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Metasequoia glyptostroboides. Metasequoia glyptostroboides 'Gold Rush' was raised in 1974 at the Kameyama Breeding Station of the Institute for Forest Tree Improvement in Mie Prefecture, Japan.

This is a rapidly-growing conifer with a delicate, ferny appearance. It has a narrower and more pyramidal form compared to Metasequoia glyptostroboides. Metasequoia glyptostroboides 'Sheridan Spire' has shaggy and attractive red-brown bark. The airy, dark-green foliage transforms into a beautiful red-brown to orange-brown color during the autumn season. Metasequoia glyptostroboides 'Sheridan Spire' prefers to grow in damp to wet sites. Metasequoia glyptostroboides is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Metasequoia glyptostroboides. Metasequoia glyptostroboides 'Sheridan Spire' was discovered in 1960 at Sheridan Nurseries in Canada.

This small tree or shrub is characterized by vivid-red new growth that matures into a glossy dark-green color. It produces orange-red flowers during the summer season. Metrosideros collina 'Fiji Fire' thrives best in full-sun but can tolerate part-shade. It is a great choice for hedges and screens, even in coastal areas. Metrosideros collina 'Fiji Fire' prefers to grow in moist, well-drained soils. Metrosideros collina is evergreen and native to French Polynesia and the Cook Islands. Learn more about Metrosideros collina.

Metrosideros collina 'Tahiti' is a dwarf Metrosideros that has red stems and felted new growth. It flowers red from winter to summer and is a great option for small gardens or pots. Metrosideros collina 'Tahiti' grows best in full sun and well-drained soil but should be protected from frost. Native to French Polynesia, the Cook Islands, and the Pitcairn Islands, Metrosideros collina 'Tahiti' is an evergreen.

Metrosideros excelsa thrives in coastal situations and can tolerate poor soils, wet, and drought conditions. It forms a large, broad-headed tree with thick, green leaves that have silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa produces a profusion of glowing, crimson-red flowers from early to mid-summer, which attract nectar-seeking birds. Metrosideros excelsa can be pruned to form hedges and screens or left as a specimen. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa.
uses: street, hedging-and-screening, attracts-bees, attracts-birds, paddocks, shade

description: This is a rare form of Metrosideros excelsa that produces yellow flowers from early to mid-summer. Metrosideros excelsa 'Aurea' thrives in coastal situations and can tolerate poor soils, wet, and drought conditions. It forms a large, broad-headed tree with thick, green leaves that have silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa 'Aurea' can be pruned to form hedges and screens or left as a specimen. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa. Metrosideros excelsa 'Aurea' originated on Mōtītī Island in the Bay of Plenty, New Zealand and was first discovered about 1940.

This pōhutukawa is more compact and has an erect growth habit, making it a well-structured tree that is suitable for the average-sized garden. It produces beautiful bright-red flowers from early to mid-summer. However, Metrosideros excelsa 'Lighthouse' is vulnerable to heavy frosts, especially when young. It is a hardy tree that can tolerate most soil and environmental conditions. Metrosideros excelsa 'Lighthouse' has green leaves with silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa. Metrosideros excelsa 'Lighthouse' was selected by Graeme Platt about 1983 and he gave it the name 'Lighthouse' because it was sourced from a tree growing near the lighthouse at the north-western end of Rangitoto Island, New Zealand.

This cultivar of Metrosideros excelsa has been selected for its more upright, narrow growth habit. Like the traditional variety, it is a hardy plant that produces scarlet-red flowers from early to mid-summer, which attract birds. Metrosideros excelsa 'Māori Princess' is an excellent choice as a street tree since it does not develop untidy aerial roots. Metrosideros excelsa 'Māori Princess' has green leaves with silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa. Metrosideros excelsa 'Māori Princess' was selected from a large tree planted (perhaps in the 1940s) in Brougham Street, New Plymouth, New Zealand.

This is a rare cultivar of Metrosideros excelsa that produces yellow flowers from early to mid-summer. Metrosideros excelsa 'Moon Maiden' thrives in coastal situations and can tolerate poor soils, wet, and drought conditions. It forms a large, broad-headed tree with thick, green leaves that have silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa 'Moon Maiden' can be pruned to form hedges and screens or left as a specimen. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa. Metrosideros excelsa 'Moon Maiden' is a selected form of Metrosideros excelsa 'Aurea' with superior growth habit and flower colour that was introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand in 1988.

This smaller-growing pōhutukawa produces magenta-red flowers from early to mid-summer and has a prolific flowering habit. Metrosideros excelsa 'Scarlet Pimpernel' can grow into a tree but can also be kept in a large container, making it a great choice for small spaces. Like the traditional Metrosideros excelsa, Metrosideros excelsa 'Scarlet Pimpernel' is tough and hardy. Metrosideros excelsa 'Scarlet Pimpernel' has green leaves with silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa. Metrosideros excelsa 'Scarlet Pimpernel' was selected by Felix Jury who propagated it from a street tree on Princess Street, Waitara in Taranaki, New Zealand and it was released by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand in 1976.

This cultivar of Metrosideros excelsa has been selected for its more upright, dense, and compact form. It is just as tough as the traditional Metrosideros excelsa, but it produces very large, vibrant red flowers from early to mid-summer that attract nectar-seeking birds. Metrosideros excelsa 'Vibrance' is a great choice for suburban gardens and is also an excellent street tree. Metrosideros excelsa 'Vibrance' has green leaves with silver-grey undersides. Metrosideros excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros excelsa. Metrosideros excelsa 'Vibrance' was found by John Dodsworth-Smith who alerted Graeme Platt to the original tree and Graeme obtained cutting material of it around 1985. The original tree is planted in a reserve near the sea at Waiomu on the Coromandel Peninsula, New Zealand.

This narrow-growing and erect tree is adorned with shiny, pointed, fresh-green leaves. From early to mid-summer, a profusion of scarlet flowers covers Metrosideros excelsa x umbellata 'Maungapiko', which attract birds. Metrosideros excelsa x umbellata 'Maungapiko' is an excellent tough coastal tree and is able to withstand much more frost than the traditional Metrosideros excelsa. It is also a great choice as a street tree. Metrosideros excelsa x umbellata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Metrosideros excelsa x umbellata is a natural hybrid between Metrosideros excelsa and Metrosideros umbellata. Metrosideros excelsa x umbellata 'Maungapiko' was discovered by Graeme Platt in the early 1980s growing in mānuka scrub at the junction of Maungapiko Track and the old Port Fitzroy - Whangaparapara Road (now Forest Road) on Great Barrier Island, New Zealand. The original tree has since been destroyed by road widening.

Metrosideros kermadecensis 'Variegata' features green leaves that are broadly margined with cream-yellow. It has a compact growth habit and produces red flowers in mid-summer. Metrosideros kermadecensis 'Variegata' is hardy in coastal areas and is an excellent choice for growing in containers and as hedges or as a street or specimen tree. Metrosideros kermadecensis is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the Kermadec Islands. Learn more about Metrosideros kermadecensis. Metrosideros kermadecensis 'Variegata' was probably first released by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and was listed in their catalogue circa 1940-1942.

This bushy tree features small, dark olive-green leaves and is cold hardy and tolerant of moderate coastal exposure. It is superb as a screen and is very adaptable to pruning into any desired shape or form. Metrosideros robusta produces rust-red flowers from early to mid-summer and is an excellent choice as a street tree. Metrosideros robusta is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros robusta.

Metrosideros robusta 'Kawa Copper' has been selected for its bushy, stocky growth habit and copper-red new growth, making it an excellent cultivar for hedging. Metrosideros robusta 'Kawa Copper' has small leaves that can be clipped to any desired shape or form. Rust-red flowers are borne from early to mid-summer. Metrosideros robusta 'Kawa Copper' is quite cold hardy and is tolerant of moderate coastal exposure. Metrosideros robusta is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros robusta. Metrosideros robusta 'Kawa Copper' was selected in 2001 from a batch of seedlings raised by Deane Keir in New Zealand.

This dense-growing tree has a neat, tight canopy of thick, olive-green leaves. Metrosideros x sub-tomentosa 'Mistral' produces a profusion of deep rust-red flowers from early to mid-summer, which attract nectar-seeking birds. It is an excellent tough coastal tree that is superb as a screen and also an excellent choice as a street tree. Metrosideros x sub-tomentosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Metrosideros x sub-tomentosa is a natural hybrid between Metrosideros excelsa and Metrosideros robusta. Metrosideros x sub-tomentosa 'Mistral' was discovered by Graeme Platt in kānuka/mānuka scrub on the Coromandel Peninsula, New Zealand, on the ranges east of Coromandel township, on the road from Coromandel to Te Rerenga.

Metrosideros umbellata is the most cold hardy of the Metrosideros genus. It has a very slow-growing, bushy, multi-stemmed growth habit, and features red new stems and leaves. The mature leaves of Metrosideros umbellata are glossy, leathery, and pointed. Glowing scarlet flowers are produced from early to mid-summer. Metrosideros umbellata requires a moist and cooler position. Metrosideros umbellata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Metrosideros umbellata.

This spectacular tree has large, glossy-green leaves and produces sweet, oval, white fruit that ripen to deep-pink, dark-red, or purple-black during the summer months. Morus alba 'Pendula' also has yellow autumn leaves, adding to its beauty. It is self-fertile, making it an excellent choice for a fruit-bearing tree. Morus alba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Morus alba. Morus alba 'Pendula' originated in Italy in 1890.

This spreading tree has thick, dark-green foliage that provides excellent shade. The leaves of Morus nigra turn yellow in the autumn, adding to its beauty. The fruit of Morus nigra ripen to a red to purple-black color in the summer and fall easily from Morus nigra. Morus nigra is also self-fertile, making it a great choice for a fruit-bearing tree. Morus nigra is thought to be native to Iran, Azerbaijan, and Turkmenistan. Learn more about Morus nigra.

Muehlenbeckia astonii is a dense, upright grower with a tangle of interlacing red-brown branches and divaricating stems. It features small, heart-shaped green leaves and is very tough and hardy, making it an excellent choice as a filler, for island beds, and for covering old tree stumps. Muehlenbeckia astonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Muehlenbeckia astonii.

Myoporum laetum is a rapid grower with bright-green, fleshy leaves. It is drought and coastal hardy and can effectively control sound, wind, sun, and blowing sand, making it an excellent choice for a screen or canopy shade tree. However, it's important to note that the leaves of Myoporum laetum are toxic to livestock. Myoporum laetum is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Myoporum laetum.

Myrsine australis is a compact grower with yellow-green to dark-green leaves that are mottled with red. The new stems of Myrsine australis are red, and it is wind tolerant. It grows well in both sun and semi-shade and makes a superb, dense hedge that can be easily trimmed into any shape or form. Myrsine australis produces small, purple-black fruit in the autumn and small white flowers from mid-summer to early autumn. Myrsine australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Myrsine australis.

Myrsine salicina is a slender, erect-growing tree with leathery, glossy, long, narrow leaves. The new leaves of Myrsine salicina often have a pink-red tinge. It can grow in both sun and shade and is tolerant of both moist and dry positions. Myrsine salicina produces cream-pink flowers in the spring and red-orange berries in the autumn that are relished by birds. Myrsine salicina is also a superb choice for a container plant. Myrsine salicina is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Myrsine salicina.

Nandina domestica 'Fire Power' is a bushy, compact grower that offers year-round foliage interest. It features green-yellow leaves during the spring and summer months, with vibrant red-orange tones throughout the winter. Nandina domestica 'Fire Power' is effective as a small hedge or in planters and is hardy, making it a great choice for a low-maintenance addition to your garden. Nandina domestica is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Nandina domestica. Nandina domestica 'Fire Power' was found in New Zealand as a natural mutation of Nandina domestica 'Nana Purpurea'.

Nerium oleander 'Madonna' produces clusters of beautiful, semi-double, white flowers in the summer and is hardy to drought while also tolerating light frosts. It is a great choice for hedging. However, it's important to note that all parts of Nerium oleander 'Madonna' are toxic to animals and humans, although poisoning is rare due to the bitter taste. Nerium oleander is evergreen and native to the region spanning from the Mediterranean to Myanmar. Learn more about Nerium oleander.

Nestegis cunninghamii develops a thick, straight trunk with coarse, corky bark and has long, leathery, dark-green leaves on a dense-headed tree. It produces bunches of bright-red berries in mid-spring and is considered the best firewood among our native timbers. Nestegis cunninghamii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Nestegis cunninghamii.

Nestegis montana is an attractive tree with smooth, narrow, dark-green leaves that are similar to those of a willow. It has an upright growth habit with a rounded crown and produces red berries in mid-summer that are adored by birds. Nestegis montana prefers more sheltered growing conditions. Nestegis montana is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Nestegis montana.

Nyssa biflora naturally grows in wet, heavy, clay soils and has a pyramidal growth habit with long, narrow leaves. It displays beautiful autumn tones of red, yellow, and orange. Nyssa biflora is deciduous and native to the United States. Learn more about Nyssa biflora.

Nyssa sinensis has wider-spreading branches than Nyssa sylvatica and smooth, large leaves that turn vibrant shades of orange, yellow, and red in autumn, even in mild climates. It is also tolerant of wet and poor-draining soils. Nyssa sinensis is deciduous and native to China and Vietnam. Learn more about Nyssa sinensis.

Nyssa sylvatica has a pyramidal growth habit with broad, sweeping, semi-weeping branches. It has dark-green, glossy leaves that turn vibrant scarlet, orange, and yellow in autumn, even in mild climates. It is also tolerant of wet and poor-draining soils. Nyssa sylvatica is deciduous and native to Canada, Mexico, and the United States. Learn more about Nyssa sylvatica.

Nyssa sylvatica 'Autumn Cascade' is a pyramidal grower that features wide-spreading branches which cascade towards the ground. During autumn, its foliage displays a stunning array of vivid-scarlet, orange, and yellow colors. Moreover, it can tolerate wet soils and poor-drainage conditions. Nyssa sylvatica is deciduous and native to Canada, Mexico, and the United States. Learn more about Nyssa sylvatica. Nyssa sylvatica 'Autumn Cascade' was developed in Australia.

Nyssa sylvatica 'Sheffield Park' is an upright grower with dark-green, glossy leaves that exhibit stunning autumn colors of orange, yellow, and red. Compared to other cultivars, the foliage of Nyssa sylvatica 'Sheffield Park' changes color two to three weeks earlier.
