Additionally, it is capable of withstanding wet soils and poor-drainage conditions. Nyssa sylvatica is deciduous and native to Canada, Mexico, and the United States. Learn more about Nyssa sylvatica. Nyssa sylvatica 'Sheffield Park' was selected from a tree planted in the early 20th century by Arthur Soames at Sheffield Park in East Sussex, England.

The fruit of Olea europaea 'Ascolano' is large and has small pits, making it excellent for use as table fruit since the olives are quite sizable. It is also well-suited for use in hedges, screens, or as a lining for avenues and driveways. Additionally, Olea europaea 'Ascolano' is frost tolerant. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces the best crops when it is planted alongside Olea europaea 'Frantoio' or Olea europaea 'Leccino'. The fruit ripens in autumn and changes color from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black hue. Olea europaea 'Ascolano' also features white flowers during the summer and grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Ascolano' originated in the Marche and Tuscany regions of Italy.

Olea europaea 'Barnea' is a vigorous, upright grower with a fairly narrow form. It yields high-quality oil and is suitable for use as both table fruit and for pickling. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces the best crops when it is planted alongside Olea europaea 'Picholine'. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before eventually turning a purple-black color. It has white flowers during the summer and grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Barnea' was developed by Shimon Lavee from a tree found in Kadesh Barnea (Nitzanei Sinai), Israel.

Olea europaea 'El Greco' is a dense and bushy tree that is well-suited for use in hedging, screening, and shaping. It is also an excellent choice for a street tree and can be grown in containers. While it is self-fertile, it typically does not produce fruit well in New Zealand. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea.

Olea europaea 'Frantoio' is known for its olives with exceptionally high-quality and quantity-yielding oil. They also pickle well when green. Olea europaea 'Frantoio' is suitable for use as a lining for avenues and driveways. Additionally, it is frost tolerant and self-fertile, making it a great cultivar for pollinating other olives. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Frantoio' originated in the region of Tuscany in Italy.

Olea europaea 'J2' yields reliable generous amounts of medium-sized fruit during the autumn season. As a compact oliver tree, it features a slender growth habit, making it ideal for small gardens. The fruit is suitable for preserving and eating fresh, maturing to a dark purple colour when ripe. Tolerant of drought, moderate frost, and cooler climates, it is useful for screening but will need some protection from the wind when younger. Olea europaea is native to the Mediterranean through Africa to China.

Olea europaea 'J5' is frost tolerant and produces a heavy yield of olives on a large tree. It is well-suited for use in hedges, screens, or as a lining for avenues and driveways. Additionally, it is self-fertile, making it capable of producing fruit on its own. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'J5' was developed in New Zealand.

Olea europaea 'Koroneiki' bears large crops of small olives that produce high-yielding oil. It is well-suited for use in hedging and screening, and is particularly suitable for coastal areas. It is also self-fertile, meaning it is capable of producing fruit on its own. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Koroneiki' originated around the city of Kalamata in Greece.

Olea europaea 'Leccino' is particularly tolerant of cold and frosts once it is established. It is an excellent choice for lining driveways and avenues. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces the best crops when it is planted alongside Olea europaea 'Frantoio'. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Leccino' originated from the region of Tuscany in Italy.

Olea europaea 'Manzanillo' produces olives that have excellent texture and are great for eating. It is also one of the best pickling olives available. The branches spread outwards, making it a great choice for pleaching. However, it is not suitable for cold areas. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces the best crops when it is planted alongside Olea europaea 'Frantoio'. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Manzanillo' originated around the city of Seville in Spain.

Olea europaea 'Mission' is a vigorous and upright grower that produces olives suitable for both oil and table eating. It is frost tolerant and self-fertile, meaning it can produce fruit on its own. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Mission' was developed in the late 18th century by Spanish missions in California, United States.

Olea europaea 'Picual' is known for its high-quality and quantity oil production. It is excellent for use in screening, hedging, or as a lining for avenues and driveways. It is also tolerant of frost and poorly-drained soils. Furthermore, it is self-fertile and can produce fruit on its own. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Picual' originated in Spain.

Olea europaea 'Verdale' is well-suited for pickling when the fruit is still in its green stage. It is a compact grower and is suitable for use in hedging and screens, featuring slightly-weeping branches. Additionally, it is self-fertile and can produce fruit on its own. The fruit ripens in autumn, transitioning from green to red before ultimately becoming a purple-black color. It features white flowers during the summer and has grey-green leaves. Olea europaea is evergreen and native from the Mediterranean through Africa to China. Learn more about Olea europaea. Olea europaea 'Verdale' originated in France.

Olearia albida is vigorous and features an erect, bushy growth habit. Its thick, dark-green leaves have a white underside. During the summer, it produces white flowers in panicles. It is capable of withstanding dry, sandy conditions and coastal exposure. Olearia albida is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Olearia albida.

Olearia paniculata is an excellent choice for coastal areas, as it is particularly hardy in such environments. It is a vigorous grower with an erect habit that makes it well-suited for use in screening or hedging. Its lemon-green leaves are tough and have wavy margins, with a white underside. It requires good drainage to thrive. During early autumn to early winter, Olearia paniculata produces small, white flowers. Olearia paniculata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Olearia paniculata.

Olearia paniculata 'Kaikōura' features dark-green leaves with wavy margins and is an excellent choice for use in screening or as a hedge. It is capable of tolerating hard coastal conditions and cold winters, but it requires excellent drainage to thrive. This particular plant was selected from Kaikōura in the South Island of New Zealand. It is also suitable as a coastal street tree. During early autumn to early winter, it produces small, white flowers. Olearia paniculata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Olearia paniculata. Olearia paniculata 'Kaikōura' was developed in New Zealand.

Olearia traversiorum is both tough and fast-growing, capable of tolerating light frosts, coastal conditions, wind, and partial shade. It is an excellent choice for use in hedging on dry and exposed sites, although it does not do well in wet areas. During late spring, Olearia traversiorum produces small clusters of white, daisy-like flowers. Olearia traversiorum is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the Chatham Islands. Learn more about Olearia traversiorum.

Parrotia persica has a broad and horizontal branch structure, and its tough leaves turn vibrant shades of orange, yellow, red, and purple in autumn. During late winter to early spring, it produces stunning red flowers. Parrotia persica is capable of withstanding considerable drought and wind exposure. It can be clipped into a hedge or trained for pleaching. Parrotia persica is deciduous and native to Iran, Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan. Learn more about Parrotia persica.

Parrotia persica 'Pendula' is a weeping form of Parrotia persica that grows into a mound shape. It features beautiful autumn colors of orange, yellow, red, and purple, making it an awesome choice as a feature tree. However, it requires ample space to grow. It is also capable of withstanding considerable drought and wind exposure. During late winter to early spring, it produces stunning red flowers. Parrotia persica is deciduous and native to Iran, Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan. Learn more about Parrotia persica. Parrotia persica 'Pendula' originated in 1934 at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew in London, England.

Paulownia tomentosa is a broad-spreading tree with a stout trunk and horizontal branches. It features huge, tropical-looking leaves that are sure to make a statement in any landscape. During the spring, large, showy, fragrant violet-blue flowers with white inners adorn the bare branches, adding a splash of color to Paulownia tomentosa. While Paulownia tomentosa is capable of withstanding moderate frosts and inland salty gales, it will not thrive right on the coast. Paulownia tomentosa is deciduous and native to China and South Korea. Learn more about Paulownia tomentosa.

Prumnopitys ferruginea is a most beautiful and slow-growing tree that features very dark-green, feathery leaves. Mature trees bear attractive red fruit from late spring to early autumn, which are adored by pigeons. It thrives in semi-shade. Prumnopitys ferruginea is correctly known as Pectinopitys ferruginea, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Pectinopitys ferruginea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pectinopitys ferruginea.

Persea americana 'Bacon' produces medium-sized fruit with smooth, thin, green skin and yellow-green flesh that is smooth and silky with a light flavor. The skin of the fruit remains green but may darken slightly when it ripens. It is typically harvested from late autumn to early spring. While it is self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted alongside Persea americana 'Hass'. Persea americana 'Bacon' forms a thick canopy with a spreading habit. Persea americana is evergreen and native to Central America from Mexico to Costa Rica. Learn more about Persea americana. Persea americana 'Bacon' was developed in 1954 by James Bacon in Buena Park, California, United States. James developed Persea americana 'Bacon' by hybridising two avocado cultivars from Mexico.

Persea americana 'Fuerte' is known for it's exquisite taste and remarkable cold tolerance. The fruit it easy to peel, bearing well every second year. This B-type avocado not only enhances pollination for A-type varieties (e.g. Persea americana 'Hass'), but also produces pear-shaped fruit from winter till spring. Plant Persea americana 'Fuerte' in a sunny, well-drained location, avoiding wet and compacted soils. Fertilize regularly during spring and summer, and protect the tree from wind during its early years. Persea americana 'Fuerte' is evergreen, and originated from the garden of Alejandro Le Blanc in Atlixco, Mexico.

Persea americana 'Hass' is the most commonly-grown avocado cultivar in the world. Its fruit has a very nutty, rich taste, and the flesh has a smooth texture with a thick skin-casing. When the fruit is ripe, the skin turns purple-black. It is typically harvested from late spring to early autumn. While it is self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted alongside Persea americana 'Bacon'. Persea americana 'Hass' forms a thick canopy with a spreading habit. Persea americana is evergreen and native to Central America from Mexico to Costa Rica. Learn more about Persea americana. Persea americana 'Hass' was planted in 1926 by Rudolph Hass in La Habra Heights, California, United States. Rudolph bought the seedling from A. R. Rideout of Whittier, California, United States. The original Persea americana 'Hass' tree stood and produced fruit until it died in 2002.

Persea americana 'Reed', discovered in the mid-20th century in Carlsbad, California, within James S. avocado grove, stands out as a premier avocado variety. This cultivar yields large round avocados with a lusciously creamy and buttery texture, free from any strings or fibres. The seed effortlessly seperates from the flesh. Classified as an A flowering type (though self-fertile in warmer climates), benefits from being planted near a B variety such as Persea americana 'Fuerte', Persea americana 'Bacon', or Persea americana 'Zutano'.Fruits from late summer to early winter.

Originating in Fallbrook, California in 1926 under R.L. Ruitt's care, Persea americana 'Zutano' produce large fruit in winter and early spring. With a thin shiny skin, they are often used as pollinator trees. While self-fertile in warmer climats, Persea americana is classified as a B flowering type, so planting Persea americana 'Zutano' near a Persea americana 'Reed' or Persea americana 'Hass' enhances fruit production in colder climates. Plant in full sun with well-draining soil, and regularly fertilize in spring and summer. Persea americana 'Zutano' is recognized as one of the more cold-tolerant varieties.

Phebalium squameum is a hardy tree that can be planted in full sun or part shade. It produces small, white, scented flowers during the spring, making it a great choice for use in hedging or as a specimen in a small garden. Once established, Phebalium squameum is tolerant of wind, coastal sites, and dry periods. However, it is frost-tender when young and is best suited to sites without hard frosts. Phebalium squameum is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Phebalium squameum.

Phebalium squameum 'Illumination' features attractive green leaves with yellow margins and produces small, white, scented flowers during the spring. It is a great choice for use in hedging or as a specimen in a small garden. Once established, Phebalium squameum 'Illumination' is tolerant of wind, coastal sites, and dry periods. However, it is frost-tender when young and is best suited to sites without hard frosts. Phebalium squameum is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Phebalium squameum.

Photinia x fraseri 'Dark Knight' is great for use in hedging and screening, featuring a vigorous and upright growth habit with an excellent branching structure. It has fiery-red new growth that slowly ages to a dark maroon color before finishing on a dark, glossy-green. If left unpruned from the previous year, it produces small white flowers in the spring. Photinia x fraseri is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Photinia glabra and Photinia serratifolia (syn. Photinia serrulata). Photinia x fraseri was found around 1940 in a batch of seedlings raised at Fraser Nurseries in Birmingham, Alabama, United States and was first put into commerce in 1955. Photinia x fraseri 'Dark Knight' was developed in New Zealand.

Photinia x fraseri 'Red Robin' features large, glossy-green leaves that are topped with shining red new growth, which can be promoted by regular clipping. It is a tough and versatile large bush that clips easily into a hedge or screen and can be shaped into any form desired. If left unpruned from the previous year, it produces small white flowers in the spring. Photinia x fraseri is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Photinia glabra and Photinia serratifolia (syn. Photinia serrulata). Photinia x fraseri was found around 1940 in a batch of seedlings raised at Fraser Nurseries in Birmingham, Alabama, United States and was first put into commerce in 1955. Photinia x fraseri 'Red Robin' was developed in New Zealand.

Photinia x fraseri 'Superhedge' has a vigorous and quick-growing habit and produces new growth with rich burgundy-red foliage. It clips well and can be formed into a beautiful hedge or screen. If left unpruned from the previous year, it produces small white flowers in the spring. Photinia x fraseri is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Photinia glabra and Photinia serratifolia (syn. Photinia serrulata). Photinia x fraseri was found around 1940 in a batch of seedlings raised at Fraser Nurseries in Birmingham, Alabama, United States and was first put into commerce in 1955. Photinia x fraseri 'Superhedge' was developed before 1999 by Paradise Plants Nursery in Kulnura, New South Wales, Australia (PVR 1778).

Phyllocladus trichomanoides is a handsome, upright-growing tree with a symmetrical form, making it ideal for use in a suburban garden to provide height without taking up too much width. It is best planted in semi-shade in soil that does not dry out quickly. Phyllocladus trichomanoides is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Phyllocladus trichomanoides.

Picea abies is a pyramidal conifer with stiff branches when young, which become more graceful with age. It is a great choice for use in inland shelter-belts and is used extensively as a Christmas tree in Europe. Picea abies is evergreen and native to Europe. Learn more about Picea abies.

Picea engelmannii subsp. mexicana is a fast-grower with a conical form, featuring blue-grey needles and small, pendant, light-brown cones. Picea engelmannii subsp. mexicana is evergreen and native to Mexico. Learn more about Picea engelmannii subsp. mexicana.

Picea pungens is a tall, compact conifer that prefers cooler climates. It has green to blue-green needles that cover all the way to the ground. It becomes more drought-tolerant once established but does not like hot conditions. It needs moist soil when young. Picea pungens is evergreen and native to the Rocky Mountains in the United States. Learn more about Picea pungens.

Picea pungens 'Baby Blue' is a more dense and smaller-growing spruce with blue-grey foliage. It performs better in colder climates and makes a superb Christmas tree. Picea pungens is evergreen and native to the Rocky Mountains in the United States. Learn more about Picea pungens.

Picea pungens 'Glauca' is a narrow, pyramidal grower that is densely covered with rich, blue-grey, needle-like leaves. Its new growth is bright blue, and it is a slow-growing, enduring conifer. Picea pungens is evergreen and native to the Rocky Mountains in the United States. Learn more about Picea pungens.

Picea sitchensis has a narrowly-conical growth habit and features blue-green needles and yellow-brown cones. It prefers moist soils that are consistently wet and is tolerant of windy and coastal sites. Picea sitchensis is evergreen and native to the west coast of North America from Alaska to California in the United States and also British Columbia in Canada. Learn more about Picea sitchensis.

Picea smithiana is a vigorous spruce with green needles. It has a narrow growth habit with slightly-weeping branches and is a healthy grower with branches that extend all the way to the ground. Picea smithiana is evergreen and native to Afghanistan, Nepal, Pakistan, Tibet, and the West Himalayas. Learn more about Picea smithiana.

Pinus pinea has been cultivated for its edible pine nuts since prehistoric times and is still used today for this purpose. It is also widely grown for its ornamental value and is often planted in gardens and parks around the world. Pinus pinea features a flat, umbrella-shaped crown and is self-fertile. The pine nuts ripen around mid-autumn. Pinus pinea is native from southern Europe in Portugal through to the Middle East in Lebanon. Learn more about Pinus pinea.

Pistacia chinensis is a handsome tree with elegant, glossy-green, pinnate leaves. It has an upright growth habit with spreading branches, making it a great choice for a shade tree. In autumn, the leaves turn vivid shades of red, yellow, and orange. Pistacia chinensis is an excellent option as a street tree. Pistacia chinensis is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Pistacia chinensis.

Pittosporum crassifolium forms an erect-growing tree with grey-green leaves that have white undersides. In spring to early summer, it produces purple flowers that fragrance the air. It is a very tough coastal-hardy plant and can be used as a specimen tree, screen, or hedge. Pittosporum crassifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum crassifolium.

Pittosporum eugenioides forms a rounded tree with large, pale-green leaves that emit a lemon fragrance when crushed. It produces pale-yellow flowers that scent the air from late spring into summer. Pittosporum eugenioides is a quick-growing and hardy option for a screen or shelter tree, as it provides foliage right to the ground. Pittosporum eugenioides is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum eugenioides.

Pittosporum eugenioides 'Variegatum' forms a large, rounded bush with large, pale-green leaves that are irregularly-margined with cream-white. When crushed, the leaves emit a lemon fragrance. In late spring through summer, it produces pale-yellow flowers that scent the air. Pittosporum eugenioides 'Variegatum' is easily grown and makes a nice, compact specimen tree with foliage right to the ground. Pittosporum eugenioides is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum eugenioides.

Pittosporum tenuifolium has an erect, pyramidal form with black branches and stems. It has small, glossy-green leaves with wavy margins and is quick and easy to grow in sun or shade. Pittosporum tenuifolium can be clipped into any size or form and is excellent as a screen. It produces purple spring flowers that scent the air with their sweet fragrance. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Elizabeth' is a compact grower with narrow, oval, wavy-edged, grey-green leaves that are edged with cream and flushed pink throughout the year. The pink colouring is more prominent in the colder months. It produces scented, dark-purple, star-shaped flowers that are borne in spring. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Elizabeth' was developed before 1997 in the United Kingdom.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Emerald Green' displays shiny, emerald-green leaves on dark stems and is a resilient, rapidly-growing species suitable for hedges and screening. It is also highly receptive to pruning. In the spring, the air is perfumed with the sweet aroma of its purple flowers. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Emerald Green' was developed in New Zealand.

With its compact size and lime-green foliage, this dwarf cultivar is perfect for creating topiaries, low hedges, and borders. It is a hardy plant that can tolerate most conditions, with the exception of excessive moisture or aridity. In the spring, the air is imbued with a delightful fragrance from its purple flowers. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Golf Ball' was developed before 2002 by M. and R. Fyfe in Hastings, New Zealand (PVR 2416).

This compact, dwarf plant is well-suited for creating topiaries, low hedges, and borders, owing to its lime-green leaves and small size. It is a hardy species that can tolerate a range of conditions, except for extremely wet or dry environments. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet scent that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Hedgehog' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Irish Luck' features deep-green foliage that is finely adorned with silver hairs along the leaf margins. It is a great choice for creating hedges or topiaries. Additionally, its purple spring flowers release a delightful, sweet fragrance into the surrounding air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Irish Luck' was developed before 2015 by John and Kathleen Ritchie in Ōtāne, New Zealand (PVR 32563).

With its bushy and erect growth habit, Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Limelight' has a pyramidal shape and striking red stems. Its small, glossy-green leaves feature lime-yellow centers, which help to brighten up darker areas. During the spring, its bright-purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that permeates the air. This species is quick and easy to cultivate in either sunny or shaded locations, and can be pruned into any size or shape. Its dense foliage makes it an excellent choice for use as a screen. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Limelight' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Little Anita' has a wider growth habit than tall and forms a dense, compact cushion of leaves. It is particularly well-suited for edging garden beds or for use in container planting. In the spring, its purple flowers give off a pleasant fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Little Anita' was developed in New Zealand.

This small, dwarf plant is perfect for creating topiaries, low hedges, and borders due to its compact form and lime-green leaves. It is a hardy species that can withstand most growing conditions, except for excessively wet or dry environments. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Little Gem' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Little Kiwi' is an excellent choice for small hedges, topiaries, and borders, with naturally dense foliage that makes it easy to grow. It can tolerate frost, wind, and coastal conditions, making it a versatile species. Additionally, during the spring, its purple flowers give off a pleasant fragrance that fills the surrounding air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Little Kiwi' was developed in New Zealand.

Featuring pale-green leaves with silver highlights, Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Millfield Mint' is an attractive addition to any garden. It is a fast-growing species that is easy to cultivate and can be clipped into any shape or size. In the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that perfumes the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Millfield Mint' was developed by Millfield Nursery in Taranaki, New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Miracle' is a hardy and fast-growing species that features oval-shaped leaves with grey-green coloring and cream-white margins. It is an easy plant to grow and can be used as a specimen or for providing shelter. During the spring, its purple flowers release a sweet fragrance that scents the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Miracle' was developed in New Zealand.

This bushy and erect plant has a rounded form and features tightly-packed small, glossy, fresh-green leaves that grow along its erect stems. It is a quick and easy species to cultivate in either sunny or shaded locations and can be clipped into any size or shape. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Its dense foliage makes it an excellent choice for use as a screen or hedge. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Mountain Green' was developed in New Zealand.

This bushy and erect plant has a pyramidal form and features small, glossy, fresh-green leaves with a lime edge that grow tightly packed along its erect, black stems. It is a quick and easy species to cultivate in either sunny or shaded locations and can be clipped into any size or shape. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Mountain Jade' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Oliver Twist' is a compact selection with silver-green leaves that is easy and fast to grow in either sunny or shaded locations. It can be pruned into any size or shape, making it a versatile species. During the spring, its purple flowers give off a pleasant fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Oliver Twist' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Silver Pillar' features small silver-green leaves with cream edges that are slightly flushed with pink during the winter. It has an upright and narrow growth habit, which rarely requires trimming, making it ideal for narrow spaces and container planting. During the spring, its purple flowers give off a pleasant fragrance that fills the surrounding air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Silver Pillar' was developed before 2006 by Plant Production in Napier, New Zealand (PVR 2816).

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Silver Sheen' has an erect, pyramidal form with black branches and stems, and features small, glossy, pale silver-green leaves with a shimmering effect. It is a quick and easy species to grow in either sunny or shaded locations and can be pruned into any size or shape, making it a versatile choice. Its dense foliage makes it an excellent option for use as a screen. Additionally, during the spring, its purple flowers release a sweet fragrance that fills the surrounding air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Silver Sheen' was developed in New Zealand.

This lovely and compact plant has tiny silver-green leaves and is well-suited for use as a low hedge or for edging garden beds. It can also be used as a filler plant in areas that require a hardy species. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Small Ball' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Stephens Island' is tolerant of colder conditions and coastal areas, and forms a dense, rounded tree with leathery, olive-green leaves. It can be pruned into any size or shape, making it a versatile option for gardeners. Additionally, its dense foliage makes it an excellent choice for use as a screen. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Stephens Island' was developed in New Zealand from trees growing on Stephens Island in the Cook Strait.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Tandara Gold' features an erect, pyramidal form with black branches and stems, and its small leaves are prominently splashed with gold. It is a great choice for brightening up darker areas in the garden, and its foliage can be pruned and shaped into any size or form. During the spring, its purple flowers emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Tandara Gold' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Variegatum' has a slender, erect, narrow, pyramidal form with grey branches and stems. Its long, green leaves feature broad cream-white margins, which make it a great option for brightening up dark areas in the garden. It can be pruned and shaped into any size or form, and its dense foliage makes it an excellent choice for use as a screen. Additionally, during the spring, its purple flowers give off a sweet fragrance that fills the air. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Variegatum' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Wai-iti' is an erect and bushy tree with oval-shaped leaves that shimmer in a clear jade-green color, contrasting beautifully with its wine-red stems. It is a great option for use as a feature tree or as a hedge. During the spring, it produces purple flowers that give off a pleasant fragrance. This species is hardy to most soil conditions, but should be avoided in wet ground. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Wai-iti' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Wrinkle Blue' has a slender, erect, narrow, pyramidal form with attractively-rippled, blue-green, glossy leaves. It is a quick and easy species to grow in either sunny or shaded locations, and can be pruned into any size or shape. During the spring, its purple flowers release a sweet fragrance that fills the surrounding air. Its dense foliage makes it an excellent option for use as a screen. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pittosporum tenuifolium. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Wrinkle Blue' was developed in New Zealand.

Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Zen' is a fast-growing plant that has lime-green new foliage, changing to a ruby-green with hues of red when matured. Will thrive in both sun and shade, and well drained soil, clipping into a nice hedge or screen. Very exposed coastal sites may cause the new growth to become salt burnt. Pittosporum tenuifolium is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Pittosporum tenuifolium 'Zen' was developed in New Zealand.

Plagianthus regius forms a graceful tree with a slender and upright growth habit. In the spring, it produces fresh-green new leaves and lime-green blossoms from mid-spring to mid-summer. It is a resilient species that can tolerate exposed conditions. Plagianthus regius is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Plagianthus regius.

This hardy coastal tree has an upright form when young, which matures into an open and spreading habit. It features distinctive, leathery, shiny green leaves, and produces large fruit that are roughly the size of dates. These fruits, which are red when unripe and turn to purple-black when ripe, are adored by birds, and are produced from early summer to mid-winter. However, this species is susceptible to frost damage. Planchonella costata is evergreen and native to New Zealand and Norfolk Island. Learn more about Planchonella costata.

Platanus x acerifolia grows rapidly to form a large, round-headed tree, with smooth mottled bark that peels off in large flakes. It features large, palmate leaves, and is a great choice for use in large lawns, parks, avenues, and streets. It can be pruned heavily, and is able to survive extreme conditions of poor soil, limited moisture, and pollution. During the autumn season, its leaves turn yellow-orange, providing a beautiful display of fall foliage. Platanus x acerifolia is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Platanus orientalis and Platanus occidentalis. Learn more about Platanus x acerifolia. Platanus x acerifolia potentially originated as far back as around 1670.

synonyms: Platanus x hispanica 'Pyramidalis', Platanus orientalis var. acerifolia 'Pyramidalis', Platanus pyramidalis, Platanus orientalis var. pyramidalis
description: Platanus x acerifolia 'Pyramidalis' is a more tidy and erect-growing form of Platanus x acerifolia, and is known for its more symmetrical shape, which makes it well-suited for use in tighter spaces, avenues, and streets. During the autumn season, its leaves turn yellow-orange, providing a beautiful display of fall foliage. Platanus x acerifolia is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Platanus orientalis and Platanus occidentalis. Learn more about Platanus x acerifolia. Platanus x acerifolia potentially originated as far back as around 1670. Platanus x acerifolia 'Pyramidalis' apparently was raised or first distributed in France or Belgium, and was introduced to Britain in about 1850.

Platanus x acerifolia 'Suttneri' is a very handsome tree with a rounded and branched head. Its bark is attractive and mottled, and peels off in large flakes. The large leaves are heavily-striped and splashed with white, making it a beautiful and unique option as a shade tree. During the autumn season, its leaves turn yellow-orange, providing a beautiful display of fall foliage. Platanus x acerifolia is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Platanus orientalis and Platanus occidentalis. Learn more about Platanus x acerifolia. Platanus x acerifolia potentially originated as far back as around 1670. Platanus x acerifolia 'Suttneri' was introduced to the United Kingdom shortly after the mid-20th century and possibly originated before 1896.

Platanus orientalis is a rapid grower that quickly forms into a large, round-headed tree with bark that peels off in large flakes, giving it a dappled appearance. It is an excellent choice for use as a shade tree in areas with enough space. This species is great for large lawns, parks, avenues, and streets, and can be pruned heavily. Additionally, it is tolerant of pollution. During the autumn season, its leaves turn yellow, providing a beautiful display of fall foliage. Platanus orientalis is deciduous and native from the eastern Mediterranean to Iran. Learn more about Platanus orientalis.

Platanus orientalis 'Ace Of Clubs' is a selected form of Platanus orientalis that grows rapidly with a more upright form and more divided foliage. Its bark peels off in large flakes to give it a dappled appearance, and its large leaves are deeply divided. During the autumn season, its leaves turn a beautiful golden color, providing a stunning display of fall foliage. It forms a handsome shade tree and is great for large lawns, parks, avenues, and streets. It can be pruned heavily, and is also tolerant of pollution. Platanus orientalis is deciduous and native from the eastern Mediterranean to Iran. Learn more about Platanus orientalis. Platanus orientalis 'Ace Of Clubs' was developed in New Zealand.

Platanus orientalis 'Alford Flame' is a hardy select form of Platanus orientalis, featuring deep-green, leathery leaves that turn a brilliant red and orange in early autumn. It is suitable for planting as an avenue, in groups, or as a specimen plant. Platanus orientalis is deciduous and native from the eastern Mediterranean to Iran. Learn more about Platanus orientalis. Platanus orientalis 'Alford Flame' was developed before 2007 by Allenton Nurseries in Ashburton, New Zealand (PVR 2750).

Platanus orientalis 'Autumn Glory' is a selected form of Platanus orientalis that grows rapidly to form a dense, round-headed tree. Its bark peels off in large flakes, giving it a dappled appearance. The smaller leaves are deeply-lobed, and during the autumn season, they turn into beautiful shades of gold and orange, making it a great choice as a shade tree for large lawns, parks, and streets. Platanus orientalis 'Autumn Glory' is also tolerant of pollution. Platanus orientalis is deciduous and native from the eastern Mediterranean to Iran. Learn more about Platanus orientalis. Platanus orientalis 'Autumn Glory' was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Platanus orientalis 'Digitata' grows into a large tree with a wide, oval crown. As a selected form of Platanus orientalis, it has deeply-divided leaves, and its attractive bark peels off in large flakes, giving it a speckled appearance on the trunk. During the autumn season, its foliage turns a beautiful shade of yellow, providing a stunning display of fall colors. Platanus orientalis is deciduous and native from the eastern Mediterranean to Iran. Learn more about Platanus orientalis. Platanus orientalis 'Digitata' was possibly first put into commerce around 1840 in the United Kingdom by the Loddiges family.

Platanus orientalis 'Fitzherbert' is a selected form of Platanus orientalis that is able to withstand exposed and windy conditions, as well as heavy clay soils. It is a compact and upright grower, featuring deeply-cut green leaves. Additionally, Platanus orientalis 'Fitzherbert' is resistant to disease. During the autumn season, its leaves turn a beautiful shade of yellow, providing a stunning display of fall colors. Platanus orientalis is deciduous and native from the eastern Mediterranean to Iran. Learn more about Platanus orientalis. Platanus orientalis 'Fitzherbert' was developed in New Zealand to withstand the Manawatū environment and is the feature tree in Fitzherbert Avenue, Palmerston North.

Podocarpus gracilior features long, narrow, fresh-green leaves that grow densely along its slender and supple branches. It is a great option for pleaching and can also be clipped to create a narrow-growing screen. Additionally, it is suitable for use in containers and as a street tree. Podocarpus gracilior is evergreen and native to eastern Africa in Ethiopia, Kenya, Sudan, Tanzania, and Uganda. Learn more about Podocarpus gracilior.

Podocarpus henkelii is a large, pyramidal-growing tree with pendent branches that are covered in shiny, dark-green, narrow leaves. It is a beautiful option for landscaping projects, but it should be protected from heavy frosts to ensure its health and longevity. Podocarpus henkelii is evergreen and native to Malawi, South Africa, Tanzania, and Zimbabwe. Learn more about Podocarpus henkelii.

Podocarpus laetus is closely related to Podocarpus totara, but it features longer juvenile leaves and thin, flaky, paper-like bark. It is a great option for hedging, and its yellow-green catkins, which appear in mid-spring to early-summer, are a source of pollen for bees. Podocarpus laetus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Podocarpus laetus.

Podocarpus macrophyllus is an upright grower with pale-green and slender leaves. It is a great option for creating very narrow and dense hedges and screens, and it is tolerant of semi-shade conditions. Additionally, it is an excellent choice as a street tree. Podocarpus macrophyllus is evergreen and native to China, Japan, Myanmar, and Taiwan. Learn more about Podocarpus macrophyllus.

Podocarpus macrophyllus var. maki has a strongly-columnar growth habit and features dense, medium to deep-green foliage. It is a great option for shearing and pruning, making it an ideal selection for use as a hedge, screen, column, or for topiary. Podocarpus macrophyllus var. maki is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Podocarpus macrophyllus var. maki.

Podocarpus parlatorei makes an excellent hedge or screen as it responds well to trimming. Its light-green new leaves mature into shiny deep-green foliage. Podocarpus parlatorei is evergreen and native to Argentina, Bolivia, and Peru. Learn more about Podocarpus parlatorei.

Podocarpus totara is a tall and pyramidal-growing tree that is covered with olive-green to bronze, needle-like leaves. Its new leaves are a fresh-green color, and its red-brown bark peels in long strips. Podocarpus totara is very tough and can tolerate dry and windy conditions. It is easily trimmed to be used as a screen or hedge, and is an excellent choice as a street tree. Additionally, its yellow-green catkins, which appear in mid-spring to early-summer, are a source of pollen for bees. Podocarpus totara is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Podocarpus totara.

Podocarpus totara 'Aurea' has a growth habit similar to Podocarpus totara, but with more graceful branches and softer leaves. Its leaves emerge yellow-green in the spring before changing to yellow in the summer, and then deepening to golden-yellow in the winter. This species is very tough and can tolerate dry and windy conditions. It is easily trimmed to be used as a screen or hedge, and is an excellent choice as a street tree. Additionally, its yellow-green catkins, which appear in mid-spring to early-summer, are a source of pollen for bees. Podocarpus totara is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Podocarpus totara. Podocarpus totara 'Aurea' is a hybrid betweeen Podocarpus totara and Podocarpus acutifolius. Podocarpus totara 'Aurea' was possibly first cultivated by James Yates who discovered a seedling growing in the bush in the early 1900s. James grew the seedling at his farm which was near Wharepūhunga in the Waikato district. In 1937, James wrote to Wellington about the Podocarpus totara 'Aurea' (which had grown into a lovely tree), and two horticulturists from Massey University came to view Podocarpus totara 'Aurea' in 1938 and returned with cuttings for propagation.

This cultivar of Podocarpus totara is characterized by its blue-grey leaves. It is a slow-growing tree that can be clipped into any shape and size, making it an excellent option for hedging and screening. Additionally, its yellow-green catkins, which appear in mid-spring to early-summer, are a source of pollen for bees. Podocarpus totara is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Podocarpus totara. Podocarpus totara 'Matapouri Blue' originated in Matapouri Bay, Northland, New Zealand.

Poliothyrsis sinensis is a broadly-conical tree that features attractive leaves and cream-colored flowers in large panicles during the late summer. It is a beautiful tree that is well-suited for home gardens, and its leaves turn a lovely shade of yellow in the autumn. Poliothyrsis sinensis is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Poliothyrsis sinensis.

Populus 'Chiba' has a narrow, fastigiate form, making it great for use in shelter belts. It is highly resistant to poplar leaf rust, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Populus 'Chiba' is tolerant of frost and wind, but it prefers moist soil conditions and does not do well in coastal areas or dry soils. Populus 'Chiba' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and is a hybrid between Populus maximowiczii and Populus nigra. Populus 'Chiba' was developed by Allan Wilkinson in New Zealand and was named after Shigeru Chiba of the Japanese Oji Paper Company who supplied the Populus maximowiczii parent.

Populus 'Crows Nest' has a narrow, fastigiate form and is well-suited for use in shelter belts. Its new leaves are red-orange, maturing to a dark-green color on the upper surface and light-green below with a red midrib. It can tolerate some drought, and it has a low to moderate resistance to poplar leaf rust. Its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Populus 'Crows Nest' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and is a hybrid between Populus x canadensis (syn. Populus x euramericana) and Populus nigra. Populus 'Crows Nest' was developed in New Zealand by Manaaki Whenua (Landcare Research) and was released in 1994 (PVR 936).

The Mataī tree has a very similar appearance to Pectinopitys ferruginea, except during its juvenile stage when it has a tangle of orange-brown branches. Once it matures, it bears purple-black fruit throughout the year. Prumnopitys taxifolia is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Prumnopitys taxifolia.

Prunus 'Accolade' has a vase-shaped form with spreading branches and is known for its beautiful yellow and orange autumn leaves. It produces semi-double, frilled, rich-pink flowers in clusters in early spring, making it an excellent street tree. However, it should be protected from strong winds. Prunus 'Accolade' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and is a hybrid between Prunus sargentii and Prunus subhirtella. Prunus 'Accolade' was raised at the Knap Hill Nursery in England from seed received shortly before 1939 from the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University in Boston, Massachusetts, United States and was released in 1952.

In late spring and early summer, golden-yellow apricots with a red blush are ready to be harvested. These apricots are highly disease-resistant and produce sweet, low-acid fruit that is perfect for eating fresh, canning, or making preserves. Prunus armeniaca 'Royal Rosa' also has white flowers in the spring and is self-fertile. Prunus armeniaca is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus armeniaca. Prunus armeniaca 'Royal Rosa' was developed in the United States.

The fruit of Prunus armeniaca 'Sundrop' are large, yellow, oval-shaped, and have a freestone, with a sweet and juicy taste. It ripens in mid-summer and is great for eating fresh or preserving. Prunus armeniaca 'Sundrop' also produces white flowers in the spring and is suitable for most regions. While it is partially self-fertile, the best crop is obtained when planted alongside Prunus armeniaca 'Trevatt'. Prunus armeniaca is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus armeniaca.

Prunus armeniaca 'Sundrop/Trevatt' is a double apricot. See Prunus armeniaca 'Sundrop' and Prunus armeniaca 'Trevatt' for descriptions. First image is of Prunus armeniaca 'Sundrop', second is of Prunus armeniaca 'Trevatt'. Prunus armeniaca is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus armeniaca.

Prunus armeniaca 'Trevatt' is vigorous and produces medium-sized, richly-flavored, golden apricots that mature in mid-summer. It thrives in warmer climates and produces white flowers in the spring. While it is self-fertile, planting it alongside other apricot cultivars such as Prunus armeniaca 'Sundrop' or Prunus armeniaca 'Royal Rosa' can result in the highest-yielding crops. Prunus armeniaca is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus armeniaca. Prunus armeniaca 'Trevatt' was developed in Australia in the early 20th century.

Prunus avium 'Compact Stella' is a heavy and regular bearer of red fruit that ripens in early summer. Its leaves turn orange to red in autumn, and it produces white flowers in the spring. Prunus avium 'Compact Stella' is hardy, and it is also self-fertile. Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Prunus avium. Prunus avium 'Compact Stella' was developed in 1964 from scions of Prunus avium 'Stella' at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Long Island, New York, United States.

The fruit of Prunus avium 'Dawson' have dark purple-black skin and dark-red flesh, and are large and firm. It ripens in early to mid-summer, and the leaves of Prunus avium 'Dawson' turn orange to red in the autumn. It produces white flowers in the spring, and pollination is done by Prunus avium 'Stella' and Prunus avium 'Compact Stella'. Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Prunus avium.

The fruit of Prunus avium 'Lapins' are large, dark-red, and firm, with a good flavor. They ripen from mid-summer and are resistant to cracking. The leaves of Prunus avium 'Lapins' turn orange to red in the autumn, and it produces white flowers in the spring. Additionally, it is self-fertile. Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Prunus avium. Prunus avium 'Lapins' was developed by Karlis Lapins at the Summerland Research Station in Summerland, British Columbia, Canada and was released in 1983.

Double grafted Prunus avium 'Lapins/Dawson is ideal for a sunny sheltered location with moist soil during the growing season.Prunus avium 'Lapins' yields large black-red fruit with red flesh and a sweet flavour. It serves as a reliable pollinator for other cherry varieties. Harvesting is done during early to mid-summer.Prunus avium 'Dawson' produces black-red fruit with firm red flesh that is ready for harvest in early summer. Both varieties do well in a low-chill environment, making this double grafted cherry ideal for warmer regions.Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe.

Prunus avium 'Rainier' is one of the best when it comes to producing yellow cherries, with abundant crops of deliciously sweet fruit. In spring, clusters of sweetly-scented white flowers appear on the branches. Large, golden-yellow cherries with a red blush are produced in early summer, with firm, cream-white flesh that is exceptionally sweet and juicy. The fruit is great for eating fresh, canning, and preserves. The leaves of Prunus avium 'Rainier' turn into beautiful shades of orange and red in the autumn. Pollination is done by Prunus avium 'Stella' and Prunus avium 'Compact Stella'. Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Prunus avium. Prunus avium 'Rainier' was developed in 1952 by Harold Fogle at Washington State University in Washington, United States and was named after Mount Rainier in Mount Rainier National Park, Washington, United States.

Prunus avium 'Stella' is a prolific and regular bearer of large, sweet, red cherries that ripen in early summer. Its leaves turn orange to red in the autumn, and it produces white flowers in the spring. Prunus avium 'Stella' is also self-fertile. Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Prunus avium. Prunus avium 'Stella' was developed in 1956 by Karlis Lapins at the Summerland Research Station in Summerland, British Columbia, Canada and was named in 1968.

Prunus avium 'Summit' produces large, heart-shaped cherries with dark-red skin and light-red, juicy flesh, and it fruits from late-spring to early-summer. Its leaves turn orange to red in the autumn, and it produces white flowers in the spring. Pollination is done by Prunus avium 'Lapins', Prunus avium 'Stella', and Prunus avium 'Compact Stella'. Prunus avium is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Prunus avium.

This is a beautiful tree that produces a profusion of fragrant, rose-pink, double blossoms from late-winter to early-spring. Its rich purple leaves persist throughout the summer and maintain their color until they fall in autumn. Prunus x blireiana is great for smaller gardens and makes an excellent street tree. Prunus x blireiana is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Prunus mume and Prunus cerasifera 'Atropurpurea' (syn. Prunus cerasifera 'Pissardii'). Learn more about Prunus x blireiana. Prunus x blireiana was developed in France and introduced into commerce in 1906.

Prunus campanulata 'Felix Jury' produces flowers from late-winter to early-spring, with a profuse display of large, deep rose-red, single blossoms in pendulous clusters that are full of nectar, delighting birds. In the autumn, the leaves turn a rich blend of red, gold, and orange. Prunus campanulata 'Felix Jury' forms an upright, pyramidal tree and makes an excellent street tree. It is not sterile. Prunus campanulata is deciduous and native to China and Taiwan. Learn more about Prunus campanulata. Prunus campanulata 'Felix Jury' was developed by Felix Jury in New Zealand and named after him by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Prunus campanulata 'Pink Cloud' is a delightful rounded, neat-headed tree with spreading branches that makes a great shade tree for a smaller garden. Clusters of soft-pink, single flowers hang from the branches from late-winter to early-spring, and these blossoms are full of nectar that delights birds. Prunus campanulata 'Pink Cloud' is an excellent street tree and a sterile cultivar. In the autumn, the leaves turn yellow, orange, and red. Prunus campanulata 'Pink Cloud' is not banned in Auckland. Prunus campanulata is deciduous and native to China and Taiwan. Learn more about Prunus campanulata. Prunus campanulata 'Pink Cloud' was developed by Felix Jury in New Zealand.

This hybrid plant produces flowers from late-winter to early-spring, with a profuse display of deep rose-red, single blossoms in pendulous clusters that are full of nectar, delighting birds. Prunus campanulata 'Superba' forms an upright, pyramidal tree, making it great for smaller gardens and lining driveways, and it also serves as an excellent street tree. Prunus campanulata 'Superba' is not sterile, and in the autumn, its leaves turn yellow, orange, and red. Prunus campanulata is deciduous and native to China and Taiwan. Learn more about Prunus campanulata.

Prunus cerasifera 'Thundercloud' has stems wreathed in dainty, pink blossoms in early-spring, and its leaves emerge red before darkening to purple, with the color persisting throughout the summer and into the autumn when the leaves fall. Prunus cerasifera 'Thundercloud' is an upright-grower and makes an excellent street tree. Prunus cerasifera is deciduous and native to southeast Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Prunus cerasifera. Prunus cerasifera 'Thundercloud' was potentially selected in 1919 by Luther Burbank in Santa Rosa, California, United States. The Prunus cerasifera 'Thundercloud' clone we have today is perhaps one of many similar clones that may not have originated from Luther's selection, but have been marketed under the same name.

Prunus cerasus 'Rhexii' is an upright, spreading tree with double, white flowers that bloom in late-spring. It has beautiful gold, orange, and red autumn leaf color, and it is hardy. However, Prunus cerasus 'Rhexii' does not set fruit. Prunus cerasus is deciduous and native to the North Caucasus region in Russia. Learn more about Prunus cerasus. Prunus cerasus 'Rhexii' originated in 2003 at the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States.

synonyms: Prunus domestica 'Reine-Claude de Bavay', Prunus domestica subsp. italica, Prunus domestica subsp. insititia
description: Prunus domestica 'Reine Claude de Bavay' is self-fertile and a heavy cropper, producing sweet, juicy, smaller-sized, green plums that ripen in early-autumn. It also produces white flowers in the spring and is well-suited to warmer districts. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus domestica 'Reine Claude de Bavay' turn yellow. Prunus domestica is deciduous and native to Turkey. Learn more about Prunus domestica.

This self-fertile almond is great for home orchards, producing white to pale-pink blossoms in early-spring. It yields heavy crops of soft-shelled, sweet-flavored almonds that ripen from early-autumn, but require a hot summer to fully mature. Prunus dulcis 'All-in-One' can tolerate a wide range of soils, except for heavy, poor-draining soils, and it should be sheltered from high winds. Prunus dulcis is deciduous and native to Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan. Learn more about Prunus dulcis. Prunus dulcis 'All-in-One' was developed before 1977 by Chris Zaiger in Modesto, California, United States (USPP4304, PVR 642).

Prunus dulcis 'Monovale' is self-fertile and produces white to pale-pink blossoms in early-spring. It yields heavy crops of hard-shelled almonds with a good, strong flavor from early-autumn. Prunus dulcis 'Monovale' can tolerate a wide range of soils, except for heavy, poor-draining soils, and it should be sheltered from high winds. Prunus dulcis is deciduous and native to Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan. Learn more about Prunus dulcis. Prunus dulcis 'Monovale' was developed in New Zealand.

Prunus x hillieri 'Spire' has a densely-branched, narrow, upright form with smaller leaves. Its green leaves turn red and orange in autumn, and it becomes a cloud of dainty, white to soft-pink blossoms in early-spring. Prunus x hillieri 'Spire' is great for narrow spaces and lining driveways, and it makes an excellent street tree. Prunus x hillieri is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and is a hybrid between Prunus incisa and Prunus sargentii. Prunus x hillieri 'Spire' was developed in the 1920s at Hillier Nurseries in Ampfield, United Kingdom and was introduced in 1956.

Prunus x incam 'Jim's Delight' has a vase-shaped tree form with a slight spreading habit. It produces small, single, pink flowers in the spring and is great for driveways or as a street tree. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus x incam 'Jim's Delight' turn yellow, orange, and red. Prunus x incam is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Prunus incisa and Prunus campanulata. Learn more about Prunus x incam. Prunus x incam 'Jim's Delight' originated as a chance seedling from a Prunus x incam 'Okamé' tree in the garden of Jim Rumbal in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand and was named after him by Vance Hooper.

Prunus x incam 'Okamé' has a compact, rounded-head and produces masses of bright, pink, bell-shaped, single blossoms that hang in pendant clusters. It flowers from late-winter to early-spring and is great for the smaller garden, making an excellent street tree. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus x incam 'Okamé' turn yellow, orange, and red, and it is a superb tree for attracting birds and bees, as its flowers are full of nectar. Prunus x incam 'Okamé' is not sterile. Prunus x incam is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Prunus incisa and Prunus campanulata. Learn more about Prunus x incam. Prunus x incam 'Okamé' was developed before 1942 by Collingwood Ingram in Benenden, England.

Prunus laurocerasus is a vigorous and hardy tree with large, shiny leaves. It produces long panicles of white flowers in the spring and is often used as a dense-growing screen or hedge, particularly in formal gardens. Prunus laurocerasus is evergreen and native to regions bordering the Black Sea in southwestern Asia and southeastern Europe, from Albania and Bulgaria east through Turkey to the Caucasus Mountains and northern Iran. Learn more about Prunus laurocerasus.

Prunus lusitanica forms a pyramidal shape with dark-green leaves. It produces panicles of scented, white flowers during the summer and is an excellent subject for pruning into any shape, form, or size. Prunus lusitanica is evergreen and native to Spain and Portugal. Learn more about Prunus lusitanica.

Prunus mume produces flowers that range in color from white to pink to red in mid-winter to early-spring. It requires a sheltered site with full sun and should be avoided in areas with late frosts, as the frosts can damage the flowers. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus mume turn yellow and orange. Prunus mume is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus mume.

Prunus mume 'Peggy Clarke' produces beautiful, double, rose-pink flowers in the spring, and its leaves turn yellow and orange in the autumn. Prunus mume is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus mume. Prunus mume 'Peggy Clarke' was introduced to North American commerce in 1941 by W. B. Clarke Nursery in San Jose, California, United States and was named after one of W. B. Clarke's daughters.

Prunus mume 'The Geisha' produces delightfully fragrant, pink, semi-double flowers with numerous central stamens that appear on its bare branches from mid-winter to early-spring. It requires a sheltered site with full sun and should be avoided in areas with late frosts, as the frosts can damage the flowers. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus mume 'The Geisha' turn yellow. Prunus mume is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus mume.

Prunus persica 'April White' produces a delicious, large, firm peach that has white flesh and yellow skin with a pink-red blush. It also has yellow autumn leaves and is highly resistant to leaf-curl. The fruit of Prunus persica 'April White' ripens from late-summer to early-autumn, and its pink blossoms appear from late-winter to late-spring. Prunus persica 'April White' is self-fertile. Prunus persica is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica. Prunus persica 'April White' was developed in New Zealand (TM 263003).

Prunus persica 'Black Boy' produces medium-sized fruit with wine-red, melting flesh. The fruit skin is pale-purple with grey fuzz, making it a popular cultivar for eating fresh and bottling. Prunus persica 'Black Boy' also has yellow autumn leaves and is a good home-garden tree. The fruit ripens in late-summer, and its pink blossoms appear from late-winter to late-spring. Prunus persica 'Black Boy' is self-fertile. Prunus persica is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica. Prunus persica 'Black Boy' was imported from France into New Zealand in the early 20th century.

Prunus persica 'Golden Queen' is a true favorite for bottling and an excellent eater. It produces fruit with firm, yellow-orange flesh and deep yellow-orange skin. The fruit is slightly flat and clingstone and ripens in late-summer. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica 'Golden Queen' appear from late-winter to late-spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Prunus persica 'Golden Queen' is self-fertile. Prunus persica is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica. Prunus persica 'Golden Queen' originated in 1908 in the garden of Edwin Reeves in Greerton, Tauranga, New Zealand and was introduced into commerce by David Hay of Montpellier Nursery in Auckland, New Zealand.

Prunus persica 'Healy's' is a cross between a nectarine and a peach, producing large, juicy, yellow-fleshed fruit. The fruit skin is a mix of yellow, orange, and red, and it is a clingstone cultivar that fruits from late-summer to early-autumn. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica 'Healy's' appear from late-winter to late-spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Prunus persica 'Healy's' is self-fertile. Prunus persica is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica. Prunus persica 'Healy's' is a hybrid between Prunus persica and Prunus persica var. nectarina. The exact origin of Prunus persica 'Healy's' is unknown, but it is thought to have originated in Hawkes Bay, New Zealand as a chance seedling of Prunus persica 'Golden Queen' crossed with possibly Prunus persica var. nectarina 'RedGold'.

Prunus persica 'Hiawatha' is an attractive peach tree with deep-purple leaves in the spring that fade to purple-green in the summer. It produces pink blossoms and purple-skinned fruit with orange flesh and a good flavor. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica 'Hiawatha' appear from late-winter to late-spring, and it is an excellent choice for fresh eating. The fruit ripens in mid-summer, and Prunus persica 'Hiawatha' is self-fertile, as well as a regular cropper. Prunus persica is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica.

Prunus persica 'Scarlett O'Hara' produces white-fleshed peaches with pink-red skin that ripen in mid-summer. The fruit is clingstone, and the flesh is firm and crunchy. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica 'Scarlett O'Hara' appear from late-winter to late-spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Prunus persica 'Scarlett O'Hara' is self-fertile. Prunus persica is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica. Prunus persica 'Scarlett O'Hara' was selected in 1989 as a seedling from Prunus persica 'Yumyeong' and was grown at the New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research orchard in Havelock North, New Zealand (PVR 1891).

Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Button Bright' produces good crops of sweet, yellow-fleshed, red-skinned fruit that ripen through mid to late-summer. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Button Bright' appear in the spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Button Bright' is self-fertile. Prunus persica var. nectarina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica var. nectarina. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Button Bright' was developed by the Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique (INRA) in France (PVR 3115).

Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Goldmine' produces medium-sized, white-fleshed, freestone fruit that is juicy and sweet, with white and red-blushed skin. The fruit ripens in mid-summer, and the pink blossoms of Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Goldmine' appear in the spring. Its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. This old favorite cultivar is known for being very productive, and it is self-fertile. Prunus persica var. nectarina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica var. nectarina. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Goldmine' originated in the early 1900s in a garden in Parnell, Auckland, New Zealand as a chance seedling of Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Ansenne'.

Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Mabel' has beautiful burgundy-purple foliage in the spring, which changes to green over the summer. It produces stunning pink blossoms in the spring, followed by delicious, sweet, purple-skinned nectarines with pale-yellow flesh in late-summer. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Mabel' is self-fertile and highly resistant to leaf curl. Prunus persica var. nectarina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica var. nectarina. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Mabel' was discovered before 2010 by Mabel Stewart in her garden in Oratia, Auckland (PVR 30818).

Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Queen Giant' produces beautifully-flavored, white-fleshed, freestone nectarines with crimson-red and pale-cream skins. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Queen Giant' appear in the spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. The fruit ripens in mid-summer, and Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Queen Giant' is self-fertile. Prunus persica var. nectarina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica var. nectarina. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Queen Giant' was developed in 1988 by Chris Zaiger in Modesto, California, United States.

Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Snow Queen' produces one of the sweetest and juiciest nectarines, with freestone fruit that has delicious snow-white flesh and red and yellow skin. The pink blossoms of Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Snow Queen' appear in the spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. The fruit ripens from early to mid-summer, and Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Snow Queen' is self-fertile. Prunus persica var. nectarina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus persica var. nectarina. Prunus persica var. nectarina 'Snow Queen' was introduced in the 1940s or 1950s by Armstrong Nurseries in Ontario, California.

Prunus salicina 'Billington' produces fruit with red-purple skin and red flesh, and it is a heavy cropper in early to mid-summer with a good flavor. The white flowers of Prunus salicina 'Billington' appear in the spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted with Prunus salicina 'Black Doris'. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina.

Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' produces medium to large fruit with dark black-purple skin and firm, dark-red flesh. The fruit ripens from late-summer to early-autumn, and Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' is a vigorous, upright tree with heavy crops of fruit. This plum is an excellent all-purpose fruit, suitable for eating, jams, sauces, and bottling. The white flowers of Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' appear in the spring, and its leaves turn yellow in the autumn. Pollinators for Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' include Prunus salicina 'Billington' and Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa'. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' was probably developed in the early 20th century by Lewis John Billington (1884-1955) in Auckland, New Zealand and named after his daughter, Doris.

Prunus salicina 'Black Doris/Billington' is a double plum. See Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' and Prunus salicina 'Billington' for descriptions. First image is of Prunus salicina 'Black Doris', second is of Prunus salicina 'Billington'. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina.

This plum cultivar produces large, sweet and juicy fruit with yellow flesh and dark-red, round skin. It is a heavy cropper, yielding fruit in mid-summer. Prunus salicina 'Burbank' features white flowers in spring and yellow autumn leaves. Although it is partially self-fertile, planting it with another cultivar such as Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' can result in better yields. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Burbank' was selected in 1885 by Luther Burbank (1849-1926) in Santa Rosa, California, United States from seedlings he had received from Isaac Bunting in Yokohama, Japan. Luther sent one to Professor Van Deman, a pomologist for the United States Department of Agriculture, who recommended that this seedling be named after Luther Burbank, and the American Pomological Society introduced Prunus salicina 'Burbank' in 1897.

The fruit is a sizable, circular, and vivid red plum with fragrant, amber-colored flesh. It is densely meaty, sugary, and succulent, ripening in the middle to late part of summer. Prunus salicina 'Fortune' bears white blossoms during the spring season, and its pollinator is Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa'. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Fortune' turn yellow during the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Fortune' originated in 1967 at the United States Horticultural Field Station in Fresno, California, United States, was selected in 1971 by John H. Weinberger, and was released in New Zealand in the mid-1980s.

The fruit has a sizable and dark-red skin, with flesh that is also dark-red in color. It is a freestone variety, with a sweet, juicy, and very firm texture, and is typically ripe around late-summer to early-autumn. Prunus salicina 'Hawera' blooms white flowers during the spring, and it is self-fertile. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Hawera' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Hawera' was discovered growing on the roadside near Hawera, Taranaki, New Zealand.

The fruit is a large and juicy plum, with yellow-red skin and yellow flesh, shaped like a mango, and has a very aromatic and sweet flavor. It typically ripens in mid-summer and is relatively easy to cultivate and maintain in a home garden setting. Prunus salicina 'Luisa' produces white flowers during the spring season and is self-fertile, although planting it with Prunus salicina 'Billington' can result in a higher yield. Moreover, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Luisa' turn yellow during the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Luisa' originated before 1986 at a property owned by Doug and Maria Falconer in Nelson Street, Hamilton, New Zealand and was named after Maria's grandmother (PVR 742).

Prunus salicina 'Omega' produces abundant crops of mid-sized, speckled red fruit with red flesh, ripening in the early-autumn period. The fruit is freestone, and Prunus salicina 'Omega' produces white flowers in the spring season. While Prunus salicina 'Omega' is partially self-fertile, planting it with Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa', Prunus salicina 'Billington', or Prunus salicina 'Burbank' can result in better yields. In addition, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Omega' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina.

The fruit is very large, with purple skin and yellow flesh, and has a sweet and juicy taste. It typically ripens in the late-summer period and is an excellent choice for cultivation in warmer regions. Prunus salicina 'Purple King' produces white flowers during the spring season and has low to moderate resistance to bacterial disease. To achieve pollination, it requires Prunus salicina 'Billington' or Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa'. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Purple King' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina.

The fruit has dark red-purple skin and sweet, juicy, red flesh. Prunus salicina 'Ruby Queen' is highly productive, with good disease resistance, making it an excellent choice for organic growing and areas with high humidity. The fruit ripens in late-summer to early-autumn, and Prunus salicina 'Ruby Queen' produces white flowers in the spring season. Prunus salicina 'Ruby Queen' requires Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' for pollination. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Ruby Queen' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Ruby Queen' was selected in 1985 by W. R. Okie and his colleagues at the Agricultural Research Service Southeastern Fruit and Tree Nut Research Laboratory in Byron, Georgia, United States and was released in 2004.
