The fruit is medium to large, round, and crimson-red, with yellow flesh that is flushed with pink. It has a sweet and juicy taste with excellent flavors, making it an all-purpose plum that can be eaten fresh, used in jams, or made into sauces. The fruit ripens from mid-summer into autumn, and Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' produces white flowers during the spring season. While Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' is partially self-fertile, planting it with Prunus salicina 'Black Doris' can result in better yields. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' was developed by Luther Burbank (1849-1926) in Santa Rosa, California, United States and was introduced in 1906.

The plums have purple-red skin and red flesh, and Prunus salicina 'Satsuma' produces white flowers during the spring season. The fruit typically ripens around late-summer and while Prunus salicina 'Satsuma' is partially self-fertile, planting it with Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' or Prunus salicina 'Shiro' can result in better yields. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Satsuma' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Satsuma' was selected by Luther Burbank (1849-1926) in Santa Rosa, California, United States from seedlings he received in 1885 from Isaac Bunting in Yokohama, Japan and was first sold in 1889.

The plums are large, golden, sweet, and juicy, and they typically ripen in mid-summer. Prunus salicina 'Shiro' produces white flowers during the spring season, and the plums are versatile and can be used for eating, cooking, canning, preserves, and desserts. Prunus salicina 'Shiro' requires Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa' for pollination. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Shiro' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina. Prunus salicina 'Shiro' was developed in 1889 by Luther Burbank (1849-1926) in Santa Rosa, California, United States and was introduced in either 1898 or 1899.

The plums are large, with deep-red skin and red flesh that is juicy and highly-flavored. Prunus salicina 'Sultan' produces white flowers during the spring season, and the fruit ripens in the late-summer period. Prunus salicina 'Sultan' requires Prunus salicina 'Santa Rosa', Prunus salicina 'Burbank', and Prunus salicina 'Omega' as pollinators. Additionally, the leaves of Prunus salicina 'Sultan' turn yellow in the autumn months. Prunus salicina is deciduous and native to Russia, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Prunus salicina.

Prunus serrula is valued for its glistening, polished, red-brown, and mahogany-like peeling bark. It produces long, narrow, serrated, green leaves that appear with the single, white blossoms in mid-spring. The autumn foliage of Prunus serrula is stunning, with yellow leaves that add a bright splash of color. In the winter, the bare branches have a glow when illuminated by the sun. Prunus serrula forms an upright shape. Prunus serrula is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Prunus serrula.

Prunus serrulata 'Amanogawa' produces fragrant clusters of semi-double, white to pale-pink flowers, which bloom in mid to late-spring. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Amanogawa' turn orange and yellow, adding a bright splash of color. Prunus serrulata 'Amanogawa' is ideal for narrow spaces where height is required, as well as for lining avenues and driveways. It is also an excellent choice as a street tree. Prunus serrulata 'Amanogawa' can still be sold in Auckland until 1 September 2023 when they will make a final decision. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Amanogawa' originated in the 19th century in Japan.

Prunus serrulata 'Ichiyo' has a spreading habit with gracefully ascending main branches. In mid to late-spring, Prunus serrulata 'Ichiyo' produces double, shell-pink flowers that open from pink buds. These flowers fade to white as they age. The leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Ichiyo' emerge as bronze-green in the spring and age to deep-green over the summer months. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Ichiyo' turn beautiful shades of orange and red, adding a bright splash of color to any landscape. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Ichiyo' originated in the 19th century in Japan.

Young trees of this cultivar have a narrow, erect, vase-shaped growth habit, but they spread out as they mature. In mid to late-spring, Prunus serrulata 'Kanzan' produces large, fully-double, pink flowers held in drooping clusters, which open from deep-pink buds. The bronze leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Kanzan' emerge with the flowers, providing a nice contrast. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Kanzan' turn shades of red, orange, and yellow, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus serrulata 'Kanzan' is an excellent choice for lining avenues and driveways and is also known for being one of the wind-hardiest flowering cherry trees. Prunus serrulata 'Kanzan' is not banned in Auckland. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Kanzan' was developed in Japan in the Edo period (1603-1867).

Prunus serrulata 'Kiku-shidare-zakura' has branches that arch before cascading down towards the ground. In mid to late-spring, Prunus serrulata 'Kiku-shidare-zakura' produces large, double, frilly, pink flowers that are borne in clusters. The spring leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Kiku-shidare-zakura' are bronze in color, and they turn green over the summer months. In the autumn, the leaves turn shades of red, orange, and yellow, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus serrulata 'Kiku-shidare-zakura' can still be sold in Auckland until 1 September 2023 when they will make a final decision. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Kiku-shidare-zakura' originated in Japan in the 19th century.

Prunus serrulata 'Pink Perfection' has an erect, spreading, vase-shaped growth habit. Prunus serrulata 'Pink Perfection' produces bronze new leaves that turn green over the summer months and change to shades of orange, yellow, and red in the autumn, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. In mid to late-spring, Prunus serrulata 'Pink Perfection' produces fully double flowers with frilled margins, which start as bright rose-pink buds and open to clear pink. Prunus serrulata 'Pink Perfection' is an excellent choice for lining driveways and avenues, as well as for use as a street tree. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Pink Perfection' was developed in 1935 by Messrs Waterer, Son and Crisp in the United Kingdom.

synonyms: Prunus serrulata 'Shogetsu', Prunus serrulata 'Shimidsu-zakura', Prunus serrulata 'Shimizu-zakura', Prunus serrulata 'Okumiyako', Prunus serrulata f. longipes
description: Prunus serrulata 'Shimidsu-sakura' is one of the loveliest flowering cherries and grows into a broad-spreading tree with gracefully-arching branches. It produces double flowers in mid to late-spring, starting as pink buds that open into pale-pink blooms that eventually fade to white. The flowers are borne in pendulous clusters, adding a soft and delicate look to Prunus serrulata 'Shimidsu-sakura'. In the autumn, the leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Shimidsu-sakura' turn shades of orange and red, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus serrulata 'Shimidsu-sakura' is not banned in Auckland. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Shimidsu-sakura' originated in the 19th century in Japan.

synonyms: Prunus serrulata 'Mount Fuji', Prunus serrulata 'Kojima', Prunus serrulata 'Hosokawa', Prunus serrulata f. albida
description: Prunus serrulata 'Shirotae' is a strong-growing, wide-spreading, flat-top cherry with tiered, horizontal branches that grow as wide as its height. In mid-spring, Prunus serrulata 'Shirotae' produces large, fragrant, pure-white, semi-double flowers from white buds that are sometimes tinged with pink. The serrated green leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Shirotae' turn shades of yellow, red, and orange in the autumn months, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus serrulata 'Shirotae' is an excellent choice as a shade tree due to its wide-spreading, flat-top growth habit. Prunus serrulata 'Shirotae' can still be sold in Auckland until 1 September 2023 when they will make a final decision. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Shirotae' originated in the 19th century in Japan.

Prunus serrulata 'Tai-haku' is tall with a spreading growth habit and a rounded crown. In mid-spring, Prunus serrulata 'Tai-haku' produces large, pure-white, single, slightly-fragrant flowers that are borne in large clusters from pink buds, making it a spectacular blossom tree. The large leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Tai-haku' mature to a deep-green color over the summer months and turn shades of yellow, red, and orange in the autumn, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus serrulata 'Tai-haku' can still be sold in Auckland until 1 September 2023 when they will make a final decision. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Tai-haku' originated in the 19th century in Japan, but became extinct. A single specimen was found in 1923 by Collingwood Ingram in a garden in Sussex, England from which Prunus serrulata 'Tai-haku' has returned to cultivation.

Prunus serrulata 'Ukon' has a vase-shaped growth habit with upright, spreading branches. Soft-pink buds open to light-green to cream flowers, sometimes tinged with pink. Prunus serrulata 'Ukon' produces large, double flowers that are very unique and nestle among the bronze-colored emerging leaves. The flowers bloom from early to mid-spring. In the autumn months, the leaves of Prunus serrulata 'Ukon' turn shades of yellow, orange, and red, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus serrulata 'Ukon' can still be sold in Auckland until 1 September 2023 when they will make a final decision. Prunus serrulata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Prunus serrulata. Prunus serrulata 'Ukon' originated in the 19th century in Japan.

otherCommonNames: Winter-flowering Cherry, Spring Cherry, Rosebud Cherry
description: Prunus x subhirtella 'Autumnalis Rosea' has a compact growth habit with upright-growing branches. In the late-autumn to early-spring period, Prunus x subhirtella 'Autumnalis Rosea' produces semi-double, scented flowers that are borne in dainty clusters. The flowers are small and open to a pale-pink color from deep-pink buds. The small, deeply-serrated leaves of Prunus x subhirtella 'Autumnalis Rosea' turn shades of red and orange in the autumn months, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x subhirtella 'Autumnalis Rosea' is an excellent choice for smaller gardens and also makes a great street tree. Prunus x subhirtella is a hybrid between Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella) and Prunus incisa. Prunus x subhirtella is deciduous and native to Japan.

otherCommonNames: Winter-flowering Cherry, Spring Cherry, Rosebud Cherry
description: Prunus x subhirtella 'Falling Snow' has a tiered growth habit with arching and gracefully-pendant branches. From early to mid-spring, the branches of Prunus x subhirtella 'Falling Snow' are smothered with pink buds that open to small, single, pale-pink to white flowers, adding a soft and delicate look to Prunus x subhirtella 'Falling Snow'. In the autumn months, the leaves of Prunus x subhirtella 'Falling Snow' turn shades of yellow and orange, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x subhirtella is a hybrid between Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella) and Prunus incisa. Prunus x subhirtella is deciduous and native to Japan. Prunus x subhirtella 'Falling Snow' was developed in about 1985 by Lake County Nursery in Madison, Ohio, United States.

otherCommonNames: Winter-flowering Cherry, Spring Cherry, Rosebud Cherry
description: Prunus x subhirtella 'Peggy Wilson' has a vase-shaped growth habit with spreading branches, making it well-suited to smaller gardens. It flowers very well in warmer climates, and in early-spring, Prunus x subhirtella 'Peggy Wilson' becomes smothered with large, pale blush-pink blossoms, adding a soft and delicate look to the landscape. In the autumn months, the leaves of Prunus x subhirtella 'Peggy Wilson' turn shades of orange and yellow, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x subhirtella is a hybrid between Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella) and Prunus incisa. Prunus x subhirtella is deciduous and native to Japan. Prunus x subhirtella 'Peggy Wilson' was developed in New Zealand.

otherCommonNames: Winter-flowering Cherry, Spring Cherry, Rosebud Cherry
description: Prunus x subhirtella 'Pendula Rosea' has slender, willowy, arching branches that build up in tiers, creating a wide-spreading fountain effect. From late-winter to early-spring, the branches of Prunus x subhirtella 'Pendula Rosea' are smothered with deep-pink buds that open to small, single, pink flowers, adding a soft and delicate look to the landscape. In the autumn months, the leaves of Prunus x subhirtella 'Pendula Rosea' turn shades of yellow and orange, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x subhirtella is a hybrid between Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella) and Prunus incisa. Prunus x subhirtella is deciduous and native to Japan. Prunus x subhirtella 'Pendula Rosea' was introduced to Britain in around 1870.

otherCommonNames: Winter-flowering Cherry, Spring Cherry, Rosebud Cherry
description: Prunus x subhirtella 'Southern Gem' has an upright growth habit and produces dainty, semi-double, blush-pink blooms that fade to white throughout the autumn, winter, and spring seasons. Prunus x subhirtella 'Southern Gem' is tolerant of root confinement, making it a good choice for smaller spaces. In the autumn months, the foliage of Prunus x subhirtella 'Southern Gem' turns shades of yellow, orange, and red, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x subhirtella is a hybrid between Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella) and Prunus incisa. Prunus x subhirtella is deciduous and native to Japan. Prunus x subhirtella 'Southern Gem' was developed in Dunedin, New Zealand.

Prunus x yedoensis has a graceful, upright growth habit with arching branches that add a soft and delicate look to the landscape. In early-spring, Prunus x yedoensis becomes smothered with almond-scented, blush-white, single blossoms, making it spectacular when in full flower. In the autumn months, the foliage of Prunus x yedoensis turns shades of orange and red, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis is an excellent choice as a street tree due to its upright growth habit and stunning display of flowers. Prunus x yedoensis is a hybrid between Prunus speciosa and Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella). Prunus x yedoensis is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Prunus x yedoensis.

Prunus x yedoensis 'Awanui' has an erect, vase-shaped, spreading growth habit that adds structure and interest to the landscape. In early-spring, Prunus x yedoensis 'Awanui' becomes smothered in fragrant, blush-pink, single blossoms that emerge from deep-pink buds, creating an unforgettable sight when in full flower. The yellow and orange autumn leaves of Prunus x yedoensis 'Awanui' add a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis 'Awanui' is an excellent choice as a street tree due to its vase-shaped growth habit and stunning display of flowers. Prunus x yedoensis is a hybrid between Prunus speciosa and Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella). Prunus x yedoensis is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Prunus x yedoensis. Prunus x yedoensis 'Awanui' was selected by Keith Adams at his nursery in Awanui Street, New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Prunus x yedoensis 'Mountain Haze' produces masses of small, pale-pink to white flowers with deep-pink centers that cover the gently-arching branches in early-spring, adding a soft and delicate look to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis 'Mountain Haze' forms a tidy, rounded shape, making it an excellent choice for smaller gardens. In the autumn months, the foliage of Prunus x yedoensis 'Mountain Haze' turns shades of orange, red, and yellow, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis is a hybrid between Prunus speciosa and Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella). Prunus x yedoensis is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Prunus x yedoensis. Prunus x yedoensis 'Mountain Haze' was developed in New Zealand.

This large, spreading tree bears horizontal branches that weep at their tips, adding a soft and graceful look to the landscape. In mid-spring, the branches of Prunus x yedoensis 'Perpendens' become smothered in large, blush-pink to white, single blossoms, creating a stunning display. The gold, orange, and red autumn leaves of Prunus x yedoensis 'Perpendens' persist well into winter, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis 'Perpendens' thrives in a sunny and well-drained spot, making it important to choose the right location for planting. Prunus x yedoensis is a hybrid between Prunus speciosa and Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella). Prunus x yedoensis is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Prunus x yedoensis.

Prunus x yedoensis 'Te Mara' produces large bunches of scented, shell-pink, single flowers that add a soft and delicate look to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis 'Te Mara' typically blooms in early-spring, and the flowers are known to attract nectar-seeking birds, adding a touch of wildlife to the garden. Prunus x yedoensis 'Te Mara' has an upright growth habit, adding structure and height to the landscape. In the autumn months, the foliage of Prunus x yedoensis 'Te Mara' turns shades of orange and red, and the leaves persist well into winter, adding a bright splash of color to the landscape. Prunus x yedoensis is a hybrid between Prunus speciosa and Prunus itosakura (syn. Prunus subhirtella). Prunus x yedoensis is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Prunus x yedoensis. Prunus x yedoensis 'Te Mara' was selected by Keith Adams at his nursery in Awanui Street, New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Pseudopanax arboreus has a rounded shape with an open-habit and spreading framework of slender stems, adding a soft and natural look to the landscape. Pseudopanax arboreus produces large, glossy, handsome leaves that are a beautiful dark green color. In autumn, Pseudopanax arboreus produces decorative bunches of purple-black berries that are known to be relished by birds. This versatile plant is very hardy and can be pruned to any size, making it an excellent choice for smaller gardens. In mid-winter to early-spring, Pseudopanax arboreus produces small, white flowers flushed with red-pink, adding a touch of delicate beauty to the garden. Pseudopanax arboreus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax arboreus.

This narrow-growing tree has a tall, erect trunk, adding height and structure to the landscape. The juvenile leaves are long and narrow, and hang from the main trunk, creating a unique and striking look. After many years, the foliage changes to a small head of leaves, which vary in color from dark-green to orange-brown, usually with an orange-yellow midrib. Pseudopanax crassifolius provides a focal point for restricted sites where a hardy, dramatic tree is required. In mid-summer to early-autumn, Pseudopanax crassifolius produces small, green-yellow flowers, adding a touch of delicate beauty to the garden. Pseudopanax crassifolius is similar to Pseudopanax ferox but has less prominently-toothed leaves. Pseudopanax crassifolius is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax crassifolius.

Pseudopanax crassifolius 'Fiddlesticks' produces long, narrow leaves that adorn its upright, slender stems, adding height and structure to the landscape. The leaves are brilliantly colored, with dark-green tops, orange-yellow to red-yellow midribs, and red-pink undersides, creating a stunning and unique look. Pseudopanax crassifolius 'Fiddlesticks' is hardy and a slow but sturdy grower, making it an excellent choice for smaller gardens. In mid-summer to early-autumn, Pseudopanax crassifolius 'Fiddlesticks' produces small, green-yellow flowers, adding a touch of delicate beauty to the garden. Pseudopanax crassifolius is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax crassifolius. Pseudopanax crassifolius 'Fiddlesticks' was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

This narrow-growing tree has a tall, erect trunk, adding height and structure to the landscape. The juvenile leaves are short and narrow, distinctly-toothed, and hang from the main trunk, creating a unique and striking look. After many years, the foliage changes to a small head of leaves, which vary in color from dark-green to orange-brown, usually with an orange-yellow midrib. Pseudopanax ferox provides a focal point for restricted sites where a hardy, dramatic tree is required. Pseudopanax ferox is similar to Pseudopanax crassifolius, but has more prominently-toothed leaves. Pseudopanax ferox is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax ferox.

This is a resilient plant with a tropical appearance, characterized by multiple stems and large, deep-green, glossy, leathery leaves that emerge on purple-red stems. In the spring, it produces decorative clusters of black berries that are a favorite among birds. This versatile plant is also highly adaptable and can be pruned to fit any desired size. During the late-winter to late-spring, it produces small white flowers, followed by purple fruits in the late-spring to late-summer, which are also a favored food of birds. Pseudopanax laetus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax laetus.

This is a dense and bushy plant that is characterized by tough, leathery, green leaves. It thrives in dry locations and is well-suited to coastal environments. Pseudopanax lessonii is an excellent option for filling in space or creating a dense screen. It can also be pruned to any desired size. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii.

With its erect stems and bright-green, glossy, palmate leaves, Pseudopanax lessonii 'Adiantifolius' is a dense and bushy grower that also features tough, leathery green leaves. It thrives in dry conditions and is well-suited to coastal environments. This versatile tree is excellent as a filler or to create a dense screen, and it can be pruned to any desired size. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii.

This unique tree is characterized by a distinct, low-growing stature with a compact and bushy habit. Its broad, green leaves are very thick and leathery in texture. It prefers dry conditions and is well-suited for coastal environments. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Cyril Watson' is an excellent option for filling in space or growing in a container. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Cyril Watson' was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and named after one of their sales managers, Cyril Watson, who was involved in the development and introduction of Pseudopanax lessonii 'Cyril Watson'.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Dark Star' is a handsome and narrow grower with erect stems that produce new growth in a deep shade of purple, gradually fading to a dark-green color with purple margins. It is an ideal choice for small spaces and can serve as an excellent, hardy filler in a variety of environments, including coastal areas. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Dark Star' was developed in New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Dreamtime' is an erect grower with long-fingered and heavily-serrated leaves. The leaves are typically purple-green in color, but during winter, they develop a deeper shade of purple. It is a hardy tree that can withstand various environmental conditions. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Dreamtime' was developed in New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Gold Finger' features thin, three-fingered leaves with bright gold-yellow new growth that eventually fades to a lush bright-green color. It can be used as a stunning backdrop in a garden or planted in pots for a short time. To maintain the intensity of the gold-yellow growth, Pseudopanax lessonii 'Gold Finger' benefits from being exposed to direct sunlight. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Gold Finger' was developed in New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Moa's Toes' is characterized by leathery leaves that are strongly-lobed to resemble moa's toes. The deep-green leaves also feature a purple-red margin. It is an upright, bushy grower that can thrive in coastal and drought-prone environments. However, it should be protected from heavy frosts. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Moa's Toes' was developed in New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Purpurea' is a dense, bushy, and compact grower that produces leaves which emerge in a purple shade before maturing to a dark-green color. It thrives in dry locations and is well-suited for coastal environments. This versatile plant can be used as a filler or to create a dense screen, and it can be pruned to any desired size. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Purpurea' was developed in New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Sabre' is an erect, narrow grower that features long, lance-shaped leaves with slightly saw-toothed edges. The dark-green, leathery leaves also have a yellow midrib, adding to its visual appeal. It thrives in dry locations and is well-suited for coastal environments. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Sabre' is an excellent choice as a focal point or to add interest to narrow spaces. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Sabre' is a hybrid between Pseudopanax crassifolius and Pseudopanax lessonii and was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Telstar' is a dense, bushy grower that features tough, leathery, green, palmate leaves that are finely-cut. It thrives in dry locations and is well-suited for coastal environments. This versatile plant is an excellent option for filling in space or creating a dense screen. It can also be pruned to any desired size. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Telstar' was developed in New Zealand.

Pseudopanax lessonii 'Trident' is an erect grower that features a small trunk from which arise many upward-growing branches. It is densely-clothed with tough, leathery, green leaves that are three-lobed in shape. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Trident' thrives in dry locations and is well-suited for coastal environments. It is an excellent option for filling in space, lining driveways, or as a street tree. Additionally, it can be pruned to any desired size. Pseudopanax lessonii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudopanax lessonii. Pseudopanax lessonii 'Trident' was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Pseudowintera colorata is an attractive grower with aromatic foliage that is rich-red in color when young, gradually maturing to a yellow-green with red speckles and margins. It makes a stunning hedge due to its unique coloration and appearance. Pseudowintera colorata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudowintera colorata.

Pseudowintera colorata 'Red Hot' is a selection of Pseudowintera colorata that features deeper and more consistent coloring than the typical species. It is an attractive grower with aromatic foliage that is rich-red in color when young, eventually maturing to a yellow-green with red speckles and margins. Due to its unique coloration and appearance, it is an excellent choice for creating a stunning hedge. Pseudowintera colorata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudowintera colorata. Pseudowintera colorata 'Red Hot' was developed before 2018 by Elliots Wholesale Nursery in Amberley, New Zealand (PVR 34007).

Pseudowintera colorata 'Red Leopard' is a selection of Pseudowintera colorata that features deeper and more consistent coloring than the typical species. It is an attractive grower with aromatic foliage that is rich-red in color when young, eventually maturing to a yellow-green with red speckles and margins. Due to its unique coloration and appearance, it is an excellent choice for creating a stunning hedge. Pseudowintera colorata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Pseudowintera colorata. Pseudowintera colorata 'Red Leopard' was developed before 1996 by D. Hughes at Blue Mountain Nurseries in Tapanui, New Zealand (PVR 1403).

otherCommonNames: Red Strawberry Guava, Red Cherry Guava
description: Psidium cattleyanum var. cattleyanum produces white flowers in the spring, followed by sweet, tangy, and red fruit in mid-autumn. It can tolerate light frosts once established and can be trimmed into a hedge or screen. Additionally, it is self-fertile, meaning it can produce fruit on its own without requiring another plant for pollination. Psidium cattleyanum var. cattleyanum is evergreen and native to Brazil and Uruguay. Learn more about Psidium cattleyanum var. cattleyanum.

Pyrus betulifolia 'Autumn Leaves' features graceful branches and dark-green foliage throughout spring and summer, which transforms into beautiful red and orange tones in autumn. It produces white flowers in the spring and can tolerate frosts, moderate winds, and periods of drought. Pyrus betulifolia is deciduous and native to China, Laos, Tibet, and Russia. Learn more about Pyrus betulifolia.

This fruit has the appearance and taste of an apple, but with the skin and texture of a pear. It has green skin with a red blush and is very sweet and juicy, making it a healthy and delicious snack. The fruit is ready to harvest from late-summer to early-autumn. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted with another pear cultivar. Pyrus x bretschneideri 'Reddy Robin' also features white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, making it a beautiful addition to any garden. Pyrus x bretschneideri is a hybrid between Pyrus pyrifolia and Pyrus betulifolia. Pyrus x bretschneideri is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Pyrus x bretschneideri. Pyrus x bretschneideri 'Reddy Robin' was developed before 2010 by the New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research (PVR 30814).

Pyrus calleryana 'Aristocrat' is a pyramidal-growing tree with an open form and spreading branches that can be trained to grow horizontally. It produces a profusion of white flowers in early spring and glossy-green leaves that turn red and yellow in autumn, adding a vibrant splash of color to any garden or street. It is tolerant of poor drainage and pollution, making it an excellent choice as a street tree or for urban environments. Pyrus calleryana is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Pyrus calleryana. Pyrus calleryana 'Aristocrat' was selected in 1969 from Pyrus calleryana seedlings grown at a nursery near Independence, Kentucky, United States and was released into commerce in 1972 (USPP3193).

Pyrus calleryana 'Bradford' is pyramidal-growing and features densely-packed branches. One of its most stunning features is the profusion of white blossoms that appear in early spring. The glossy green leaves of Pyrus calleryana 'Bradford' turn a beautiful array of colors in autumn, including red, orange, and maroon. Due to its size and hardiness, it is an excellent choice as a street tree. Pyrus calleryana is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Pyrus calleryana. Pyrus calleryana 'Bradford' originated at the United States Department of Agriculture station in Glenn Dale, Maryland, United States from Pyrus calleryana seed purchased in 1919 in Nanjing, China and was released into commerce in 1960.

Pyrus calleryana 'Candelabra' features a dense, columnar growth habit, making it ideal for planting in avenues, streets, and narrow spaces. It produces lustrous, dark-green leaves that turn vibrant shades of red and orange during autumn, adding a beautiful touch of color to any landscape. Pyrus calleryana 'Candelabra' is very tolerant of wind and can grow in a range of soils, including dry, poor, and intermittently wet soils. Additionally, it produces white flowers in the spring, making it an attractive addition to any garden or street. Pyrus calleryana is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Pyrus calleryana. Pyrus calleryana 'Candelabra' was developed before 2013 by Frank Goeddert of Frank's Trees in Nelson, New Zealand (PVR 31198).

Pyrus calleryana 'Kea' is a multi-branched tree with a dense, bushy growth habit. Its glossy, green leaves turn red and orange during autumn, adding a stunning touch of color to any landscape. It is a hardy plant that can tolerate both dry and heavier, intermittently wet soils. Additionally, it produces white flowers in the spring, making it an attractive addition to any garden or landscape. Pyrus calleryana is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Pyrus calleryana. Pyrus calleryana 'Kea' was developed before 2002 by M. Sligh in Queenstown, New Zealand (PVR 2374).

Pyrus communis 'Conference' produces long-necked, green pears with some russeting, featuring an excellent juicy flavor. It is moderately-vigorous and slightly-spreading, making it an excellent choice for home gardeners. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted with Pyrus communis 'Packham's Triumph'. The fruit ripens in mid-autumn, and Pyrus communis 'Conference' also produces white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Conference' was developed by Thomas Francis Rivers at his Rivers Nursery in Sawbridgeworth, England and was named after winning first prize at the National British Pear Conference in London, England in 1885.

Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice' produces large, classic, gourmet pears that are widely considered to be some of the best-tasting pears available. The fruit features green skin flushed with red and rich, juicy flesh that tastes like sweetened cinnamon. It ripens in mid to late autumn, and Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice' has an upright and vigorous growth habit. It requires high chilling hours to set fruit, and pollinators include Pyrus communis 'Beurre Bosc', Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien', Pyrus communis 'Winter Cole', and Pyrus communis 'Winter Nelis'. Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice' produces white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice' was raised in 1849 - 1850 at the garden owned by the Comice Horticole in Angers, France by the gardener Hilaire Dhommé and the President of the Comice Horticole, Millet de la Turtaudière.

Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice/Conference' is a double pear. See Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice' and Pyrus communis 'Conference' for descriptions. Image is of Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice'. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis.

Pyrus communis 'Red Bartlett' produces pears with bright-red skin when fully ripe. The fruit is very aromatic and has a melty flesh with good flavor. It ripens in mid to late summer and is an all-purpose pear that can be used for eating fresh, preserving, baking, and poaching. Pollinators for Pyrus communis 'Red Bartlett' in the North Island are Pyrus communis 'Packham's Triumph' and Pyrus communis 'Winter Nelis', while in the South Island, the pollinators are Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice' and Pyrus communis 'Conference'. Pyrus communis 'Red Bartlett' produces white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Red Bartlett' was discovered in the early 1930s as a bud sport (spontaneous mutation) on a Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien' tree in Victoria, Australia.

Pyrus communis 'Seckel' produces small to medium-sized gourmet fruit with a golden color and a red blush. The yellow flesh is finely grained, juicy, and melting with spicy overtones, making it an excellent choice for eating. Pyrus communis 'Seckel' is resistant to fireblight and its pollinators include Pyrus communis 'Packham's Triumph' and Pyrus communis 'Winter Nelis'. Pyrus communis 'Seckel' produces white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Seckel' is believed to have been discovered in the early 1800s by a farmer growing as a wild seedling near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States.

Pyrus communis 'Taylor's Gold' produces pears with russeted, cinnamon-colored skin and a juicy, aromatic flavor. The flesh is ivory to cream-colored. The fruit ripens from mid to late autumn and its pollinators include Pyrus communis 'Packham's Triumph', Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien', and Pyrus communis 'Winter Cole'. Pyrus communis 'Taylor's Gold' produces white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Taylor's Gold' was discovered in 1986 growing in an orchard belonging to Michael King-Turner in Motueka, New Zealand (PVR 626).

Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien' produces large, green-yellow fruit that is great for eating or bottling. The fruit is harvested from late summer to early autumn and keeps well. It is also a good pollinator, and its pollinators include Pyrus communis 'Beurre Bosc', Pyrus communis 'Winter Nelis', Pyrus communis 'Doyenné du Comice', and Pyrus communis 'Conference'. Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien' produces white blossoms in the spring and yellow and orange autumn leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien' is thought to have originated sometime from 1765 to 1770 in the yard of John Stair in Aldermaston, England.

Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien/Conference' is a double pear. See Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien' and Pyrus communis 'Conference' for descriptions. Image is of Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien'. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis.

In late-autumn, small dessert pears with russeted, green skin ripen. It is a prolific and reliable fruiter, and has a spreading growth habit. The fruit lasts well into winter, making it a good keeper. Its pollinators include Pyrus communis 'Beurre Bosc', Pyrus communis 'Packham's Triumph', and Pyrus communis 'Williams' Bon Chrétien'. During spring, Pyrus communis 'Winter Cole' produces white blossoms, and in autumn, its leaves turn yellow and orange. Pyrus communis is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Pyrus communis. Pyrus communis 'Winter Cole' is a seedling of Pyrus communis 'Winter Nelis' that was raised by J. C. Cole in Richmond, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia and was introduced in the late 1880s.

In spring, the willow-like leaves of Pyrus salicifolia 'Pendula' are silver-white and turn grey-green during the summer. It forms tiers of branches that can be easily trimmed. Pyrus salicifolia 'Pendula' produces small, white blossoms in the spring and can withstand strong winds and drought conditions. Pyrus salicifolia is deciduous and native to Iran, Turkey, Russia, Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan. Learn more about Pyrus salicifolia.

Pyrus pyrifolia 'Hosui' has golden-brown skin, and is extremely juicy with fine-grain textured flesh, a rich flavour and tastes distinctly of brandy. Partly sel-fertile but will produce more fruit when planted near another Asian Pea, or Bartlett variety. Early spring brings dainty white flowers, and copper bronze foliage, followed by fruit in mid-summer, and finally bright red leaves in autumn. Prune in late spring to early summer to encourage the best crop. Pyrus pyrifolia 'Hosui' will easily grow in fertile well-drained soils and full sun, but will need shelter and protection from frosts. Pyrus pyrifolia is deciduous and native to China. Pyrus pyrifolia 'Hosui' was first developed in the 1970's by the National Horticulture Research Station of Japan.

When young, Quercus afares has a pyramidal or fastigiate habit, but it spreads as it ages. It develops corky bark that is thinner than the corky bark found on Quercus suber and bears plentiful crops of acorns. It can tolerate dry, coastal sites and is semi-evergreen in warm climates. Quercus afares is deciduous and native to Algeria and Tunisia. Learn more about Quercus afares.

This is an easily-grown, rounded tree that produces glossy leaves felted with grey underneath. During autumn, the leaves turn a vibrant orange-red, especially in warm, sunny weather. Quercus bicolor also produces acorns and can tolerate moist soils, making it suitable for growth on the edge of water. Quercus bicolor is deciduous and native to southeast Canada and north-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Quercus bicolor.

This is a handsome, large, fast-growing tree with grey, deeply-fissured bark. Its glossy-green leaves turn yellow and brown in autumn, and in warm climates, it can be semi-evergreen. Quercus canariensis produces large crops of acorns and can grow equally well on light and heavy soils. It is also tolerant of dry, coastal sites. Quercus canariensis is deciduous and native to Algeria, Morocco, Portugal, Spain, and Tunisia. Learn more about Quercus canariensis.

This oak is one of the hardiest and can tolerate strong winds and drought conditions once established. Its thick, glossy, green leaves last through summer, and turn yellow in autumn. Quercus canariensis x robur produces copious quantities of acorns and has an upright and broadly-spreading form. Quercus canariensis x robur is deciduous and native to Morocco and Spain.

otherCommonNames: Bitter Oak, Mossy-cupped Oak, Wainscot Oak
description: This oak is fast-growing and coastal-hardy, producing a wide-spreading tree of noble proportions. Its rich-green, oblong, lobed leaves turn yellow in autumn, making it an excellent choice for both shelter and as a specimen tree. Quercus cerris also produces large crops of acorns. Quercus cerris is deciduous and native from south-central and southern Europe to Turkey, Syria, and Lebanon. Learn more about Quercus cerris.

This oak is one of the most brilliantly-coloured, with its fiery-scarlet autumn leaves that persist well into winter. It forms a stately specimen with an open-branching structure that allows lawn to grow underneath. Quercus coccinea is more narrow-growing than most oaks. Quercus coccinea is deciduous and native to north-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Quercus coccinea.

Quercus ellipsoidalis produces glossy, green, deeply-cut leaves that turn scarlet and purple in autumn. It is tolerant of strong, prevailing winds. Quercus ellipsoidalis is deciduous and native to Canada and the United States. Learn more about Quercus ellipsoidalis.

Quercus ilex forms a large tree with a dense, wide-spreading crown. Its small, leathery leaves are dark-green with grey undersides. Quercus ilex is coastal and drought-hardy, and with its dense form and smaller leaves, it can be clipped into a tough hedge or screen. It is also an excellent choice for training into topiary forms. Quercus ilex is evergreen and native to south-central Europe and parts of the Mediterranean. Learn more about Quercus ilex.

This is a vigorous-growing, columnar tree with lanceolate, glossy-green leaves. Its new spring growth is bronze-red, adding an extra dimension of interest to Quercus laurina. The supple, slender stems of Quercus laurina lend themselves well to being trained horizontally for espaliering and pleaching. Additionally, it can be easily clipped into standards and other forms. Quercus laurina is deciduous and native to Mexico. Learn more about Quercus laurina.

Quercus mexicana has an open, spreading, round-headed form. Its thick, leathery, dark-green leaves have no teeth or lobes, contributing to its unique appearance. The distinctive bark of Quercus mexicana is covered with bumps and ridges, adding to its character. It is coastal and drought tolerant. Quercus mexicana is deciduous and native to Mexico. Learn more about Quercus mexicana.

Quercus palustris has a neat, pyramidal habit with spreading branches. Its glossy, green, deeply-cut leaves turn scarlet and orange in autumn, adding to its beauty. Quercus palustris is tolerant of wet soils and strong winds, making it a hardy choice for various growing conditions. Quercus palustris is deciduous and native to north-central and eastern United States and Ontario, Canada. Learn more about Quercus palustris.

This is a handsome, full-canopy shade tree that differs from Quercus robur in its long-stalked, broadly-oval, large leaves. Quercus petraea x robur produces clusters of oval acorns, which add to its overall appeal. It is coastal and drought hardy, making it a suitable choice for a variety of growing conditions. Quercus petraea x robur is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Quercus petraea x robur.

This is the classic oak, famed for its broad shape, deep-fissured bark, and characteristic acorns. Its lime-green leaves in spring mature into a dark-green color. The leaves turn yellow in autumn and persist into winter, making it an attractive tree year-round. It is ideal for parks, paddocks, lining avenues, and as a magnificent specimen tree. Quercus robur is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Quercus robur.

Quercus robur 'Fastigiata' has a neat, tight, columnar habit, making it a great choice for narrow spaces where height is required. Its dark-green leaves turn yellow in autumn, then brown in winter. Quercus robur 'Fastigiata' is versatile and can be planted as a screen, to line avenues and driveways, or as a focal point. It is also an excellent street tree due to its slender form. Quercus robur is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Quercus robur.

This is a large, broad-headed tree with deep-green leaves that turn red and yellow in autumn, adding to its beauty. Quercus rubra becomes a high-branched, wide-spreading tree with a deep rooting-system, which allows lawn and other plants to be grown underneath it. Additionally, Quercus rubra produces acorns. Quercus rubra is deciduous and native to southeastern Canada and north-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Quercus rubra.

Quercus suber is characterized by its thick, fissured, corky bark. Its small, oval, toothed leaves are dark-green with grey undersides. Quercus suber is coastal and drought hardy, making it suitable for various growing conditions. It can be clipped into a tough hedge or screen, and is also ideal for training into topiary forms. Additionally, it is an excellent choice for a street tree. Quercus suber is evergreen and native to Algeria, France, Italy, Morocco, Portugal, Spain, and Tunisia. Learn more about Quercus suber.

Radermachera sinica has erect stems that are covered in bipinnate, glossy, green leaves. It is an excellent quick-growing, narrow screen, and can be cut back severely to renew growth quickly. However, it only tolerates moderate frosts. It is also an excellent choice for a container plant. Radermachera sinica produces white, trumpet-like, hanging flowers in late summer, adding to its beauty. Radermachera sinica is evergreen and native to China and Taiwan. Learn more about Radermachera sinica.

This palm is elegant, graceful, and slow-growing. It grows best in a shady, sheltered spot in moist soil, but it can also grow out in the open, although the leaves may not be as lush. It looks best when planted in groups. Note that this palm is frost tender, so it is important to protect it from cold temperatures. Rhopalostylis sapida is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Rhopalostylis sapida.

This palm is known as the world's most southern palm. It is hardier than Rhopalostylis sapida to both frost and drought and has broader leaves. Rhopalostylis sapida var. chathamica can handle coastal and exposed conditions, making it a great choice for a variety of growing conditions. Rhopalostylis sapida var. chathamica is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the Chatham Islands. Learn more about Rhopalostylis sapida var. chathamica.

Robinia x ambigua 'Bella's Gold' is a compact grower with golden-yellow leaves that contrast nicely against its new red stems. It can be clipped into a topiary form for added interest. Robinia x ambigua 'Bella's Gold' produces long, white, pea-like flowers in early summer, adding to its beauty. Robinia x ambigua is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, a hybrid between Robinia viscosa and Robinia pseudoacacia, and originated shortly before 1812 in France. Robinia x ambigua 'Bella's Gold' was developed in New Zealand.

synonyms: Robinia x margaretta 'Casque Rouge', Robinia x margaretiae 'Pink Cascade', Robinia x slavinii 'Casque Rouge'
description: This is a round-headed tree with black bark and soft, mid-green, pinnate leaves. In late spring, Robinia x margaretiae 'Casque Rouge' produces short, pendulous racemes of showy, lilac-pink flowers in great profusion, adding to its beauty. It is a shade tree that is suitable for smaller gardens. During autumn, the leaves turn yellow. Robinia x margaretiae 'Casque Rouge' is tolerant of heat, drought, and pollution. Robinia x margaretiae is a hybrid between Robinia hispida and Robinia pseudoacacia. Robinia x margaretiae is deciduous and native to the eastern United States. Robinia x margaretiae 'Casque Rouge' has an unknown origin, but the first recorded mention of it was in 1934 when it was sold in the United States.

This is an elegant, ornamental tree with delicate, mid-green foliage that develops a rounded head of branches. It produces fragrant, pink flowers in spring, with attractive pea-like flowers that hang in racemes along the branches. During autumn, the leaves turn yellow, adding to the beauty of Robinia x margaretiae 'Hillieri'. Robinia x margaretiae 'Hillieri' is easy to grow in full sun, tolerant of drought, and is hardy. Robinia x margaretiae is a hybrid between Robinia hispida and Robinia pseudoacacia. Robinia x margaretiae is deciduous and native to the eastern United States. Robinia x margaretiae 'Hillieri' was raised by Messrs Hillier at Hillier Nurseries in Ampfield, United Kingdom and named in 1933.

Robinia pseudoacacia 'Frisia' is one of the most brilliantly-coloured, with its yellow foliage. It forms a neat, rounded head on a sturdy trunk, and its golden-yellow colour is maintained until leaf-drop. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Frisia' is tolerant of heat, drought, and pollution, making it an excellent choice as a street tree. It may sometimes produce long, white, pea-like flowers in early summer, adding to its beauty. Robinia pseudoacacia is deciduous and native to eastern-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Robinia pseudoacacia. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Frisia' was found by W. Jansen in around 1935 at a former nursery in Zwollerkerspel, Overijssel, Netherlands.

Robinia pseudoacacia 'Lace Lady' has rich, green, pendulous leaves that cover stems which are uniquely contorted and twisted, adding to its visual interest. It is an ideal choice for container planting and small gardens. During autumn, the leaves turn soft-yellow. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Lace Lady' is tolerant of heat and drought, making it a hardy choice for various growing conditions. Sometimes, Robinia pseudoacacia 'Lace Lady' produces long, white, pea-like flowers in spring, adding to its beauty. Robinia pseudoacacia is deciduous and native to eastern-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Robinia pseudoacacia. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Lace Lady' was discovered in 1985 by Peter Cunningham as a chance seedling in a cultivated area in Kumeū, near Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 568 and USPP9771).

This is an improved cultivar, known for its softer spines and larger yellow leaves than Robinia pseudoacacia 'Frisia'. The leaves of Robinia pseudoacacia 'Tropical Splash' hold their color better through autumn, adding to its visual appeal. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Tropical Splash' forms a neat, rounded head on a sturdy trunk, making it an excellent choice as a street tree. Additionally, it is tolerant of heat, drought, and pollution, making it a hardy choice for various growing conditions. Robinia pseudoacacia is deciduous and native to eastern-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Robinia pseudoacacia. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Tropical Splash' was developed before 2010 by John McLaren in Cromwell, New Zealand (PVR 30819).

Robinia pseudoacacia 'Umbraculifera' has a compact, rounded head of spineless branches, making it an ideal choice for a variety of landscape designs. Its fresh, soft-green foliage is a visual delight, while its yellow autumn leaves add to its seasonal beauty. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Umbraculifera' is tolerant of heat and drought, making it a hardy choice for various growing conditions. Robinia pseudoacacia is deciduous and native to eastern-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Robinia pseudoacacia. Robinia pseudoacacia 'Umbraculifera' originated in France or Austria in about 1810 and was introduced to Britain in around 1820.

Salix babylonica is characterized by its arching, wide-spreading branches that weep to the ground, adding to its unique visual appeal. The branches are polished brown and covered with slender, deep-green leaves that have blue-grey undersides. During autumn, the leaves turn yellow. Salix babylonica produces slender catkins with new spring leaves. It is a wonderful choice as a paddock, park, or shade tree, and looks particularly great when planted next to water. Salix babylonica is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Salix babylonica.

otherCommonNames: Great Sallow, Goat Willow, Pussy Willow
description: Salix caprea 'Pendula' has a beautiful weeping form and is an excellent choice for moist areas and small gardens. In late winter, Salix caprea 'Pendula' is adorned with large, silver catkins that add to its visual interest. Salix caprea 'Pendula' has large, green, coarse leaves that are blue-green underneath, adding to its textural beauty. During autumn, the leaves turn yellow, adding to the seasonal interest of Salix caprea 'Pendula'. Salix caprea is deciduous and native to Europe, through parts of north Asia, to China and Japan. Learn more about Salix caprea. Salix caprea 'Pendula' originally came from James Smith (1759-1848) of Monkwood Grove near Ayr, Scotland. Apparently, James found Salix caprea 'Pendula' on the banks of the River Ayr. Salix caprea 'Pendula' was then put into commerce by Thomas Lang in Kilmarnock, Scotland and was first advertised in 1853.

Salix matsudana 'Tortuosa' has twisted and contorted branches and stems, making it an excellent choice for year-round interest in the landscape. The cut stems are popular for floral work and can be used in various floral arrangements. Salix matsudana 'Tortuosa' is attractive and ornamental, and is well-suited for damp soils. During autumn, the leaves turn a golden-yellow color, adding to its seasonal interest. Salix matsudana is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Salix matsudana. Salix matsudana 'Tortuosa' was originally cultivated in China and then introduced in the early 1920s to France by Joseph Hers (1884-1965).

Salix vitellina 'Pendula Aurea' is characterized by its graceful form, with arching, wide-spreading branches that weep to the ground, adding to its visual appeal. Salix vitellina 'Pendula Aurea' has golden-yellow new branches that are covered with slender, soft-green leaves, adding to its beauty. It is an excellent choice as a shade tree for parks and paddocks and looks particularly great when planted next to water. During autumn, the leaves turn a golden-yellow color, adding to its seasonal interest. Salix vitellina 'Pendula Aurea' is correctly known as Salix x sepulcralis 'Chrysocoma', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Salix x sepulcralis is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Salix alba and Salix babylonica. Learn more about Salix x sepulcralis. The origin of Salix x sepulcralis 'Chrysocoma' is not certain, but it was put into commerce in 1888 by Späth nursery in Berlin, Germany.

otherCommonNames: Peruvian Pepper Tree, Brazilian Pepper Tree, Mulli
description: Schinus molle has a graceful habit and is characterized by its aromatic, dark-green foliage, adding to its visual appeal. During summer, Schinus molle produces white to yellow flowers, which are followed by red to purple berries in autumn and winter, adding to its beauty. Schinus molle is drought-tolerant and can withstand extreme heat, making it a hardy choice for various growing conditions. Schinus molle is evergreen and native to northeast Argentina, southern Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, Peru, and Uruguay. Learn more about Schinus molle.

This is a unique and rare tree that grows very slowly. While it can grow up to 30 meters in the forest, when grown in a pot or small garden, it will stay within 2 meters even after several decades. Sciadopitys verticillata forms a neat, pyramidal shape with symmetrical and horizontal branches, adding to its visual appeal. It has fibrous red-brown bark and leathery, glossy-green leaves in whorls. Sciadopitys verticillata prefers moist soils and should be protected from severe frosts when young. Sciadopitys verticillata is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Sciadopitys verticillata.

This is a stately tree that has a pyramidal form, making it an excellent choice for various landscape designs. It is considered one of the most handsome conifers and is noted for its longevity. Sequoia sempervirens is also quick-growing, adding to its appeal. It requires adequate moisture in free-draining soil to thrive. Sequoia sempervirens has straight, towering trunks that are covered in thick, red-brown bark, adding to its visual interest. Sequoia sempervirens is evergreen and native to the states of California and Oregon in the United States. Learn more about Sequoia sempervirens.

This is a selection of Sequoia sempervirens , which is more compact and smaller-growing compared to the species. Sequoia sempervirens 'Korbel' forms a bushy, conical shape with grey-green to silver-blue needles, adding to its visual appeal. It is also quick-growing, making it an excellent choice for various landscape designs. Sequoia sempervirens 'Korbel' is well-suited for growing as a shelter belt and prefers damp soil in a sheltered area to thrive. Unlike the species, it rarely produces cones or pollen. Sequoia sempervirens is evergreen and native to the states of California and Oregon in the United States. Learn more about Sequoia sempervirens. Sequoia sempervirens 'Korbel' was discovered before 1972 as an upper-crown branch mutation on a 600 year old Sequoia sempervirens growing near the town of Korbel, California, United States by PhD student, Kwabena Tufuor.

Sequoiadendron giganteum is different from Sequoia sempervirens in that it has a denser growth habit with shorter scales of deep blue-green, adding to its visual appeal. Sequoiadendron giganteum has a pyramidal form that is clothed from the ground upwards, making it an excellent choice as a specimen or for use in wide-spaced shelter belts. It prefers well-drained soils and can tolerate exposed and dry sites, adding to its hardiness. Sequoiadendron giganteum is evergreen and native to California, United States. Learn more about Sequoiadendron giganteum.

Sophora chathamica bears a profusion of golden-yellow flowers from late-winter to mid-spring, adding to its visual appeal. Sophora chathamica does not go through a juvenile tangle of shoots. Its larger leaves are more densely packed on the stems, making it an excellent choice for various landscape designs. Sophora chathamica is very hardy and can tolerate dry and windy positions, adding to its hardiness. Sophora chathamica is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora chathamica.

Sophora fulvida has a neat, spreading form, making it an excellent choice for various landscape designs. Its small, grey-green leaves can tolerate moderate coastal conditions and dryness, adding to its hardiness. Sophora fulvida produces large, golden-yellow flowers that attract nectar-seeking birds, adding to its visual appeal. It is an excellent street tree and flowers from mid to late-spring. Sophora fulvida is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora fulvida.

Sophora godleyi is a distinctive grower, with an upright form and pendulous side branches, adding to its unique and attractive appearance. From a distance, its leaves appear grey-green, adding to its visual appeal. Sophora godleyi produces yellow flowers from mid-spring to early-summer, further enhancing its aesthetic value. Sophora godleyi is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora godleyi.

Sophora godleyi 'Goldie's Mantle' is a bushier and more compact-growing cultivar of Sophora godleyi with pendulous branches, making it an excellent choice for various landscape designs. Like the species, it produces yellow flowers from mid-spring to early-summer, adding to its visual appeal. Sophora godleyi is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora godleyi. Sophora godleyi 'Goldie's Mantle' was selected by John Goldie from a tree near Ōhingaiti, New Zealand.

Sophora longicarinata forms a slender tree with tiny, fresh-green leaves, adding to its delicate and elegant appearance. It produces large, pale-yellow flowers that nectar-seeking birds adore, adding to its aesthetic value. Sophora longicarinata is an excellent choice as a street tree and flowers from mid-spring to mid-summer. Sophora longicarinata is evergreen and native to New Zealand on the limestone hills of Tākaka. Learn more about Sophora longicarinata.

Sophora microphylla is known for developing gracefully arching and spreading branches with small leaves, which add to its delicate appearance. It produces golden-yellow flowers that attract nectar-seeking birds, adding to its ornamental value. Sophora microphylla can be grown in sun or semi-shade but should be avoided in very dry sites. It looks lovely when sited overlooking water, adding to its overall aesthetic value. The flowers of Sophora microphylla appear from late-winter to mid-spring. Sophora microphylla is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora microphylla.

Sophora molloyi typically grows in a spreading, bushy manner and tends to be wider than it is tall. It can be found in coastal scrub environments located in exposed maritime sites. Its yellow flowers bloom from the middle of autumn until the middle of spring. Sophora molloyi is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora molloyi.

Sophora molloyi 'Dragon's Gold' is a dense, bushy grower that spreads widely, with an abundance of foliage. Its yellow flowers bloom from late autumn to early spring and are known to attract nectar-seeking birds. Sophora molloyi 'Dragon's Gold' is capable of enduring cold conditions and coastal winds. Sophora molloyi is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora molloyi. Sophora molloyi 'Dragon's Gold' was selected in the 1950s by Terry Hatch of Joy Plants from plant material sourced from Stephens Island, New Zealand.

Sophora tetraptera has larger leaves and flowers compared to Sophora microphylla. Its slender form gives it an elegant and airy appearance. The golden-yellow flowers of Sophora tetraptera are known to attract nectar-seeking birds. It is recommended to grow Sophora tetraptera in a location with some sun or semi-shade, and where the soil is not too dry. It can be particularly attractive when placed overlooking water. Sophora tetraptera typically blooms from mid-spring to early summer. Sophora tetraptera is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Sophora tetraptera.

Sorbus aria 'Lutescens' is compact and upright, with a pyramidal shape. Its bold, rounded leaves are covered in a dense layer of white hairs, which gives them a silvery appearance. In autumn, the leaves turn yellow, adding to the visual appeal of Sorbus aria 'Lutescens'. Sorbus aria 'Lutescens' is an excellent choice for planting along streets. Sorbus aria is deciduous and native to west, central, and southern Europe and northwestern Africa. Learn more about Sorbus aria. Sorbus aria 'Lutescens' was released into commerce in France before 1885 by Messrs Simon-Louis.

Sorbus aucuparia 'Scarlet King' has an erect growth habit with a compact, oval crown. Its grey-green pinnate leaves turn light-orange in autumn, adding to its beauty. Sorbus aucuparia 'Scarlet King' produces white flowers in late spring, which then develop into large bunches of bright-red, oval fruit from late summer to autumn. Sorbus aucuparia 'Scarlet King' thrives in climates with cold winters. It is also an excellent choice for a street tree. Sorbus aucuparia is deciduous and native to most of Europe, parts of Asia, and northern Africa. Learn more about Sorbus aucuparia.

Sorbus devonensis has a compact, oval, and rounded form. Its large, rounded leaves are green on the upper side and grey underneath. During autumn, the leaves turn yellow, adding to the visual appeal of Sorbus devonensis. In the spring, Sorbus devonensis produces white flowers, which are then followed by bunches of brown, speckled fruit from late summer to autumn. Sorbus devonensis is correctly known as Karpatiosorbus devoniensis, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Karpatiosorbus devoniensis is deciduous and native to Great Britain and Ireland. Learn more about Karpatiosorbus devoniensis.

otherCommonNames: Chinese Scholar Tree, Chinese Pagoda Tree
description: Styphnolobium japonicum 'Pendula' is known for its beautiful, weeping canopy formed by its drooping branches. The foliage of Styphnolobium japonicum 'Pendula' is deep-green, and oval-shaped, giving it a feathery appearance. In some cases, the foliage will turn yellow in the autumn before falling. Styphnolobium japonicum 'Pendula' produces stunning white flowers in late summer, which may continue into the autumn season. Styphnolobium japonicum is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Styphnolobium japonicum. Styphnolobium japonicum 'Pendula' was introduced into commerce in the United Kingdom by the Loddiges family in the early 19th century.

This beautiful tree has a slender trunk and a wide-spreading, fan-like branching structure, making it ideal for pleaching. In early summer, Styrax japonicus produces fragrant, bell-shaped, white flowers with golden stamens that hang gracefully beneath the branches. During the autumn season, the leaves of Styrax japonicus turn yellow, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Styrax japonicus is deciduous and native to China, Japan, and Korea. Learn more about Styrax japonicus.

This palm is a tall and elegant tree suitable for temperate areas. The trunk of Syagrus romanzoffiana remains narrow, providing wonderful height with a canopy of deep-green, upright, and spreading fronds. The leaves are soft, contributing to the overall elegance of Syagrus romanzoffiana. This palm is also known for its ability to withstand strong winds, including some coastal winds. Syagrus romanzoffiana is evergreen and native to northeast Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay. Learn more about Syagrus romanzoffiana.

x Sycoparrotia semidecidua is known for its broadly-spreading canopy and exfoliating bark. In the winter, small red flowers with red stamens bloom on the bare branches of x Sycoparrotia semidecidua, adding color to the otherwise drab season. During autumn, the green leaves turn a vibrant combination of yellow, orange, and red. x Sycoparrotia semidecidua can also be pleached, making it suitable for use as a colorful hedge. x Sycoparrotia semidecidua is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Parrotia persica and Sycopsis sinensis.

otherCommonNames: Brush Cherry, Scrub Cherry, Creek Lilly Pilly
description: Syzygium australe has a compact and upright growth habit that can be easily trimmed and shaped. The new foliage of Syzygium australe starts out maroon-red and gradually changes to a glossy, dark-green color as it matures. In the spring, Syzygium australe produces white flowers, which are then followed by small, edible, pink or dark-red fruit in autumn and winter. Syzygium australe is suitable for use as a hedge, screen, or for topiary. Once established, it is also able to tolerate both coastal and drought conditions. Syzygium australe is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales and Queensland in Australia. Learn more about Syzygium australe.

otherCommonNames: Brush Cherry, Scrub Cherry, Creek Lilly Pilly
description: Compared to Syzygium australe, Syzygium australe 'Resilience' is more resistant to psyllids, grows faster, has a straighter central leader, and a stronger root system. Its glossy-green foliage is preceded by striking red new growth. In the spring, Syzygium australe 'Resilience' produces white flowers, which are then followed by small, edible, pink or dark-red fruit in autumn and winter. Syzygium australe 'Resilience' is ideal for use as a hedge, screen, or for topiary, and is able to tolerate coastal and drought conditions once established. Syzygium australe is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales and Queensland in Australia. Learn more about Syzygium australe. Syzygium australe 'Resilience' was developed in Australia.

Taxodium distichum has a pyramidal shape and features soft-green, feathery leaves during the spring season. The leaves turn russet and gold in the autumn and are known to persist well into the winter months. Taxodium distichum can grow in up to 0.6 meters of water but can thrive in all marshy ground as well as ordinary garden soil. Taxodium distichum is deciduous and native to eastern and southeastern United States, Mexico, and Guatemala. Learn more about Taxodium distichum.

Taxodium distichum 'Cascade Falls' has soft-green, feathery leaves that emerge during the spring season. It features pendulous side branches that add to its ornamental value. The leaves turn russet and gold in the autumn and can persist well into the winter. Taxodium distichum 'Cascade Falls' is capable of growing in up to 0.6 meters of water but can also thrive in all marshy ground and ordinary garden soil. Taxodium distichum is deciduous and native to eastern and southeastern United States, Mexico, and Guatemala. Learn more about Taxodium distichum. Taxodium distichum 'Cascade Falls' was discovered before 1998 on the bank of a lake in Auckland, New Zealand and was introduced by Cedar Lodge Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand (PVR 1496).

Taxodium distichum 'McLaren Falls' has soft-green, feathery leaves that emerge during the spring season. It features pendulous side branches that add to its ornamental value. The leaves turn russet and gold in the autumn and can persist well into the winter. Taxodium distichum 'McLaren Falls' is capable of growing in up to 0.6 meters of water but can also thrive in all marshy ground and ordinary garden soil. Taxodium distichum is deciduous and native to eastern and southeastern United States, Mexico, and Guatemala. Learn more about Taxodium distichum. Taxodium distichum 'McLaren Falls' was discovered at McLaren Falls in Lower Kaimai, New Zealand.

otherCommonNames: Mexican Bald Cypress, Montezuma Swamp Cypress, Montezuma Bald Cypress, Ahuehuete
description: Taxodium distichum var. mexicanum is known for its broad-spreading canopy and slightly-bowed branches. It is capable of tolerating very wet conditions and can withstand extended flooding. Taxodium distichum var. mexicanum is correctly known as Taxodium mucronatum, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Taxodium mucronatum is deciduous and native to Mexico, Guatemala, and Texas, United States. Learn more about Taxodium mucronatum.

This enduring tree features dark-green, glossy leaves and has a slow growth rate. Its ability to be clipped and shaped easily makes it an excellent choice for formal plantings and topiary designs. Taxus baccata is evergreen and native to Europe, northwestern Africa, and Iran. Learn more about Taxus baccata.

Taxus baccata 'Fastigiata' has an erect and columnar growth habit, slowly forming a narrow, upright column of closely-packed branches. Taxus baccata 'Fastigiata' features small, dark-green leaves and maintains its narrow shape without the need for clipping. Taxus baccata is evergreen and native to Europe, northwestern Africa, and Iran. Learn more about Taxus baccata. Taxus baccata 'Fastigiata' was discovered in 1767 by George Willis on the slopes of the Cuilcagh mountain near Florencecourt, Ireland.

Thuja 'Green Giant' is an excellent choice for creating a shelter belt and has been successfully used for this purpose worldwide. It is disease-free, making it a low-maintenance option, and can provide a fantastic shelter or a beautiful dark-green ornamental backdrop. Additionally, it is fast-growing, allowing it to quickly establish itself in the desired location. Thuja 'Green Giant' is a hybrid between Thuja standishii and Thuja plicata. Thuja 'Green Giant' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was found in 1937 at D. T. Poulsens Nursery in Kvistgård, Denmark. It wasn't until 1967, when the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States received Thuja 'Green Giant' from D. T. Poulsens Nursery, that Thuja 'Green Giant' became widely known and began entering commerce.

This conifer has a very erect and columnar growth habit, with flattened, fan-like sprays. It is a reliable, enduring, and quick-growing tree with deep-green leaves. Thuja occidentalis 'Pyramidalis' is perfect for creating a narrow screen that requires no trimming. It can also be used as a focal point or to line avenues and driveways, adding to the overall aesthetic appeal of the landscape. Additionally, it is a superb choice as a container plant. Thuja occidentalis is evergreen and native to central and eastern Canada and north-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Thuja occidentalis.

Compared to Thuja occidentalis 'Pyramidalis', Thuja occidentalis 'Smaragd' is shorter and has finer leaves. Its leaves are fresh-green in color, and Thuja occidentalis 'Smaragd' forms a dense, narrowly-conical habit. Thuja occidentalis 'Smaragd' is very reliable and quick-growing, making it an excellent choice for screens and focal points. It also serves as a superb container plant. Thuja occidentalis is evergreen and native to central and eastern Canada and north-central and eastern United States. Learn more about Thuja occidentalis. Thuja occidentalis 'Smaragd' was selected in 1950 by D. T. Poulsens Nursery in Kvistgård, Denmark.

Thuja plicata is an excellent choice for providing permanent shelter and privacy. It is quick-growing and features a pyramidal, bushy form that requires little pruning. Thuja plicata is hardy and can withstand wind and drought conditions. It is also canker-resistant, which adds to its durability. Additionally, the foliage of Thuja plicata is safe for cattle to eat without causing harm. Thuja plicata is evergreen and native to the west coast of North America from Alaska down to California in the United States, including British Columbia, Canada. Learn more about Thuja plicata.

Tilia cordata features green leaves during the summer months, which turn yellow in the autumn season. It forms a dense, pyramidal shape and produces masses of pale-yellow, sweetly-scented flowers in the summer. These flowers are known to attract bees, making it a beneficial addition to any landscape. The pliable branches of Tilia cordata can be trained along wires for pleaching, and Tilia cordata can also be grown as a hedge. Tilia cordata is deciduous and native to most of Europe. Learn more about Tilia cordata.

Tilia x europaea forms a large, umbrella-shaped canopy and features green, heart-shaped leaves that turn yellow in the autumn season. It produces a mass of pale-yellow flowers in the summer that attract bees, making it a valuable addition to any landscape. Tilia x europaea is particularly well-suited for use in parks and along large avenues, and it can also be trained for pleaching. Tilia x europaea is a hybrid between Tilia cordata and Tilia platyphyllos. Tilia x europaea is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Tilia x europaea.

Tilia platyphyllos has a large, umbrella-shaped canopy and features broad, green, heart-shaped leaves that turn yellow in the autumn season. It produces a mass of pale-yellow flowers in the summer, which are attractive to bees. Tilia platyphyllos is an ideal choice for use in parks, along large avenues, and driveways. It can also be trained for pleaching, making it a versatile addition to any landscape. Tilia platyphyllos is deciduous and native to much of Europe. Learn more about Tilia platyphyllos.

This robust tree features erect branches that develop into an umbrella shape as Tilia tomentosa matures. Its dark-green, rounded leaves have a silver underside that looks stunning when ruffled by breezes.
