Tilia tomentosa produces a mass of pale-yellow, sweetly-scented flowers in the summer, which are known to attract bees, making it a beneficial addition to any landscape. Tilia tomentosa is deciduous and native to southeastern Europe. Learn more about Tilia tomentosa.

This robust tree has a narrow, conical growth habit and features graceful side branches. Its dark-green, heart-shaped leaves have a silver underside that looks stunning when ruffled by breezes. Tilia tomentosa 'Orbicularis' produces a mass of pale-yellow, sweetly-scented flowers in the summer, which are known to attract bees, making it a beneficial addition to any landscape. Tilia tomentosa is deciduous and native to southeastern Europe. Learn more about Tilia tomentosa. Tilia tomentosa 'Orbicularis' is a seedling of Tilia tomentosa 'Petiolaris' that was raised in 1868 at the Simon-Louis Freres nursery near Metz, France.

Tilia tomentosa 'Petiolaris' is a fabulous choice for use as a specimen tree. It forms a large, broad crown with downward-sweeping branches and features large, dark-green leaves with silver undersides that add to its ornamental value. Tilia tomentosa 'Petiolaris' produces fragrant, yellow flowers in the summer that are known to attract bees, adding to its overall appeal. Tilia tomentosa is deciduous and native to southeastern Europe. Learn more about Tilia tomentosa.

This palm is known for being the most cold-hardy species and is able to survive in colder regions of New Zealand. A distinctive characteristic of this palm is the thick layer of protective hair that covers its trunk. The palm features big, light-green, fan-shaped leaves that form a compact canopy. It is known for being coastal and wind hardy, making it a great choice for gardens located in exposed areas. Trachycarpus fortunei is evergreen and native to China and Myanmar. Learn more about Trachycarpus fortunei.

otherCommonNames: Smooth Elm, Silver Elm, Tartan Elm
description: This beautiful tree has a graceful, open, vase-shaped habit and features deep-green leaves that are marbled and speckled with white. Ulmus carpinifolia 'Variegata' looks particularly stunning when planted in groups and is an excellent choice for lining avenues, as well as for use as a standalone specimen tree in a lawn or paddock. It is known for being able to tolerate strong winds and poor soils, adding to its overall hardiness. Ulmus carpinifolia 'Variegata' also has yellow autumn leaves, which further adds to its aesthetic value. Ulmus carpinifolia is deciduous and native to Europe, northern Africa, and parts of southwestern Asia. Learn more about Ulmus carpinifolia. Ulmus carpinifolia 'Variegata' is believed to have been cultivated in France from 1772.

Ulmus 'Frontier' forms a vase-shaped structure with a rounded head and features small, dark-green leaves that turn into a glowing burgundy color in the autumn season. The leaves can persist well into the winter months, adding to the ornamental value of Ulmus 'Frontier'. Ulmus 'Frontier' is tolerant of moderate coastal winds and drought, making it a great choice as a shade tree in coastal regions. It does not produce seeds, which is an advantage for landscapes where seed dispersal is unwanted. Additionally, Ulmus 'Frontier' is highly resistant to Dutch elm disease and is an excellent choice for use as a street tree. Ulmus 'Frontier' is a hybrid between Ulmus carpinifolia (syn. Ulmus minor) and Ulmus parvifolia. Ulmus 'Frontier' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in 1971 by the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States and was released in 1990.

Ulmus glabra 'Camperdownii' features a round dome shape, formed by its contorted branches that cascade to the ground. It has large, dark-green leaves and is known for turning yellow in the autumn season. Ulmus glabra is deciduous and native to most of Europe. Learn more about Ulmus glabra. Ulmus glabra 'Camperdownii' was discovered by David Taylor, the Earl of Camperdown's head forester, sometime between 1835 and 1840 in the forest at Camperdown House in Dundee, Scotland.

This unique tree is characterized by its wide-spreading, horizontal branches, making it an excellent choice for use as a shade tree. Ulmus glabra 'Horizontalis' is hardy and can withstand wind and drought conditions, adding to its overall resilience. The branches of Ulmus glabra 'Horizontalis' can be pruned to keep the size in check, making it a versatile addition to any landscape. Ulmus glabra 'Horizontalis' is also known for turning yellow in the autumn season, which further adds to its aesthetic value. Ulmus glabra is deciduous and native to most of Europe. Learn more about Ulmus glabra. Ulmus glabra 'Horizontalis' originated in 1816 at a nursery in Perth, Australia but was first distributed by James Booth & Son in Hamburg, Germany.

Ulmus glabra 'Pendula' forms an umbrella shape, with its branches cascading all the way to the ground. It features large, coarse, green leaves that turn yellow in the autumn season, adding to the aesthetic value of Ulmus glabra 'Pendula'. Ulmus glabra 'Pendula' can be trained to spread its branches outwards on a frame, making it an excellent choice for use as a shade tree. Additionally, Ulmus glabra 'Pendula' is known for being very hardy and can withstand both wind and drought conditions. Ulmus glabra is deciduous and native to most of Europe. Learn more about Ulmus glabra.

Ulmus x hollandica 'Jacqueline Hillier' is known for forming a wonderful, character-filled canopy. Its arching stems are covered with small, dark-green leaves, giving it a unique and ornamental appearance. Ulmus x hollandica 'Jacqueline Hillier' is very trainable and is a popular choice for use in bonsai, as young trees can look mature from an early age. Ulmus x hollandica 'Jacqueline Hillier' is also an excellent choice for use in topiary. In the autumn season, the leaves of Ulmus x hollandica 'Jacqueline Hillier' turn into a beautiful shade of orange, further adding to its aesthetic value. Ulmus x hollandica is a hybrid between Ulmus carpinifolia (syn. Ulmus minor) and Ulmus glabra. Ulmus x hollandica is deciduous and native to parts of Europe. Learn more about Ulmus x hollandica. Ulmus x hollandica 'Jacqueline Hillier' was found in 1966 in a private garden in Selly Park, Birmingham, England.

Ulmus x hollandica 'Wredei' is characterized by its narrow-growing habit, making it an excellent choice for use in narrow spaces. Ulmus x hollandica 'Wredei' features bright-yellow leaves in the spring season that gradually fade to yellow-green in the summer before turning yellow once again in the autumn. It is a superb choice for use as a street tree, although it is important to protect it from coastal winds, which can cause damage to Ulmus x hollandica 'Wredei'. Ulmus x hollandica is a hybrid between Ulmus carpinifolia (syn. Ulmus minor) and Ulmus glabra. Ulmus x hollandica is deciduous and native to parts of Europe. Learn more about Ulmus x hollandica. Ulmus x hollandica 'Wredei' originated in 1875 as a sport of Ulmus x hollandica 'Dampieri' at the Alt-Geltow Arboretum, near Potsdam, Germany.

Ulmus 'Lobel' is known for its vigorous growth and striking, upright growth habit. Ulmus 'Lobel' features bronze new leaves that mature to a deep-green color, before turning yellow in the autumn season. It is highly resistant to Dutch elm disease, adding to its overall hardiness. Ulmus 'Lobel' is also coastal and drought hardy, making it a great choice for landscapes located in exposed areas. It is an excellent option for use as a hardy screen tree for lining large avenues and is also highly recommended for use as a street tree. Ulmus 'Lobel' is a hybrid between Ulmus minor 'Bea Schwarz' and the hybrid formed between Ulmus 'Exoniensis' and Ulmus wallichiana. Ulmus 'Lobel' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and was raised Dorschkamp Research Institute for Forestry and Landscape Planning in Wageningen, Netherlands.

Ulmus 'Louis van Houtte' has a distinctive vase-shaped structure, with a large, spreading canopy. In the spring season, Ulmus 'Louis van Houtte' produces large, yellow-green leaves that gradually mature to a yellow color, which they retain through the autumn season before falling. When planted in full sun, Ulmus 'Louis van Houtte' can achieve the best leaf coloring. It is an excellent choice for use as a specimen tree, owing to its ornamental value and unique structure. Ulmus 'Louis van Houtte' is deciduous and not native to New Zealand.

Ulmus parvifolia forms a rounded head with graceful, pendulous branches and a slender trunk. Ulmus parvifolia also features peeling bark, adding to its unique appearance. Small, dark-green leaves cover Ulmus parvifolia and turn orange and yellow in the autumn season. Ulmus parvifolia is tolerant of moderate coastal winds and drought conditions, making it an excellent choice for use as a street tree. It is also highly resistant to Dutch elm disease, adding to its overall hardiness. Ulmus parvifolia is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Ulmus parvifolia.

Viburnum opulus 'Roseum' produces large, snowball-shaped flowers that emerge lime-green and mature to a pure-white color. The flowers bloom in mid-spring and are quite striking. Viburnum opulus 'Roseum' is characterized by its robust, upright growth habit and arching branches, which add to its overall ornamental value. The green, maple-like leaves of Viburnum opulus 'Roseum' turn into a beautiful shade of orange and red in the autumn season. It is important to note that Viburnum opulus 'Roseum' does not produce berries. Viburnum opulus is deciduous and native to Europe, Siberia, Turkey, and northern Algeria. Learn more about Viburnum opulus. Viburnum opulus 'Roseum' has been known in European gardens since the 16th century.

Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' is characterized by its multi-branched structure, which forms a dense, rounded shape. It produces small, dark-green, leathery leaves that add to its overall ornamental value. In the spring season, Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' produces blush-white flowers that emerge from carmine-pink buds, followed by blue fruit in the autumn season. Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' is an excellent option for use as a hedge or screen, as it grows right to the ground and clips readily. It is capable of growing in shaded areas. Compared to Viburnum tinus, Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' is more floriferous, has smaller leaves, and is smaller in overall size. Viburnum tinus is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean. Learn more about Viburnum tinus. Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' originated at Wakehurst (Wakehurst Place), a house and botanic gardens in West Sussex, England, and was bought by Gerald Loder from Messrs Dickson of Chester. Henry Philip Price (1877-1963) named Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' in 1960.

Young trees of Vitex lucens typically grow upright, but will eventually form a large, spreading canopy after several decades. The leaves of Vitex lucens are a rich shade of green and feature wavy edges, adding to its ornamental value. In the late-autumn to mid-spring period, Vitex lucens produces pink-red flowers that attract tuis and bellbirds, while wood pigeons favor the red berries that are produced from mid-summer to mid-spring. Vitex lucens is capable of tolerating wind and coastal exposure, but can only withstand light frosts. Vitex lucens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Vitex lucens.

This palm species is known for its immense, fan-shaped leaves that weep when mature. As the palm ages, its old leaves drop off the trunk, leaving a distinctive criss-cross scarring on the trunk that adds to its ornamental value. The palm stems are characterized by their vicious, curved barbs, which are a distinctive feature to be wary of. Despite this, the palm is quite hardy and can thrive in temperate regions. Washingtonia robusta is evergreen and native to Mexico. Learn more about Washingtonia robusta.

Yucca gigantea features green, stiff, and hard leaves that lack spines and resemble dagger blades. The leaves can grow up to 1.2 meters in length. In summer, Yucca gigantea produces clusters of beautiful white flowers that are not only ornamental but also edible, commonly used in a variety of dishes ranging from meat stews to salads. Yucca gigantea can be grown as a specimen tree outdoors or as a houseplant indoors. Yucca gigantea is evergreen and native to Mexico and Central America. Learn more about Yucca gigantea.

Zelkova serrata has a vase-shaped form with a spreading crown of branches that weep at their tips. It features narrow, pale-green leaves that turn beautiful shades of yellow, orange, and scarlet in autumn. Zelkova serrata is tolerant of drought once it's established and can withstand strong winds. Zelkova serrata is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Learn more about Zelkova serrata.

Zelkova serrata 'Kiwi Sunset' is a showstopper with its handsome golden-yellow leaves in autumn and yellow-green leaves in summer. Its new leaves emerge red, providing a lovely contrast to the older leaves. Pruning can be done to keep the height of Zelkova serrata 'Kiwi Sunset' down, which will encourage the long branches to weep, creating a striking effect. Zelkova serrata is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Learn more about Zelkova serrata. Zelkova serrata 'Kiwi Sunset' was developed before 1996 by Allenton Nurseries in Ashburton, New Zealand (1215).
